div2.entryFree: alphabetical letter m * [The twenty-fourth letter of the alphabet; called miymN. It is one of the letters termed majohuwrap, or vocal, and of those termed $afahiy~ap or labial: it is a letter of augmentation. -A2- As a numeral, it denotes forty.]
See Supplement

R. Q. 1 maA^omaA^ato *
She (a ewe or she-goat or a gazelle) uttered continuously the cry miy^o miy^o, (K,) or (accord. to the Tes-heel) mAa'=I maA='i: [and this is confirmed by a verse which I have cited voce taxaw~ana:] (MF:) thus written in his Háshiyeh. (TA.)

1 maw^uja * , aor.
maAu^a (or maA^aja, aor,
maAa^a , M), inf. n. muw^uwjapN, It (water) was, or became, what is termed A^ujaAj, (S, K,) i. e., salt, (TA,) [or bitter, or salt and bitter, &c.].
maA='N maA^ojN * , (and, as occurring in a verse of Ibn-Harmeh, maAjN, without ', IB,) Water such as is termed A^ujaAj, (S, K,) i. e., salt, (TA,) [or bitter, or salt and bitter, &c.]

1 maA^ada * , aor.
maAa^a , (S, L, K,) inf. n. maA^odN, (S, L,) It (a plant, L, K, and a tree, L, and a branch, S, L) was, or became, flourishing and fresh, and soft, tender, and supple: (L:) or it quivered, shook, or played loosely, and was, or became, succulent, or sappy, (L, K,) and flourishing and fresh, and soft, tender, and supple: (K:) it (a branch or twig) became filled with its first sap: and maw^uda, aor.
maAu^a , it (a plant) became succulent, or sappy. (L.) yamoA^adu maA^odFA HasanFA It (a branch) is [beautifully] soft, tender, and supple, and quivering. (S, L.)

4 AmA^d *
It (the imbibing of moisture, L, K, and the [rain or season called] rabiyE, and the like, L) caused a plant [or tree or branch] to become flourishing and fresh, and soft, tender, and supple: (L:) or to quiver, shake, or play loosely, and to become succulent, or sappy, (L, K,) and flourishing and fresh, and soft, tender, and supple. (K).

8 AmtA^d xayorFA *
He gained, or acquired, good, or prosperity. (S, L, K.)

maA^odN * and ↓ yamow^uwdN A [plant or tree or] branch [flourishing and fresh, and soft, tender, and supple: see 1: or] quivering, shaking, or playing loosely, and succulent, or sappy, flourishing and fresh, and soft, tender, and supple: (K:) or a plant [or tree] or branch soft, tender, and supple; (S, L;) and ↓ may^iydN signifies the same, (K,) applied to a branch; and so ↓ maAy^idN: (TA:) which last also signifies a branch succulent, or sappy; and so maA^odN, (L,) and ↓ mumoA^adN: (TA:) and (as some say, L) maA^odN signifies soft, tender, or supple, applied to anything. (L, K.) ― -b2- In like manner, maA^odN and ↓ yamow^uwdN are applied to (assumed tropical:) a man: (K:) and maA^odapN (TA) and yamow^uwdapN and yamow^uwdN to a female. (K.) You say rajulN maA^odN, (L,) and yamow^uwdN, (S, L,) (assumed tropical:) A young, and soft, or tender, man: and A_imoraA^apN maA^odapN, (L,) and yamow^uwdapN, (S, L,) and yamow^uwdN, (L,) (assumed tropical:) a young, and soft, or tender woman: (S, L:) and jaAriypN maA^odapN, (K,) and yamow^uwdapN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) a soft, or tender, damsel: (K:) and jArypN maA^odapu Al$~abaAbi, and maAdapN, without ', (assumed tropical:) a damsel having youthful softness, thinness of skin, and plumpness. (L.) ― -b3- maA^odu Al$~abaAbi (assumed tropical:) The softness, or tenderness, of youth. (L.) ― -b4- makaAnN vaA^odN maA^odN [A place moist and soft]; (S, L;) as also ↓ vay^idN may^idN. (T, art. vA^d.) -A2- maA^odN The moisture that exudes from the earth, before it springs forth: (L, K:) of the dial. of Syria. (L.)
may^idN * : see maA^odN.
may^iydN * : see maA^odN.
maAy^idN * : see maA^odN.
mumoA^adN * : see maA^odN.
yamow^uwdN * : see maA^odN.

div2.head: mA^r, &c
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 mat~a * , aor.
matu3a , inf. n. mat~N, He extended, or stretched out, (S, K,) a rope, &c. (TA); i. q. mad~a (S, K) and maT~a and magaTa. (TA.) ― -b2- mat~a fiY Als~ayori i. q. mad~a. (TA.) ― -b3- mat~a, aor.
matu3a , inf. n. mat~N, He drew [water], or drew up [a bucket], without a pulley. (S, K.) ― -b4- mat~a, aor.
matu3a , inf. n. mat~N; (S, K;) and ↓ matomata, inf. n. matomatapN; (K;) He sought to bring himself near [to another], or to approach [to him], or to gain access [to him], or to advance himself in [his] favour, (tawas~ala,) by relationship, (S, K,) or by what is termed Huromap, [see maAt~apN, below,] or by other means: (TA:) or i. q. tawaS~al [which seems here to signify nearly or exactly the same as tws~l] by relationship, or by what is termed daAl~ap [or blandishment, &c.] (L.) ― -b5- mat~a A_ilayohi biAl$~aYo'i He sought to bring himself near to him, &c., (tws~l Alyh,) by the thing. (M.) ― -b6- ↓ matomata He sought to bring himself near, &c., [to another,] by affection, or love, or by relationship. (IAar.) ― -b7- laA tamut~aAoni A_ilaY All~`hi biHabolK walaA tamud~aAni A_ilayohi bisababK [Ye two shall not approach, or obtain access, to God by means of any friend, nor shall ye do so by means of any relation]. A trad. (TA.) ― -b8- mat~ahu i. q. Talaba A_ilayohi AlmataAta, q. v. infra. (L.)

3 mAt~ fulaAnFA *
He reminded such a one of what are termed mawaAt~ [pl. of maAt~apN, q. v.]. (A.)

5 tamat~aY * , originally tamat~ata, which has not been heard, (like taZan~aY for taZan~ana, TA,) i. q. tamaT~aY. (K.) ― -b2- tamat~aY fiY AlHaboli He bore upon the rope in order to break it, (K,) or to stretch it out. (TA.) See also art. mtw.
R. Q. 1 mtmt * : see 1, in two places.

mat~aY * dial. form of mataY, q. v. (K.) It occurs in the following instances:
A^alamo tasoA^ali AlA^aTalaAla mat~aY EuhuwduhaA
[Didst thou not ask the remains of the dwelling, when were their times?] AHát asked As respecting mt~Y in this hemistich, and he answered, I know not. AHát thinks that it is for mataY: or that it may be for mat~FA, inf. n. of mat~a; and that the meaning may be [Didst thou not ask the remains of the dwelling,] whereof the times when men were present there are (or were) long past, or distant, or remote? but he confesses that he does not know. (L.) MF remarks upon it, that it is very extraordinary. (TA.)

mataAtN * signifies maA yumat~ bihi; (K;) i. e., That whereby one seeks to bring himself near [to another], or, to approach [to him], or, to advance himself in [his] favour; or to gain access [to him]. (TA.) Talaba A_ilayohi AlamatAta [He sought the means of drawing near to him, or, of advancing himself in his favour, &c.: or he sought access to him]. (TA.) [See also ↓ maAt~ap, which signifies the same.]

maAt~apN *
i. q. HuromapN and wasiylapN: [the former signifies, Anything that is sacred or inviolable; and here, such a bond, or tie, or the like; or a quality &c. to be regarded as sacred, or inviolable; or that which renders one entitled to respect and reverence: so says IbrD: the latter, a thing whereby one seeks to bring himself near, or to approach, to another, or to advance himself in his favour:] (S, K:) pl. mawaAt~u. (S.) [See also mataAtN, which signifies the same.] ― -b2- bayonanaA raHimN maAt~apN, i. e. qariybapN, Between us is a near relationship. (L.)

1 mataA^a * , aor.
mataAa , He beat a person with a staff or stick. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. mato'N, (TA,) He extended, or stretched out, a rope: (S, K:) a dial. form of mataA. [See art. mtw]. (S.)

1 mataHa AlmaA='a * , aor.
mataHa , (inf. n. matoHN, S,) He drew water: (S, Msb, K:) or he drew up water by means of the pulley and its appertenances. (L.) ― -b2- mataHa Ald~alowa He drew out the bucket: (Msb:) or he pulled the rope of the bucket, drawing [the rope] with one hand, and taking [it to draw again] with the other hand, at the head of the well; as also mataHa biAld~alowi. (L.) -A2- mataHa bihaA Pepedit. (S, K.) ― -b2- mataHa bisaloHihi Alvum dejecit; (S, K;) as also mataxa bihi. (TA.) -A3- mataHa Aln~ahaAru (tropical:) The day advanced, the sun becoming high: (S, K:) a dial. form of mataEa: (S:) became prolonged. (TA.) ― -b2- mataHa, and ↓ AmtH, (tropical:) It (a day, and a night,) was long, or prolonged. Said of a summer-day and of a winter-night. (As.)
4 A^amotaHa see 1.

5 AlA_ibilu tatamat~aHu fiY sayorihaA * (tropical:) The camels move their fore-legs alternately turaAwiHu biA^ayodiyhaA, A, and some copies of the K; in other copies of the K, tataraw~aHu;) in going along, (K,) like as the drawer of water moves alternately his two arms. (A.)

8 AmttH *
He pulled out a thing: (Aboo-Turáb and T, art. ntH, and K:) as also A_inotataHa. (Aboo-Turáb and T, ubi supra.)
matoHN * inf. n. of 1: see matuwHN.

by^orN matuwHN * (tropical:) A well from which one draws water with the two hands by means of the pulley: (S, L, K:) or, of which the bottom, or part from which the water is drawn, is near to the mouth: pl. mutuHN. (L.) [See also jaruwrN.] ― -b2- [You say,] sironaA EuqobapF matuwHFA [in the CK Eaqbapa] (tropical:) We proceeded a long march. (S, L, K, *) ― -b3- ↓ bayonanaA farosaHN matoHFA, and ↓ maAtiHN, and ↓ mat~aAHN, (tropical:) Between us is a long league. (L.) ― -b4- layolN mat~aAHN (tropical:) A long night. (S, K.) ― -b5- A_ilaY All~ayoli ↓ yawomN mat~aAHN (tropical:) A day in which travelling is prolonged until the evening without intermission or alighting. (L.) See maAtiHN.
mat~aAHN * : see matuwHN. ― -b2- farasN mat~aAHN (tropical:) A long horse, (A, TA,) that stretches himself out much or takes long steps, mad~aAdN, (A, K,) in going along. (TA.)

maAtiHN * and ↓ matuwHN A drawer of water; (S;) applied to a man who draws the water from the mouth of the well: one who draws it from the bottom being called maAy^iHN: pl. of maAtiHN, mut~aAHN. (L.) ― -b2- maAtiHN A camel that draws water: pl. mawaAtiHu. (L.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce *am~apN.] ― -b3- See mtuwHN.

div2.head: mtr, &c
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 mav~a * , [aor.
mavi3a ,] It (a bone) distilled, or let flow, the only matter that was in it: (TA:) [like nav~a]. ― -b2- mav~a, (S, K, aor.
mava3a , inf. n. mav~N, TA,) and ↓ mavomava, (K,) or, as in some copies of the K, ↓ vamavomava, (TA,) It (a niHoY, or butterskin,) exuded [its butter: as also nav~a]. (S, K.) You do not say of it naDaHa. (S.) ― -b3- yamiv~u mav~a AlHamiyti He sweats like the butter-skin. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- mav~a, aor.
mavi3a , He (a man) sweated by reason of fatness. (TA.) ― -b5- jaA'a yamiv~u He came in a fat state, and looking as though he were anointed. (TA.) ― -b6- mav~a qayoHFA wadamFA, aor.
mavu3a ; or aor.
mavi3a ; accord. to different readings of a phrase in the story of Abrahah; [It exuded matter and blood]: in the former case, the verb is trans.; in the latter, intrans.; and qyHA, in the latter case, is regarded as a specificative. (Suh.) ― -b7- mav~a $aAribahu, (aor.
mavu3a , inf. n. mav~N, ISd,) He put some grease upon his mustaches: (S, K:) or he greased his mustaches so that they glistened: (ISd:) or he wiped his mustaches with his hands, they having been greased, and left some remains, or traces, of grease visible upon them: (AZ:) IDrd thinks mav~a and nav~a to be syn. (TA.) ― -b8- mav~a AljuroHa, [aor.
mavu3a ,] He removed the purulent matter from the wound: (Aboo-Turáb, K:) or he anointed the wound; as also nav~a. (Aboo-Turáb.) ― -b9- mav~a, aor.
mavu3a , (inf. n. mav~N, TA,) He wiped his hand (or fingers, TA,) with a napkin, or with dry grass, (S,) or the like: (TA:) a dial. form of ma$~a: (S:) or he wiped anything: (TA:) [as also niv~a.]

R. Q. 1 mavomava *
He saturated a wick with oil. (K.) ― -b2- mavomava, He immersed [a thing] in water. (K.) -A2- mavomava, (inf. n. mavomavapN, S, and mivomaAvN, S, K,) He mixed, or confounded. (S, K.) You say mvmv A^amorahumo He confounded their affair. (S.) ― -b2- mavomavahu He moved it, or shook it, about; (S, K;) like mazomazahu: (As, S:) you say A^axa*ahu famavomavahu He took it, and moved it, or shook it, about, and went forwards and backwards with it. (S.) ― -b3- A poet says,
vum~a A@sotaHav~a *aroEahu A@sotiHovaAvaA
nakafotu Hayovu mavomava AlmiyomaAvaA
i. e., I came upon his track: and [the case is, that] the viper makes its course confused: therefore the poet means, that he came upon (A^aSaAba) a confused track. (S, app. from As.) [It seems to me, that he is speaking of the track of a viper.] mivomaAvN, with kesreh, is the inf. n.; and mavomaAvN, with fet-hah, is the subst. (S, K.) [By the subst., is here meant the ideal subst., or abstract noun, (like zalozaAlN and qaloqaAl, as dis-
tinguished from zilozaAlN and qiloqaAlN,) signifying Mixture, or confusion.] -A3- mavomavuwA binaA, (K,) or mvmvwA bnA saAEapF, and ↓ tamavomavuwA, (TA,) i. q. lavolivuwA. (K.)

R. Q. 2
see 1 and R. Q. 1.

nabotN mav~aAvN *
A moist plant. (TA.)
mavomaAvN * : see R. Q. 1.

div2.head: mvl, &c
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 maj~ahu mino fiyhi * , (S, K, &c.,) and maj~a bihi, aor.
maju3a , and some allow
maja3a , but this is not well known, and, unless the medial letter of the pret. be pronounced with kesreh by those who use this form of the aor., it is to be rejected utterly, (TA,) He cast it forth, or ejected it, or spirted it, from his mouth; meaning beverage, or wine, $araAb: (S, K:) and spittle: or, accord. to some, water only: or a thing: (L:) or, properly, something fluid; lafaZahu being used to signify “ he cast it forth ” from his mouth when the thing meant is not fluid: but used with relation to all other things that are perceived by any of the senses, figuratively: (MF:) accord. to Sh, it is used to signify the pouring forth of water, and of spittle, from the mouth, when it is ejected to a short distance or far; or, as some say, only when it is ejected far. (TA.) It is made trans. by means of bi because syn. with ramaY [which is trans. by the same means]. (MF.) ― -b2- maj~ati Aln~aHolu AlEasala The bees ejected the honey from their mouths. (TA.) ― -b3- maj~a AlEiroqu biAld~ami The vein ejected, or spirted forth, blood. (TA.) ― -b4- maj~ati Al$~amosu riyqahaA (tropical:) [The sun ejected its spittle; meaning the filmy substance described in the explanation of luEaAbu Al$~amosi]. (A.) ― -b5- h`*aA kalaAmN tamuj~uhu AlA^asomaAEu (tropical:) This is language which the ears reject. (MF.) ― -b6- qaraA^a A=yapF famaj~a bihaA (tropical:) He read a verse of the Kur-án, and dismissed it from his mind]; i. e., did not reflect upon it. (MF, from a trad.) -A2- maj~a and baj~a, (TA in this art.,) or maj~a and naj~a, (TA in art. nj,) acc. to IAar, are syn. (TA.)

4 Amj~ * , (S, K,) and, by poetic licence, A^amojaja, (TA,) inf. n. A_imojaAjN, (As,) He (a horse) ran violently: (TA:) or he (a horse) began to perform the act of running, before it (his run, As) was vehement, or ardent. (qabola A^ano yaDoTarima). (As, S, K.) ― -b2- He (a man) went, or went forth journeying, through (fY) countries. (S, K.) ― -b3- He went away, or departed, to (A_ilY) a country or town. (TA.)

7 Anmj~t nuqoTapN mina Alqalami *
A drop [of ink] became spirted from the reed-pen. (S, K.)

R. Q. 1 majomaja fiY xabarihi * , (inf. n. majomajapN, TA,) He was not explicit in his information. (S, K.) [See also HajoHaja.] ― -b2- majomaja AlkitaAba He made the writing indistinct in its letters: (S, K:) or he rendered the writing confused, and marred it with the pen. (Lth.) majomaja xaT~ahu He made his handwriting confused. (A.) ― -b3- majomaja bifulaAnK He pursued an indirect course of speech with such a one, and turned him back from one state to another: (Shujáa Es-Sulamee, K:) as also bajobaja bihi. (Shujáa.)

maj~N * (S, K) and ↓ mujaAjN (TA) The grain of the maA$: (K:) or the grain called mA$; and called by the Arabs xul~arN and zin~N: (T:) or a kind of grain resembling the lentil, (but more round, TA); an arabicized word; in Persian mA$: (S:) or, accord. to El-Jawáleekee, it is Arabic: accord. to AHn, what is called maj~apN [n. un. of maj~N, which is a coll. gen. n.,] is a sour or salt, or salt and bitter, plant, or tree, (HamoDapN) resembling the TaHomaA=', but more delicate, and smaller. (TA.) -A2- See mujaAjN.

mujujN *
Drunken men. (K.) ― -b2- Bees. (K.)

mujaAjN * (S, K) and mujaAjapN (S) Spittle, or saliva, that one casts forth from his mouth: (S, K:) or the latter, [and so, app., ↓ maj~apN, see maj~aAjapN] a portion of such; a gob of spittle. (TA.) ― -b2- mujaAjN fami AljaAriyapi Girl's saliva, or spittle. (TA.) ― -b3- Also mujaAjN, (K,) and mujaAju Aln~aHoli [The ejected spittle of the bees], (S, K,) honey. (S, K.) ― -b4- mujaAju AljaraAdi (tropical:) The slaver of locusts. (TA.) ― -b5- mujaAju Ald~abaY The slaver of little locusts. (L.) ― -b6- mujaAju Almuzoni (tropical:) [The ejected spittle of the clouds; i. e.,] rain. (S, K.) ― -b7- mujaAjp also signifies (tropical:) The expressed juice of a thing. (S.) ― -b8- mujaAju AlEinabi (tropical:) What flows of the expressed juice of grapes. (TA.) -A2- See maj~N.
maj~aAjN * (tropical:) A writer: so called because his pen emits ink. (TA.)

AlA^u*unu maj~aAjapN waliln~afosi HamoDapN * (assumed tropical:) The ear is wont to reject instruction, through forgetfulness, while the mind has eager desire to listen thereto, is said in a trad. (TA.) And in another trad., waliln~afosi HamoDapN ↓ liloA^u*uni maj~apN [meaning the same]. (TA., art. HmD.) [See also HamoDapN.]

maAj~N * One whose slaver flows by reason of old age, or extreme age: (K:) an old man who ejects his spittle, and cannot retain it, by reason of age: you say A^aHomaqu maAj~N, meaning a stupid, or foolish, drivelling, or slavering, fellow: (S:) and so, simply, maAj~N: or stupid, or foolish, and decrepit: fem. with p: (TA:) and pl. maAj~uwna (IAar) and muj~aAjN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, An old she-camel: (K:) or a she-camel so old that she ejects the water from her throat: (S:) and in like manner an old and slavering he-camel: fem. with p: (TA:) and pl. majajapN. (IAar.)
qawolN mamojuwjN * (tropical:) A saying which the ear rejects. (TA.)
tamaj~aHa * : see tabaj~aHa in art. bjH.

1 majada * , aor.
majuda , inf. n. majodN; (L, K;) and majuda, aor.
majuda , inf. n. majaAdapN; (S, L, K;) He (a man, S) was, or became, possessed of, or characterized by, majod [or glory, honour, dignity, nobility, &c.; he was, or became, glorious, in a state of honour or dignity, noble, &c.: see majodN below]. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- See 3. ― -b3- majadati AlA_ibilu, (AZ, IAar, S, L, K,) aor.
majuda , (AZ, L,) inf. n. majodN (AZ, L, K) and mujuwdN; (AZ, S, L, K;) and ↓ Amjdt; (L, K;) The camels fed in a land abounding with pasturage, and satiated themselves therewith: (AZ, L:) or, lighted upon abundant pasturage: (IAar, L, K:) or, obtained of fresh herbage, (xalFY, S, K,) or of herbage, (L,) nearly as much as satiated them, (S, L, K,) and their bodies made this known. (L.) See 4. ― -b4- majadati Alganamu, inf. n. mujuwdN, The sheep, or goats, ate of leguminous plants so as to blunt the sharpness of their hunger. (A.) ― -b5- [Hence, app., accord. to the A, the signification of majada and majuda given in the commencement of this art.]

2 mj~dhu * , inf. n. tamojiydN, He attributed, or ascribed to him, majod [or glory, honour, dignity, or nobility, &c.; he glorified him; honoured him; &c.]; (S, L;) he magnified him, and praised him; as also ↓ Amjdhu. (L, K.) ― -b2- mj~dhu and ↓ Amjdhu He (God) honoured his (a man's) deeds, or actions: or may He honour his deeds, or actions! (A.) ― -b3- mj~dhu and ↓ Amjdhu He made it (a gift) large, or abundant. (L, K.) ― -b4- See 4.

3 mAjdhu * , inf. n. mijaAdN, He vied, or competed, with him (EaAraDahu) in majod [or glory, honour, dignity, nobility, &c.]. (L, K.) You say, ↓ maAjadotuhu famajadotuhu, (aor. of the latter
majuda , S, L,) I vied, &c., with him in glory, &c., and overcame him therein. (S, L, K.)

4 A^amojada see 1 and 2. ― -b2- nazaluwA bihimo faA^amojaduwhumo [They alighted at their abode as guests, and they entertained them honourably]. (A.) ― -b3- Amjd waladahu, and liwaladihi, He chose [noble or generous] mothers [whereon to beget his children; and thus caused his children to be noble or generous]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- A^amojadanaA fulaAnN qirFY Such a one gave us a sufficient and superabundant entertainment. (L.) ― -b5- Amjdhu sab~FA wa*am~FA He reviled and dispraised him much. (IKtt.) ― -b6- Amjd AlA_ibila; (AZ, IAar, L, K;) and ↓ mj~dhA, (S, L, K,) inf. n. tamojiydN; (S, L;) and ↓ majadahaA; (K;) He filled the camels bellies with fodder, (AZ, L, K,) and satiated them: (AZ, L:) or he fed the camels upon abundant pasturage: (IAar, L:) or he satiated the camels: (K:) or he fed them upon herbage so as nearly to satiate them, in the beginning of the [season called] rabiyE: (L:) or he half-filled their bellies with fodder: (K:) the people of El-'Áliyeh say, Aln~aAqapa ↓ majada, (L,) or Ald~aAb~apa, aor.
majuda , inf. n. majodN, (S,) he filled the belly of the she-camel, (L,) or of the beast of carriage, (S,) with fodder: (S, L:) and the people of Nejd, ↓ mj~dhA, inf. n. tamojiydN, he half-filled her belly with fodder: (AO, A'Obeyd, S, L:) and Amjd Ald~aAb~apN He gave the beast of carriage much fodder. (As, L.)

5 tmj~d *
He had majod [or glory, honour, dignity, nobility, &c.,] attributed, or ascribed, to him. (L.)

6 tmAjd *
He mentioned his [i. e. his own] majod [or glory, honour, dignity, nobility, &c., made a show of glory, &c.]; (K;) or the goodness of his actions, and the glory, &c., of his ancestors. (TA.) ― -b2- tmAjd Alqawomu fiymaA bayonahumo The people vied among themselves, or competed, for, or in, majod [or glory, honour, dignity, nobility, &c.], each mentioning his own mjd. (S, * L, K. *)

10 Astmjd * [He desired, or sought, majod, or glory, honour, dignity, nobility, &c.;] he gave largely from a desire of majod. (S, L.) ― -b2- It is said in a proverb, fiY kul~i $ajarK naAro waA@sotamojada A@lomaroxu waA@loEafaAro (tropical:) In all trees is fire; but the markh and 'afár yield much fire: (S, L, K: *) as though they had taken as much fire as sufficed them, (S, L,) and were therefore fit substances for striking fire: (L:) or because they yield fire quickly; wherefore they are likened to him who gives largely from a desire of majod. (S, L.) See maroxN, and EafaArN.

majodN *
Glory; honour; dignity; nobility; syn. Eiz~N (Msb) and $arafN [q. v.] (L, Msb) and karamN: (S, L, K:) or ample glory, honour, dignity, or nobility: (L:) or the acquisition of glory, honour, dignity, or nobility; syn. nayolu $arafK: (M, L, K:) or the acquisition of what suffices thereof and of lordship: (L:) [and hence, acquired glory, honour, dignity, or nobility:] or only glory, honour, dignity, or nobility, transmitted by one's ancestors: (M, L, K:) ISk says, that majod and $araf are [transmitted] by one's ancestors; but Hasab [q. v.] and karam may belong to a man without ancestors who possessed these qualities: (S, L:) or, specially, nobleness, or generosity, of ancestors: (M, L, K:) or personal glory, or nobility with goodness of actions: and nobleness, or generosity, of actions: (L:) or generosity; liberality; syn. karamN (S, L, K) and saxaA='N: (L:) or manly virtue or moral goodness; syn. muruwo'apN. (L.) [Accord. to the A, majodN thus used, and consequently each of the words in this art. derived from it, is tropical: but if so, it is a Haqiyqap Eurofiy~ap, or word so much used in a particular tropical sense as to be, in this sense, conventionally regarded as proper.]

majiydN * (from majuda, L) and ↓ maAjidN (from majada, L) A man (S) possessing, or characterized by, majod [or glory, honour, dignity, nobility, &c.; glorious, in a state of honour or dignity, noble, &c.]: (S, L, K:) glorious, in a state of honour or dignity, noble, abounding in good, and beneficent; but the former has a more intensive sense: or the latter, characterized by gloriousness or nobleness of actions: (K:) or, by personal glory or nobility with goodness of actions; and the former has a more intensive sense: or both, generous and munificent: (L:) and the latter, good in disposition, and liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous: (ISh, L, K:) pl., either of the former or of the latter, A^amojaAdN. (L.) ― -b2- Almajiydu as an epithet of God signifies The Glorious, or Great, or Great in dignity, who gives liberally, or bountifully: or the Bountiful and beneficent: (L, TA:) and ↓ AlmaAjidu is applied in the same manner: (L:) or the former, He who is glorified for his deeds. (T, L.) ― -b3- majiydN is also applied in the Kur as an epithet to the throne (Earo$) of God; and to the Kur-án; (L.) and signifies exalted; sublime; (IAar. L, K;) noble; (Zj, L, K;) when thus applied: (IAar, Zj, L, K:) but in ch. lxxxv., v. 15, for *uw AlEaro$i Almajiydi, some read *w AlEaro$i Almajiydu, making Almjyd an epithet of *w; and in the same ch., v. 21, for huwa quraA=nN majiydN, some read hw quroA=nN majiydK, making mjyd an epithet of God. (L.) Almajiydu alone also occurs in a trad. as meaning the Kur-án. (L.)

maAjidN * : see majiydN. ― -b2- Also, applied to a camel: see majadati AlA_ibilu: pl. muj~adN and mujudN and mawaAjidu. (L.) ― -b3- maAjidN Much; abundant; syn. kaviyrN. (K, TA.) [In the CK, kaviyrN Almajodi.] ― -b4- layosato bimaAjidapK lilT~aEaAmi walaA lil$~araAbi She does not eat or drink much. Said by Aboo- Habbeh, describing a woman. (L.)
A^amojadu * [More, or most, glorious, honourable, noble, &c.]: pl. A^amaAjidu. (A.)

huwa A^aholu Alt~amaAjiydi *
He is a fit, or deserving, object of praises for majod [or glory, honour, dignity, nobility, &c.]. (A, TA.)
1 majVra see bjr; and as an imitative sequent see art. dEr.
3 mAjrhu * , inf. n. mumaAjarapN and mijaArN, (tropical:) He practised usury with him; syn. raAbaAhu. (K.) See also 4.

4 Amjr fiY AlbayoEi * , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_imojaArN, He practised what is termed majorN in selling; he sold a thing for what was in the belly of a certain she-camel (S, Msb) or other beast: (Msb:) or he practised what is termed muHaAqalap: see majorN, below: (Msb:) or i. q. maAjara, inf. n. mumaAjarapN; (tropical:) [he practised usury: see 3.] (TA.)

majorN *
What is in the belly of a pregnant animal, (IAar, Mgh,) or of a she-camel, (Msb, K,) and of a ewe or a she-goat, (K,) when her pregnancy has become manifest: (TA:) or (Msb; in the K, and) the sale of a thing for what is in the belly of a certain she-camel: (S, Msb:) or the sale of a camel, or other thing, for what is in the belly of a she-camel: (AZ, Mgh, * TA:) or the purchase of what is in the bellies of she-camels and of ewes or she-goats: and the purchase of a camel for what is in the belly of a she-camel: and ↓ majarN [signifies the same, but] is a word of weak authority, or a barbarism; (K:) and the latter appears to be the case, for it is rejected by Az and IAth: (TA:) or (Msb; in the K, and) i. q. muHaAqalapN [or the sale of corn in the ear for wheat-grain]: (IAar, Msb, K:) and muzaAbanapN [or the sale of dates on the tree for dates by measure]: and (assumed tropical:) a game of hazard; syn. qimaArN: and (assumed tropical:) usury; syn. ribFY: (IAar, K:) it is a subst. from A^amojara fiY AlbayoEi. (Msb.) majorN, (S,) or bayoEu Almajori, (TA,) is forbidden in a trad. (S, TA.) Perhaps bayoEu Almajori may be termed mjr in this trad. tropically. (TA.) -A2- A great army (see a verse cited in art. dhm).
majarN * : see majorN.
2 mj~shu * , (S, A, &c.,) inf. n. tamojiysN, (A, K,) He made him a majuwsiY~ [or Magian]: (S, A, Msb, K:) he taught him the religion of the majuws. (TA.)

5 tmj~s *
He became a majuwsiY~ [or Magian]; (S, A, K;) he became of the religion of the majuws. (Msb.)

Almajuwsu * [The Magians]; a certain nation: it is a Persian word: (Msb:) majuwsu [here written in two copies of the S and in the CK with tenween, but afterwards shown in the S to be imperfectly decl., and expressly said to be so in the Msb, art. hwd,] is pl. of majuwsiY~N: (S, K:) [or rather the former is a coll. gen. n., and the latter is the n. un.:] the latter is a rel. n. from Almajuwsiy~apu, q. v., (S,) and is an epithet applied to a man: (K:) Almajuwsu has the article Al only because it is used as a pl., (Aboo-'Alee, S, M, L,) for Almajuwsiy~uwna; (ISd, L;) for otherwise mjws could not receive the art., being of itself determinate; and it is also of the fem. gender; wherefore, with respect to inflection, it is like the qabiylap, not the HaY~; and the same is the case with respect to yahuwdu; (Aboo-'Alee, S;) [i. e.,] each of these two words is imperfectly decl. because they mean thereby the qbylp [so called, so that it is a fem. proper name]. (Msb, art. hwd.) majuwsu was a certain man with small ears, who instituted a religion (K) for the majuws, (TA,) and invited [them] to it : (K:) so says Az: he was not Zarádusht [or Zoroaster] the Persian, as some say, because he [Zarádusht] was after Abraham, whereas the religion of the mjws is [more] ancient; but Zarádusht revived it, and published it, and added to it: (MF:) the name is arabicized, from manoja kuw$, or myj kw$, or miyxa kuw$, (as differently written in different copies of the K, the first being the reading in the TA, and the last being that in the CK), the latter of which words signifies “ the ear, ” [in Persian, but written with k,] and the former meaning “ short. ” (TA.)

Almajuwsiy~apu *
The religion of the majuws [or Magians]. (S, K.) Mohammad said that the qadariy~ap were the majuws of his people, because the latter believed in two principles, light and darkness, and ascribed good to light and evil to darkness, and in like manner the qdry~p ascribed good to God, and evil to man and the devil. (TA.)

div2.head: mjE, &c
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 maH~a * , (S, K,) aor. yamiH~u and yamuH~u [the latter contr. to analogy] (K) and yamaH~u, (L,) inf. n. maH~N and maHaHN and muHuwHN; (K;) and ↓ AmH~; (S;) It (a garment) became old and worn-out. (S, K.) ― -b2- It (a dwelling) had its vestiges obliterated. (L.) ― -b3- It (a writing) became obliterated. (L.) -A2- maH~a Alka*~aAbu, aor. yamuH~u, inf. n. maHaAHapN, [The liar pleased, or contented, with his words, but did, or performed, nothing: or lied, from whatsoever place he came]. (L.)
4 A^amoHa3a see 1.
maH~N * (S, K) and ↓ maAH~N (TA) An old and wornout garment. (S, K.)
muH~N * The purest, best, or choicest, part of anything. (K.) ― -b2- The yolk of an egg; (S, K;) as also ↓ muH~apN: (ISh, K:) or the entire contents of an egg; (K;) the yolk and the white. (ISh.)
muH~apN * : see muH~N.

maH~aAHN *
One who pleases or contents thee with his words, but who does, or performs, nothing: (T, S, K:) an habitual liar: (S, K:) one who will not tell thee truly whence he comes; who lies to thee even respecting the place whence he comes. (L.)
maAH~N * : see maH~N.

1 maHuta * , aor.
maHuta , It (a day) was violently hot: (S:) or was hot. (K.) ― -b2- laA^amoHatan~aka I will assuredly fill thee with anger. (K.)

maHotN *
Strong; vehement; violent; or intense; syn. $adiydN; (S, K;) as an epithet applied to anything. (S.) ― -b2- yawomN maHotN A day violently hot; like HamotN: (S:) or a hot day. (K.) layolapN maHotapN [A night vehemently hot: or a hot night]. (TA.) ― -b3- maHotN Intelligent: or acute in mind; (K;) or of full strength of heart, and acute in mind: (TA:) pl. muHuwtN and muHataA'u; (K;) the latter as though formed from the imaginary sing. maHiytN. (TA.) ― -b4- maHutN Pure; free from admixture; genuine. (K.) ― -b5- EarabiY~N maHotN baHotN A pure, or genuine, Arab. (TA.) [See also baHotN.]

1 maHava $ayoy^FA *
i. q. Havamahu. (L.)

maHovN *
One who mixes with people, and eats and converses with them. (MF, from the Námoos of [the Mulla 'Alee] El-Káree: [but SM expresses some doubt of its correctness, or whether it be correctly mxv].
maHaArapN mHAr mHArh mHArp : see art. Hwr, to which it belongs accord. to As and others: Lth mentions it in art. mHr. (TA.)

1 maHoSN * [an inf. n. of which the verb is app. maHaSa, aor.
maHaSa ,) A thing's becoming, or being, clear, pure, or free from admixture. (TA.) See also 5, throughout. -A2- maHaSahu: see 2, in three places. -A3- maHaSa, aor.
maHaSa , (S, K,) inf. n. maHoSN, (TA,) He (an antelope) ran: (S, K:) or ran vehemently: (TA:) or vigorously: (AA, TA:) or was quick, or swift, in his running; as also fiY Eadowihi ↓ AmtHS. (TA.) And hence, (TA,) maHaSa Als~ayora, [app. for fiY Als~ayori,] said of a man, He exerted himself, or was vigorous, in journeying. (K, TA.)

2 mH~Shu * , inf. n. tamoHiySN, He rendered it clear, pure, free from every admixture or imperfection or the like; as also ↓ maHaSahu, aor.
maHaSa , inf. n. maHoSN. (Az, A, TA.) You say, maH~aSa Al*~ahaba, (A, TA,) or ↓ maHaSahu, (S, K,) He cleared, or purified, the gold from what was mixed with it, (S, A, K,) i. e. from the earth, or dust, and dirt, (TA,) biAln~aAri by fire. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) He (God) purged, or purified it; namely a man's heart: and him; namely a man repenting. (A.) It is said in the Kur, [iii. 135,] waliyumaH~iSa A@ll~`hu A@l~a*iyna A@manuwA (tropical:) And that God may purify those who believe: (TA:) or purge away the sins of those who believe: (Fr, TA:) or these words have another meaning, which see below. (TA.) It is also said in a trad., mentioning a sedition, or conflict and faction, or the like, yumaH~aSu Aln~aAsu fiyhaA kamaA yumaH~aSu *ahabu AlmaEodini, i.e. (tropical:) Men shall be cleared therein, one from another, like as the gold from the mine is cleared from the earth, or dust. (TA.) tamoHiySu Al*~unuwbi signifies (tropical:) The purging of sins. (TA.) And you say, maH~iSo Ean~aA *unuwbanaA, meaning (tropical:) Remove thou, or put thou away, from us our sins. (TA.) [But this phrase may be rendered somewhat differently; as will be seen below.] And A@ll~`hu maA bika ↓ maHaSa, and maH~aSahu; i.e. (tropical:) May God remove, or put away, what is in thee. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] (assumed tropical:) He tried, proved, or tested, him: (S, IAth, K:) and accord. to Ibn-'Arafeh, the verb has this meaning in the phrase quoted above from the Kur: [but he adds,] because the trial of the Muslims diminishes their sins: for (TA) tamoHySN also signifies The diminishing [a thing]. (Ibn- 'Arafeh, K.) You say, maH~aSa A@ll~`hu Eanoka *unuwbaka May God diminish thy sins. (TA.) ― -b4- And the clearing, or cleansing, flesh from sinews, (K, TA,) for the purpose of twisting them into a bow-string. (TA.)
4 A^amoHaSa see 5, throughout.

5 tmH~S * [It became clear, pure, free from every admixture or imperfection or the like; as also ↓ AnmHS; and ↓ A_im~aHaSa; and ↓ A^amoHaSa; and ↓ maHaSa, q. v.] ― -b2- [Hence,] tmH~St *unuwbuhu (tropical:) [His sins became purged away]. (A, TA.)
And tmH~St AlZ~alomaA='u (tropical:) The darkness became cleared away, or removed. (A, TA.) And Al$~amosu ↓ A^amoHaSati, and ↓ AnmHSt, (K,) and ↓ A_im~aHaSat, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The sun appeared, and became clear, after an eclipse. (K, TA.) And Alr~ajulu ↓ A^amoHaSa, (inf. n. A_imoHaASN, TA) (assumed tropical:) The man recovered from his disease. (Ibn-'Abbád, K. *)
7 AnmHS * and A_im~aHaSa : see 5, in two places.
8 A_imotaHaSa see 1.
mumaH~aSN * One whose sins are put away from him: mentioned by Kr.: but he says, I know not how this is; for that which is mumaH~aS is the sin [itself]. (TA.)

1 maHaDahu * , (S, A, K,) aor.
maHaDa , (K,) inf. n. maHoDN, (TK,) He gave him to drink [milk such as is termed] maHoD; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ AmHDhu. (S, K.) ― -b2- He made it (namely milk) to be such as is termed maHoD; (A;) and ↓ AmHDhu signifies [the same; or] he made it (milk, or anything, S) to be pure, sheer, free from admixture, unmingled, unmixed, or clear. (S, Msb.) ― -b3- [And hence,] maHaDotu Alwud~a, aor. and inf. n. as above, (tropical:) I made love, or affection, true, or sincere; as also ↓ A^amoHaDotuhu. (Msb.) And maHaDahu Alwud~a, (S, A, K,) and Aln~uSoHa, (A,) and maHaDa lahu Aln~uSoHa, (TA,) (tropical:) He made love or affection, and good advice, to be pure, or sincere, to him; [i.e. he was pure, or sincere, to him in love, or affection, and in good advice;] as also Alwud~a ↓ AmHDhu; (S, A, K;) or, accord. to IDrd, this latter only; (A;) but this latter was unknown to As; (IB;) and AlnSH ↓ AmHDhu; (A;) and lh AlnSH ↓ AmHD. (TA.) And ↓ A^amoHaDahu AlHadiyva (tropical:) He was true, or veracious, to him in the narration, or in discourse. (IKtt, K.) And fulaAnN AlHaq~a ↓ maH~aDaniY (assumed tropical:) [Such a one declared, or told clearly, to me the truth]. (A, TA, voce Sab~aHa.) -A2- maHiDa, (Sgh, K,) aor.
maHaDa , inf. n. maHaDN, (TK,) He drank [milk such as is termed] mHD; (Sgh, K;) as also ↓ AmtHD. (S, K.) See also 10. -A3- maHuDa, aor.
maHuDa , inf. n. muHuwDapN, (assumed tropical:) He became pure in his Hasab [or grounds of pretension to respect]. (S, K.) And maHuDa fiY nasabihi, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He was pure, or unmixed, in his race, lineage, or parentage. (Msb.)
2 maH~aDa see above.
4 AmHDhu * : see maHaDahu, throughout. ― -b2- AmHD Ald~aAb~apa (tropical:) He fed the beast of carriage with maHoD, meaning qat~ [a kind of trefoil, or clover]. (IKtt.)
8 A_imotaHaDa see maHiDa.

10 AstmHD * [He asked for, or demanded, or desired, milk such as is termed maHoD]. (A.) ― -b2- [In a copy of the A, it has also assigned to it the signification given above to maHiDa and AmtHD; but in this instance I think it a mistranscription for AmtHD.]

maHoDN *
Milk that is pure, sheer, free from admixture, unmingled, unmixed, or clear; (Lth, S, A, K;) without froth; (Lth, A;) or not mixed with water: (S, Msb;) whether sweet or sour; no other milk being so called: (S:) but it occurs repeatedly in trads. as meaning milk absolutely: (TA:) pl. miHaADN. (K.) It is said in a trad. (baAriko lahumo fiY maHoDihaA wamaxoDihaA Do Thou bless them in their [the beasts'] pure milk and churned milk. (TA.) And in another, faA@EomiduwA A_ilaY $aApK mumotaliy^apF $aHomFA wamaHoDFA [And betake yourselves to a ewe, or she-goat,] fat, and abounding with milk. (TA.) [See also an ex. voce zubodN: and another voce Sar~aHa.] ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Anything (Az, TA) pure, sheer, free from admixture, unmingled, unmixed, genuine, or clear; (Msb, TA;) that is not mixed with any other thing. (Az, Msb, TA.) You say, fiD~apN maHoDN, (K,) and maHoDapN, (A, K,) and ↓ mamoHuwDapN, (K,) (tropical:) Pure, unmixed, unalloyed, silver: (A, * K:) so says Sb: but you say, h`*ihi AlfiD~apu maHoDFA (tropical:) [This is silver in a pure state]; putting the last word in the accus. case, used as an inf. n. (TA.) And EarabiY~N maHoDN (tropical:) An Arabian of pure, or unmixed, race, or lineage, or parentage: (S, A, Msb: *) [a genuine Arabian:] and the epithet is the same as fem. [and dual] and pl., (S, Msb,) accord. to the more approved usage; (Msb;) [for it is originally an inf. n.;] but you may, if you please, use the fem. and dual and pl. forms, as in the instances of [the synonymous epithets] qalobN and baHotN: (S:) and Aln~asabi ↓ huwa mamoHuwDu (tropical:) he is pure, or unmixed, in race, or lineage, or parentage: (K, TA:) and AlD~ariybapi ↓ mamoHuwDu (tropical:) rendered pure in nature, or disposition; (Az, O;) freed from faults or vices: (Az:) and maHoDu AlHasabi (tropical:) pure in grounds of pretension to respect: (TA:) and AlHasabi ↓ mamoHuwDu (tropical:) rendered pure therein: (O, K:) the pl. of maHoDN thus used is miHaADN [a pl. of mult.] and A^amoHaADN [a pl. of pauc.]. (TA.) You say also, A^uHib~uka Hub~FA maHoDFA (tropical:) [I love thee with a pure, sincere, or true, love]. (A.) And maHoDu AlA_iyomaAni occurs in a trad. as meaning (tropical:) Pure faith or belief. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, i. q. qat~N [A kind of trefoil, or clover]. (IKtt)

maHiDN * A man who loves [milk such as is termed] maHoD; like as one says, $aHimN laHimN, meaning one “ who loves fat and flesh meat: ” (O:) or one who eagerly desires maHoD; as also ↓ maAHiDN: (K:) each is a relative epithet; (TA:) or ↓ the latter signifies a possessor of maHoD; (S, K;) similar to laAbinN and taAmirN: (S:) and the former, a drinker of maHoD. (TA voce vafilN, q. v.)
maAHiDN * : see maHiDN, in two places.
A^umoHuwDapN * (tropical:) True, or sincere, advice. (K, TA.)
mamoHuwDN * : see maHoDN, in four places.

div2.head: mHT, &c
div2.entryFree: See Supplement
mx~x AlEaZoma * , (K,) and ↓ tmx~xhu and ↓ Amtx~hu (S, K) and ↓ maxomaxahu, (K,) He extracted the marrow from the bone. (S, K.)

4 Amx~ *
It (a bone) was, or became, marrowy; had, or contained, marrow in it. (S, K.) ― -b2- It (a camel, S, L, and a sheep or goat, L, K) became fat: (S, L, K:) or became in the first stage of fatness; or in the last stage when becoming lean. (L.) ― -b3- Amx~ (tropical:) It (a branch, or twig,) became sappy, and succulent. (L, K.) ― -b4- (tropical:) It (standing corn, K, or its grain, L) became supplied with the farinaceous substance. (L, K.)
5 tamax~a3a see 1.
8 A_imotaxa3a see 1.

R. Q. 1
see 1.

max~N *
i. q. liynN Softness, &c.: or layonN soft, &c. (So in different copies of the K.)

mux~N * The marrow (niqoY, in the CK naqiY~,) of a bone; (K;) that which is in a bone; (S;) the substance which is extracted from a bone; (IDrd;) the greasy or oily substance which is in a bone: (Msb:) pl. mixaxapN (S, K) and mixaAxN. (K.) ― -b2- [Any kind of pulp.] ― -b3- ↓ mux~apN is a more special term than mux~N, (S,) signifying A portion, or piece, of marrow. (L.) ― -b4- $ar~N m~aA yujiyuw^ka A_ilaY mux~api EuroquwbK [It is an evil thing that compelleth thee to have recourse to the marrow of a hock]. A proverb. (S.) [See art. Erqb.] ― -b5- mux~N also signifies (sometimes, S,) (assumed tropical:) The brain. (S, K.) ― -b6- Also, The bulb (lit. fat, $aHomap,) of the eye. (A, K.) Mostly used in this sense in poetry. (TA.) ― -b7- Also, (tropical:) Good, profit, or advantage. Ex. laA A^araY liA^amorika mux~FA I see no good, or profit, or advantage, [pertaining] to thy affair. (A.) ― -b8-
Also, (tropical:) The purest, choicest, best, or most excellent, part of anything: (S, A, L, K:) and ↓ mux~apN (A, L) and ↓ muxaAxapN. (TA.) Ex. h`w^ulaA='u mux~u Alqawomi, and ↓ mux~atuhumo, (tropical:) These are the best of the people. (A.) And Ald~uEaA='u mux~u AlEibaAdapi (tropical:) Supplication is the purest, or best, part of religious worship, or devotion. (L, from a trad.) And h`*aA mino mux~i qalobiY, and ↓ mux~atihi, (tropical:) This [proceeds] from the purest, or best, [affections] of my heart. (L.)
mux~apN * : see mux~N.

maxiyxN * A bone containing marrow. (K.) ― -b2- maxiyxapN A ewe, (L, K,) and a she-camel, (L,) having marrow in her bones. (L, K.) ― -b3- Also, the latter, (tropical:) An excellent she-camel: (TA:) pl. maxaAy^ixu. (K.)

muxaAxapN *
What one sucks from a bone; (L;) what comes forth from a bone into the mouth of him who sucks it. (K.) ― -b2- See mux~N.

mumix~N * act. part. n. of A^amax~a. ― -b2- bayona Almumix~api wAlEajofaA='i [Between the fat she-camel or ewe, and the lean]. A proverb. (S, A, L.) Said of a thing which is of a middling sort. (A.) ― -b3- lisaAnN mumix~N A sharp, or ready, tongue, powerful to speak: and a tongue that intercedes well. (A.) A^amorN mumix~N (A, L, K) and ↓ mumax~ixN, (A,) A thing, or an affair, in which is excellence, and good: (A:) or, that benefits; syn. TaAy^ilN: (L:) but accord. to the K, long; syn. TawiylN. (TA.)
mumax~ixN * : see mumix~N.

1 maxaja Ald~alowa * , (aor.
maxaja , K, inf. n. maxojN, TA) He drew the bucket, and dashed it in the water, in order that it might fill: (Lh, S, K:) or maxaja Ald~alowa wagayorahaA, and maxaja bihaA, and ↓ tmx~jhA, and tmx~j bihaA, and ↓ tmAxjhA, and tmAxj bhA, he agitated, or moved about, the bucket, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- maxaja Albiy^ora He agitated the water of the well violently: and he plied the well with the large bucket. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] maxaja, (aor.
maxaja , inf. n. maxojN, TA) Inivit feminam. (As, S, K.)
5 tamax~aja see 1. ― -b2- tmx~j AlmaA='a He agitated the water; put it in motion, or into a state of commotion. (A'Obeyd, K.)
6 tamaAoxaja see 1.

1 maxarati Als~afiynapu * , (S, A, K,) or mxrt Alsfynp AlmaA='a, (TA,) aor.
maxara (S, K) and
maxura , (S, TA,) inf. n. maxorN and muxuwrN, (S, K,) The ship clave the water with its stem, and ran: (AHeyth:) or clave the water with a noise: (A:) or ran, cleaving the water with a noise: (S:) or ran: or faced the wind in her course: (K:) or advanced and retired. (TA.) And maxara Als~aAbiHu The swimmer clave the water with his arms (K, TA.) in swimming. (TA.) The primary signification of maxorN is the act of cleaving: and it also signifies the making a noise or sound. (TA.)

5 tmx~r Alr~iyHa *
He (a horse) faced the wind, (K,) or turned his nose towards the wind, (TA,) for the sake of greater ease to himself; as also ↓ AmtxrhA, and ↓ AstmxrhA. (K.) It is mostly said of the camel: you say, tmx~rt AlA_ibilu Alr~iyHa The camels faced the wind, and snuffed it. (TA.) And, met., of a man; as in the following ex.: xarajotu A^atamax~aru Alr~iyHa, app. meaning, (tropical:) I went forth to snuff the wind. (TA.) You also say, Alr~iyHa ↓ A_isotamoxarotu (assumed tropical:) I directed my nose towards the wind. (S, A.) And it is said in a trad., A_i*aA A^araAda A^aHadukumu Albawola faloyatamax~ari Alr~iyHa (S, K) (assumed tropical:) When any one of you desires to make water, let him see whence the wind blows, and not face it, that it may not drive back the urine against him, (S, TA,) and cause it to sprinkle him; but let him turn his back to the wind. (TA.) And again, (K,) in a trad. of Surákah, as related by ISh, on the same subject, (TA,) ↓ A_isotamoxiruwA Alr~iyHa, i.e., Turn ye your backs to the wind, (K,) in making water; (TA;) as though, (kaA^an~ahu: so in the copies of the K; but in the Nh of IAth, liA^an~ahu, for, TA) when one turns his back to it, he (as it were, TA) cleaves it with his back, so that it passes on his right and left: for though tamax~urN sometimes means the act of facing the wind, yet in this trad. it means the turning the back: (K:) but this is not properly its meaning; for the meaning is, the looking to see whence the wind blows: then the man is to turn his back. (TA.) You say also tmx~rt AlA_ibilu AlkalaA^a The camels turned themselves towards the pasture. (L.)
8 A_imotaxara see 5, throughout.
10 A_isotamoxara see 5, throughout.

maAxirapN * sing. of mawaAxira, (TA,) which occurs in the Kur, xvi. 14, (S,) and xxxv. 13, (TA,) meaning, Ships cleaving the water with their stems: (K, * TA:) or thrusting the water with their stems: (Ahmad Ibn-Yahya:) or the sound of the running whereof, (Fr, K,) by means of the winds, (Fr,) is heard: (Fr, K:) or running: (S:) or advancing and retiring by means of one wind. (K.)

maAxuwrN * (tropical:) The shop of a vintner: so called by the people of El-'Irák: (L, voce HaAnuwtN:) a place of assembly of vintners: (TA:) a place of assembly of vicious or immoral persons: (S, TA:) a place of assembly, (A,) or a house, (K,) which gives reason for suspicion, or evil opinion. (A, K.) And (tropical:) He who superintends or manages such a house, and leads [others] to it. (K.) An arabicized word, from [the Persian] mayoxuwro, or maYo xuwro, or mayoxawAro, (as in different copies of the K,) meaning “ a winedrinker ” : so that as a name of the place, it is tropical: (TA:) or Arabic, from maxarati Als~afiynapu, (K,) meaning “ the ship advanced and retired ”; (TA;) because of men's frequenting it, going to and fro: (K:) in which case also it is tropical. (TA.) Pl mawaAxiyru (A, K) and mawaAxiru. (K.) The former pl. occurs in a trad. (TA.)

1 maxaDa All~abana * , (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
maxuDa , (S, A, Msb, K,) and
maxiDa , and
maxaDa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. maxoDN, (Msb,) He churned, or beat and agitated, the milk, (Mgh,) in the mimoxaDap: (A, Mgh:) and (A) he took the butter of the milk: (A, K:) or he extracted, or fetched out, the butter of the milk, by putting water in it, and agitating it: (Msb:) or maxoDN signifies one's agitating the mimoxaD wherein is the milk of which the butter has been taken. (Lth.) ― -b2- [Hence,] maxoDN relates also to many things. (TA.) Thus, you say, (TA) maxaDa Al$~aYo'a, (K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He shook, or agitated, the thing vehemently. (K, TA.) It is said in a trad., mur~a Ealayohi bijinaAzapK tumoxaDu maxoDFA; (L;) or tumoxaDu maxoDa Alz~q~; (O;) (assumed tropical:) [A bier with a corpse was conveyed past him] being shaken, or agitated, quickly; (L, TA;) or being shaken, or agitated, vehemently [like as the milkskin is shaken, &c.] (O, TA.) You say also, maxaDa Ald~alowa, (K,) or biAld~alowi, (Fr, S, O, L,) which latter is the correct phrase, (TA,) or maxaDa AlmaA='a biAld~alowi (A,) and maxaDa Albiy^ora biAld~alowi, (TA,) (tropical:) He dashed the bucket in the water of the well, to fill it: (Fr., S, O, L, K:) or he drew much water with the bucket: (A:) and the last, he drew much with the bucket from the well, and agitated it. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence,] maxaDa raA^oyahu (A, Msb) (tropical:) He turned over, or revolved, his idea, or opinion, [in his mind,] and considered what would be its results, (Msb,) until the right course appeared to him. (A, Msb.) ― -b4- And maxaDa A@ll~`hu Als~iniyna Hat~aY kaAna *`lika zubodatahaA (tropical:) [God caused the years to revolve until that was their issue, or result]. (A, TA.) ― -b5- And maxaDa said of a camel, (tropical:) He brayed (hadara) in his $iqo$iqap [i.e. faucial bag, or bursa faucium]. (K, TA.) -A2- maxiDato, (ISh, IAar S, Msb, K,) aor.
maxaDa ; (S, K;) or maxaDato; (so in a copy of the A and in a copy of the Mgh) or both; (JK, K;)
aor. of the latter, as of the former,
maxaDa ; (K;) and muxiDato; (ISh, L, K;) but this last is disallowed by IAar; (TA;) and the generality of Keys and Temeem and Asad say mixiDato, with kesr to the m, [for maxiDato,] and in like manner they do in the case of every [incipient] letter before a guttural letter in words of the measures faEilotu and faEiylN; (Nuseyr, TA;) inf. n. maxaADN (ISh, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and mixaADN (Msb, K) and maxaDN; (A;) said of a she-camel, (ISh, S,) or of a woman, (IAar,) or absolutely, (A, Mgh,) or also absolutely, (Msb, TA, *) of a woman, and of a she-camel, and of other beasts, (TA,) (tropical:) She was taken with the pains of parturition, (ISh, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) being near to bringing forth; (Msb;) as also ↓ max~aDato, inf. n. tamoxiyDN; (K;) and ↓ tmx~Dt; (ISh, and so in some copies of the K;) each of these last two is correct; (TA;) and ↓ AmtxDt. (ISh.) And maxiDato said of a woman, (tropical:) Her child moved about in her belly, previously to the birth: (Ibráheem El-Harbee:) and in like manner, biwaladihaA ↓ tmx~Dt, (S, * TA,) said of a she-camel, (tropical:) her young one became agitated in her belly at the time of bringing forth: (TA:) and ↓ tmx~Dt [alone], said of a ewe, or she-goat, (assumed tropical:) she conceived, or became pregnant. (As, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] maxiDa Als~aHaAbu bimaAy^ihi, and ↓ tmx~D, (TA,) and Als~amaA='u ↓ tmx~Dt, (A, TA,) (tropical:) [The cloud, or clouds, and] the sky, or heaven, prepared, or became ready, to rain. (A, TA.) And All~ayolapu Eano SabaAHi sawo'K ↓ tmx~Dt, (A,) or yawomi sawo'K, (TA,) (tropical:) The night had an evil morning. (TA,) And Ald~ahoru biAlofitonapi ↓ tmx~D (tropical:) Time, or fortune, brought trial, civil war, sedition, or the like: (K, TA:) as though from AlmaxaADu. (K.) 'Amr Ibn-Hassán, one of the Benu-l-Hárith-Ibn-Hemmám-Ibn-Murrah, says, (Seer, S,) but the saying is also ascribed to Sahm Ibn-Khálid Ibn- 'Abd-Allah Esh-Sheybánee, and to Khálid Ibn- Hikk Esh-Sheybánee, (TA,)
Almanuwnu lahu biyawomK ↓ tamax~aDati
A^anaY walikul~i HaAmilapK tamaAmu
meaning [Time, or fortune,] was pregnant with a day for him, of which the time of birth had come: [for for every one that is pregnant there is a term of completion.] (S.)
2 max~aDa see maxiDato.

4 AmxD All~abanu *
The milk attained to the proper time for [its being churned, or] having its butter taken, or extracted. (S, A, Msb.) In the O and K, it is made to signify the same as AmtxD: but it seems that Sgh has inadvertently omitted, after it, the words HaAna lahu A^ano yumoxaDa, and that the author of the K has copied him without referring to other lexicons. (TA.) ― -b2- Also AmxD, (K,) said of a man, (TA,) (tropical:) He had his she-camels taken with the pains of parturition; (K, TA;) and his she-camel, in like manner. (TA.)

5 tmx~D *
It (milk) was, or became, agitated in the mimoxaDap; (S, A, * TA;) as also ↓ AmtxD. (S, O, K.) [See also 4.] ― -b2- It (milk) had its butter taken. (K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) It (a child, or young one,) moved about in the belly of its mother; as also ↓ the latter verb. (S, TA.) ― -b4- See also maxiDato and what follows it, to the end of the paragraph.
8 A_imotaxaDa see 5, in two places: ― -b2- and see maxiDato.

10 AstmxD All~abanu *
The milk was slow in becoming thick and fit for churning, and its butter would hardly, if at all, come forth: such is the best of milk, because its butter is in it. (A.) ― -b2- Also, The milk was slow in acquiring flavour after it had been collected in the skin. (TA.)
maxoDN * : see maxiyDN.

maxaADN mxAD (assumed tropical:) The pains of parturition; (S, Msb;) as also ↓ mixaADN. (Msb.) -A2- Applied to she-camels, (tropical:) Pregnant: (AZ, As, S, ISd, A, Msb, K, &c.:) used in this sense as an epithet of good omen, whence they augur that their young ones will become agitated in their bellies at the time of parturition: (ISd:) having their young in their bellies: (M, TA:) or such as are called Ei$aAr, that have been ten months pregnant: (Th, K:) but ISd says, I have not found this explanation of mxAD on any authority beside that of Th: (TA:) [see also Eu$araA='u:] it has no proper sing: (S:) a single one is termed xalifapN, (AZ, As, S, A, &c,) which is extr. (K, TA) with respect to rule: (TA:) or maxaADN signifies, or it signifies also, (accord. to different copies of the K,) she-camels in the state in which they are from the time when the stallion is sent among them (ISd, K) until he brays (Hat~aY yahodira), or, accord. to another relation, until they are left (Ht~Y tugodara), i.e., (ISd,) until he ceases (Ht~Y yanoqaTiEa, in the copies of the K, erroneously, HtY tnqTE, TA) from covering: (ISd, K:) a pl. (K) having no sing. (ISd, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) Aibonu maxaADK (tropical:) A young male camel, which, (As, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) having completed a year (As, S, Mgh) from the day of its birth, (As,) has entered upon the second year: (As, S, Mgh, Msb, K:) because his mother, (S, IAth, Mgh, K,) from whom he has been separated, (S,) has become adjoined to the maxaAD, (S, IAth, Mgh, K,) or pregnant camels, (IAth, K,) whether she have conceived or not; (S, IAth, * K; *) for they used to make the stallion-camels to cover the females a year after these had brought forth, (IAth, K, *) in order that their young ones might become strong, so that they conceived in the second year: (IAth:) or because its mother has been covered, and has conceived, and become adjoined to the maxaAD, i.e., to the pregnant camels; and this appellation it bears until it has completed the second year; but when it has entered upon the third, it is called Aibonu labuwnK: (Msb:) or a young male camel when his mother has conceived: (K:) or whose mother has become pregnant: or when the she-camels among whom is his mother have become pregnant, though she have not become so: (IAth, K:) the female is called binotu maxaADK; (IAth, Msb, K;) or Aibonapu maxaADK: (S:) the pl., (S, Msb, K,) of both the male and female appellations, (Msb,) is banaAtu maxaADK, (S, Msb, K,) only; like banaAtu labuwnK and banaAtu A=waY. (S.) Sometimes one adds to it the article Al, (Msb, K,) saying, Aibonu AlmaxaADi: (Msb:) [for] Abn mxAD is indeterminate; and when you desire to make it determinate, you affix the article Al, as above; but this only makes it determinate as a generic appellation. (S.)
mixaADN * : see maxaADN.
maxuwDN * : see maAxiDN, in two places.

maxiyDN * and ↓ mamoxuwDN (S, Msb, K) and ↓ maxoDN (TA, voce maHoDN, q. v.) [Churned milk:] or milk which has been churned (Al~a*iY qado muxiDa), and of which the butter has been taken: (S:) or milk of which the butter has been taken: (K:) or milk of which the butter has been extracted, or fetched out, by putting water in it, and agitating it. (Msb.)

maAxiDN * , applied to a she-camel, (ISh, IAar, S, K,) and to a woman, and a ewe or she-goat, (IAar, Msb, K,) and any pregnant animal, (S, A, * Msb,) (tropical:) Taken with the pains of parturition, (ISh, IAar, S, A, Msb,) being near to bringing forth; (IAar, Msb, K;) as also ↓ maxuwDN: (ISh:) and, applied to a ewe or she-goat, having conceived; as also ↓ the latter epithet; (As, K;) pl. of the former, mux~aDN (S, Msb, K) and mawaAxiDu. (A, K.) ― -b2- The Arabs say, in one of their imprecations, Sab~a A@ll~`hu Ealayoka A^um~a HubayonK maAxiDFA, meaning (assumed tropical:) [May God pour upon thee] the night. (Ibn-Buzurj.)

A_imoxaADN *
Fresh milk (Haliyb), (K,) or churned milk (labanN maxiyDN), (Lth,) as long as it remains in the mimoxaDap: (Lth, K:) or, as some say, milk collected in the place of pasturage until it amounts to the quantity of a camel-load: pl. A^amaA xiyDu. (Lth.) You say A_imoxaADN mino labanK and A_iHolaAbN mino labanK: (Lth:) or the former is of ewes or she-
goats, or of cows; and the latter, of camels. (TA, in art. Hlb, q. v.) ― -b2- See also mimoxaDN.

mimoxaDN *
A skin; syn.; siqaA='N; (K;) as also ↓ A_imoxaADN, which is mentioned by Sb, and thus explained by Seer: (TA:) or a skin (sqA') in which is maxiyD [or churned milk, &c.]: (TA:) or the receptacle in which the milk whereof the butter has been taken is agitated: (Lth:) and ↓ mimoxaDapN [and app. the former also] the vessel, (Mgh,) or receptacle, (Msb,) [generally a skin,] in which milk is churned or beaten and agitated; (Mgh, K; *) or in which the butter of the milk is extracted, or fetched out by putting water in it, and agitating it; (Msb;) [i.e. a churn;] i. q. A_iboriyjN. (S.)
mimoxaDapN * : see what next precedes.
mimoxaADN * (assumed tropical:) A she-camel having a quick flow of milk. (JK.)
mamoxuwDN * : see maxiyDN.

musotamoxiDN * Milk slow in becoming thick and fit for churning: (K:) or that hardly, if at all, becomes so; and when it has become so, is churned; and this is the best of the milk of ewes or goats, because its butter is destroyed (Asthlk) in it. (TA.) [But see 10.]

1 maxoTN * , [an inf. n., of which the verb is app. maxaTa,] the act of flowing; and of going, coming, or passing, out, or forth: this is the primary signification; and hence muxaATN, q. v. (TA) ― -b2- [Hence also,] maxaTa Als~ahomu, (S, K,) aor.
maxaTa and
maxuTa , inf. n. muxuwTN, (K,) (tropical:) The arrow transpierced, (S, K,) and went forth on the other side. (S.) ― -b3- [And] maxaTa bihi Aljamalu (assumed tropical:) The camel went quickly with him. (Sgh, K.) ― -b4- [And] maxaTa fiY AlA^aroDi, inf. n. maxoTN, (assumed tropical:) He went away quickly in the land. (TA.) -A2- maxaTa AlS~abiY~a, inf. n. maxoTN, He wiped the nose of the child; and in like manner you say of a lamb or kid: (L:) and ↓ mx~Thu, (Msb,) inf. n. tamoxiyTN, (Z, K,) he removed the mucus from out of his nose: (Msb:) and he (the pastor) wiped off from its (a lamb's or kid's) nose what was upon it [at the time of the birth]. (Z, K.) And maxaTa AlmuxaATa He cast the mucus (S, K) mino A^anofihi from his nose. (S.) ― -b2- [And hence,] maxaTa Als~ayofa (tropical:) He drew the sword (K, TA) from its scabbard; (TA;) as also ↓ AmtxThu: (S, K:) and sometimes they said, (S,) maA fiY yadihi ↓ AmtxT (tropical:) he pulled out what was in his hand; (S, K;) he seized, took away quickly by force, or snatched away, what was in his hand: (S, L, K:) and rumoHahu mino marokazihi ↓ AmtxT (tropical:) he pulled out his spear from its place in which it was stuck. (TA.) ― -b3- [And] maxaTahu, (S, K, *) aor.
maxaTa , inf. n. maxoTN, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He drew it; pulled it. (S, K. *) You say, maxaTa fiY Alqawosi (assumed tropical:) [He drew the bow; or drew, or pulled, its string with the arrow]. (S.)
2 max~aTa see 1.
4 AmxT Als~ahoma * , (S, K,) inf. n. A_imoxaATN, (TA,) (tropical:) He made the arrow to transpierce, (S, A, K,) and to go forth on the other side. (A.)
5 tamax~aTa see 8.

8 AmtxT *
He blew his nose; ejected the mucus from his nose; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ tmx~T: (S, K:) or the latter signifies he had the mucus removed from out of his nose. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 1, in three places.

muxaATN *
Mucus; snivel; what flows from the nose, (S, K, TA,) like luEaAb from the mouth: (TA:) pl. A^amoxiTapN only. (TA.) ― -b2- muxaATu Al$~ayoTaAni, (K,) also called muxaATu Al$~amos, and luEaAbu Al$~amos, and riyqu Al$~amosi, all these appellations having been heard from the Arabs, (TA,) (tropical:) [The fine filmy cobwebs called gossamer, which are occasionally seen in very hot and calm weather, when the sun is high, floating in the air, in stringy or flaky forms;] what appears in the sun's rays to him who looks into the air in the time of vehement midday-heat: (K, TA:) mxAT Al$yTAn is explained by Z and IB as meaning what comes forth from the mouth of the spider. (TA in art. xyT.)

muxaATapN * (AO, K) and ↓ mux~ayoTN, (K,) called by the latter name by some of the people of ElYemen, (Sgh, TA,) and by the people of Egypt [in the present day], (TA,) [and ↓ mux~ayoTaA, (Golius, on the authority of Ibn-El-Beytár, but if it end with a short A, i.e. without ', it should be written mux~ayoTaY,)] [The cordia myxa, or smooth-leaved cordia; also called sebestena, and sebesten, and Assyrian plum;] a kind of tree, (K, TA,) producing a viscous fruit, [whence its name, like the Greek μύξα, which signifies both mucus and this kind of plum,] which is eaten; (TA;) called in Persian sibisotaAn [or saPisotaAn]; (K, TA;) i. q. A^aTobaA='u Alkalobap [bitch's dugs], [its fruit] being likened thereto. (TA.) (See De Sacy's “ Abd-allatif, ” pp. 68 — 72.]
mux~ayoTN * and mux~ayoTaA: see what next precedes.
sahomN maAxiTN * (tropical:) An arrow transpiercing, and going forth on the other side. (TA.)
A^amoxaTu mino sahomK * (tropical:) [More transpiercing than an arrow]: a proverb. (JK.)

div2.head: mxn, &c
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 mad~ahu * , (S, L, K,) aor.
madu3a , (L,) inf. n. mad~N; and mad~a bihi; and ↓ md~dhu; [or this has an intensive or a frequentative signification;] and ↓ tmd~dhu; (L, K;) and ↓ mAd~hu, or mAddhu, (as in different copies of the K, TA,) inf. n. mumaAd~apN and midaAdN; (K;) He drew it (namely a rope, &c., A); pulled it: strained it: extended it by drawing or pulling; stretched it. (L, K, El-Basáïr.) You say also mad~a Alqawosa [He drew the bow]; (S, Msb, K, in art. nzE;) and mad~a mina Albiy^ori [He drew water from the well]. (S, K, art. mtH.) [Hence, app., mad~a biA^arofaAdiY: see rifodN.] ― -b2- qaAy^ilu kalimapi Alz~uwri waAl~a*iY yamud~u biHabolihaA fiY AlA_ivomi sawaA='N [The utterer of falsehood and he who transmits it are in respect of the sin alike]: a trad. of 'Alee; in which the utterer of the falsehood is likened to him who fills the bucket in the lower part of the well, and the relater thereof to him who draws the rope at the top. (L.) ― -b3- mad~a He extended, or stretched forth, his hand or arm, foot or leg, &c. (The Lexicons passim.) ― -b4- bayonanaA ↓ tamad~adonaAhu We drew, pulled, strained, or stretched, it between us, or together. (L.) [But in a copy of the M, it is tamaAdadonaAhu.] ― -b5- mad~a AlHarofa, aor.
madu3a , inf. n. mad~N, He lengthened the letter. (L.) ― -b6- mad~a Sawotahu (tropical:) He prolonged, or strained, his voice [as the Arab does in chanting]: (L:) and fiY AlS~awoti ↓ tamad~ada Einoda AlwaEiydi (assumed tropical:) [He strained the voice in threatening]. (K, art. nmr.) ― -b7- mad~a, inf. n. mad~N, (tropical:) It (his sight) was, or became, stretched, and raised, A_ilaY $aYo'K towards a thing. (K.) ― -b8- mad~a baSarahu A_ilaY $aYo'K, aor.
madu3a , [inf. n. mad~N,] (tropical:) He stretched, and raised, his sight towards a thing. (A, * L.) ― -b9- madadotu EayoniY A_ilaY ka*aA (tropical:) I looked at such a thing desirously. (IKtt, El-Basáïr.) ― -b10- mad~aha, aor.
madu3a , (Lh, L,) inf. n. mad~N, (Lh, L, K,) He expanded it, or stretched it out: (L, K:) he extended it, elongated it, or lengthened it. (L.) ― -b11- mad~ A@ll~`hu AlA^aroDa God expanded, or stretched out, and made plain, or level, the earth. (Lh, L.) ― -b12- mad~a A@ll~`hu AlZ~il~a (tropical:) God extended, or stretched forth, the shade. (A.) See 8. ― -b13- mad~a A@ll~`hu fiY Eumorihi (tropical:) God made his life long; (S, A, * L;) as also ↓ Amd~a. (IKtt.) ― -b14- mad~a A@ll~`hu fiY Eumorika (tropical:) May God make thy life long! (L.) ― -b15- mud~a fiY Eumorihi (tropical:) He had his life lengthened. (L.) ― -b16- AlA^ajala ↓ A^amad~a, inf. n. A_imodaAdN, (tropical:) He deferred, or postponed, the term, or period of duration. (K.) ― -b17- lahu fiY AlA^ajali ↓ Amd~ (tropical:) He deferred, or postponed, to him the term, or his term. (TA.) ― -b18- mad~ahu, aor.
madu3a , (L,) inf. n.
mad~N; and ↓ Amd~hu, inf. n. A_imodaAdN; (L, K;) but the latter is little used; (L;) (tropical:) He made him to continue; to go on long; left him, or let him alone, long, or for a while; granted him a delay, or respite. (L, K. *) Ex. mad~ahu fiY gay~ihi, (S, L,) and ↓ Amd~hu, (L,) (tropical:) He made him to continue, &c., in his error. (S, L.) And in like manner, mad~a A@ll~`hu lahu fiY AlEa*aAbi (tropical:) God made him to continue, or go on long, in a state of punishment. (L.) See also 3. ― -b19- mad~a fiY Als~ayori (tropical:) He made much advance in journeying. (L.) ― -b20- mad~ahu, inf. n. madadN and midaAdN, He made it much in quantity; increased it. (L, TA.) ― -b21- mad~a, (S, L, Msb,) aor.
madu3a , [contr. to analogy,] (L,) inf. n. mad~N; (S, L, K;) It (water, L, and a river, S, L, and a sea, or great river, L) flowed: (S, L, K:) it (water, L, and a sea, or great river, L, Msb) increased; as also ↓ Amd~; both of which verbs are also used transitively: (Msb:) or became much in quantity, copious, or abundant, in the days of the torrents; as also ↓ Amtd~: (L:) contr. of jazara [it ebbed]. (Lth, S, M, K in art. jzr.) ― -b22- waAdiY ka*aA yamud~u fiY nahori ka*aA Such a valley flows into and increases such a river. (A, L.) ― -b23- mad~ahu, (Lh, S, L, Msb,) aor.
madu3a , (Lh, L,) inf. n. mad~N; (Lh, L, Msb;) and ↓ Amd~hu; (L, Msb;) It (a thing) entered into it, (i. e., a like thing,) and increased it, or made it copious or abundant: (Lh, L:) it (a river, S, L, or sea, or great river, L, Msb) flowed into it, (i. e., another river, or sea, or great river,) and increased it, replenished it, or made it copious or abundant: (S, * L, Msb: *) it (a well) fed it, i. e., another well: (L:) [see an ex. in a verse cited in art. grw, conj. 3]: both these verbs are also used intransitively. (Msb.) ― -b24- [mad~~ti Als~uwqu (assumed tropical:) The market was full of people and of goods for sale. See the part. n.] ― -b25- mad~a Alqawoma, [aor.
madu3a , inf. n. mad~N,] He became an auxiliary to the people: (K:) and madadonaAhumo We became auxiliaries to them: somewhat differing from ↓ A^amadonaAhumo, which signifies We aided them, or succoured them, by others than ourselves: (AZ, S, L, K:) you say, bimadadK ↓ A^amodadotuhu I aided him, and strengthened him, [or increased his numbers and strength,] with an army: (S, * Msb:) and AlA^amiyru junodahu biAlxayoli waAlr~ijaAli ↓ A^amad~a The commander aided, or succoured, his army with cavalry and infantry, or with horses and men: and bimaAlK kaviyrK ↓ Amd~humo He aided them with, or, as some say, gave them, much wealth: (L:) and [it is said in the Kur, lii. 22,] waA^amodadonaAhumo bifaAkihapK (S, L) And We will increase their provision time after time with fruit: (Beyd, Jel:) or with relation to evil, you say madadotuhu; and with relation to good, ↓ A^amodadotuhu: (K:) so says Yoo: (L:) this is generally the case; and the following are examples: A^amodadonaAhumo bifaAkihapK [explained above]: and namud~uhumo mina AlEa*aAbi (ElBasáïr) [Kur, xix. 82,] We will prolong and increase to them punishment: (Beyd;:) but Z relates, that Akh said the reverse, like waEada and A^awoEada: the usage of the Arabs, however, does not accord with either of these assertions. (MF.) ― -b26- mad~a It (anything) became full, and rose. (Sh, L.) ― -b27- mad~a Als~iraAja, (aor.
madu3a , A, [inf. n. mad~N,]) He put oil (or the like, K) into the lamp. (A, L, K.) ― -b28- mad~a Ald~awaApa, (aor.
madu3a , inf. n. mad~N, Msb,) and ↓ Amd~haA, He put ink into the receptacle thereof; (S, * Msb;) he increased its water, and its ink. (L.) ― -b29- In like manner, mad~a Alqalama, and ↓ Amd~hu, He supplied the reed-pen with ink. (L.) ― -b30- mad~ahu mud~apF mina Ald~awaApi, aor.
madu3a ; and mud~apF ↓ A^amad~ahu is also allowable; (L;) or simply mad~ahu (A) and A^amad~ahu; (S, A, K;) He gave him a dip of ink from the receptacle thereof with a reed-pen. (S, TA.) ― -b31- mad~a, inf. n. mad~N, He dipped the reedpen in the receptacle of ink a single time for writing. (Msb.) See also 10. ― -b32- mad~a AlA^aroDa, (aor.
madu3a , A, inf. n. mad~N, L,) He manured the land with dung: (A, K:) or he added to the land manure composed of dung and ashes, or of earth or dust and dung, or of strong earth; or simply earth; or sand; to render it more productive. (L.) ― -b34- mad~a AlA_ibila, (AZ, S, A, L, K.) aor.
madu3a , inf. n. mad~N; (AZ, L;) and ↓ Amd~hA; (S, A, L;) He gave madiyd (or water upon which had been sprinkled, or with which had been mixed, some flour, or the like, &c.) to the camels to drink: (AZ, S, A, L, K:) or he put some barley coarsely ground, and then moistened, into the camel's mouths: (AZ, L:) or mad~ahu bimadiydK, aor.
madu3a , inf. n. mad~N, signifies, as some say, he fed him with fodder. (M.)
2 mad~a3a see 1, first sentence.

3 maAdadotuhu * , inf. n. mumaAd~apN and midaAdN, I pulled him, he pulling me: (Lh, L:) I contended with him in drawing or pulling, in straining, or in stretching; syn. jaA*abotuhu. (L.) ― -b2- mAd~hu Alv~awoba [He pulled, strained, or stretched, the garment, or piece of cloth with him]. (A.) ― -b3- maAd~ahu He prolonged to him a time. (L, from a trad.) ― -b4- maAd~a fiY Almud~api (tropical:) He prolonged, protracted, or lengthened, the space of time. (IAth, from a trad.) ― -b5- mAd~hu, (L,) inf. n. mumaAd~apN (L, K) and midaAdN, (L,) (tropical:) He protracted, delayed, or deferred, with him; put him off. (L, K. *) See also 1.

4 A^amoda3a See 1 throughout. ― -b2- Amd~ fiyhi He (God) made it (the means of subsistence) ample: made it (wealth or the like) abundant: increased it, namely, a sea or river. (IKtt.) ― -b3- Amd~hu He made it (anything) to become full, and to rise. (Sh, L.) See also 1. ― -b4- Amd~, inf. n. A_imodaAdN, He aided, or succoured: and he gave. (K.) See mad~a Alqawoma. ― -b5- Amd~ fiY mi$oyatihi He (a man) walked with an elegant, and a proud, and self-conceited, gait, with an affected incline of his body from side to side. (TA.) See also 5. ― -b6- Amd~ (inf. n. A_imodaAdN, L, &c.) It (a wound) produced midap, or thick purulent matter. (S, L, Msb. K.) ― -b7- Amd~ (inf. n. A_imodaAdN, K) It (the plant called Earofaj, S, L, K, and the Sil~iyaAn, and the Tariyfap, TA) became succulent, the sap running in it: (S, L, K:) and it, (the twig, or wood, of any of the three plants above mentioned,) being rained upon became soft, or supple. (L.)

5 tmd~d * : see 8. ― -b2- It (leather, A) or a skin for water, &c., and anything that may be extended by drawing or pulling, (L,) stretched. (A, * L.) ― -b3- See also 1. ― -b4- tmd~d He (a man) stretched himself: he walked with an elegant, and a proud, and self-conceited, gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side, and stretching out his arms: syn. tamaT~aY. (S, L.) [Both these verbs are commonly used in the present day in the former sense.] See also 4.
6 tamaAd~aA Alv~awoba * [They two pulled, strained, or stretched, the garment, or piece of cloth, together]. (A.)

8 Amtd~ * , (S, L, K,) and ↓ tmd~d, [or this has an intensive or frequentative signification,] (L, K.) It (a rope, &c., A) because drawn, or pulled: it became strained: it became extended by drawing or pulling; it extended itself; it stretched. (L, K, El-Basáïr.) See also 5. ― -b2- Amtd~ It became expanded, or stretched out. (Msb.) ― -b3- It became elongated, or extended, or long. (Msb.) ― -b4- [It (a time) became protracted.] ― -b5- Amtd~ bihimu Als~ayoru (tropical:) The journey became long to them. (A, * L.) ― -b6- Amtd~ (tropical:) It (a man's life) became long. (A.) ― -b7- (tropical:) It (the shade) became extended, or stretched forth. (A) ― -b8- It (a disease) spread. (A.) See 1. ― -b9- Amtd~: (A, L;) and ↓ mad~a, (L, K,) inf. n. mad~N; (S, L, K;) (tropical:) It (the day, S, A, L, K, and the period of morning called AlD~uHaY, L,) became high; it became advanced, the sun being high: (S, L, K:) and the former, (tropical:) it (the day) shone forth. (L.) ― -b10- Amtd~; and ↓ mad~, inf. n. mad~; (TA;) said of the shade, (tropical:) It extended]. (A.) ― -b11- Amtd~ A_ilaY AlA_ijaAbapi A_ilayohi [app. (assumed tropical:) He strained himself to give his consent to it.] (K, voce A_inbaAEa, q. v. in art. bwE.)

10 Astmd~ mina Ald~awaApi * ; (A, L, Msb, K:) and ↓ mad~a minohaA, inf. n. mad~N; (L, Msb, K;) He took ink from the receptacle thereof with the reed-pen, for writing: (Msb:) or he took a dip from the receptacle of ink with the reed-pen. (L.) See also 1. ― -b2- Astmd~ Aln~afasa [He drew breath.] (M,
TA, art. nfs.) ― -b3- Astmd~ He asked, sought, or desired mdada [or aid, or succour, in war, &c.]. (S, L, K.) ― -b4- Astmd~hu He asked, sought, or desired, of him (a commander, A) madd [or aid, or succour, in war, &c.] (A, * L.)

R. Q. 1 madomada *
He fled. (T, L, K.)

md~N * inf. n. of 1, q. v. ― -b2- [As a subst.] qadoru mad~i AlbaSari (tropical:) A piece of land (S, L) [occupying] the space of the extent of vision; i. q. madaAhu. (S, L, K.) It is said in the K, art. mdY, that one should not say md~ AlbSr, but only madaAhu; this was originally said by El-Hareeree: but some urge against it the expression in a trad., mad~u Sawoti Almuw^a*~ini: (MF:) the trad. is, A_in~a Almuw^a*~ina yugofaru lahu mad~a Sawotihi, or, according to another reading, madaY Swth; i. e., (tropical:) Verily the muëdhdhin shall be forgiven to the extent of the prolonging of his voice; meaning, largely. (L, TA.) ― -b3- A^atayotuhu mad~a Aln~ahaAri, and mad~a AlD~uHaY, (A,) and fiY mad~ipi, (L,) (tropical:) I came to him at the time when the day, and the morning, was hïgh; or was advanced, the sun being high. (A, L,) mad~a is here an inf. n. put adverbially. (L.) ― -b4- h`*aA mad~u Aln~ahaAri AlA^akobaru (tropical:) This is the highest time of day. (A.) ― -b5- kalimaAtihi ↓ suboHaAna A@ll~`hi midaAda, (A, L, K,) and ↓ madadahaA, (L,) and midaAda Als~amawaAti, (L, K,) and madadahaA, (L,) (tropical:) I extol, or celebrate, or declare, the absolute purity, or perfection, or glory, of God, much as his words are numerous, (L,) and, as the heavens are many, or large: (L, K: *) ↓ mdAd and ↓ mdd are here inf. ns. of mad~ahu, q. v.: (L:) or the first of these phrases is from mdAd the pl. of mud~N, a certain measure. (K.) ― -b6- mad~N, app. an inf. n. used as a subst., A flow of water; a torrent: pl. muduwdN. (Msb.)

mud~N *
A certain measure with which corn is measured; equal to a pint (riTol) and one third, (S, L, Msb, K,) of the standard of Baghdád, (Msb,) with the people of El-Hijáz, (S, L, Msb,) and accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee; (L;) i. e., the quarter of a SaAE; the SAE being five pints and one third: (Msb:) such was the md~ of the Prophet; (L, TA;) and the SAE above defined was that of the Prophet: (Msb, art. SwE:) or two pints, (S, L, Msb, K,) with the people of El-'Irák, (S, L, Msb,) and accord. to Aboo- Haneefeh, (L,) who held the SAE to be eight pints: (Msb, art. SwE:) or the quantity (of corn, L) that fills the two hands of a man (of moderate size, K) when he extends his arms and hands; (L, K;) and therefore called mud~: (K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^amodaAdN and [of mult.] midaAdN (L, Msb, K) and midadapN (L. K) and midadN. (L.) ― -b2- midaAdN pl. of mud~N, or inf. n. of mad~a, see mad~N.

madadN * (S, K, &c.) ― -b2- A^amoruhumo madadN Their affair, or case, is conformable to the just mean; like A^amadN and zamamN. (TA in art. zm). ― -b3- Aid, or succour, given to one's people in war, &c., such as an auxiliary force, and corn; (T, L;) an accession to an army, &c.; (Mgh;) a military force forming an accession to warriors in the cause of God: (L:) pl. A^amodaAdN only: (Sb, L:) in like manner, ↓ maAd~apN signifies anything wherewith one aids a people in war, &c. (L.) ― -b4- [A mystic aid imparted by a waliY~.] ― -b5- See mad~N.

mad~apN *
A single act of drawing or pulling; of straining; of stretching; &c. (S, L.) ― -b2- See mud~apu.

mud~apN * (tropical:) The utmost, or extreme, extent, term, limit, reach, or point, of time, and of place. (L, K.) Ex. lih`*ihi AlA^um~api mud~apN (tropical:) To this nation, or people, is [appointed] an extreme term of endurance, or continuance. (L.) ― -b2- mud~apN (tropical:) A long space of time; or any space of time; syn. burohapN: (S, L, K:) a portion of time, whether little or much: (IAth, Msb:) pl. midaAdN. (A.) ― -b3- mud~apN A dip of ink; the quantity of ink that is taken upon the reed-pen. (S, A, * K.) The vulgar say ↓ mad~apN and mid~apN. (TA.)

mid~apN *
Thick purulent matter, (A, Msb,) i. q. qayoHN, (S, L, Msb, K,) that collects in a wound: (S, L:) the thin is called SadiydN. (A, Msb.) ― -b2- See mud~apN.

madadiY~N *
An auxiliary soldier. (L.)

midaAdN *
Anything that is added in a thing, because of its utility: this is the original signification accord. to old lexicologists. (MF.) ― -b2- Ink; syn. niqosN (S, L, K) and HiborN; (MF;) that with which one writes: (L, Msb:) so called because it aids the writer: (IAmb, L:) this is the common acceptation of the word. (MF.) ― -b3- midaAdN (or midaAdu Als~iraAji, A) Oil (or the like, K) that is put into a lamp. (A, L, K.) ― -b4- midaAdN (or midaAdN AlA^aroDi, A) Dung: (A, K:) or manure composed of dung and ashes, or of earth or dust and dung, or of strong earth; and simply earth or dust; and sand. (L.) ― -b5- midaAdN A row of trees; not of palm-trees. (IAar, in TA, voce A^usokuwbN, q. v.) ― -b6- A mode, manner, fashion, and form. (L, K.) Ex. banawoA buyuwtahumo EalaY midaAdK waAHidK They built their houses after one mode, &c. (L.) ― -b7- midaAdu qayosK A certain game (T, K) of the Arabs, (K,) or of children. (T.) ― -b8- yanobaEivu fiY AlHawoDi miyzaAbaAni midaAduhumaA A^anohaAru Aljan~api [Two pipes, or spouts, whereof the sources (lit. the source) of the supply are the rivers of paradise, pour into the pond which is without its precincts]; i. e., the rivers of paradise flow into those pipes, or spouts, and increase their flow, or make it copious, or abundant. (L, K. *) ― -b9- midaAdN sing. of A^amid~apN, (L,) which signifies The large needles (masaAl~u, M, L, TT; in the CK and a MS copy of the K, misaAk; in the TA, masaAk) [which are inserted] in the two sides of a piece of cloth when its manufacture is commenced. (M, L, TT, K.) ― -b10- Also, the pl., The threads which compose the warp of a web. (K.)

madiydN *
Drawn, or pulled: strained: stretched: lengthened: i. q. ↓ mamoduwdN. (L, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Tall: long: (L, K:) fem. with p: (L:) and pl. mududN, (L, K,) which preserves its original form [instead of becoming mud~N] because it does not resemble a verb. (Sb, L.) ― -b3- madiydu AlqaAmapi, (S, L,) and Aljisomi (L,) (tropical:) A man tall of stature, (S, L,) and, of body. (L.) ― -b4- qad~N madiydN (tropical:) A tall stature. (A.) ― -b5- ↓ fiY EamadK mumad~adapK, in the Kur, [civ., last verse,] is explained by Th as signifying (tropical:) Upon tall pillars. (L.) ― -b6- A^aqamotu mud~apF madiydapF (tropical:) I remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, a long space of time. (A.) ― -b7- Almadiydu The second metre (baHor) in prosody: (L, K:) so called because of the extension of its A^asobaAb and A^awotaAd.
