mariysiy~apN * [in the modern Egyptian dial. mariysiY] The south wind, that comes from the direction of mariysN, which, says AHn, is the lowest part of the country of the Nubians, next to the district of A^usowaAn. (M.)

faHolN mar~aAsN *
A strong stallion: (K:) or a stallion strong, or vehement in labour or exertion. (M, Sgh.) ― -b2- layolapN mar~aAsapN (tropical:) A night's journey in which is no remissness or languor; (M;) i. e., (M,) a hard and fatiguing and long night's journey. (IAar, M, K.)

maArasotaAnN *
A hospital for the sick: and arabicized word [from the Persian]: (Yaakoob, S, K:) originally biymaArisotaAno: (Yaakoob, TA.)
A^amorasu * [an imitative sequent and corroborative of A^axorasu, as is shown in the M, art. mrs, see A^axorasu.]

mutamar~asN * [originally A place where one rubs or scratches himself against a thing. Hence, app., the saying,] ― -b2- maA bifulaAnK mutamar~asN (tropical:) [Nothing can be done with, or got from, such a one]: said of him from whom the enemy can obtain no advantage: (A:) or of him who is hardy and strong, so that he who strives with him cannot withstand him, because he has striven against calamities and contentions: (TA:) and of the avaricious man, from whom he who is in want cannot obtain anything. (A, TA.)

1 mariDa * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
maraDa , inf. n. maraDN and maroDN, (Msb, K,) which latter is a dial. form rarely used, (Msb,) He (a man, S, or an animal [of any kind], Msb) was, or became, [diseased, disordered, distempered, sick, or ill; i. e.] in the state termed maraDN (S, Msb, K) denoting that change of the constitution or temperament which is described in the explanation of this term below; (K;) as also ↓ AmrD, expl. by SaAra *aA maraDK. (K, TA; but not in the CK.) ― -b2- [Hence, mariDati AlEayonu (tropical:) The eye became languid; or languishing; or weak: (see mariyDN:) or, as Golius says, on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof, was weak from much, and too much, looking.] ― -b3- And mariDati All~ayolapu (tropical:) The night became dark. (Th, O.) ― -b4- [The verb probably has several other tropical significations agreeable with explanations of maraDN and mariyDN which will be found below.]

2 mr~Dhu * , (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. tamoriyDN, (S, Msb, K,) He took care of him in his sickness; (Sb, S, Mgh;) and treated him medically, to remove his disease; the measure faE~ala in this instance having a privative quality, though its quality is in most instances confirmative: (Sb:) or he took good care of him, namely a sick person: (K:) or he undertook, or managed, or superintended, the medical treatment of him. (Msb.) -A2- mr~D fiY AlA^amori, (IDrd, A,) [and mar~aDahu, (O, K voce DahoyaA^a,)] inf. n. as above, (S, K,) (tropical:) He fell short of doing what he ought to have done, or was remiss, in, or with respect to, the affair: (S, A:) or he did not exert himself to the full, or to the utmost, or beyond what is usual, in it: (IDrd:) or he did it weakly, or feebly, (K, * TA,) not firmly or soundly: (TA:) as also fiyhi ↓ mArD. (TA.) [See also 5.] And mr~D fulaAnN fiY HaAjatiY (tropical:) Such a one was deficient in activity in accomplishing my want. (TA.) And mr~D fiY kalaAmihi (tropical:) He was weak in his speech. (IDrd.) ― -b2- [HakaAhu biSiygapi Alt~amoriyDi, probably a post-classical phrase, signifies (assumed tropical:) He mentioned it, or related it, in a manner implying that it was doubtful, or was a mere assertion; as when the word qiyla is used.]
3 mArD fiY AlA^amori * : see 2. ― -b2- maAraDotu raA^oyiY fiyka (tropical:) I deceived myself, or endeavoured to deceive myself, respecting thee. (A, TA.)

4 AmrD * : see 1. ― -b2- He had a bane, or murrain, (Yaakoob, S,) or a disease, or distemper, (A, TA,) in his beasts, (Yaakoob, S, A,) or camels. (TA.) -A2- AmrDhu He (God, S, Msb) rendered him mariyD [or diseased, &c.]. (Sb, S, * Msb, K.) You say also, A^akala maA lamo yuwaAfiqohu faA^amoraDahu (A, TA) [He ate what did not agree with him, and] it caused him to fall into AlmaraD [or disease, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A_imoraADu AlA^jofaAni (S, voce A_isojaAdN) (tropical:) The lowering of the eyelids [in a languid, or languishing, manner: see mariyDN]. (TK, voce A_isojaAdN.) ― -b3- AmrDhu also signifies He found him to be mariyD [or diseased, &c.]. (K.) -A3- Also AmrD (assumed tropical:) He was near to being right in opinion, (S, L, K, *) though not altogether right. (L.) In the K, this signification is wrongly assigned to AmrDhu. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely El-Ukeyshir El-Asadee, praising 'Abd-el-Melik Ibn-Marwán, (TA.)
wal`kino taHota *aAka Al$~ayobi HazomN
A_i*aA maA Zan~a A^amoraDa A^awo A^aSaAbaA
[But beneath that hoariness is good judgment: when he forms an opinion, he is nearly right, or he is right]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Also, AmrDhu fulaAnN (tropical:) Such a one was near to attaining the object of his [another's] want. (A, TA.)

5 tmr~D * (tropical:) He was weak, or feeble, in his affair. (A, * K, TA.) [It seems to be indicated in the A that ↓ tmArD also has this signification; like as mArD in nearly the same sense is syn. with mr~D, q. v.: or perhaps tmArD signifies (tropical:) he feigned, or made a false show of, weakness, or feebleness, in his affair: it is said, in the A, to be used tropically as well as properly.]

6 tmArD *
He feigned, or made a false show of, maraD [or disease, &c.] in himself. (S, A. *) ― -b2- See also 5.
maroDN * : see 1: and see what here next follows, in six places.

maraDN * (IDrd, S, O, Msb, K) and ↓ maroDN: (Msb, K:) see 1: i. q. suqomN [Disease, disorder, distemper, sickness, illness, or malady]; (IDrd, S;) which is the contr. of SiH~apN; and affects man and the camel [&c.]: (IDrd:) or a certain state foreign to the constitution or temperament, injurious to the intellect; whence it is known that pains and tumours are accidents arising therefrom: or, as IF says, that whereby a man passes beyond the limit of health or soundness or perfection or rectitude, whether it be disease (Eil~ap),
or (assumed tropical:) hypocrisy, or (assumed tropical:) a falling short of doing what he ought to do in an affair: (Msb:) or a dark and disordered state of the constitution or temperament, after a clear and right state thereof: (O, K:) or ↓ maroDN is (assumed tropical:) [a disease] of the heart: (K:) Aboo-Is-hák says, maraDN and suqomN are said to be in the body and (assumed tropical:) in religion, like as SiH~apN is said to be in the body and in religion; and ↓ maroDN is in the heart, applying to (assumed tropical:) everything whereby a man quits a state of soundness or perfection or rectitude in religion: (TA:) and As says, I recited to Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà [the words of the Kur, ii. 9, &c.,] fiY quluwbihimo maraDN and he said to me ↓ “ maroDN, O boy ”: (AHát, IDrd, Msb:) and maraDN, or this and ↓ maroDN also, signifies (assumed tropical:) doubt: and (assumed tropical:) hypocrisy: (K:) and (assumed tropical:) weakness of belief: (TA:) and the former, (TA,) or ↓ both, (K,) (assumed tropical:) languor, or languidness, or weakness: (K:) and (assumed tropical:) darkness (IAar, K) in the heart: (IAar:) and (assumed tropical:) defectiveness; deficiency; or imperfection; (IAar, K;) which last is said by IAar to be the primary signification: (TA:) or maraDN in the body is a languor, or languidness, or weakness, of the limbs, or members: and in the eye, (assumed tropical:) weakness of sight: and in the heart, (assumed tropical:) a flagging, or remissness, in respect of the truth: (Ibn-'Arafeh:) or it properly signifies an accidental affection of the body, which puts it out of the right state proper to it, and necessarily occasions interruption, or infirmity, in its actions: and tropically, (tropical:) affections of the mind, which interrupt, or mar, its integrity; such as (tropical:) ignorance; and (tropical:) evil belief; and (tropical:) envy; and (tropical:) malevolence, or malice; and (tropical:) love of acts of disobedience; for these prevent from the attaining of excellences, or lead to the cessation of true eternal life: (Bd, ii. 9:) it is a gen. n.: (IDrd:) and the n. un. is ↓ maroDapN: (A, TA:) it is one of the inf. ns. which have pls., like $ugolN and EaqolN; the pls. of these three being A^amoraADN and A^a$ogaAlN and EuquwlN. (Sb.) fiY qulowbihimo maraDN, in the Kur, [ii. 9, &c.,] means (assumed tropical:) In their hearts is doubt: (AO:) or (assumed tropical:) doubt and hypocrisy. (TA.) And Al~a*iY fiY qalobihi maraDN, in the same, [xxxiii. 32,] (assumed tropical:) In whose heart is darkness: or (assumed tropical:) flagging, or remissness, in respect of what is commanded and what is forbidden: or (assumed tropical:) love of adultery or fornication: (TA:) or hypocrisy. (A.)
mariDN * : see mariyDN.
maroDapN * [A single disease, &c.]: see maraDN, near the end of the paragraph.

muraADN *
A disease [or blight or the like] which affects fruits, and destroys them. (K.)

mariyDN * [Diseased; disordered; distempered; sick; or ill;] in the state termed maraDN (Msb, K) denoting that change of the constitution or temperament which is described in the explanation of the latter word above; (K;) as also ↓ mariDN (K,) and ↓ maAriDN, (IB, Msb, K,) the first [and second] being from the verb of which the inf. n. is maraDN, and the third from that of which the inf. n. is maroDN, (Msb,) and ↓ mamoruwDN, and ↓ mutamar~iDN: (TA:) or, applied to a body, it signifies deficient in strength: (IAar:) pl. miraADN (A, K, TA:) and maroDaY (IDrd, Msb, K) and maraADaY (IDrd, K) and muraDaA='u; (TA;) or miraADN may be pl. of maAriDN (TA) [or of mariDN]. Accord. to Lh, you say, Eudo fulaAnN faA_in~ahu mariyDN [Visit thou such a one, for he is sick]: and laA taA^okulo h`*aA A_ino A^akalotahu ↓ AlT~aEaAma faA_in~aka maAriDN meaning tamoraDu [i. e. Eat not thou this food, for thou wilt be sick if thou eat it]. (TA.) [mariyDN has also several tropical significations.] You say also, EayonN mariyDapN (tropical:) An eye in which is languor, or languidness, or weakness: (S, TA:) pl. A^aEoyanN miraADN, and maroDaY. (A, TA.) And A_imoraA^apN mariyDapu AlA^aloHaAZi and mryDpu Aln~aZari (assumed tropical:) A woman weak in sight. (IDrd.) And qalobN mariyDN (assumed tropical:) A heart deficient in religion. [IAar.) And $amosN mariyDapN (tropical:) A sun having a feeble light; (A, K; *) not clear, (S, TA,) and not beautiful. (TA.) And A^aroDN mariyDapN (tropical:) A land in which are frequent seditions, or factions, or conflicts, or dissensions, (A, TA,) and wars, (A,) and slaughters: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) in a weak condition: (K:) or straitened with its inhabitants: or (assumed tropical:) in which the wind is still, and the heat intense: or that causes disease; meaning (assumed tropical:) corrupt in its air. (TA.) And riyHN mariyDapN (A, K) (tropical:) A weak wind: (K:) or (tropical:) a still wind: or (tropical:) a wind intensely hot, and blowing feebly. (TA.) And layolapN mariyDapN (tropical:) A night in which no star shines; (A;) in which the sky is clouded, so that there is no light. (TA.) And raA^oYN mariyDN (A, TA) (tropical:) An opinion deviating from what is right. (TA.)
maAriDN * : see mariyDN, in two places.

mumoriDN * A man having diseased camels: so in the following trad.: laA yuwridu mumoriDN EalaY muSiH~K [One having diseased camels shall not bring them to water immediately after one whose camels are in a healthy state]: the prohibition being not because of the transition of disease by contagion; but because sometimes disease may befall the healthy beasts, and it may come into the mind of the owner that that is from contagion. (TA.) [See also muSiH~N.]
mimoraADN * A man frequently diseased or sick. (S, K.)
mamoruwDN * see mariyDN.
mutamar~iDN * : see mariyDN. ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) A man weak, or feeble, in his affair. (TA.)

1 mariTa * , aor.
maraTa , (K,) inf. n. maraTN, (S, Mgh,) He (a man, S) had little, scanty, or thin, hair upon the sides of his face, or of his cheeks; (S;) or upon his body, and eyebrow, and eye, in consequence of a weakness of this last, and of frequent shedding of tears: (K, TA:) or most of his hair fell off. (Mgh.) [See also mrt and mrd]. -A2- maraTa, aor.
maruTa , (S,) inf. n. maroTN, (K,) He plucked out hair (S, K,) as also ↓ mr~T, (K,) inf. n. tamoriyTN, (TA,) and feathers, and wool, from the body. (TA.)
2 mar~aTa see 1: ― -b2- and 8. -A2- mr~T Alv~awoba, inf. n. tamoriyTN, He shortened the sleeves of the garment, and made it into a miroT. (K.)
3 mArThu * , (K,) inf. n. mumaAraTapN and miraATN, (TA,) He plucked out his hair, and scratched him with his nails. (K.)

4 AmrT Al$~aEaru *
The hair attained to the time at which it should be plucked out; it was time for it to be plucked out. (S, K.) ― -b2- AmrTt Aln~axolapu (assumed tropical:) The palm-tree dropped, or let fall, its ripe dates (Jm, K) in a juicy, or sappy, state. (Jm.) -A2- AmrTt Aln~Aqapu waladahaA The she-camel cast her fœtus in an imperfect state, with no hair upon it. (IDrd.)

5 tmr~T Al$~aEaru * , (S, K,) quasi-pass. of mar~aTahu, (TA,) The hair fell off by degrees; became scattered; (S, * K;) as also ↓ A_im~araTa, of the measure A_ifotaEala, [originally AmtrT,] (K,) or, [rather,] as in the TS, of the measure A_inofaEala, [originally A_inomaraTa,] quasi-pass. of maraTahu. (TA.) [In like manner] you say also, tmr~Tt A^awobaAru AlA_ibili The fur of the camels became scattered. (TA.) And qu*a*u Als~ahomi ↓ A_im~araTato The feathers of the arrow fell off. (TA, from a trad.) And tmr~T Al*~iy^obu The hair of the wolf fell off until little thereof remained upon him. (TA.) [See also mariTa.]
7 A_im~araTa * [said in the TS to be of the measure AnfEl]: see 5, in two places.

8 AmtrThu *
He seized it, took it hastily, or snatched it unawares, (K, TA,) from his hand: (TA:) or he collected it together, (K, TA,) namely, a thing that he had found; as also ↓ mr~Thu. (TA.) -A2- A_im~araTa [said in the K to be of the measure AftEl]: see 5, in two places.

miroTN *
A [garment of the kind called] kisaA=', of wool, or of xaz~ [q. v.], (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) or of linen, (TA,) and (tropical:) of hair-cloth, being
tropically applied to one of this last description in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, (MF,) used as an A_izaAr, [i. e. a waist-wrapper,] (S, Mgh, Msb,) in former times, (S,) and sometimes a woman throws it over her head, (Mgh,) and wraps herself in it: (Mgh, Msb:) or a green [perhaps meaning gray as is often the case] garment: or any garment that is not sewed: (TA:) [see 2:) pl. muruwTN. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.)
muruTN * : see A^amoraTu, in two places.
miroTaAwaAni * : see murayoTaA='u.
miraATN * : see A^amoraTu.
mariyTN * : see A^amoraTu.

muraATapN *
What falls, of hair, when it is plucked out; (S, K; *) or when it is combed: (K, * TA:) or what is plucked out from the arm-pit. (Lh.)
murayoTaY * The uvula. (Hr, K.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

murayoTaA='u * ; so accord. to As (S, TA) and AO; accord. to El-Ahmar, ↓ murayoTaY; but As disputed this with him, and overcame him; (TA;) [dim. of maroTaA='u, fem. of A^amoraTu;] only used in the dim. form; (TA;) or it has the form of the dim. of maroTaA='u: (Mgh:) The part between the navel and the pubes: (As, S, Mgh, K:) or between the breast and the pubes: (Lth, K:) or a thin skin between the navel and the pubes, (IDrd, K, *) on the right and left, where the hair is plucked out, extending to the groins; (IDrd;) as also ↓ murayoTaY: (TA:) or a thin skin in the belly: (Mgh:) or [the dual] murayoTaAwaAni signifies the two sides of the pubes of a man, which have no hair upon them: (Mgh, TA; *) or the sing., (accord. to the K,) or the dual, (accord. to the TA,) two veins (K, TA) in the soft parts of the belly, (TA,) upon which he who cries out vehemently bears: (K, TA:) and (the dual, accord. to the TA) the bare part of the lower lip, over which is the sabalap (K, TA) next the nose: (TA:) and (the dual again, accord. to the TA) the parts on either side of the tuft of hair between the lower lip and the chin; as also ↓ miroTaAwaAni, with kesr. (K.) ― -b2- The arm-pit. (K.) -A2- A thing with which one ties, binds, or makes fast. (Hr, TA.)
maAriT * : see A^amoraATu, in two places.

A^amoraTu * A man having little, or scanty, or thin, hair upon the sides of his face, or of his cheeks; (S;) or upon his body, and eyebrow, and eye, in consequence of a weakness of this last, and of frequent shedding of tears; (K, TA;) [in the CK, the word $Er is omitted in this explanation;]) or upon his body and breast; when all the hair has gone, he is said to be A^amolaTu: (TA:) pl. muroTN and miraTapN; (K;) the former regular; the latter, extr., and thought by ISd to be a quasi-pl. n. (TA.) [The fem.] maroTaA='u signifies A woman having no hair upon her pubes and what is next to it. (IDrd.) You say also hiYa maroTaA='u AlHaAjibayoni She has little, or scanty, or thin, hair in the eyebrows: the mention of the eyebrows being indispensable. (TA.) And HaAjibN A^amoraT An eyebrow of which most of the hair has fallen off. (Mgh.) See also A^aToraTu. ― -b2- A wolf of which some of the hair has fallen off; (Az, TA;) or whose hair has been plucked out. (K.) ― -b3- And hence, as being likened thereto, (Az, TA,) (tropical:) A thief, or robber; (As, AA, T, S, K;) as also EumoruwTN. (As, T.) ― -b4- An arrow of which the feathers have fallen off: (S:) or an arrow having no feathers; (K;) as also ↓ mariyTN and ↓ miraATN (K) and ↓ maAriTN (L, TA) and ↓ muruTN, (S, K,) as in the phrase muruTu Alqi*aA*i, in a verse [cited voce maSonaEN, wrongly asserted to be] of Lebeed, though we may read muroT, which is pl. of A^amoraTu, as this may be correctly applied as an epithet to the sing. because of the pl. which follows it: (S:) the pl. of ↓ mArT is mur~aTu and mawaAriTu; (L, TA;) and the pl. of ↓ muruTN is A^amoraATN [a pl. of pauc.] (K, TA) and miraATN. (S, K.) ― -b5- $ajarapN maroTaA='u (assumed tropical:) A tree having no leaves upon it. (TA.)

naxolapN mumoriTN *
A palm-tree dropping, or letting fall, its ripe dates (Jm, K) in a juicy, or sappy, state. (Jm.) And ↓ mimoraATN One that usually does so. (Jm, K.) -A2- naAqapN mumoriTN A she-camel casting her fœtus in an imperfect state, with no hair upon it. (Jm.) And ↓ mimoraATN One that usually does so. (Jm.) [See mumorijN.]
mimoraATN * : see mumoriTN, in two places.

div2.head: mrE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 maz~a * , [sec. pers. mazuzota aor.
mazu3a ,] inf. n. mazaAzapN, It had, or acquired, a taste between sweet and sour. (TA; but only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is there mentioned.) AZ also mentions, as heard from the Kilábees, the saying, qa*o maz~a $araAbukumo A^aqobaHa AlmazaAzapi, and Almuzuwzapi, as meaning, [Your beverage, or wine,] hath become very sour. (TA.) -A2- maz~ahu, (S, A, K,) aor.
mazu3a , (S,) inf. n. maz~N, (S, TA,) [and accord. to one copy of the S, mazaAzapN, but this I regard as a mistake of a copyist,] He sucked it; i. q. maS~ahu. (S, A, K.)
5 tamaz~a3a [He sipped:] see 10 in art. dbr.

R. Q. 1 mazomazahu * , (S, K,) inf. n. mazomazapN, (S,) He put him, or it, in motion, or into a state of commotion; or shook him, or it; (S, K;) and moved him, or it, forwards and backwards: (S, TA:) or he put him, or it, in violent motion, or into a state of violent commotion; or shook him, or it, violently: (Mgh, art. tr; and TA:) as, for instance, a drunken man, in order that he might recover from his intoxication. (S, * TA.) See also tarotarahu.

R. Q. 2 tamazomaza *
He ate, and drank, what had a taste between sweet and sour. (TA.) -A2- He, or it, was, or became, put in motion, or in a state of commotion, or shaken, (K, TA,) and moved forwards and backwards: or in violent motion, or into a state of violent commotion, or shaken violently. (TA.) ― -b2- tamazomaza liloqiyaAmi He raised himself, (K,) or put himself in motion, (TA,) to stand. (K, TA.)
maz~N * : see its fem. maz~apN.

muz~N * , applied to beverage, or wine, (S, K,) and to a pomegranate, (Lth, S, K,) Having a taste between sweet and sour: (Lth, S, K:) fem. with p. (A.) AZ mentions its signifying Very sour beverage or wine; as heard from the Kilábees. (TA.) You say also xamorapN muz~apN, meaning, Wine, or a wine in which is a taste between sweet and sour; said to be from mixing unripe and ripe dates [in making it]: (TA:) or wine in which is a sour taste, (S, K,) and in which is no goodness. (S.) See also maz~apN.

qahowapN maz~apN *
Wine having a pleasant, delicious, or sweet, taste: (S, K, * TA:) so called because it bites, or burns, the tongue; (S, TA;) as also ↓ muz~N, (K, TA,) which, however, is [not an epithet but] a subst.: (TA:) or the former signifies l*y*p AlmqTE [app. meaning having a pleasant sharpness, or acidity]: (so in the L, TA:) J says, that one should not say ↓ miz~apN, but this form is said to occur in one relation of a verse or El-Aashà. (TA.) See also muz~N. -A2- Also maz~apN A single suck or sucking. (S, A, K.) It is said in a trad. laA tuHar~imu Almaz~apu walaA Almz~ataAni [The sucking once will not render marriage unlawful, nor will the two suckings], meaning, in drawing milk from the breast. (S.) [See a similar saying voce EayofapN.]
miz~apN * : see maz~apN.

1 mazaja * , (S, K,) aor.
mazuja , (L Msb,) [not
mazaja , as in the lexicons of Golius and Freytag,] inf. n. mazojN, (K, &c.,) He mixed, mingled, incorporated, or blended, (S, K,) a thing with (bi) water; (Msb;) or beverage, or wine, ($araAb,) with
something else. (S.) ― -b2- mazaja (tropical:) He exasperated, or irritated. (K.) mazajotuhu EalaY SaAHibihi I enraged him, and exasperated him, or irritated him, against his companion. (A.)

2 mz~j * , inf. n. tamoziyjN, He gave. (K.) Ex. mz~j Als~aAy^ila He gave the beggar something. (ISh.) -A2- mz~j, inf. n. tamoziyjN, It (an ear of corn, K, and a grape, TA,) became changed in colour from green to yellow. (T, K.)

3 mAzjhu * , inf. n. mumaAzajapN, It mixed, mingled, commingled, intermixed, intermingled, or became incorporated or blended, with it; as some does with water. (TA.) -A2- mAzjhu, (tropical:) He contended with him, or disputed with him, for glory, or honour, or glorious or honourable qualities, and the like. (K.)
8 tmAzxA * and ↓ AmtzjA They two mixed, or mingled, or became mixed or mingled, each with the other. (TA.)

8 Amtzj *
It was, or became, mixed with (bi) another thing. (TA.) See 6.

$araAbN mazojN *
i. q. ↓ mamozuwjN, Mixed mine, or beverage. (TA.) ― -b2- See mizojN.

mizoju $aYo'K * , and ↓ mizaAjuhu, What is mixed, or mingled, with a thing; its admixture. (TA.) ― -b2- Al$~araAbi ↓ mizaAju What is mixed with mine, or a beverage. (S, K.) Alxamori kaAfuwrN ↓ mizaAju [see Kur, lxxvi., 5,] The odour, not the taste, of the wine is [like] camphor. (TA.) ― -b3- Albadani ↓ mizaAju [The constitution, or temperament, of the body;] the aggregate natural constituents (TabaAy^iEu) with which the body is composed; (S, K;) i. e. the four humours of the body; namely, black bile [Als~awodaA='u], yellow bile [AlS~aforaA='u], (Almir~ataAni), phlegm (Albalogamu), and blood (Ald~amu). (TA) Pl. A^amozijapN. (Msb.) You say, ↓ huwa SaHiyHu AlmizaAji, and faAsiduhu, He is of sound, and of unsound, constitution, or temperament: meaning the humours of the body. And A^amozijapu Aln~isaA='i muxotalifapN The constitutions, or temperaments, of women are discordant, or various. (A.) ― -b4- mizojN (As, K, &c.) and ↓ mazojN, (Az, S, &c.,) or the latter is erroneous, or a word of weak authority, (K,) Honey: (S, K:) or honey in the comb; syn. $ahodN: (T:) so called because every sweet beverage is mixed with it. (AHn.) ― -b5- Also, Water with which wine is mixed. (TA.) ― -b6- mizojN The bitter almond; as also ↓ maziyjN: see lawozN (K:) but IDrd doubts of its correctness; and it is said to be correctly munoj [which is Persian]. (TA.)
mizaAjN * : see mizojN.

mawozajN *
A boot, (K,) worn by women: (A:) an arabicized word, (S, K,) from the Persian muwzaho: (S:) pl. mawaAzijapN (because it is a foreign word, S) and mawaAziju. (S, K.)
maziyjN * : see mizojN.
rajulN maz~aAjN * , and ↓ mumaz~ijN; A man who continues not of one disposition, or temper, but varies in disposition, or temper: or a liar, who confounds, or confuses, things. (IAar.)
mamozuwjN * : see mazojN.
mumaz~ijN * : see maz~aAjN.
TaboEu EuTaArida mutamaz~ijN * [The nature of the planet Mercury is various]. (A.)

1 mazaHa * , aor.
mazaHa , inf. n. mazoHN, (S, K,) and quasiinf. n. muzaAHN and muzAHapN, (K,) [the latter like its syn. duEaAbapN,] but Fei says that this last is mazaAHapN, (TA,) [and he mentions it as an inf. n.,] He jested or joked; (S, Msb, K;) contr. of jad~a [which signifies “ he was serious, or in earnest ” ”]: (M:) or he talked or behaved in a free and easy manner, with the view of blandishing and conciliating, without annoying; so that it excludes the meaning of mocking or ridiculing or deriding. (MF.)
3 mAzHhu * , inf. n. mizaAHN (S, K) and mumaAzaHapN, (K,) He jested, or joked, with him. (S, K.)

6 tamaAzaHaA *
They two jested, or joked, one with the other. (S, K.)

mazoHapN *
A jest, or joke; a single act of jesting, or joking. (Msb.)
muzaAHN * and muzaAHapN, substs., A jesting, or joking. (S, K.) [See 1.]

rajulN maz~aAHN *
A man who is a great jester, or joker. (A.)
1 mazada * , &c.: see art. mSd.

mizorN *
A certain kind of beverage, (S, Mgh,) or nby*, (A, K,) made of *urap [a kind of millet]: (A, Mgh, K:) [it is now called in Egypt and Nubia buwzha and buwZh: see De Sacy's “ Abdallatif, ” pp. 324 and 572; and my “ Modern Egyptians, ” vol. i. ch. iii.:] and of barley: (Mgh, K:) or of wheat: (Mgh:) and of [other] grains: (TA:) A'Obeyd mentions that the Ibn- 'Omar explains the various kinds of nabiy* thus: bitoEN is nby* of honey: and jiEapN is nby* of barley: and mizorN, of *urap: and sakarN, of dried dates: and xamorN, of grapes: and sukurokapN is the wine of the Abyssinians; Aboo-Moosà El-Ash'aree says that it is of *urap, and it is also called suquroqaEN, app. arabicized from sukurokap, which is Abyssinian: (S:) mizorN and sukurokahN are the same. ― -b2- See Supplement.

div2.head: mzE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 mas~ahu * , (A, Mgh,) first pers. masisotuhu, (S, M, Msb, K,) for which they sometimes say misotuhu, rejecting the first s, (Sb, * S, M, * K,) and transferring the kesreh thereof to the m (Sb, * S, M, *) contr. to general rule, (Sb, M,) and some do not transfer the kesreh, but leave the m with its fethah, [saying masotuhu,] like Zilotumo and Zalotumo for Zalilotumo, an irregular contraction, (S,) aor. yamas~uhu, (S, Msb, K,) [and yamosasohu when mejzoom, accord. to rule,] inf. n. mas~N (S, M, A, Msb, K) and masiysN, (S, * M, A, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) and mis~iysaY; (S, * K;) and [mas~ahu,] first pers. masasotuhu; aor. yamus~uhu, (AO, S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. mas~N; (Msb;) the former of which two verbs is the more chaste; (S, TA;) He touched it, or felt it, [generally the former,] syn. lamasahu, (M, A, K,) with his hand: (TA: as from the K [but wanting in a MS copy of the K and in the CK:]) or he put his hand to it without the intervention of anything: (Msb:) or mas~N is like lamosN; excepting that the latter is [sometimes] used to signify the seeking for [or feeling for] a thing, even though it be not found; whereas the former is [only] said of that [action] with which is perception by the sense of lms: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [see also lamasahu:] and [in like manner you say,] maAs~a Al$~aYo'u Al$~aYo'a, inf. n. mumaAs~apN and misaAsN, (M, A, *) meaning, the thing met [or touched] the thing with its substance. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] mas~ahaA, (M, A, Msb,) first pers. masisotuhaA, aor. yamas~uhaA, (Msb,) inf. n. mas~N and masiysN, (Mgh, Msb,) (tropical:) Inivit eam; scil. mulierem; (M, A, Msb;) as also ↓ maAs~ahaA, (M, A, Msb,) inf. n. mumaAs~apN (S, Msb) and misaAsN: (Msb:) the former is used in this sense in several places in the Kur, and is said by some to be preferable to the latter: (TA:) and tamaAs~N is also used metonymically for [the coming together, in the sense of] mubaADaEapN, as well as mumaAs~apN. (S.) ― -b3- mas~a AlmaA='u Aljasada, inf. n. mas~N, (tropical:) The water wetted the body. (Msb.) ― -b4- mas~a also signifies (tropical:) He, or it, struck, or smote; because striking, or smiting, like touching, is with the hand. (TA.) You say, mas~ahu
biAls~awoTi (tropical:) He struck him with the whip]. (A.) ― -b5- And it is said of anything annoying or hurtful that befals a man. Thus in the Kur, [ii. 74, and iii. 23,] lano tamas~anaA Aln~aAru (tropical:) [The fire of hell will not smite us; or here it may be rendered touch us]. And [ii. 210,] mas~atohumu AlbaA^osaA='u [Distress, or misfortune, smote, or afflicted, or befell, them]. And in other instances; all which are similar to the saying in the same, *uwquwA mas~a saqara. (TA.) [See mas~N below.] You say also, mas~ahu AlmaraDu (tropical:) [Sickness smote him, or befell him]: and mas~ahu AlEa*aAbu (tropical:) [Punishment befell him]: and mas~ahu Alkibaru (tropical:) [Old age came upon him]. (A.) And mas~atohu Aljin~u (tropical:) [lit. The jinn, or genii touched him; meaning, affected him with madness, or insanity]: (TA:) [whence,] mus~a, [in the TA, mus~a bihi, app. meaning, from what immediately precedes, mus~a biAljunuwni, inf. n. mas~N,] He was, or became, [touched with madness, or insanity: or] mad, or insane: (K:) as though the jinn had touched him. (TA.) And mas~ahu biEa*aAbK (tropical:) He punished him. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b6- [Hence, app.,] mas~ato A_ilayohi AlHaAjapu, (S, K,) inf. n. [mas~N and] masiysN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) [which seems to signify either The want of him, or it, was difficult of accomplishment, or distressing; or the want was difficult of accomplishment, or distressing, to him]. (S, K,. [In both these lexicons, the meaning is left to be inferred only from the fact that this phrase immediately follows the explanation of HaAjapN maAs~apN, q. v.]) ― -b7- [mas~a is also said of what is good, as well as of what is evil; as in the following instance:] mas~atohu mawaAs~u Alxayori waAl$~ar~i (tropical:) [The haps of good fortune, and of evil,] happened to him, or betided him. (TA.) ― -b8- [As touching implies proximity,] mas~ato bika raHimu fulaAnK signifies (tropical:) The relationship of such a one is near to you. (S, K, * TA.) ― -b9- And as mas~a originally signifies “ he touched or felt with the hand, ” it is used metaphorically as meaning (tropical:) He took a thing; as, for instance, (in a trad.,) water from a miyDaA^ap. (TA.) -A2- mas~a is made doubly trans. by means of the prep. bi prefixed to the second objective complement. (Msb.) See 4, in two places.
3 maAosa3a see 1, in two places: and see laA masaAsi.

4 A_ms~hu Al$~aYo'a *
He made him, or caused him, to touch the thing: (S, * IJ, M, A: *) he enabled him to touch it. (Mgh.) ― -b2- A^amas~a Aljasada maA='F, and Aljasada bimaA='K ↓ mas~a, (tropical:) He wetted the body with water; or caused water to wet the body. (Msb.) And A^amas~a wajohahu AlT~iyba (tropical:) He smeared his face with the perfume. (Mgh.) And A^amas~atohu EaAriDayohaA, and biEaAriDayohaA ↓ mas~atohu, (tropical:) She smeared the sides of her cheeks with it; namely, perfume. (Mgh.) ― -b3- A^amas~ahu $akowaY (tropical:) He made a complaint to him. (M, TA.)

6 tmAs~A *
They (two bodies) touched each other; were, or became, in contact. (M, A, * K, *) ― -b2- Hence, (K,) (tropical:) They two came together in the way of mubaADaEap: (S, Msb, * K: *) in this sense the verb is used in the Kur, lviii. 4 and 5. (S, TA.) See also mas~ahaA.

mas~N * : see 1. ― -b2- It is used to denote [the first sensible effect of] anything annoying or hurtful that befalls a man. (TA.) Thus in the Kur, [liv. 48,] (TA,) *uwquwA mas~a saqara (tropical:) Taste ye the first effect upon you of the fire of hell: (K, TA:) or the stroke thereof: (Jel:) or the heat and pain thereof. (Bd.) In like manner you say, (K,) wajada mas~a AlHum~aY (M, K) (tropical:) He felt the commencement, or first touch, [or access,] of fever, before its taking him forcibly, and becoming apparent. (M, L.) And lamo yajido mas~FA mina Aln~aSabi (tropical:) He did not feel the first sensation of fatigue. (TA, from a trad.) [And hence,] bihi mas~N mina Aljunuwni (tropical:) [In him is a touch, or stroke, of madness, or insanity, or diabolical possession]: (S, TA:) and mas~N, alone, signifies madness, or insanity, or diabolical possession: (M, A, * Mgh, K:) as in the Kur, ii. 276: (TA:) and you say bihi mas~N in him is madness, &c.: (A, * Mgh:) for they assert that the devil touches one and his intellect in consequence becomes confused. (Mgh.) ― -b3- You say also, huwa Hasanu Almas~i fiY maAlihi (tropical:) He has the impress of a good state, or condition, in his camels, or sheep, or goats: and raA^ayotu lahu mas~FA fiY maAlihi (tropical:) I saw him to have an impress of a good state, or condition, in his camels, &c.: like as you say A_iSobaEFA. (A, TA.)

laA masaAsi * , (S, M, K,) like qaTaAmi, (S, K,) indecl., with kesr for its termination, because altered from the inf. n. mas~N, (S,) signifies [properly There shall be no touching: or] touch not thou: (K:) or touch not thou me: (M:) and some read thus in the Kur, [xx. 97:] (M, K:) it is a saying of the Arabs: (S:) and sometimes one says masaAsi [alone], in the sense of an imperative, [affirmatively,] like daraAki and nazaAli: (K:) but ↓ laA misaAsa, in the Kur, [ubi supra,] (S, M, K,) accord. to the reading of others, (M,) signifies There shall be no mutual touching: (M:) or I will not touch nor will I be touched. (S, K.)
laA misaAsa * : see laA masaAsi.

masuwsN * (tropical:) Water that is reached by the hands; or taken with the extended hands: (M, K, * TA:) in the K, naAlatohu is put by mistake for tanaAwalatohu [which is the reading in the M]: (TA:) accord. to which explanation, it has the signification of a pass. part. n.: (M:) or, [in the K and,] (tropical:) wholesome water, (A, TA,) that removes thirst, or the heat of thirst, as soon as it touches it: (M, A, * K, * TA:) accord. to which explanation, it has the signification of an act. part. n.: (M:) and (assumed tropical:) anything that cures thirst, or the heat of thirst: (IAar, K:) or, [in the K, and,] (assumed tropical:) water between sweet and salt: (S, K:) or, [in the K and,] (assumed tropical:) sweet and clear water: (As, K:) and (assumed tropical:) salt, or bitter and thick and undrinkable, water, that burns everything by its saltness. (M.) You say also riyqapN masuwsN (tropical:) Some saliva that takes away thirst. (IAar, M.) And kalaA^N masuwsN (assumed tropical:) Herbage that has a fattening and beneficial effect upon the animals that pasture on it. (AHn, M.) ― -b2- Also, i. q. faAdozahorN [The bezoar-stone]: (K:) or tiroyaAqN [an antidote against poison]: (M:) or both these words by which it is explained mean the same thing. (TA.)
mas~aAsapN * : see maAs~ahN.

HaAjapN maAs~apN * (assumed tropical:) A want difficult of accomplishment; or pressing; syn. muhimopN. (S, K.) ― -b2- raHimN maAs~apN (tropical:) Near relationship; (S, M, A, * K;) as also ↓ mas~aAsapN. (TA.) ― -b3- [Also, as a subst., sing. of mawaAs~N, of which an ex. has been given above, (see 1,) signifying Haps of good fortune, and of evil.]
mamosuwsN * A man in whom is a touch, or stroke, (mas~N,) of madness, insanity, or diabolical possession: (S, TA:) or mad, insane, or possessed by a devil. (AA, M, A, Mgh, K.)

1 masaA^a AlT~ariyqa *
He went along the middle of the road; (K;) or the hard and elevated part (maton) of the road. (TA.) ― -b2- masaA^a He was slow, or tardy. (K.) ― -b3- masaA^a Haq~ahu He delayed giving him his due. (K, TA.) ― -b4- masaA^a Alqidora He stilled, or allayed, the boiling of the pot. (K.) ― -b5- masaA^ahu biAlqawoli He soothed, or softened, him by words. (K.) ― -b6- masaA^a He beguiled, or deceived. (K.) ― -b7- masaA^a EalaY $aYo'K, (K,) inf. n. maso'N, (TA,) He became accustomed, or inured to a thing. (K.) -A2- masaA^a bayonahumo and ↓ AmsA^, He excited discord between them. (K, TA.) ― -b2- masaA^a, (S, K,) aor.
masaAa , (K,) inf. n. maso'N (S, K) and musuw'N, (K,) He was hard, or impudent, and rude; not caring for what one said, or did to him. (AZ, S, K.)
4 A^amosaAa see 1.

5 tms~A^ *
It (a garment) rent, or became ragged and worn out. (IB, K.)
maso'N * The middle of a road. (K.) [See 1, and see misoHN.]

maAsiy^N *
Hard, or impudent, and rude; not caring for what one says or does to him. (AZ, S.) Perhaps maAsK is from this: (see art. msY:) or perhaps it is formed by transposition from maAy^isN: see art. mys. (AM.)

1 masaHa $ayoy^FA * , aor.
masaHa , inf. n. masoHN; and ↓ ms~Hhu, inf. n tamosiyHN; He wiped a thing that was wet or dirty, with his hand, or passed his hand over it to remove the wet or dirt that was upon it: (L:) masoHN and tamosiyHN and ↓ tamas~uHN signifying the passing the hand over a thing that is flowing [with water or the like], or dirtied, soiled, or polluted, to remove the fluid or dirt, or soil or pollution; (L, K;) as when one wipes his head with his hand to remove water; and his forehead, to remove sweat. (L.) [It often signifies He stroked a thing with his hand; as, for instance, the Black Stone of the Kaabeh; see below.] ― -b2- masaHa raA^osahu mina AlmaA='i; and jabiynahu Alr~a$aHi; He wiped his head with his hand to remove the water that was upon it; and his forehead to remove the sweat. (L.) ― -b3- masaHa biraA^osihi (S) He wiped with his hand, or passed his hand closely over, his head, or a part thereof, without making any water to flow upon it: so in the Kur, v. 8; where it is said, faA@gosiluwA wujuwhakumo waA^ayodiyakumo A_ilaY A@lomaraAfiqi waA@mosaHuwA biruw^uwsikumo waA^arojulakumo A_ilaY A@lokaEobayoni: here A^arojulakumo is in the acc. case as an adjunct to Aydykm; [i.e., as a third objective complement to the verb AgslwA; not as an adjunct to rw^wskm;] but some read A^arojulikumo, putting it in the gen. case because of its proximity to rw^wskm; (Jel;) [in like manner as xaribK is put in the gen. case in the phrase h`*aA juHoru Dab~K xaribK, an ex. given by many of the grammarians, showing that this is allowable in prose,] notwithstanding that it is said, by Aboo-Is-hák the grammarian, that the putting a noun in the gen. case because of its proximity to a preceding noun in that case is not allowable except in poetry, when necessity requires it: (L:) the head, which is wiped, is mentioned between the arms and the feet, which are washed, to show the order which is to be observed in the purification. (Jel.) But masaHa signifies both he wiped with the hand, and also he washed: so says IAth: (L:) and AZ and IKt say the like: (Msb:) you say masaHotu yadaY~a bAlmaA='i, meaning I washed my hands with water. (AZ, Msb.) ― -b4- masaHa $ayoy^FA biAlmaA='i He wiped a thing with his hand wetted with water; passed his hand, wetted with water, over a thing. (Msb.) ― -b5- masaHa Albayot He compassed the House [of God, i.e. the Kaabeh: because he who does so passes his hand over the corner in which is the Black Stone]. (L.) ― -b6- masaHa A@ll~`hu Eanoka maA bika May God remove that which is in thee! (L;) or, wash and cleanse thee from thy sins! (TA, art. mSH.) A prayer for a sick person. (L, from a trad.) ― -b7- masaHahu He anointed him or it with oil. (A.) ― -b8- musiHa biAlkarami, inf. n. masoHN, (tropical:) He was characterized by somewhat, or by some sign or mark, of nobility. (L.) [See masoHapN.] ― -b9- masaHa, inf. n. masoHN, He combed and dressed hair; syn. ma$aTa. (K.) ― -b10- masoHu All~uHiYa [The stroking of the beards] was a sign of reconciliation. (S, O, in art. Eq: see Eaqu biAls~ahomi.) ― -b11- masaHahu, or masaHahu biAlmaEoruwfi, i. e. bAlmErwf mina Alqawoli, (L,) inf. n. masoHN; (L, K;) and ↓ ms~Hhu, (L,) inf. n. tamosiyHN; (L, K;) He spoke to him good words, deceiving, or beguiling, him therein, (L, K,) and giving him nothing. (L.) ― -b12- fulaAnN yamosaHu raA^osa zayodK (tropical:) Such a one beguiles, or deceives, Zeyd. (A.) [See also 3.] ― -b13- masaHa, inf. n. masoHN and tamosaAHN He lied; uttered what was false. (K.) ― -b14- masaHa fiY AlA^aroDi, inf. n. musuwHN, He set forth journeying through the land, or earth: (A'Obeyd, K: *) as also maSaHa. (TA.) ― -b15- masaHahumo (tropical:) He passed lightly by them, or brushed by them, without remaining by them. (L.) ― -b16- masiHa, [aor.
masaHa ,] inf. n. masaHN, The inner sides of his (a man's, S) thighs rubbed together, (S, L, K,) so as to become sore and chapped: (L:) or he had the inner side of his knee inflamed by the roughness of his garment. (L, K.) ― -b17- masaHa AlA_ibila, inf. n. masoHN (tropical:) He made the camels to journey all the day long: and he made the backs of the camels to be wounded by the saddles, and emaciated them; as also ↓ mas~aHahaA, inf. n. tamosiyHN: (K:) and in the latter sense you say masaHa Aln~aAqapa, and ↓ ms~HhA. (TA.) ― -b18- masaHati AlA_ibilu yawomahaA (tropical:) The camels journeyed all the day. (S.) masaHati AlA_ibilu AlA^aroDa yawomahaA daA^obFA (tropical:) The camels journeyed all the day laboriously. (TA.) -A2- masaHa, (S,) inf. n. masoHN (K) and misaAHapN, (S, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) (tropical:) He measured land. (S, K.) -A3- masaHa, inf. n. masoHN, (tropical:) He cut, or severed: and he struck, or smote: (K:) he severed the neck, and the arm. (TA.) masaHa Eunuqahu and biEunuqihin, aor.
masaHa , inf. n. masoHN, He smote his neck: or, as some say, severed it, or cut it through. Agreeably with both these significations masoHFA is rendered in the Kur, xxxviii. 32: some say that what is here meant is the wiping with the hand wetted with water: accord. to IAth, Solomon is here said to have smitten the necks and hock-tendons of the horses. (L.) [See art. Tfq.] masaHahu biAls~ayofi He smote him with the sword: (L:) and he cut him with the sword: (S, L:) or masaHahu signifies he struck him gently with a staff, or stick, and with a sword. (TA in art. dhn.) ― -b2- See 8. ― -b3- Also masaHahumo He slew them. (L.) -A4- masaHahu, (inf. n. masoHN, K,) He (God) created him blessed, (AHeyth, K,) and goodly: (AHeyth:) ― -b2- and, contr., created him accursed, (AHeyth, K,) and foul, or ugly. (AHeyth.) -A5- masaHa, (S,) inf. n. masoHN, (K,) (tropical:) Inivit feminam. (S, K.)
2 mas~aHa see 1, in four places.

3 mAsHhu * (tropical:) He took him by the hand; applied the palm of his hand to the palm of the other's hand. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He made a compact, or covenant, with him. (TA.) ― -b3- maAsaHaA (tropical:) They used blandishing, soothing, or wheedling, words, one to the other, deceiving thereby; (K;) their hearts not being sincere. (TA.) You say gaDiba famaAsaHotuhu Hat~aY laAna (tropical:) He was angry, and I coaxed, or wheedled, him until he became gentle, or mild. (TA.) [See also 1.]

5 tms~H biAlmaA='i *
He washed himself with water. (A, Z.) ― -b2- tms~H (tropical:) He performed the ablution called AlwuDuwo'. (IAth.) ― -b3- tms~H biAlA^aroDi (S, L) (tropical:) He performed the action termed Alt~ayam~um: or he made his forehead to touch the ground in prostration, without anything intervening. (L.) ― -b4- fulaAnN yutamas~aHu bivawobihi (tropical:) Such a one has his garment passed over men's persons as a means of their advancing themselves in the favour of God: (L:) [i.e., he is a holy man, from the touch of whose garment a blessing is derived: see St. Matthew's Gospel, ix., 20 and 21]. fulaAnN yutamas~aHu bihi (tropical:) Such a one is a person by means of whom one looks for a blessing (butabar~aku bihi,) by reason of his excellence, (K,) and his devotion; (TA;) as though one advanced himself in the favour of God by approaching him. (L.) [See also an ex. voce rukonN.] ― -b5- fulaAnN yatamas~aHu (tropical:) Such a one has nothing with him, or in his possession; as though he wiped his arms with his hands: (K:) [for it is a custom of the Arabs to do thus as an indication of having nothing.] ― -b6- tms~H He wiped himself, mino $aYo'K to remove a thing, and bi$aYo'K, with a thing. (L.) [See also 1.]

6 tamaAsaHaA * (tropical:) They acted in a friendly or sincere manner, one to the other; syn. taSaAdaqaA: or they made a contract, or bargain, one with the other, and each struck the palm of the other's hand with the palm of his own hand [to confirm it], (K,) and swore to the other. (TA.) ― -b2- tamaAsaHuwA (tropical:) They took one another by the hand. (TA.)

8 AmtsH *
He drew a sword (K) from its scabbard; as also ↓ masaHa. (TA.)

masoHN *
i. q. balaAsN; (S, K;) i.e., A garment of thick, or coarse, hair-cloth: so in the T: and a piece of such stuff as is spread in a house or tent: (TA:) a blAs such as is worn by monks: (Mgh:) a kisaA=' of hair-cloth: (L:) an old and worn-out garment: (Kull:) pl. A^amosaAHN and musuwHN; (S;) the former a pl. of pauc., and the latter a pl. of mult. (L.) ― -b2- misoHN The main part, and middle, of a road; syn. jaAd~apN: (K:) pl. A^amosaAHN (TA) and musuwHN. (K.)
masaHN * , a subst., Paucity of flesh in the posteriors and thighs; or smallness of the buttocks, and their sticking together; or paucity of flesh in the thighs; syn. rasaHN. (L.)

EalaY fulaAnK masoHapN mino jamaAlK * , (S, K,) or ↓ misoHapN, (L,) (tropical:) Upon such a one there appears somewhat of beauty; (L, K;) or, some sign, or mark, or trait, of beauty: (L:) and msHpu karamK, some sign, or mark, trait, or indication, of nobility; and the like: a mode of expression said, by Sh, to be used only in praise; so that you do not say Ealayohi msHpu quboHK: (L:) but you say also bihi msHpN mino huzaAlK in him is somewhat, or some sign, or mark, of leanness; (L, K;) which is a phrase of the Arabs mentioned by Az. (L.) ― -b2- masoHapN in the cheek of a horse: see SifaAHN.
misoHapN * : see masoHapN.

masiyHN *
Anointed: wiped over with some such thing as oil. (K.) ― -b2- A king. (El-'Eynee.) ― -b3- AlmasiyHu [The Messiah, the Christ, the Anointed,] Jesus, on whom be peace ! (S, Msb, K,) [correctly] an arabicized word, [from the Hebrew,] originally ma$iyHaA, with $: (T, Msb:) but the learned differ as to this word, whether it be Arabic or arabicized: F relates, in the K, his having mentioned, in his Expos. of the Meshárik el-Anwár, fifty opinions respecting the derivation of it; and in another work he has made the number fifty-six. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, (K,) or AlmasiyHu Alka*~aAbu, (S,) or ↓ Almis~iyHu, (K,) [The Messiah, or Christ, surnamed the Great Liar; the False Christ; Antichrist; also called] EdDejjál, Ald~aj~aAlu: (S, K:) it is not allowable, however, to apply to him the appellation AlmasiyHu without restriction; wherefore one says AlmasiyHu Ald~aj~aAlu [or Alka*~aAbu]; (TA;) [unless in a case like the following, in which] a poet says
A_i*aA AlmasiyHu yaqotulu AlmasiyHa
[When the true Messiah shall slay the false Messiah] (Msb.) [Many opinions respecting the derivation of the appellation thus applied are also mentioned by various authors.] ― -b5- masiyHN Sweat: (T, S, K:) so called because it is wiped off (yumosaHu) when it pours forth. (T.) ― -b6- masiyHN (tropical:) A dirhem [or silver coin] of which the impression is obliterated; syn. A^aTolasu; (S, Msb, K;) having no impression. (Msb.) ― -b7- masiyHN (S, K) and ↓ masiyHapN (TA) A piece of silver. (As, S, K.) ― -b8- masiyHN. (tropical:) i. q. mamosuwHu Alwajohi, (K,) i.e., A man having one side of his face plain, without eye or eyebrow: said to apply in this sense to EdDejjál, among others. (IF, L.) ― -b9- One-eyed. (Az.) [See also A^amosaHu.] ― -b10- masiyHN A rough napkin, or kerchief, with which one wipes himself: (L, K:) so called because the face is wiped with it, or because it retains the dirt. (TA.) [A dusting-cloth, or dish-clout, or the like, is now called ↓ mimosaHapN.] ― -b11- masiyHN Beautiful in the face. (TA.) ― -b12- masiyHN One who journeys or goes about much for the sake of devotion, or as a devotee; as also ↓ mis~iyHN (K,) and ↓ A^amosaHu, (TA,) the fem. of which is masoHaA='u. (K, TA.) See mas~aAHN. -A2- masiyHN (tropical:) Multum coiens; as also ↓ maAsiHN. (K.) ― -b2- masiyHN Erring greatly. (TA.) ― -b3- masiyHN A great liar; one who lies much; as also ↓ maAsiHN and ↓ mimosaHN (K) and ↓ timosaHN (Lh, K) and ↓ A^amosaHu, (TA,) the fem. of which last is masoHaA='u. (K, TA.) See maAsiHN. -A3- masiyHN Very veracious; syn. Sid~iyqN: (K, L, TA: in the CK SadiyqN:) a meaning unknown to many of the lexicologists, and probably obsolete in their time. (L.) -A4- masiyHN Created blessed, and goodly; (L;) created (mamosuwHN) with blessing, or prosperity: (K:) ― -b2- and, contr., created accursed, and foul, or ugly; (L;) created with unfortunateness. (K.)
misaAHapN * (tropical:) Mensuration of land. (Msb.) [See also 1.] ― -b2- See also takosiyrN.

masiyHapN *
i. q. *uw^aAbapN, [a portion, or lock, of hair hanging down loosely from the middle of the head to the back; or the hair of the fore part of the head; the hair over the forehead; or the part whence that hair grows; or a plait of hair hanging down; &c.]: (S, L, K:) or hair that is left without its being dressed with oil or anything else: or that part of a man's head that is between the ear and the eyebrow, rising to the part below that where the sutures of the scull unite: or that part of the side of the hair upon which a man puts his hand, next to his ear: or the hair of each side of the head: pl. masaAy^iHu: or msAy^H signifies the place which a man wipes with his hand: or, accord. to As, the hair: or, accord. to Sh, the hair which one wipes with his hand, upon his cheek and his head. (L.) ― -b2- See masiyHN. -A2- masiyHapN A bow: (S, K:) or an excellent bow: (L.) pl. masaAy^Hu. (S, K.)
mas~aAHN * (tropical:) A measurer of land; (TA;) as also ↓ masiyHN. (L.)
mis~iyHN * and Almis~iyHu: see masiyHN.

bihi maAsiHN *
He (a camel) has a fretting of the edge of the callosity upon his breast, produced by his elbow, without making it bleed: if he make it bleed, you say bihi HaAz~N: (S, L:) and he has a chafing of his arm-pit produced by his elbow, but not violent, by reason of the disease called DaAgiT. (L.) ― -b2- See masiyHN. ― -b3- maAsiHN and ↓ masiyHN A great slayer; one who slays much, or many. (Az, L.)

maAsiHapN *
A woman who combs and dresses hair; syn. maA$iTapN. (S.)

A^amosaHu * A flat place, with small pebbles, and without plants, or herbage. (S.) ― -b2- masoHaA='u A plain tract of land, with small pebbles, (S, K,) and without plants, or herbage: (S:) [ex.] mararotu bixariyqK mina AlA^aroDi biyona masoHaAwayoni [I passed by a depressed tract of land containing herbage between two plain tracts containing small pebbles and without herbage]: (Fr, S:) or a piece of flat ground, bare, abounding with pebbles, containing no trees nor herbage, rugged, somewhat hard, like a flat place in which camels &c. are confined, or in which dates are dried, not what is termed quf~, nor what is termed saholap: (ISh:) pl. masaAHK and masaAHY [i. e. masaAHaY or masaAHiY~u]; pl. forms proper to substs.; as it is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (L.) ― -b3- Also masoHA='u Red land. (K.) ― -b4- masoHaA='u A woman having little flesh in her posteriors and thighs; or foul, ugly, or unseemly; syn. rasoHaA='u. (S.) [In the K., AlA^aroDu Alr~asoHaA='u, given as an explanation of AlmasoHaA='u, is an evident mistake for AlmaroA^apu Alr~asoHaA='u, as observed by Freytag.] ― -b5- A^amosaHu, or A^amosaHu Alqadami, A man having a flat sole to his foot, without any hollow: (L:) fem. masoHaA='u: (L, K:) and ↓ masiyHN, or Alqadamayoni ↓ masiyHu, signifies the same: and also having smooth and soft feet, without fissures or chaps, so that they repel water when it falls upon them. (L.) ― -b6- Also masoHaA='u, (K,) or msHA='u Alv~adoYi, (L,) A woman whose breast has no bulk. (L, K.) ― -b7- Also masoHaA='u A one-eyed woman: [see also masiyHN:] and such as is termed bixoqaA='u, whose eye is not mulaw~azap: so in [most of] the copies of the K., but in some, bil~aworap: (TA:) [the meaning seems to be whose eye has no crystalline humour]. ― -b8- A^amosaHu A man having little flesh in his posteriors and thighs; or having small buttocks sticking together; syn. ArsH: fem. masoHaA='u: pl. musoHN. (L.) ― -b9- A^amosaHa A man (S) having the inner sides of his thighs rubbing together (S, L, K)
so as to become sore and chapped: (L:) or having the inner side of his knee inflamed by the roughness of his garment: (L, K:) fem. masoHaA='u, and pl. musoHN. (L.) ― -b10- gaArapN masoHaA='u (tropical:) A hostile attack, or incursion, by a troop of horse, in which the attacking party passes lightly by the party attacked, or brushes by them, without remaining by them. (L, from a trad.) ― -b11- See masiyHN.
A^amosaH * [app. used as a subst., and therefore with, or without, tenween,] A flat tract of land: pl. A^amaAsiHu. (TA.) ― -b2- A smooth desert; or smooth waterless desert. (Lth.)

A^umosuwHN *
Any long piece of wood in a ship: (K:) pl. A^amaAsiyHN. (TA.)
mimosaHN * and mimosaHapN: see masiyHN.

mamosuwHu AlA^aloyatayoni *
Having the buttocks cleaving to the bone, and small. (L.) ― -b2- mamosuwHN A eunuch whose testicles have been extirpated. (TA.) ― -b3- EaDudN mamosuwHapN An arm, from the shoulder to the elbow, having little flesh. (TA.) ― -b4- mamosuwHu A thing foul, or ugly, and unfortunate, and changed from its proper form, or make. (TA.) [See art. msx.]

timosaHN *
A dissembler; a deceiver; (K;) one who blandishes, soothes, or wheedles, one with his words, and deceives him. (TA.) ― -b2- timosaHN An audacious, or insolent, and wicked, or corrupt, man: (L, K:) or a great liar, who, if asked, will not tell thee truly whence he comes; who lies to thee even as to the place whence he comes. (L.) [See also masiyHN.] ― -b3- See timosaAHN.

timosaAHN * , (S, Msb, K,) and ↓ timosaHN, (Msb, K,) the latter app. a contraction of the former, (Msb,) [The crocodile]; a well-known aquatic animal, (S,) a creature like the tortoise, of great size, found in the Nile of Egypt and in the river Mihrán, (K,) which is the river of Es-Sind; (TA;) or [rather] resembling the waral about five cubits long, and less; that seizes men and oxen, and dives into the water with them and devours them: pl. of the former tamaAsiyHN, and of the latter tamaAsiHu. (Msb.)

1 masaxahu * , (S, K,) aor.
masaxa , (K,) inf. n. masoxN, (S,) He transformed him, or metamorphosed him, (S, Msb, K,) into a worse, or more foul, or more ugly, shape. (S, K.) Ex. masaxahu A@ll~`hu qirodFA God transformed him into an ape. (S, K.) [See Kur, xxxvi. 67.] ― -b2- masaxa $iEorFA He took and transformed poetry; accord. to the most common usage, by the substitution of what is synonymous with the original, wholly or partly; but sometimes by altering the meanings. (M, F.) See 1 (last sentence) in art. slx. ― -b3- masaxa AlkaAtibu The writer corrupted what he wrote by changing the diacritical points and altering the meaning. (Msb.) ― -b4- masaxa Aln~aAqapa, (L, K,) aor.
masaxa , inf. n. masoxN, (L,) (tropical:) He rendered the she-camel lean, and wounded her back, by fatigue and use: (A'Obeyd, L, K:) as also masaHa. (L.) ― -b5- masuxa, [aor.
masuxa ,] inf. n. masaAxapN (assumed tropical:) It (flesh-meat, and fruit,) was, or became, tasteless, or insipid: it (food) had no salt nor colour nor taste: and, sometimes, it was between sweet and bitter. (L.) ― -b6- masaxa TaEomahu (assumed tropical:) It caused its taste to depart; took away its taste. (S.)

4 Amsx *
It (a humour) became dissolved. (L, K.)

7 A_im~asaxati AlEaDudu * , [or A_inomasaxat, the original form,] The arm, between the shoulder and the elbow, became lean. (L.) A_inomisaAxu HamaApi Alfarasi Lankness of the muscle of the thigh (sAq) called] the HmAp of the horse (S, K) is disliked. (S.) [In some copies of the S, this is omitted.]

masoxN * and ↓ masiyxN, (L, K,) [the former originally an inf. n., and therefore used as sing. and dual and pl. without alteration, though musuwxN is used as a pl. by late writers, (see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., ii. 273,)] the latter of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (L,) Transformed, or metamorphosed, into a worse, or more foul, or more ugly, shape. (L, K.) Ex. AljaAn~u masoxu Aljin~i The Jánn, which are slender serpents, are the transformed of the Jinn, or Genii; like as certain persons of the Children of Israel were transformed into apes. [See Kur, ii. 61.] (L, from a trad.) ― -b2- Also, the ↓ latter, Deformed; rendered ugly in make, or form. (K.) Hence, some say, the appellation of Ald~aj~aAlu ↓ Almasiyxu [more commonly AlmasiyHu Ald~j~An, q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, the same, (tropical:) A man having no beauty. (S, K.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Weak and stupid: (K:) also an epithet applied to a man. (TA.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Flesh-meat, (S, L, K,) and fruit, (L, K,) that has no taste; tasteless; insipid: (S, L, K:) or, applied to food, that has no salt nor colour nor taste: and sometimes, that is between sweet and bitter. (L.) El-Ash'ar Er-Rakabán, of the tribe of Asad, a Jáhilee, says, addressing a man named Ridwán, (L,)
masiyxN maliyxN kalaHomi AlHuwaA
ri laA A^anota HulowN walaA A^anota mur~N
[Tasteless, insipid, like the flesh of a new-born camel, thou art not sweet nor art thou bitter]. (S, L.)

masaxN *
Leanness of the arm, between the shoulder and the elbow. (L.)
masiyxN * : see masoxN.

maAsixiY~N *
A bow-maker. (S, L, K.) AHn says, that maAsixapu, a man of the tribe of Azd, of Es-Saráh, is asserted to have been a bowmaker: and Ibn-El-Kelbee says, that he was the first of the Arabs who made bows; that the people of Es-Saráh who made bows and arrows were numerous, because of the abundance of trees in their district, and hence every bowmaker in after times received the above appel-lation. (L.) ― -b2- maAsixiy~apN (L, K) and maAsixiy~aAtN (S, L) Bows: so called in relation to the abovementioned bow-maker, Másikhah of the tribe of Azd: (S, L, K:) Másikhah was his surname, and his name was Nubeysheh the son of El- Hárith, one of the sons of Nasr the son of Azd. (TA.)
huwa A^amasaxu mino laHomi AlHuwaAri * [He, or it, is more tasteless, or insipid, than the flesh of the newborn camel]: i.e., he, or it, has no taste. A proverb. (S.)
mamosuwxN * A horse, having little flesh in the rump, or buttocks: and mamosuwxapN AlEajuzi A woman having little flesh in her posteriors: (K:) but the more approved pronunciation is with H. (TA.)

1 masada * , aor.
masuda , (S, M, L,) inf. n. masodN, (S, M, L, K,) He twisted a rope: (M, L, K:) or he twisted it well. (ISk, S, L.) ― -b2- masada, aor.
masuda , (M, L,) inf. n. masodN, (S, M, L, K,) He pursued a journey laboriously, or with energy; or he held on, or continued, the journey; syn. A^adoA^aba Als~ayora, (S, M, L, K,) by night: (S, M, L:) or he journeyed on continually, whether by night or by day: (M, L:) because the so journeying renders an animal lean, or lank. (Lth, L.) ― -b3- masada, aor.
masuda , [inf. n. masodN,] (tropical:) It (leguminous herbage, A, or continued travel, Lth) rendered an animal lean, lank, light of flesh, slender, or lank in the belly. (Lth, A, L.) El-'Abdee says, describing a she-camel, and likening her to a wild bull,
yamosuduhu Alqaforu walayolN sadiY
The bare and waterless desert renders him lean, &c., and dewy night. (L.) ― -b4- musida, inf. n. masodN, (tropical:) It (the belly) was, or became, soft, of small dimensions, even, and without any ugliness. (M, L.) ― -b5- The following expression of Ru-beh,
yamosudu A^aEolaY laHomihi wayaA^orimuhu
means (tropical:) It (the milk of camels) strengthens the
upper parts of his flesh, (referring to a pastor, not to an ass, as J says, IB, L,) and renders it, firm. (L.) ― -b6- Hasanapu Almasodi, applied to a damsel, (tropical:) i. q. mamosuwdapN, q. v. (S, L.)

masadN * The fibres that grow at the roots of the branches of the palm-tree; syn. liyfN: (S, A, L:) you say HabolN mino masadK a rope, or halter, of those fibres: (S, A:) also, masadN alone signifies a rope of those fibres: (S, M, L, K:) or, of those of the [kind of palm-tree called] muqol: (Zj, L, K:) or, of the leaves of the palm-tree: or, of the soft hair of the camel: (S, M, L: [see an ex. voce zaAhiqN:]) or, of other hair: or, of wool: or, of hides: (M, L:) or, of camels' hides: (S, L:) or, of plants: or, of the bark of a tree: (L:) or, of any thing: (M, L, K:) or a plaited rope, firmly twisted, (M, L, K,) of any of the materials above mentioned: (M, L:) applied to a rope, it is for mamosuwdN; and is thus similar to nafoDN, meaning mA nufiDa: (L:) pl. A^amosaAdN and misaAdN. (M, L, K.) HabolN mino masadK in the Kur, cxi., last verse, is said to mean A chain seventy cubits in length, whereby the woman upon whose neck it is to be put shall be led into hell, (Zj, T, M, L,) firmly twisted of iron; as though it were a rope of iron strongly twisted. (L.) ― -b2- masadN mugaArN (tropical:) A back compact like a rope strongly twisted. (M, L.) ― -b3- masadN An iron axis of a pulley. (M, L, K.)
misaAdN * , a dial. form of misoA^abN; (S, L, K;) i. e., A skin for clarified butter: and one for honey: (S, M, L:) a black skin for wine &c. (AA, L.)
saAqN masodaA='u * (tropical:) An even, and a goodly, or beautiful, shank. (M, L.)

mamosuwdN * (tropical:) A man of well-turned, compact, and slender, make; syn. majoduwlu Alxaloqi; (S, L, K;) i. e., light of flesh; or tall and slender; or of goodly stature; syn. mamo$uwqN; as though twisted; (TA:) a belly soft, of small dimensions, even, and having in it no ugliness. (M, L.) mamosuwdapN, applied to a damsel; (S, K;) the same as the masc. applied to a man; (L, K;) slender; or light of flesh; or tall and slender; or of goodly stature: (L, M:) and, applied to a woman, compact in make; of well-knit frame. (L.)

div2.head: msr &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 ma$~a * , (S, A,) aor.
ma$u3a , (S,) inf. n. ma$~N, (S, A, K,) He wiped his hand with a thing, (S, A, K), or with a rough thing, (As, S,) and with a napkin, (A,) to cleanse it, (S, A, K,) and to remove its greasiness. (As, S, A, K.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce muDah~abN.] You say also, ma$~a A^u*unahu, and biA^u*unihi, He wiped his ear. (TA.) And A^umo$u$o muxaATaka Wipe thou away the mucus of thy nose. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He wiped an arrow, and a bow-string, with his garment, to make it soft. (A, TA. *) -A2- ma$~a, (Lth, A, Mgh,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (K,) He sucked, (Lth, A, Mgh,) a bone, (A,) or the heads, or extremites, of bones, (Mgh, K,) [i. e.] what are termed mu$aA$, they being chewed; (Lth;) as also ↓ tm$~$hu, (Lth, A, K,) and ↓ Amt$~hu, and ↓ ma$oma$ahu, of which last the inf. n. is ma$oma$apN: (TA:) and (TA) AlEaZoma ↓ tm$~$ he ate the mu$aA$ [q. v.] of the bone: or he sucked the whole of it; or extracted its marrow; syn. tamak~akahu: (S, TA:) and ↓ m$~$hu, (TK,) inf. n. tamo$iy$N, (K,) he extracted its marrow; (K, * TA;) as also ↓ Amt$~hu. (TA.) ― -b2- ma$~a Aln~aAqapa, (S,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (assumed tropical:) He milked the she-camel leaving some of the milk in the udder: (S, K: *) and ma$~N also signifies (assumed tropical:) the milking to the uttermost; and so ↓ A_imoti$aA$N: (TA:) you say, maA fiY AlD~aroEi ↓ Amt$~ (assumed tropical:) he took, (K,) i. e. milked, (TA,) all that was in the udder. (K, TA, from Ibn-'Abbád.) ― -b3- huwa yamu$~u maAla fulaAnK, (A, TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (tropical:) He takes the property of such a one, thing after thing; (A, K, TA;) as also yamu$~u mino maAlihi: (TA:) or the latter, (accord. to one copy of the S,) or mn mAlh ↓ yamota$~u, (accord. to other copies of the S, and the TA,) he obtains of his property. (S, TA.)
2 ma$~a3a see 1.
4 Am$~ * , (K,) inf. n. A_imo$aA$N, (TA,) It (a bone) had in it what might be sucked, or extracted; i. e., (TA,) had in it marrow. (K, TA.)
5 tama$~a3a see 1, in two places.
8 Amt$~ * : see 1, in five places. ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) He performed the purification termed A_isotanojaA=' (IAar, A, K) with a piece of stone or a lump of dry clay or loam. (IAar, K.)
R. Q. 1 ma$oma$a * : see 1.

mu$aA$N * The heads of bones, (S, Mgh, K,) that are soft, (S,) that may be chewed, (S, K,) or that are sucked: (Mgh:) or soft bones: (A:) or the heads of bones such as the knees and elbows and shoulder-bones: (A'Obeyd:) and the bone within a horn: (Mgh:) sing. [or rather n. un.] with p: (S, K,) which is also said to signify the prominent part of the shoulder-bone. (TA.) rajulN ha$~u Almu$aA$i rixowu Almagomazi (tropical:) [lit. A man soft, or fragile, in the heads of the bones, flabby where he is felt or pressed,] denotes dispraise. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The soul, or spirit; syn. nafosN. (S, K.) You say fulaAnN Tay~ibu Almu$aA$i (tropical:) Such a one is generous in soul, or spirit. (S, A. *) nahi$u Almu$aA$i, applied by Aboo-Dhu-eyb to a horse, means (tropical:) Light, or quick, in spirit, or in the bones, or in the legs. (S, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Natural disposition. (K, TA.) You say, fulaAnN lay~inu Almu$aA$i (tropical:) Such a one is good in natural disposition; one who abstains from coveting. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) Origin. (K, Ibn-'Abbád.) So in the saying Anh lkrym Almu$aA$i (tropical:) Verily he is of generous origin: (Ibn-'Abbád, TA:) or this means (tropical:) verily he is a lord, or chief. (A, TA.) [And similar to this is the saying] ↓ huwa fiY mu$aA$api qawomihi (tropical:) He is among the best of his people. (A, * TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Light, sharp, or quick, and who does much service in journeying and at home: (K:) or (assumed tropical:) light in spirit: or (assumed tropical:) one who is a light burden (xafiyfu Almaw^uwnapi) to him who consorts with him: or (assumed tropical:) sharp or quick in motions: and, as some say, xafiyfu Alma$aA$i means (assumed tropical:) one who does much service in journeying and at home: so accord. to Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.)

ma$uw$N *
A napkin, (S, A,) or rough napkin, (TA,) or thing with which to wipe the hand. (S, K.) See 1, first signification.
mu$aA$apN * : see mu$aA$N, in two places.

mi$omi$N * , (S, K,) in the dial. of El-Basrah, (TA,) and ↓ ma$oma$N, (AO, S, K,) in the dial. of El-Koofeh, (TA,) [The apricot;] a certain thing that is eaten; (S;) a well-known fruit; (K;) called in Persian zarodN Aluw [or zarodo A=luw]; (TA.) than which few things are found more productive of cold, or coolness, to the stomach, and befouling, and weakening: (K:) some, (K,) namely, the people of Syria, (TA,) apply this appellation to the A_ij~aAS [which with others signifies the plum; but with them, the pear]: (K:) so says Lth: and some of the people of Syria pronounce it [mu$omusN,] with damm. (TA.)
mu$otN * [The fist; the hand clinched: a Persian word arabicized]. (Mgh, in art. n$r.) [See an ex. voce taw~N, where it has a redundant n affixed to it.]

1 ma$aja * , aor.
ma$uja , inf. n. ma$ojN, He mixed, or confused, syn. xalaTa, (K,) one thing with (bi) another. (TK.) ― -b2- ma$aja bayonahumaA He made a confusion, or disturbance, (xalaTa,) between them two. (S.)
mi$ojN * and ma$ajN and ma$ijN: see ma$iyjN.

ma$iyjN * (S, K) and ↓ ma$aja (K) and like ktf in its two dial. forms, (fiY lugatayohi, K accord. to the
TA,) i. e., ↓ ma$ijN and ↓ mi$ojN, or like katifN in a dial. of little authority, (fiY lugay~apK, CK and a MS. copy of the K.) [See ma$oyuwHaA='u, in art. $yj.] A thing mixed, or confused: (S, K:) or any two things mixed together: or any two colours mixed together: or what is a mixture of red and white: (TA:) pl. (of all the above forms, TA) A^amo$aAjN. (S, K.) ― -b2- nuTofapN A^amo$aAjN, occurring in the Kur, lxxvi. 2, [A drop consisting of] mixtures; meaning the sperma genitale, because it is a mixture of various kinds: (ISk:) or [a drop consisting of] mixtures of sperma genitale and blood: (Zj:) or [a drop consisting of] the sperma genitale of the man mixed with that of the woman and with her blood. (S, K.) ― -b3- Also A^amo$aAjN What collect together in the navel. (K.)
See Supplement

1 ma$aTa Al$~aEara * , aor.
ma$uTa and
ma$iTa , (M, Msb,) inf. n. ma$oTN, (M, Msb, K,) He combed the hair; loosed and separated it with the comb; or combed and dressed it; syn. raj~alahu, (M, K, *) or sar~aHahu: (Msb:) and ↓ m$~Thu signifies he did so much. (Msb.) You say also ma$aTati AlmaA$iTapu AlmaroA^apa, aor.
ma$uTa , inf. n. as above, [The mA$Tp combed, or combed and dressed, the woman's hair.] (S, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) daAy^imu Alma$oTi is applied to (tropical:) A blandisher, or coaxer. (K, TA.) -A2- ma$oTN also signifies The act of mixing. (Fr, K.) You say, ma$aTa bayona AlmaA='i waAll~abani [He mixed together the water and the milk]. (TA.)
2 ma$~aTa see 1.

8 Amt$T *
He combed, or combed and dressed, his hair: (Msb, K: *) [and in like manner,] you say of a woman, Amt$Tt. (S, TA.)
ma$oTN * : see what next follows.

mu$oTN * (S, Msb, K,) and ↓ mi$oTN, (Msb, K,) but the latter disapproved by IDrd, (TA,) and ↓ ma$oTN, (K,) and accord. to some with each of the three vowels to the $, but this requires consideration [in other cases than those here following], (MF,) and ↓ mu$uTN (Ks, K) and ↓ mu$uT~N (AHeyth, K) and ↓ ma$iTN (K) and ↓ mimo$aTN, (IB, K,) of all which the first is the most chaste, (TA,) A comb: pl. A^amo$aATN (S, Msb, K,) and mi$aATN. (IB, K.) ― -b2- mu$oTN mina AlHadiydi A curry comb (miHas~apN): so called by a poet because it has teeth like the mu$oT. (TA, art. nmS.) ― -b3- Also mu$oTN (tropical:) [An upright loom;] a loom with which one weaves, set upright: (K, TA:) pl. A^amo$aATN. (TA.) You say Daraba Aln~aAsiju bimi$oTihi and A^amo$aATihi (tropical:) [app. meaning The weaver wove with his upright loom and his upright looms]. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) [The metatarsal bones;] the sulaAmayaAt of the upper part of the foot; (S, K;) i. e. the slender bones spread upon the foot, exclusive of the toes; [also called, more particularly, or perhaps only called, mu$oTu Alqadami or mu$oTu Alr~ijoli:] pl. A^amo$aATN. (TA.) You say, Ainkasara mu$oTu qadamihi (tropical:) [His metatarsal bones broke]. (TA.) And qaAmuwA EalaY A^amo$aATi A^arojulihimo (tropical:) [They stood upon their metatarsal bones]. (TA.) ― -b5- mu$oTu Alkatifi (assumed tropical:) The wide bone of the scapula: (S:) or a wide bone thereof: (K:) or the wide flesh thereof: (T, TA:) ― -b6- mu$oTN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A certain mark made with a hot iron upon camels, (K,) in the form of a comb, (Sb, TA,) upon the body, and the neck, and the thigh. (Aboo-'Alee, TA.)
mi$oTN * : see mu$oTN.
ma$iTN * : see mu$oTN.
mu$uTN * : see mu$oTN.
mu$uT~N * : see mu$oTN.

mi$oTapN *
A mode, or manner, of combing, or of combing and dressing the hair. (S, * TA.)

lim~apN ma$iyTN *
A lock of hair descending below the lobe of the ear combed, or combed and dressed; i. q. ↓ mamo$uwTapN. (S, TA.)

mu$aATapN *
What falls, of hair, on the occasion of combing, or combing and dressing it. (S, * Msb, K. *)
mi$aATapN * The art, or occupation, of the maA$iTap. (K.)

ma$~aATN *
A comb-maker. (TA.) ― -b2- See also maA$iTapN, in two places.

maAsiTapN * [A female comber, or comber and dresser, of the hair;] (S;) a female who combs the hair, or combs and dresses it, well; (K;) and [in like manner] ↓ ma$~aATapN a girl who performs well the art of combing, or combing and dressing, the hair. (TA.) And one of the post-classical writers has used in his poetry the epithet ↓ ma$~aATN [applied in like manner to a man or boy]. (TA.
A^amo$aTu * : see mamo$uwTN.
mimo$aTN * : see mu$oTN.
mamo$uwTN * : fem. with p: see ma$iyTN. ― -b2- baEiyrN mamo$uwTN. (assumed tropical:) A camel marked with the mark termed mu$oT; (K;) as also ↓ A^amo$aTu. (TA.)

div2.head: m$Z &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 maS~ahu * , (A, Msb,) first pers. maSiSotu, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. yamaS~u; (S, Msb, K;) and first pers. maSaSotu, aor. yamuS~u; (Msb, K;) but the former is the more chaste; (T, Msb, TA,) inf. n. maS~N; (S, M, Msb;) [He sucked it; or sucked it in; or sipped it, i. e.] he drank it (namely water, A, or a thing, S, M,) with a minute draught, ($urobFA raqiyqFA: so in a copy of the A, and in the CK,) or with a gentle draught: ($urobFA rafiyqFA: so in some copies of the K, and in the TA:) or he took it (namely a small quantity of a fluid) by drawing in the breath: and whether $ariba may be used to denote this, as it is in the K, requires consideration: (MF:) or i. q. ra$afahu: (S, K, art. r$f:) or i. q. tara$~afahu: (M:) ra$ofN signifies the “ taking ” water “ with the lips; ” and is more than maS~N: (Msb, art. r$f:) and ↓ AmtS~hu signifies the same; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) and so ↓ tmS~Shu: (M, A:) or the last signifies he did so leisurely. (S, K.) You say, Alr~um~aAna ↓ AmtS~, i. e. maS~ahu [He sucked the pomegranate]; and so of other things. (TA.) And maS~a AljaAriyapa He sucked the damsel's saliva from her mouth. (IAar, in L, art. mSd.) And maS~a MINA ALD~UNOYAA (tropical:) He obtained a little of worldly goods. (TA.)

4 AmS~hu * [He made him to suck: or he gave him to suck]. (S, A, K.) You say A^amoSaSotuhu AlmaA='a (A) or Al$~aYo'a (S) [I made him to suck, or I gave him to suck, the water, or the thing]. ― -b2- (tropical:) He said to him yaA maS~aAnu, q. v. (S, * A, TA.) You say, huwa yumiS~uhu wayubaZ~iruhu. (K, art. bZr, which see in the present work.)
5 tamaS~a3a see 1, in which two explanations of it are given.
8 A_imotaSa3a see 1. in two places.

R. Q. 1 maSomaSa * , (S, A,) or maSomaSa faAhu, (M, TA,) inf. n. maSomaSapN, (S, M, K,) [He rinsed his mouth with water; he agitated water in his mouth; syn. maDomaDa: (M:) or he did so with the extremity of his tongue, (S, M, K,) or with the fore parts of his mouth; (A;) whereas the latter signifies he did so with his mouth altogether; (S, M, A;) the difference between maSomaSapN and maDomaDapN being similar to that between qaboSapN and qaboDapN: (S, M:) the former is mentioned in a trad. as being done after drinking milk; but not after eating dates. (S.) You say also, maSomaSa AlA_inaA='a He washed the vessel; (ISk, S, M;) as also maDomaDahu: (ISk, Yaakoob, M:) or he washed out, or rinsed, the vessel; he put water into the vessel, and shook it, to wash it; (As, TA;) he poured water into the vessel, and then shook it,
without washing it with his hand, and then poured it out. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.) And maSomaSa Alv~awoba He washed [or rinsed] the garment, or piece of cloth. (M, TA.)
muS~apN * : see what next follows.

muSaASN *
What is sucked from, or of, a thing; (M, TA;) as also ↓ muSaASapN. (M, A, TA.) You say, TaAbato muSaASatuhu fiY famiY What was sucked from it, or of it, was good, or sweet, or pleasant, in my mouth. (A.) ― -b2- [And hence,] The pure, or choice, part of anything; (S, K;) as also ↓ muSaAmiSN: (K:) and (S) the purest, or choicest, (S, M,) of a thing; as also ↓ muSaASapN and ↓ muSaAmiSN. (M.) And AlmaAli ↓ muS~apu signifies the same as muSaASuhu, (K, TA,) i. e. The pure, or choice part of property, or of the property. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN muSaASu qawomihi, (S, M,) and ↓ muSaASatuhu, (M,) Such a one is the purest in race, or lineage, of his people: and in like manner you say of two, and of more, and of a female. (S, M.) And huwa mino muSaASi qawomihi [He is of the purest, or choicest, of his people]. (A.) ― -b3- Also, Pure, or choice, applied to Hasab [or grounds of pretension to respect, &c.]; as also ↓ muSaAmiSN. (A.) You say also, A_in~ahu lamuSaAmiSN fiY qawomihi Verily he is distinguished, or characterized, by pure grounds of respect among his people. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- Also, The origin, source, or place of origination, of a thing. (M, TA.) You say, huwa kariymu AlmuSaASi He is generous, or noble, in respect of origin. (TA.) Accord. to Lth, muSaASu Alqawomi signifies The original source of the people: and the most excellent of their middle class. (TA.)

maSuwSN *
A certain kind of food, (S, K,) of flesh-meat, cooked, and steeped in vinegar; (K;) or, as some say, steeped in vinegar, and then cooked: (TA:) or of the flesh of birds particularly: (K:) pronounced by the vulgar with damm to the m: (S:) but what is said in the Nh implies that it is with damm; for it is there said, “ and it may be with fet-h to the m. ” (TA.)
muSaASapN * : see muSaASN, in four places.
maSuwSapN * : see mamoSuwSapN.
maS~aASN * : see what next follows.

maS~aAnN *
A cupper; because he sucks; (M, TA;) and so ↓ maS~aASN: (K, voce Haj~aAmN, which is its syn.:) fem. of the former with p. (M.) ― -b2- A man who sucks his ewes or she-goats; by reason of his meanness, or ungenerousness: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) i. e. who sucks from their udders with his mouth; lest the sound of the milking should be heard; as also, ↓ maAS~u; (TA;) and so maloHaAnu and mak~aAnu. (A'Obeyd, TA.) [But in the TA it is written maS~aAnu, without tenween; and so in two copies of the S.]) ― -b3- yaA maS~aAnu, [said to a man,] and yaA maS~aAnapu, to a female, denote vituperation, meaning (tropical:) O sucker (maAS~ S, K) of such a thing, (S, TA,) i. e. (TA) of the baZor [q. v.], (K, TA,) of thy mother: (S, K, TA:) or the meaning is O sucker (raADiE) of the ewes or she-goats: (K:) ISk says, (TA,) you should not say ↓ yaA maAS~aAnu: (S, TA:) but Ibn-'Abbád says, (TA,) one says wayoliY EalaY maAS~aAni boni maAS~aAnK, and ↓ maAS~aAnapa boni maAS~aAnapa, (K, TA,) meaning [Alas for me, on account of] the mean, or ungenerous, the son of the mean, or ungenerous! (TA.)
muS~aAnN * , with damm, The sugar-cane; [because it is sucked.] (IKh, IB.)
muSaAmSN * : see muSaASN, in four places.
maAS~N * , act. part. n. of 1: see maS~aAnN, in two places.
maAS~aAnu * and maAS~aAnapu: see maS~aAnN.

waZiyfN mamoSuwSN * (tropical:) A slender pastern; (K, TA;) as though it were sucked. (TA.) And mamoSuwSapN (M, A) and maSuwSapN (AZ, ISk, K) (tropical:) A woman emaciated (AZ, ISk, M, A, K) by reason of a disease infecting her; (AZ, ISk, M;) as though she were sucked. (M, TA.)

1 maSata * , ([aor.
maSuta ,] inf. n. maSotN TA,) Inivit puellam: [K:) dial. form of mSada. (TA.) ― -b2- maSata Aln~aAqapa He laid hold upon the womb of the camel, and put in his hand, and extracted the water [i. e. the semen injected into it]. (M, K.) [See also masaTa.] ― -b3- maSata AlmiEaY He squeezed out what was in the intestine, or gut, with his fingers. (TA.) ― -b4- maSata It (herbage) purged cattle; or relaxed them in the bowels. (Marg. note in a copy of the S.) ― -b5- maSata He squeezed an ulcer, so as to express the matter. (Marg. note in a copy of the S) ― -b6- maSata He sucked saliva. (Marg. note in a copy of the S.)

1 maSaHa * , aor.
maSaHa , inf. n. muSuwHN (and maSoHN, TA), He, or it, (a thing, S,) went away; passed away; departed. (S, K.) ― -b2- It finished; came to an end; ceased. (S, K.) ― -b3- It (a garment) became old and worn-out. (S, K.) ― -b4- It (a plant) became faded in its blossoms. (S, K.) ― -b5- Also, inf. n. muSuwHN, It (a blossom) faded; or lost its colour. (AHn.) ― -b6- maSaHa, (inf. n. muSuwHN, TA,) It (the shade) became short. (S, K.) ― -b7- maSaHa, inf. n. muSuwHN, It (an udder) ceased to have milk. (TA.) ― -b8- It (the milk of a camel) ceased; passed away. (S, K.) ― -b9- maSiHa, aor.
maSaHa , It (shade) became deficient and thin. So accord. to the K; but in other lexicons, the verb, with reference to shade, is maSaHa. (TA.) ― -b10- maSaHa, inf. n. muSuwHN, It (a writing) became obliterated, or nearly so. (TA.) ― -b11- It (a dwelling) became obliterated; or its vestiges became effaced. (TA.) ― -b12- maSaHa bihi, (S, K,) and ↓ A^amoSaHahu, (IB,) He took away, carried off, or went away with, it; or caused it to go, go away, or pass away. (S, IB, K.) ― -b13- maSaHa fiY AlA^aroDi, inf. n. maSoHN, He set forth journeying through the land, or earth: as also masaHa. (ISd.)
4 A^amoSaHa see 1.

A^amoSaHu *
Deficient and thin shade. (K.)

1 maSaxa * , aor.
