maSaxa , (L,) inf. n. maSoxN; and ↓ AmtSx and ↓ tmS~x; (L, K;) He pulled away a thing (L, K) from the inside of another thing, (L,) and took it: (K:) and maSaxa and ↓ AmtSx he pulled away an A^umoSuwxap of the kind of plant called vumaAm, or of that called naSiY~, (S, L,) from within another AmSwxp thereof, (L,) and took it: (S, L:) and ↓ tmS~x he pulled out the white pith called AmSwxp of the barodiY~. (AHn, L.) -A2- maSaxa, inf. n. maSoxN, a dial form of masaxa, q. v. (L, K. *)

4 AmSx *
It (a plant of the kind called vumaAm) put forth its A^amaASiyx [pl. of A^umoSuwxap, q. v.] (K.)
5 tamaS~axa see 1 in two places.
7 A_im~aSaxa * , inf. n. A_im~iSaAxN, It (a child) became disunited from its mother; (K;) i. e., from the belly of its mother. (L, TA.)
8 AmtSx * , It (a thing) became disunited from (Eano) another thing. (TA.) ― -b2- See 1 in two places.
maSuwxapN * A ewe or she-goat whose udder is flaccid at the base; (T, K;) as though it were disunited (AmtSxt, i. e. AnfSlt,) from the belly. (T, L.)

muS~aAxN *
A certain plant having coats (qu$uwr) like the onion; (K;) of which Az says, I have seen, in the desert, a plant called muS~aAxN and y^ud~aA='N
having coats (q$wr), one above another; whenever one peels off one A^umoSuwxp (or coat) there appears another; and its coats (q$wr) are an excellent fuel: the people of Haráh (hrAp) call it dlyzA*. (L.)

A^umoSuwxapN *
A sheath or coat, of a plant, enveloping, or surrounding, another sheath or coat, and the latter another, and so on: (T, L:) a xawSap of the kind of plant called vumaAm, (S, K,) and of that called naSiY~; (S;) what is plucked from the nSY~, like a rod; (AHn;) [i. e., a sheath of the vmAm or the nSY~;] there is a species of the vmAm having no leaves properly so called, its leaves being sheaths (A^anaAbiyb) set one into another, each sheath (A^unobuwbap) of which is called AmSwxp, and when it is pulled away it comes forth from the inside of another, as though it were a stopper taken out from a vessel in which collyrium (kuHol) is kept: (Lth:) pl. A^umoSuwxN and A^amaASiyxu: (S, K:) the former is a lexicological pl., [or rather a coll. gen. n., of which AmSwxp is the n. un.,] and the latter is the proper pl. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, The white pith of the barodiY~. (AHn.)

1 maSadahaA * , aor.
maSuda , (M,) inf. n. maSodN, (S, M, L, K,) He sucked her breast (Lth, S, M, L, K) in a certain manner. (S, M, L.) You say, qab~alahaA famaSadahaA He kissed her and sucked her breast. (Lth, L.) ― -b2- maSadahaA, (IAar, L,) inf. n. maSodN; (IAar, L, K;) He sucked her (a damsel's) saliva from her mouth; like maS~ahaA, and ra$afahaA, and raf~ahaA: (IAar, L:) and maSada he sucked (IAar, S, L, K) saliva. (IAar, S, L.) ― -b3- maSadahaA, (S, M, L,) aor.
maSuda , (M,) inf. n. maSodN, (S, M, L, K,) Inivit eam, (S, M, L, K,) quodam modo; (M;) scil, ancillam suam. (L); as also mazadahaA, inf. n. mazodN. (M.) -A2- maSada, inf. n. maSodN, He brought under; subdued; rendered submissive; syn. *al~ala. (K.)

maSodN *
Thunder. (L, K.) ― -b2- maSodN Rain: (L:) and with p, a shower of rain; a rain: you say, maA A^aSaAbatonaA AlEaAma maSodapN, (and mazodapN, TA,) Not a rain has fallen on us this year. (M, L, K.) ― -b3- maSodN Intenseness of cold; (Kr, M, L, K;) as also ↓ maSadN: (K:) or, simply, cold; (Er-Riyáshee, L;) as also ↓ maSodapN. (S, M.) And, contr., Intenseness of heat: (Kr, M, L, K:) and ↓ maSodapN, simply, heat. (AZ, L.) You say, maA wajadonaA lahaA AlEaAma maSodapF, (and mazodapF, ISk, S, M, L,) We have not found it (the earth, AZ,) to have, this year, cold (AZ, S, M, L) nor heat: (AZ, L:) or, intenseness of cold nor intenseness of heat. (Kr, M, L.) ― -b4- maSodN and ↓ maSadN and ↓ maSaAdN A high (M, K) and red (M) hill, or mountain, such as is called haDobapN: (M, K:) or the last, (As, S, M, K,) and the others also, (M,) the upper part, or top, of a mountain: (As, S, M, K:) and the last, a place of refuge: and applied to a man: (A:) pl. of the last, A^amoSidapN and muSodaAnN. (S, M, K.) Az holds the m in mSAd to be augmentative, and the pls. to have been formed on the supposition of its being radical. (L.) See also art. Syd.
maSadN * : see maSodN.
maSodapN * : see maSodN.
maSaAdN * : see maSodN.

2 mS~rhu *
He made it (namely a town) a miSor, i. e. a limit, or boundary, between two things. (IAar.) ― -b2- maS~aruwA AlmakaAna, inf. n. tamoSiyrN, They made the place, or appointed it to be, a miSor [meaning a city, or town, such as is thus called]. (M, * K.) It is said of 'Omar, maS~ara AlA^amoSaAra, (TA,) which is a phrase like mad~ana Almuduna, (S,) [and signifying He appointed the cities, or towns called A^amoSaAr: or] mS~r AlAmSAr signifies he built the [cities, or towns, called] AmSAr: (A:) among which AmSAr were El-Basrah and El-Koofeh. (A, TA.)

5 tmS~r *
It (a place) became a miSor [meaning a city, or town, such as is thus called]. (M, K.)

miSorN *
A partition, barrier, or thing intervening, between two things: (S, M, K:) as also ↓ maASirN: (K:) and (S) or limit, or boundary, between two lands: (M, K:) pl. muSuwrN. (S, M.) The people of Egypt, (S,) or of Hejer, (M,) or of both, (TA,) write in their contracts, (S, M, *) A_i$otaraY fulaAnN Ald~aAra bimuSuwrihaA Such a one bought the house with its limits, or boundaries. (S, M, * K. *) ― -b2- Hence, A great town; syn. baladN EaZiymN; (Bd, ii. 58;). a kuwrap [here meaning city, or provincial city]: (M, K:) or a kuwrap (Lth, IF, Msb) in which the [ordinances of God which are termed] Huduwd are executed, and (Lth, TA) in which the [spoil or tribute termed] faYo' and the [alms termed] SadaqaAt are divided (Lth, IF, Msb) without consulting the Khaleefeh; such is its signification in the language of the Arabs: (Lth, TA:) or that [town] whereof the greatest of its mosques will not hold, or contain, its inhabitants: (KT:) it is masc. and perfectly decl., and fem. and imperfectly decl.: (Msb:) [but this remark seems properly to relate to the word when used as the name of the metropolis of Egypt, and of Egypt itself, agreeably with what is said in the S, M, and K:] pl. A^amoSaArN. (S, M, Msb.) The dual, AlmiSoraAni, is applied to El-Koofeh and El-Basrah. (S, M, A, K.)

maSiyrN *
A gut, an intestine, or a bowel, into which the food passes from the stomach; syn. miEFY: (S, M, Msb, K:) or specially, as some say, of a bird, and of an animal which has a soft foot, or xuf~, [as the camel,] and of such as have a cloven hoof: (M, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^amoSirapN (M, K) and [of mult.] muSoraAnN, and pl. pl. maSaAriynu: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) the last accord. to Sb; (M;) but some say that it is not established; (A;) and Lth says, that it is a mistake; but Az says, that it is pl. of muSoraAnN, and that the Arabs have given it this form of pl. imagining the m to be a radical letter; (TA;) and some say, that maSiyrN is of the measure mafoEilN, [originally maSoyirN,] derived from SaAr A_ilayohi AlT~aEaAmu [“ the food passed to it ”], and they say muSoraAnN in like manner as they say musolaAnN as pl. of masiylu AlmaA='i, likening mafoEilN to faEiylN: (S, TA:) miSoraAnN also is a dial. form of muSoraAnN. (Fr, Sgh, TA.) [See also maSaAr~, in art. Sr.] ― -b2- muSoraAnu AlfaArapi, (S, Msb,) or muSoraAnu AlfaA^ori, (Mgh, K,) (tropical:) A bad kind of dates. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.)
maASirN * : see miSorN; and see maA^oSirN, in art. ASr.

div2.head: mSE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 maD~a * , (A,) or maDiDa, like fariHa, (K) [but maDiDa, being contr. to rule, is probably a mistranscription, and its being said to be like fariHa may be only to indicate the form of the sec. pers. &c.,] sec. pers. maDiDota, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yamaD~u, (S, K,) inf. n. maDaDN (S, Msb, K) and maDiyDN (S, A, K) and maDaADapN, (S, K,) He suffered, or experienced, pain; (S, A, Msb, K;) mina Al$~aYo'i from the thing; (Msb;) or mina AlmuSiybapi from the calamity, or misfortune; (S, * A, K, * TA;) and mina AlkalaAmi from the speech. (A, TA.) And maDiDotu liloA^amori I experienced distress from the affair, or event. (TA.) -A2- maD~ahu: see 4, throughout.

4 AmD~hu * , (AO, Th, S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_imoDaADN; (S;) and ↓ maD~ahu (AO and the other authorities mentioned above, IDrd, A,) aor.
maDu3a , (M, Msb, TA,) inf. n. maD~N (IDrd, M, A, Msb, K) and maDiyDN; (M, A, K;) but the latter form of the verb was not known to As, (S,) and is said by Th, (S,) and by Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El- 'Alà, (IDrd,) to be obsolete; (IDrd, S;) or the former is of the dial. of Temeem; (AO;) It (a wound, Th, S, Msb, and disquietude of mind, Msb) pained him: (Th, S, Msb:) it (disquietude of mind, and grief,) burned him, and distressed him: (M, TA:) it (a thing) affected, or distressed, his heart with grief; (A, K;) and both are said also of pain, and of disquietude of
mind, and of a man beating another. (A.) You say also, AlkuHolu yumiD~u AlEayona; (S, Msb, K;) and ↓ yamuD~uhaA, (A, K,) and ↓ yamaD~uhaA; (K;) The collyrium pains the eye: (A, K:) or burns it: (S:) or pains and burns it: (TA:) or stings it by its pungency. (Msb.) And ↓ maD~a Alxal~u faAhu The vinegar burned his mouth. (IDrd, K.) And A^amaD~aniY h`*aA Alqawolu This saying distressed me. (TA.) And AmD~hu jiloduhu fadalakahu His skin itched [and he therefore rubbed it]. (M, K.)

R. Q. 1 maDomaDa * , (K,) or maDomaDa AlmaA='a fiY fiyhi, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. maDomaDapN (S, K) and miDomaADN and maDomaADN, (K,) this last is said by As to be allowable, (TA,) [He rinsed his mouth with water;] he agitated water (S, Msb, K) round about (Msb) in his mouth; (S, Msb, K;) lilowuDuwo'i for the wDw', q. v.; (K;) as also ↓ tamaDomaDa llwDw', (K,) or fiY wuDuwoy^ihi in his wDw', (S,) or biAlomaA='i ↓ tmDmD. (Msb, TA.) [See also maSomaSa.] ― -b2- maDomaDa, (As, Lh,) inf. n. maDomaDapN, (K,) also signifies He agitated a vessel [so as to rinse it, or wash it out, with water]: (As:) or he washed a vessel, (Lh, K,) or other thing; (K;) so, [for instance,] a garment, or piece of cloth; as also maSomaSahu [q. v.] (Lh.) -A2- [Hence,] maA maDomaDotu EayoniY binawomK (S, A, L) (tropical:) I did not sleep. (S, L.) And maA maDomaDato EayoniY binawomK, (L,) or ↓ maA tamaDomaDato, (A,) (tropical:) My eye did not sleep. (L.) [The inf. n.] miDomaADN also signifies (tropical:) The state of sleeping. (TA.) And maDomaDa (tropical:) He slept a long sleep. (TA.) And maDomaDa Aln~uEaAsu fiY Eayonihi (tropical:) Drowsiness crept in his eye; (TA;) and [so] Aln~uEaAsu fiY Eayonihi ↓ tamaDomaDa, (S, TA,) or Aln~awomu sleep. (A.) And ↓ tamaDomaDati AlEayonu biAln~uEaAsi (tropical:) [The eye became infused with drowsiness]. (TA.) -A3- maDomaDapN also signifies, accord. to El-Fárábee, The making, or uttering, of a sound; or the sound itself; (Sawot;) of the serpent, &c.: or, as some say, its (a serpent's) making motions with the tongue [so as to produce a sound]. (Msb.)

R. Q. 2
see R. Q. 1, in five places.

maD~N * , applied to collyrium, (L, K,) and to the style, or bodkin, with which it is applied to the eyes, (S, O,) an inf. n. used as an epithet; (O;) Paining; (K;) or burning; (O, L;) or hot. (S.) You say, kaHalahu kuHolFA maD~FA He applied to his eyes burning [or paining] collyrium. (L.) And kaHalahu bimulomuwlK maD~K He applied collyrium to his eyes with a hot, (S,) or burning, (O,) [or paining,] style. (S, O.) ― -b2- rajulN maD~u AlD~arobi A man who beats, or strikes, painfully. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) ― -b3- A_imoraA^apN maD~apN A woman who does not bear, or endure, what displeases her, or grieves her; (IAar, K;) as though it pained her, or burned her: (IAar:) or whom a small word pains: or whom a small thing hurts, or annoys. (T, TA.) [It occurs coupled with baD~apN, to which it should not be regarded as merely an imitative sequent.]
maD~apN * : see maD~N: ― -b2- and what next follows.

maDaDN * The pain of a calamity or misfortune. (S, K.) [See 1.] ― -b2- Sour milk; (K;) [so called because it bites the tongue;] and so ↓ maD~apN, (K,) and baD~apN, of the milk of camels. (Ibn-'Abbád.)
maDaADN * The state of being burned. (TA.)

muDaADN *
A pain which affects a man in the eye &c., from a thing that burns: so in the O, on the authority of IAar; but in the TS it is ↓ miDomaADN. (TA.) ― -b2- Water that is intolerable by reason of saltness. (IAar, K.)
maDiyDN * The burning of collyrium [&c.: see maD~ahu, explained with A^amaD~ahu]: (L:) and ↓ miDomaADN [in like manner] signifies a burning. (K.)

maD~aADN *
Burning: [or rather, burning much:] applied by El-'Ajjáj as an epithet to travel. (TA.)
miDomaADN * : see muDaADN: ― -b2- and maDiyDN.

1 maDaHa EiroDahu * , aor.
maDaHa , (inf. n. maDoHN; TA;) and ↓ A^amoDaHahu, (inf. n. A_imoDaAHN; TA;) He disgraced, or dishonoured, him; blasted his reputation; (El-Umawee, S, K;) imputed to him, or accused him of, a vice, or fault, or the like. (TA.)
4 A^amoDaHa see 1.

1 maDara * , aor.
maDura ; (S, A, Msb, K;) and maDira, aor.
maDara ; (A, K;) and maDura, aor.
maDura ; (K;) inf. n. muDuwrN, (S, Msb, K,) of the first, (S, Msb,) and maDorN, [also of the first,] and maDarN, [of the second;] (K;) It (milk, S, A, Msb, K, and [so in the A, but in the K or,] beverage of the kind called nabiy*, A, K) was, or became, sour, or acid: (Msb:) or sour, or acid, biting the tongue: (A:) or such as to bite the tongue; (S, TA;) before becoming raAy^ib: (TA:) or sour, or acid, and white. (K.)

2 mD~rhu * , inf. n. tamoDiyrN, He referred his lineage, or origin, to muDar [Mudar, the ancestor of most of the Arabs who trace up their genealogy to Ismá'eel, or Ishmael]: (K:) or he made him to be of the race of muDar by referring his lineage, or origin, to them. (A.) -A2- It is said, of the race of muDar, in a trad., mD~rhA All~`h fiY Aln~aAri, meaning, May God make them to be in the fire [of hell]; the verb being derived from their name: (TA:) or may God collect them together [therein]; like as one says jan~ada Aljunuwda: (Z, TA:) or destroy them; (K;) from the saying *ahaba damuhu xiDorFA miDorFA, in the first of the senses explained below: (TA:) J says, [in the S,] that its origin seems to be from muDuwru All~abani, meaning “ the biting of the tongue by milk, ” and that it is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or intensiveness. (TA.)

5 tmD~r *
He asserted himself to be related, or to belong, to the race of muDar. (A, K.) See 2. ― -b2- He entered into a league (taEaS~aba, A: in the copies of the K, tagaD~aba; but the former, with the two unpointed letters, is the right reading: TA:) with, (A,) or for, (K,) the race of muDar. (A, K.) ― -b3- He affected to be like, or imitated, or assimilated himself to, the race of muDar. (S, TA.)

*ahaba damuhu xiDorFA miDorFA * , (S, A, K,) and xaDirFA ↓ maDirFA, (K,) His blood went unrevenged, or unretaliated, or unexpiated by a mulct: (S, K:) or so as to occasion no inconvenience or trouble (haniyoy^FA mariyoy^FA) to the slayer: (A:) mDrA is an imitative sequent: Ks mentions also biDorFA, with b. (S.) ― -b2- You say also, xu*ohu xiDorFA miDorFA, (K, TA,) and ↓ xaDirFA maDirFA, (Sgh, TA, and so in the CK,) Take thou it in a fresh, or juicy, state. (K.) See also art. xDr.
maDirN * : see maADirN. -A2- xaDirFA maDirFA: see miDorFA, in two places.
muDaAru All~abani * , (TS,) or ↓ muDaArapu All~abani, (K,) What flows from milk (TS, K) when it becomes sour, or acid, and clear. (TS.)
maDiyrN * : see maADirN.
muDaArapN * : see muDaAru All~abani.

maDiyrapN *
A kind of cooked food made of [sour] milk that bites the tongue: (S:) or a small quantity of broth, or gravy, cooked with milk such as is termed maDiyr, and sometimes mixed with fresh milk: (K:) or a small quantity of broth, or gravy, cooked with milk and other things: (TA:) or, as made by the Arabs, flesh-meat cooked with pure milk that bites the tongue, until the flesh-meat is thoroughly done, and the milk has become thick; and sometimes they mix fresh milk with milk that has been collected in a skin; and in this case it is the best that can be. (AM, TA.)

maADirN * (S, A, Msb, K) and ↓ maDiyrN (A, Msb, K) and ↓ maDirN, (IAar, K,) the last thought by ISd to be a kind of relative or possessive epithet,
because the verb is maDara, (TA,) [but it seems that he was unacquainted with, or that he disallowed, the form maDira, of which it is the regular part. n.,] Milk that is sour, or acid, (A, Msb,) biting the tongue: (A:) or such as bites the tongue, (S, TA,) before becoming raAy^ib: (TA:) or that has become sour, or acid, and white. (K.)
maDoraHN * and maDoraHiY~N: see art. DrH.

div2.head: mDg &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 maT~ahu * , (S, K,) aor.
maTu3a , (S, TA,) inf. n. maT~N, (TA,) He drew it; pulled it; strained it; extended it by drawing or pulling; stretched it; stretched it out; extended it; lengthened it; i. q. mad~ahu: (S, K:) maT~N and maTowN and mad~N are all one [in meaning]. (Az, TA.) You say, maT~a Ald~alowa, (K,) or maT~a biAld~alowi, (Lh,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Lh,) He drew, or pulled, the bucket. (Lh, K.) And maT~ HaAjibayohi He extended, or stretched, his eyebrows (S, TA) in speaking. (TA.) This last phrase also signifies (tropical:) He behaved proudly; (S, K, TA;) and so maT~a xad~ahu; (K, TA;) syn. takab~ara [for which in the CK we find takab~urFA]. (S, K.) You say also, maT~a A^aSaAbiEahu He extended his fingers, (K, TA,) as though (TA) talking, or addressing, with them. (K, TA.) And maT~a AlHuruwfa [He lengthened the letters]; for mad~ahaA. (As, in TA, in remarks on the letter T.) And maT~a xaT~ahu, and xaTowahu, He extended, and made wide, his handwriting, and his stepping: and maT~a [alone], aor. and inf. n. as above, [xaTowahu being understood,] he made his stepping wide. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., of Saad, laA tamuT~uwA bA=miyna Ye shall not lengthen [the word] A=miynu [amen: yet this is done by most, if not by all, of the Muslims in the present day]. (TA.)
2 tamoTiyTN * , [inf. n. of mT~T, and app. originally meaning The act of lengthening the tongue overmuch:] (tropical:) the act of reviling. (K, TA.)

5 tmT~T *
He stretched himself: he walked with an elegant, and a proud, and self-conceited, gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side, and stretching out his arms; syn. tamad~ada; (S, K;) as also tamaT~aY; like taZan~ayotu from AlZ~an~u; tmT~T being the original form. (TA.) It is said in the Kur, [lxxv. 33,] vum~a *ahaba A_ilaY A^aholihi yatamaT~aY Then he went to his family walking with an elegant, and a proud, and self-conceited, gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side; syn. yatabaxotaru; (Fr, Bd, Jel, TA;) from AlmaT~u, because he who so walks extends his steps, so that it is originally yatamaT~aTu; (Bd;) or from AlmaTaA, signifying “ the back, ” because he who so walks twists his back. (Fr, Bd.) ― -b2- It (water, As, TA, and thick sour milk, TA) roped, or drew out, with a viscous, glutinous, cohesive, sticky, ropy, or slimy, continuity of parts; it was, or became, viscous, glutinous, cohesive, sticky, ropy, or slimy. (As, TA.) [See also R, Q, 2.] ― -b3- tmT~T fiY AlkalaAmi He varied (law~ana) in speech. (Sgh, K.)

R. Q. 1 maTomaTa fiY kalaAmihi *
He extended, and lengthened, his speech: (IDrd:) or maTomaTa signifies he flagged in his handwriting, or in his speech. (IAar, Az, K.)

R. Q. 2 tamaTomaTa *
It (water) became thick. (Sgh, K.) [See also 5.]
muTuTN * [a pl., of which the sing. is probably ↓ maTiyTN, like as the sing. of its syn. mududN is madiydN,] Tall, or long; applied to any animals. (IAar.)

maTaATN *
Thick and sour camels' milk; (Ibn- 'Abbád, K;) such as is termed qaAriS; so called because it ropes, or is ropy. (TA.)
muTaATN * : see what next follows.

miTaATN *
Extended; [meaning long;] as also ↓ muTaATN, and ↓ maTaAy^iTN; applied as an epithet to what is termed SalFA [app. here meaning the “ middle of the back ”]; (K;) and to a camel. (TA.)
maTiyTN * : see muTuTN.

maTiyTapN *
thick water, (S,) or turbid and thick water, (K, TA,) remaining (TA) in the bottom of a watering-trough: (S, K, TA:) or slime; or strong, or thick, slime: or, accord. to As, water in which is ropy mud: pl. maTaAy^iTu: which, as pl. of the same sing., also signifies places hollowed by the feet of beasts of carriage, in the ground, in which slime, or strong or thick slime, collects. (TA.)
muTayoTaY * : see what next follows.
maTiyTaA='u * : see what next follows.

muTayoTaA='u * , a dim. n. which has no undiminished form, (Z, in the Fáïk,) The act of walking with an elegant, and a proud, and self-conceited, gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side: and the act of stretching out the arms in walking: (S, K:) as also ↓ muTayoTaY, (As, Kr, K,) in both these senses, (As, TA,) and ↓ maTiyTaA='u. (K.) You say, ma$aY AlmuTayoTaA='a [He walked in either of the manners above described]. (S, TA.)
muTaAy^iTN * : see miTaATu.

1 maTaA^a * , aor.
maTaAa , Inivit feminam. (Ibn-ElFaraj, K.)
maTovN * : see art. Tv.
See Supplement

1 maTarati Als~amaA='u * , aor.
maTura , inf. n. maTarN, [The sky, or, as it sometimes means, the rain,] rained; as also ↓ A^amoTarat: (T, S, Msb:) but the former is said to relate to that which is sent in mercy, and the latter to that which is sent in punishment. (Msb.) See also what follows. ― -b2- [Both are also trans. You say,] maTaratohumu Als~amaA='u, (A, K,) aor.
maTura , (TA,) inf. n. maTorN and maTarN; (K:) and ↓ A^amoTaratohum, (A, TA,) which latter is the worse form, [as will be seen below,] The sky rained upon them. (A, K, TA.) And muTironaA We were rained upon; we had rain. (S. TA,) ― -b3- You say also, maTarahumo xayorN, and $ar~N, (tropical:) [Good, and evil, poured upon them; or betided them]. (A.) And maTaraniY bixayorK (tropical:) He did good to me. (K.) And maA maTaraniY bixayorK (tropical:) [He did not any good to me]. (A.) And maA muTira minohu xayorFA, [in the CK, incorrectly, xayorN,] and bixayorK, (tropical:) Good did not betide him from him, or it. (K, TA.) But ↓ A^amoTarahumu A@ll~`hu is only said in relation to punishment: (K, TA:) as in the saying in the Kur, [xxvi. 173, and xxvii. 59,] Ealayohimo ↓ waA^amoTaronaA maTarFA fasaA='a maTaru A@lomuno*ariyna (tropical:) [And we rained upon them a rain, and evil was the rain of the warned people]: and again in the Kur, [xv. 74,] Ealayohimo HijaArapF mino sij~iylK ↓ waA^amoTaronaA (tropical:) [And we rained upon them stones of baked clay]: the stones being regarded as rain because of their descent from the sky: some, however, hold that maTara and ↓ A^amaTara are the same in meaning. (TA.) -A2- mar~a Alfarasu yamoTuru, inf. n. maTorN (S, A) and ↓ muTuwrN; (S;) and ↓ yatamaT~aru; (S, A;) (tropical:) The horse passed, or went, running vehemently, like the pouring of rain: (A:) or went quickly; or hastened; (S;) as also maTara Alfarasu, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. ns.: (K:) or this last signifies the horse was quick in his passing, or going, and in his running; and so ↓ tmT~r. (TA.) You say also, bihi farasuhu ↓ tamaT~ara (A, TA) (tropical:) His horse ran, and hastened, or went quickly, with him. (TA.) And maTarati AlT~ayoru, and ↓ tmT~rt, (tropical:) The birds hastened, or were quick, in their descent. (K.) And Alxayolu ↓ tmT~rt (tropical:) The horses came, (K, TA,) and went, quickly, (TA,) outstripping one another. (K, TA.) ― -b2- maTara fiY AlA^aroDi, inf. n. muTuwrN; and ↓ tmT~r; (tropical:) He (a man) went away in, or into, the country, or land; (S, K;) and hastened; as also qaTara. (TA, art. qTr.) ― -b3- *ahaba AlbaEiyru famaA A^adoriY mano maTara bihi
(S, K *) (tropical:) [The camel has gone away, and I know not who has gone with it, or] has taken it: (K:) and in like manner, *ahaba vawobiY Alx (tropical:) my garment has gone, &c. (TA.)

4 A^amoTara see 1, in four places. ― -b2- AmTr A@ll~`hu Als~amaA='a God made the sky to rain. (S, Msb.) ― -b3- AmTr AlmakaAna He found the place rained upon. (Sgh, K.) ― -b4- A^amoTaronaA We were in rain. (TA.) -A2- kal~amotuhu faA^amoTara, (Mubtekir El-Kilábee, A, K, *) and ↓ A_istmTra, (Mubtekir, A,) (tropical:) I spoke to him, and he lowered his eyes, looking towards the ground, (A^aToraq, Mubtekir, A, K, [which also signifies he was silent, not speaking, but accord. to the TA, (see 10,) should not be so rendered here,]) and his forehead sweated. (A, K.)

5 tmT~r *
He exposed himself to the rain: (A, K:) or he went out to the rain and its cold. (K.) -A2- See also 10, in two places. -A3- See also 1, in five places.

10 AstmTr *
He asked, or begged, or prayed, for rain; (S, Msb, TA;) as also ↓ tmT~r. (TA.) You say xarajuwA yasotamoTiruwna A@ll~`ha, and ↓ yatamaT~aruwnahu, [They went forth praying to God for rain.] (A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AstmTrhu (tropical:) He sought, desired, or demanded, his beneficence, or bounty; (A, TA;) he asked him to give like rain. (S.) ― -b3- [And hence, perhaps,] AstmTr lils~iyaATi (assumed tropical:) He endured patiently the whips [as though he desired that the stripes should fall like rain upon him]. (TA.) ― -b4- And AstmTr (assumed tropical:) He was silent; he did not speak [when spoken to, as though he desired that words should pour upon him like rain]: in the K, this meaning is assigned to A^amoTara, which should not be used in this sense: see also musotamoTirN; and see 4. (TA.) ― -b5- AlmaAlu yasotamoTiru (tropical:) [The camels, or sheep, &c.,] go out to the rain. (A.) See also 5. ― -b6- AstmTr (tropical:) He (a man) sough shelter from the rain. (TA.) ― -b7- AstmTr vawobahu He (a man) put on his garment in the rain. (Ibn-Buzurj.)

maTarN *
Rain: (A, Msb, K, TA:) pl. A^amoTaArN. (S, A, Msb, K.) See maTorapN: and see also ZahorN, p. 1929, a.
maTirN * : see maATirN: ― -b2- and see also mamoTuwrN.
maTorapN * [A rain; a shower of rain]. (A; and S, K, voce magorapN, &c.) You say maTorapN mubaArakapN [A blessed rain.] (A.) See maTarN. -A2- See also maTarapN.

maTarapN * , (Fr, Sgh, K, also mentioned in the L, on the authority of IAar, and in such a manner as implies that it may be also ↓ maTorapN, TA,) A [skin of the kind called] qirobap: (K, &c.:) applied in the present day to an A_idaAwap and the like: (TA:) [I have found it now applied to a large bottle of leather, and of wood: pl. A^amoTaArN.]
maTirapN * : see EaTirN.
maToraAnN * [sometimes pronounced miToraAnN, and muToraAnN, A metropolitan]: see jaAvaliyqN.
maTiyrN * : see mamoTuwrN: ― -b2- and maATirN.
maT~aArN * (tropical:) A horse that runs vehemently. (K, TA.)

maATirN * . ― -b2- samaA='N maATirapN, (A, Msb,) and ↓ mumoTirapN, (A,) A raining sky. (A, Msb.) See also mimoTaArN. ― -b3- yawomN maATirN, (A, K,) and ↓ mumoTirN, (K,) and ↓ maTiyr, (A,) and ↓ maTirN, (K,) which last is a possessive epithet, (TA,) (tropical:) A day of rain. (A, K.) -A2- See also mutamaT~irN.
mamoTarN * : see what next follows.

mimoTarN * (S, K) and ↓ mamoTarN and ↓ mimoTarapN (K) What is worn in rain, to protect one; (S;) a garment of wool, (K,) worn in rain, (TA,) by which to protect one's self from the rain; (K;) from Lh. (TA.)
mumoTirN * and mumoTirapN: see maATirN.
mimoTarapN * : see mimoTarN.

samaA='N mimoTaArN *
A sky pouring down abundance of rain. (A.) See also maATirN.

mamoTuwrN * (tropical:) A place, (K,) and a valley, (A,) rained upon, or watered by rain; as also ↓ maTiyrN; (A, K, TA;) and ↓ maTirN, as in a verse cited voce xaTowapN: and so ↓ maTiyrN and ↓ maTiyrapN applied to a land (A^aroDN). (TA.)

xaraja mutamaT~irFA *
He went forth into the gardens and fields after rain. (A.) -A2- TaAy^irN mutamaT~irN (tropical:) A bird hastening, or going quickly, (S, TA,) in its descent; (TA;) [as also ↓ maATirN, of which the pl., muT~arN, occurs in the following ex.:] Ru-beh says,
waAlT~ayoru tahowiY fiY Als~amaA='i muT~arFA
[And the birds descend in the sky, hastening]. (TA.) mutamaT~irN is also applied to a horseman, as signifying hastening, or going quickly. (S.)

musotamoTarN * (tropical:) A man [from whom beneficence, or bounty, is sought, or desired: and hence,] naturally disposed to beneficence, or bounty. (IAar, TA.) -A2- (tropical:) A place that is open and uncovered. (A, K.)

musotamoTirN * [Asking, begging, or praying, for rain. ― -b2- Hence,] (tropical:) Seeking, desiring, or demanding, beneficence, or bounty, (Lth, K,) from a man. (Lth.) You say, maA A^anaA mino HaAjatiY Einodaka bimusotamoTirK (tropical:) I am not covetous of obtaining from thee the object of my want. (IAar.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A place needing rain. (A, K.) ― -b4- (tropical:) Silent; not speaking [when spoken to, as though desiring that words should pour upon him like rain]. (K.) -A2- [One] on whom rain has fallen. (K.)

div2.head: mTs &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

maZ~N * The pomegranate-tree: (K:) or the wild pomegranate, (As, T, S, M,) or the wild pomegranate-tree: (Lth, M, K:) or a sort of pomegranate (IDrd) that grows in the mountains of the saraAp, not producing fruit, but only blossoms, (IDrd, K,) and these in abundance: (IDrd *) in its blossoms is honey, (K,) in abundance, (TA,) and they are sucked: (K:) it produces blossoms, but does not form fruit, and the bees eat them, and yield good honey therefrom: AHn says, it grows in the mountains, and produces many blossoms, but does not mature its produce, (laA yurab~iY,) but its blossoms have much honey: (M:) it has fire-wood of the best quality, the most excellent thereof in yielding fire, and it is made to flame like candles: Es-Sukkaree says, it is the wild pomegranate, which bees eat, and it produces only leaves, having no pomegranates: the n. un. is with p. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, i. q. damu AlA^axawayoni, which is the same as damu AlgazaAli, (AHeyth, K,) called in the present day AlqaATiru Almak~iY~u (TA) [and qaToru mak~apa, i. e. the red, resinous, inspissated juice which we call dragon's blood.] ― -b3- Also, The expressed juice of the roots of the A^aroTaY, (K, TA,) which are red, the tree itself being green, and which, when camels eat them, cause their lips to become red. (TA.) ― -b4- [Forskal, in his Flora, page ciii., mentions The dianthera trisulca as called in El-Yemen mD or mZ.]
See Supplement

1 maEata * , aor.
maEata , (inf. n. maEotN, TA,) He rubbed (K) a skin, or hide. (TA.)

1 maEaja * , aor.
maEaja , inf. n. maEojN, He, or it, (a horse, and the wind, S, and a torrent, TA,) went quickly, or swiftly. (S, K.) See art. Emj. ― -b2- mar~a yamoEaju He (a horse) went at an easy pace: (S:) and in like manner maEajato she (a camel) went at an easy pace. (Th.) ― -b3- maEajati Alr~iyHu, aor.
maEaja , inf. n. maEojN, The wind blew gently. (IAth.) ― -b4- Alr~iyHu tamoEaju fiY Aln~abaAti The wind turns over the herbage to the right and left. (IAth.) ― -b5- maEaja fY sayorihi He inclined, in his course in every direction, by reason of his sprightliness. (TA.) ― -b6- maEaja, aor.
maEaja , inf. n. maEojN, He affected various modes in running: he (a horse) pressed against one of the branches of
the bit, and then against the other, now on the right and now on the left; [inclining in his run now to the right and now to the left, by reason of his sprightliness: see maE~aAjN]. (TA.) ― -b7- maEaja AlfaSiylu DaroEa A^um~ihi, (aor.
maEaja , inf. n. maEojN, TA,) The young weaned camel struck its head against its mother's udder, and inverted (as in the S, or opened, as in the K) its mouth around it, in order to suck: (S, K,) as also magaja. (TA, arts. mEj and mgj.)

farasN maEuwjN *
A swift horse. (S.) riyHN maEuwjN A wind swift in its course. (TA.) ― -b2- farasN maEuwjN, and ↓ mimEajN, A horse that often affects various modes in running: that often presses against one of the branches of the bit, and then against the other, now on the right and now on the left; [inclining in his run now to the right and now to the left, by reason of his sprightliness]. (TA.) [In like manner,] ↓ HimaArN maE~aAjN An ass that inclines in his run to the right and left by reason of his sprightliness. (TA.)
maE~aAjN * and mimoEajN: see maEuwjN.

1 maEadahu * , aor.
maEada , (inf. n. maEodN; L,) and ↓ AmtEdhu; He snatched it unawares; seized it hastily when its owner was unawares: (L, K:) or he seized it and took it away; snatched it away; took it away quickly by force. (L.) ― -b2- Also, ↓ both verbs, He drew, or pulled, it: (L:) or drew, or pulled, it quickly. (S, L, K.) Ex. maEada Ald~alowa, and maEada bihaA, and ↓ AmtEdhA, He drew up, or pulled up, the bucket: or drew, or pulled, it out, or forth, from the well. And maEada Alr~umoHa and ↓ AmtEdhu, He pulled forth the spear from the place where it was stuck in the ground. And sayofahu ↓ AmtEd He drew forth his sword from its scabbard. (L.) ― -b3- maEada bihi, aor.
maEada , inf. n. maEodN and muEuwdN, He took it (a thing) away; carried it off; went away with it. (K.) ― -b4- Hence, maEada bixuSoyayohi He removed his testicles; (L, TA;) or he pulled them; as also maEada humaA. (Lh, L, TA.) ― -b5- maEadahu He took it (namely, flesh,) with his fore-teeth. (K.) ― -b6- maEadahu He plucked it out; namely, hair; as also magadahu. (L.) -A2- muEida, (L, K,) and maEida, aor.
maEada , inf. n. maEodN and maEadN, (IKtt,) He (a man, L,) had a diseased, or disordered, stomach, so that he did not find his food wholesome: (L, K:) or his stomach pained him. (Ibn-T reef.) ― -b2- maEadahu He, or it, hit, or hurt, his maEidap, or stomach. (L, K.) -A3- maEada fiY AlA^aroDi, (aor.
maEada , inf. n. maEodN and muEuwdN, L,) He went away journeying through the land, or earth. (S, L, K.)
8 A_imotaEada see 1 in five places.

R. Q. 2 tamaEodada *
He assumed the garb, dress, habit, or external appearance, of the sons of Ma'add: mentioned also in art. Ed [which see for other explanations not repeated here]: (K:) he endured with patience their mode of life in travel and in a fixed residence: (Lth, L:) and he subjected himself to a hard, or difficult life: said to be not derived from any other word. (L.) ― -b2- tamaEodada He became numbered among the sons of Ma'add. (L.) ― -b3- It (a people or party) removed from Ma'add to El-Yemen, and then returned. (Lth, L.) ― -b4- (tropical:) He became big, bulky, gross, or coarse, and fat: (Lh, TA:) (tropical:) he (a boy) became big, bulky, gross, or coarse, and hard, and lost the freshness and tenderness of youth. (A.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) He (an emaciated man) began to become fat. (K.) ― -b6- He (assumed tropical:) (a sick man) became convalescent. (K.)

nazoEN maEodN *
A quick pulling up, or out, of the bucket from a well: (IAar, S, * L:) or a strong pulling up, or out; as though the bucket were pulled up from the bottom of the well: or a pulling up, or out, by means of the pulley, (L,) [and therefore quick]. -A2- maEodN Bigness; bulkiness; grossness; coarseness. (K.) ― -b2- Big; bulky; gross; coarse; (ISd, L, K,) and strong: (ISd:) applied to a thing. (ISd, L.) ― -b3- A quick, or swift, camel. (S, K.) ― -b4- Fresh, and soft, or tender; applied to a leguminous plant; (L, K;) fresh and juicy; applied to the same, (S,) and to fruit. (L, K.) ― -b5- ruTabapN maEodapN, and ↓ mutamaE~idapN, A fresh and juicy ripe date. (L, K.) ― -b6- In the phrase busorN vaEodN maEodN, mEd signifies Fresh and soft or tender: (S, L:) or it is a mere imitative sequent, (S, L, K,) not used alone. (S, L.) See art. vEd.
maEodapN * , miEodapN, miEidapN: see maEidapN.

maEidapN * and miEodapN (S, L, Msb, K) and maEodapN and miEidapN; (TA;) the first of which is the original form; (Msb, TA;) the second and third being contractions; and the fourth, as well as the others, mentioned by Expositors of the Fs.; (TA;) The stomach of a human being; the place in which is the food before it descends into the lower intesstines, or guts; (L, K;) in a man, what the kari$ is in every ruminating animal; (S, L;) or in animals that have cloven hoofs, and such as have feet like those of the camel: (M, L, K:) accord. to ISd, from maEodN, applied to a thing, signifying “ strong, and big, bulky, gross, or coarse: ” (TA:) pl. maEidN (L, K) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n., of which maEidapN is the n. un.,] and miEadN: (L, Msb, K:) the latter as though formed from miEodapN. (L.)

maEad~N * The side (L, K) of a man, &c.: (L:) or, in a horse, the part of each side between the lower portion of the shoulder-blade and the extremity of the ribs, consisting of thick and compact flesh behind the shoulder-blade; the protuberance whereof is approved, because, when that part is narrow, it compresses the heart: (L:) or, in a horse, the part between the head of each shoulder-blade and the hinder extremity of the portion of flesh and sinew next the back-bone: (L, K:) and the flesh that is beneath the shoulderblade, (L, K,) or a little below it; which is the best of the flesh of the side: (L:) and the place of the horseman's heel: (L, K:) or the part of a beast of carriage which is the place of the rider's leg: (Lh, L:) and the belly: (Aboo-'Alee, L, K:) also, a vein in the part of a horse called manosij. (L, K.) See also art. Ed.
maAEidN * : see what follows.
mimoEadN * (L, K) and ↓ maAEid (L) A wolf that runs quickly. (L, K.)
mamoEuwdN * A man having a diseased, or disordered, stomach, so that he does not find his food wholesome: (L:) having a bad stomach. (A.)
mutamaE~idapN * : see maEodN.

1 maEira * , [aor.
maEara , inf. n. maEarN,] said of a man, (S,) and of the head, and of the tail, (TA,) His or its hair fell off; (S, TA;) as also ↓ tmE~r, said of the head: (TA:) and the former said of the head, its hair became little, or scanty. (TA:) and maEirato, said of the forelock, (Aln~aASiyap, K,) or of that of a horse, (TA,) it lost all its hair: (K:) and maEira, said of a solid hoof, it lost the hair that hung down upon it from the fore part of the pastern. (TA.) ― -b2- maEira, (A, K,) aor.
maEara , (K,) inf. n. maEarN, (S, TA,) said of hair, (S, A, K,) and of plumage, and the like, (K,) It fell off; (S, A;) as also ↓ tmE~r, said of hair: (S, A:) or it became little, or scanty; as also ↓ A^amoEara: (K:) and, said of a finger-nail, or toe-nail, (tropical:) it came out, or fell out, (A, K,) in consequence of something befalling it, or hurting it. (K.) See maEar~apN in art. Er. ― -b3- [Hence,] maEira, (TA,) or maEira mino maAlihi, (A,) (tropical:) He became poor; (A, TA;) as also ↓ A^amoEara, (S, A,) inf. n. A_imoEaArN; (TA;) or the latter, he became poor, and his travelling-provisions failed or became exhausted; as also ↓ mE~r, inf. n. tamoEiyrN. (K.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] AlA^aroDu ↓ A^amoEarati (tropical:) The land became destitute of herbage: or its herbage became little, or scanty: (K:) contr. of A^amoraEat. (IKtt.)
2 maE~ara see 1.

4 A^amoEara see 1, in the three places. ― -b2- A^amoEaronaA (tropical:) We came upon a land destitute of herbage: (A, TA:) or we found dearth, scarcity, drought, or sterility: (TA:) and AmEr Alqawomu the people became afflicted with dearth, scarcity, drought, or sterility. (TA.) -A2-
AmErt AlmawaA$iY AlA^aroDa (tropical:) The beasts pastured upon the land, (i. e., its trees or herbs, TA,) and left no pasturage in it. (TS, L, K.) ― -b2- AmErhu (assumed tropical:) He despoiled him of his property, (K, TA,) and reduced him to poverty. (TA.)
5 tamaE~ara see 1, in two places.

maEirN * A man, (S,) and a head, (A,) whose hair is falling off, or has fallen off; (S, A;) as also ↓ A^amoEaru and ↓ mutamaE~irN: (A:) or having little hair; (TA;) as also ↓ A^amoEaru: (S:) and the first and second, a camel's foot (xuf~) of which the hair (both $aEar and wabar) has gone: and ↓ maEoraA='u, a forelock (naASiyap, K, or that of a horse, TA,) of which all the hair has gone. (K.) ― -b2- Hair, and plumage, and the like, little in quantity, or scanty; as also ↓ A^amoEaru: and the latter, hair falling off. (K.) ― -b3- [Hence,] (tropical:) A man who is niggardly, or avaricious, having little beneficence; (K;) unpropitious, mean, and hard, or difficult. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A man having little flesh. (TA.) ― -b5- qaAEN maEirN, and A^aroDN maEirapN, (tropical:) A plain, and land, destitute of herbage: (A:) or the latter, accord. to Yaakoob, land having little herbage: and ↓ makaAnN A^amoEaru a place having little herbage. (S.)

A^amoEaru * : fem. maEoraA='u: see maEirN, throughout. -A2- Also, of a solid hoof, (assumed tropical:) The hair that hangs down upon it (K, TA) from the fore part of the pastern: because it has a disposition to fall off. (TA.)
mutamaE~irN * : see maEirN.

1 maEiza Al$~aYo'u * , [and maEizati AlA^aroDu, accord. to the explanation of the inf. n. in the S,] aor.
maEaza , (TK,) inf. n. maEazN, (S, K, TK,) The thing [and the ground] was, or became, hard. (S, * K, * TK.) -A2- maEiza said of a man: see 4. -A3- maEazotu AlmiEozaY, waDaA^anotu AlD~aA^ona, aor.
maEaza , I set apart the goats from the sheep. (K.)

4 AmEz *
He, (a man, A,) or it, (a people, S,) became abundant in goats; his or its, goats became abundant, or numerous; (S, A, K;) as also, ↓ maEiza, aor.
maEaza , (K,) inf. n. maEazN. (TK.)

maEozN * , and ↓ maEazN, (S, A, Msb, K,) gen. ns., (S, Msb,) [or rather quasi-pl. ns., signifying Goats;] the kind of ganam opposed to DaA^onN; (S, A, K;) the kind of Eanam that have hair; (Msb, TA;) the DA^on being those that have wool; (TA;) as also ↓ miEozFY, (S, Msb, K,) accord. to Sb, (S,) with tenween, (S, Msb,) when indeterminate, (Msb,) and perfectly decl., (S,) the A [which is written Y] being a letter of quasicoördination, not a characteristic of the fem. gender, (S, Msb,) for the word is quasi-coördinate to dirohamN, of the measure fiEolalN; for the A of quasi-coördination follows the same rules as a letter belonging to the word itself, as is shown by their saying ↓ muEayozK and A^urayoTK [originally muEayoziYN and A^urayoTiYN] as the dim. forms of miEozFY and A^aroTFY with tenween, the letter next after the Y of diminution being with kesr, like as they say durayohimN; for if the A were to denote the fem. gender they would not change it into Y [in muEayoziYN, the original form of muEayozK,] like as they do not change it in the dims. of HubolaY and A^axoraY [which are HubayolaY and A^uxayozaY]: (S:) it is sometimes made fem., [by being written or pronounced miEozaApN,] and sometimes it is made imperfectly decl. [and therefore without tenween]: (K:) Fr says, that it is [itself] fem., but that some make it masc. [and therefore with tenween]: but A 'Obeyd says, that most of the Arabs pronounce *iforaY without tenween, while some of them pronounce it with tenween, whereas all of them pronounce miEozFY with tenween: (S:) IAar says, that it is perfectly decl. when likened to the measure mifoEalN, and imperfectly decl. when held to accord. with the measure fiEolaY: (TA:) accord. to Aboo-'Amr, Ibn-El-'Alà, it is from maEazN, [inf. n. of maEiza,] and in like manner *iforaY is from *afarN: (As, S:) ↓ maEiyzN also signifies the same as maEozN, (S, A, K,) or is pl. of maEozN, [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] like as EabiydN is of EabodN; (Msb;) and ↓ A^umoEuwzN also is syn. with maEozN, (S, K,) and so are ↓ miEaAzN (K) and ↓ miEozaA='N: (Sgh, K:) [respecting A^umoEuwzN, see also below:] maEozN [as well as its syns. mentioned above, like all quasi-pl. ns., is sometimes masc., but generally] is fem.: (Msb:) a male is called ↓ maAEizN, (S, A, Msb, K,) and so a female; (Msb, K;) or a female is called ↓ maAEizapN (S, A, TA) [and ↓ maEozapN (M, voce $aroqaA='u)] and ↓ miEozaAp; (TA;) and $aApN [or rather $aApN mina AlmaEozi] is also used as a sing., (Msb,) and is applied to a male and to a female: (Msb, art. $wh:) [see also ZaboYN:] A^amoEuzN is a pl. [of pauc.] of maEozN, like as A^aEobudN is of EabodN: (Msb:) the pl. of ↓ maAEizN, (K,) or of maAEizapN, (S,) is mawaAEizu; (S, K;) and ↓ miEaAzN and ↓ A^umoEuwzN are said to be quasi-pl. ns. (TA.) The goats of the Arabs of the desert have short hair, not long enough to be spun; but the goats of the cold countries, and of the people of the fertile regions, have abundant hair, and of this the Akrád [or Kurds] fabricate their tents. (T in art. bnY.) See also tadomuriY~N in art. dmr; and see DaAy^inN in art. DA^n.
maEozapN * : see their syn. maEozN.
miEozFY * : see their syn. maEozN.
miEozaA='N * : see their syn. maEozN.
miEozaApN * a fem. sing. of maEozN, q. v. (TA.)
miEaAzN * : see their syn. maEozN.
maEiyzN * : see their syn. maEozN.
muEayozK * dim. of miEozoY, syn. of maEozN, q. v. (Sb, S.)

maE~aAzN *
A possessor, or master, of miEozFY [or goats]. (S, K.)
maAEizN * and maAEizapN sings. of maEozN, q. v. (S, K. *) ― -b2- The former also signifies Goats' skin. (S, K.)

A^amoEazu * , and its fem. maEozaA='u, applied respectively to a place (makaAnN) and to land or ground (A^aroDN), (tropical:) Hard, (S, K,) and abounding with pebbles: (S:) or both, [used as substs.,] rugged and stony ground: (A:) or a place abounding with pebbles, and hard: or the latter, small pebbles: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) thus A 'Obeyd explains a sing. as having a pl. signification: (TA:) or the latter, a desert, (SaHoraA=') in which is elevation and ruggedness, consisting of soil, or clay, and pebbles, mixed together, but hard ground, rough to the tread: (ISh, TA:) pl. muEozN, (K,) [a pl. of each as an epithet, or of each used as a subst.,] because imagined to have the character of an epithet; (TA;) and A^amaAEizu, [a pl. of the former,] because the character of a subst. predominates in it; and maEozaAwaAtN, a pl. of the latter. (TA.)

A^umoEuwzN * : see its syn. maEozN. ― -b2- It also signifies, (K,) or is said to signify, (S,) A herd of gazelles, (S, K,) in number from thirty to forty; (S, TA;) or from thirty upwards: or a number of buckgazelles collected together: (TA:) or a number of A^awoEaAl [or mountain-goats] collected together: (A, K:) or of AwEAl such as are termed vayaAtil: (Az, TA:) pl. A^amaAEiyzu and A^amaAEizu. (K.)

1 maEiTa * , (S, K,) aor.
maEaTa , (K,) inf. n. maEaTN, (S,) He (a man) was, or became, without hair upon his body: (S:) and in like manner you say of a man's skin: (TA:) and of a wolf, meaning his hair fell off by degrees, or part after part: but you should not say maEiTa $aEaruhu: (S:) [but see 5:] or, said of a wolf, it signifies he was, or became, mischievous, malignant, or foul; syn. xabuva: or his hair became scanty, or little, (K,) and ↓ tmE~T said of a wolf, his hair fell off: (Mgh, Msb:) and ↓ A_im~aEaTa, (S, K,) of the measure A_ifotaEala, or
[rather] A_inofaEala, (accord. to different copies of the K,) said of a rope, (S, K,) &c., (S,) it became worn smooth. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also 5. -A2- maEaTa, aor.
maEaTa , (K,) inf. n. maEoTN, (TA,) He plucked out hair [or wool] (K, TA,) from the head of a sheep or goat. (TA.)

5 tmE~T *
It (hair, S, Msb, [in the TA, Alrjl is inadvertently put for Al$Er, and copied in the TK, with the addition of $Erh in the explanation,]) fell off by degrees, or part after part, (S, Msb, K, TA,) upon the ground, (TA,) by reason of disease, (S, K, TA,) or the like; (S;) as also ↓ AmtET, (S,) and ↓ A_im~aEaTa, (S, K,) of the measure A_ifotaEala, (K,) or [rather] of the measure A_inofaEala [originally A_inomaEaTa]: (S:) and [accord. to some, but see 1, above,] ↓ maEiTa, aor.
maEaTa , (Msb,) inf. n. maEaTN, (Mgh, Msb,) it (hair) fell off. (Mgh, Msb.) You say also, tamaE~aTato A^awobaAruhu His fur became scattered. (K, TA) ― -b2- See also 1.
7 A_im~aEaTa * , [said in the S, and in one place in a copy of the K, to be of the measure A_inofaEala]: see 1: ― -b2- and 5.
8 AmtET * and A_im~aEaTa [which latter is said in one place in the copies of the K, to be of the measure A_ifotaEala]: see 5: ― -b2- and for the latter, see also 1.
maEiTN * : see A^amoEaTu.

A^abuw muEoTapa *
The wolf: (K:) a gen. proper name thereof; similar to *uw^aAlapu and A^usaAmapu and vuEaAlapu. (TA.)

A^amoEaTu * , applied to a man, Having no hair upon his body; (S, K;) or whose hair has fallen off; fem. maEoTaA='u: (Msb:) [and pl. muEoTN:] and, applied to a wolf, whose hair has fallen off by degrees, or part after part: (S:) or, thus applied, mischievous, malignant, or foul: [see 1:] or whose hair has become scanty, or little: as also ↓ maEiTN: (K:) and maEoTaA='u, applied to a she-wolf, has the former of the last two significations: and, applied to a ewe, it signifies whose wool has fallen off. (TA.) ― -b2- liS~N A^amoEaTu (tropical:) A mischievous, malignant or foul, or wolf-like, thief, or robber; (S, * L;) likened to the wolf termed AmET: pl. muEoTN. (S, L.) ― -b3- A^amoEaTu applied to sand, (K,) and maEoTaA='u applied to a tract or collection of sand (ramolapN), (TA,) and to land (A^aroDN), (K,) and muEoTN applied to sands (rimaAlN), (K,) also signify (tropical:) Destitute of herbage. (K, TA.) ― -b4- Also A^amoEaTu [app. applied to sand or the like], Extended upon the face of the earth or ground. (TA.) ― -b5- And AlmaEoTaA='u, (IAar, K,) as a subst., (IAar,) The pudendum; syn. Als~awo'apu. (IAar, K.)

div2.head: mEq &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 magava * , (S,) aor.
maguva , (TK,) inf. n. magovN, (K,) He steeped, soaked, or macerated, a thing in water, and rubbed it with the fingers; he steeped it in water, and mashed it with the hand; (TA;) he steeped, and mashed with the hand, medicine in water; syn. marava. (S, K. *) ― -b2- magava AlmaTaru AlkalaA^a inf. n. magovN, The rain fell upon the herbage, and rendered it yellow, and bad-tasted, and laid it prostrate. (TA.) ― -b3- magava, [aor.
maguva ,] He submerged, or immersed, him, or it, in water. (K.) ― -b4- mugiva He was affected by a fever. (TA.) ― -b5- magavatohu AlHum~aY The fever attacked him; or pained him. (TA.) ― -b6- magavuwhu, [aor.
maguva ,] (S,) inf. n. magavN, (K,) They beat him lightly, (S, K, *) as though they shook him about (kaA^an~ahumo talotaluwhu). (S.) ― -b7- magava EiroDahu, (inf. n. magovN, K,) He defamed him; disgraced him; dishonoured him; (S, K;) aspersed him by reviling. (TA.) ― -b8- magavahumo bi$ar~K He did evil to them. (TA.)
3 maAgavaA * , inf. n. migaAvN and mumaAgavapN, They clashed, and contended, each against the other; syn. HaAk~aA waxaASamaA. (K.)

magovN *
Evil, as a subst. (K.) ― -b2- Conflict, (K,) and engagement of brave men in war, in the field of battle. (TA.) ― -b3- A struggling in wrestling. (TA.) See magivN. ― -b4- Play; syn. EabavN. (K.) One of the additions of F. (TA.)

magivN * , (S, K,) or ↓ magovN, (L,) and ↓ mumaAgivN, (L,) A strong wrestler. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also, the latter, A man pertinacious in altercation. (TA.) ― -b3- magivN and ↓ magiyvN An evil, a wicked, or malignant, man: after the manner of a rel. n. [denoting habitual state or action, and the like]. (TA.)

mugaAvN * The lightest, or slightest, of the diseases incident to camels. (El-Hejeree.) ― -b2- Also, A certain tree, two carats' weight (qiyraATaAni) of the root of which is an emetic and laxative: (K:) or, as in one copy [of the K], a certain plant, in the root of which is a poisonous quality (smyp [i. e., sum~iy~ap]); the drinking of a grain of it [in water] causes looseness of the bowels, and vomiting, in an excessive degree. (TA.) But these properties [says SM] are strange, and not mentioned by the physicians. Ibn-El-Kutbee says, in [the book entitled] maA laA yasaEu AlT~abiyba jaholuhu, mgAv is [the name of] roots which are imported, of a hot and moist temperament, in one of the last measures of the second degree, (fY AwAxr AlvAnyp,) [the degrees of heat and cold and dryness and moistness being four,] the best of which are the white and soft, inclining to yellow: it is fattening, strengthening to the limbs or members, of use in cases of fracture and contusion, applied in a bandage, and drunk; also for the gout (niqoris), and spasmodic contraction (ta$an~uj); and softens hardness of the joints; and improves the voice, and clears the throat and lungs; and excites to sexual intercourse. Some say, that it is the name of] the roots of the wild pomegranate; but this assertion is not of established authority. Others say, that it is a kind of suwranojaAn; and this is not improbable. The hakeem [Dáood] says, in the Tedhkireh, mgAv is [the name of] a certain plant in El-Kerej (Alkrj) and the parts adjacent; roots extending deep into the earth, and thick, with a rind inclining to black and red, which, when peeled off, discloses a substance, between white and yellow: the best thereof is the heavy, sweet-scented, in taste inclining to sweet, with a slight bitterness. It is said to have rough, or coarse, and wide, leaves, like those of the radish; and a white flower; and seeds resembling the grains of the sumonap, and called qlql: hence it has been imagined to be the pomegranate: and it is said to be a species of swrnjAn: its strength, or virtue, lasts about seven years: and there is a kind of it brought from 'Abbádán, and towards Syria, weak in operation; and it is this which is used in Egypt. (TA.) [M. Rouyer, in the Descr. de l'Egypte, tome 11 of the sec. ed., p. 452, describes it as follows: a root of a whitish colour, mucilaginous, fleshy, or pulpous, and of an aromatic odour: it is nutritive and aphrodisiac: it is taken in the simple substance; and they make of it a sherbet, which should be drunk hot: this root comes from the Indies.]
magiyvN * and ↓ mamoguwvN Herbage laid prostrate by rain: (S, K:) herbage that is rained upon, and rendered yellow, and bad-tasted, and laid prostrate by the rain. (TA.) ― -b2- See magivN.

mamoguwvN *
Affected by a fever. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- See magiyvN.
mumaAgivN * : see magivN.
1 magaja AlfaSiylu DaroEa A^um~ihi * : see mEj.

1 magada * , aor.
magada , (inf. n. magodN, S, L,) He (a child, and a lamb or kid, S, L, and a young camel, L, K) sucked his mother: he (a young camel) struck his mother in her udder with his head, and sucked her: and he (a lamb or kid) took the teat of his mother in his mouth to suck; (L;) as also maEa*a, with the unpointed E and the pointed *. (IKtt.) ― -b2- magada He sucked, or sucked in, a thing: (K:) he sucked, or sucked in, the inside of Sarabap, i. e., [a piece of] the gum of the TaloH; for there is sometimes in the inner part thereof what resembles glue and the honey of dates or bees. (S, L.) See
also magodN, below. ― -b3- magada, aor.
magada , inf. n. magodN; (L, K;) and magida, aor.
magada , (L,) inf. n. magadN; (L, K;) He, (L,) or it, (the body, K,) became full and fat. (L, K.) ― -b4- magadahu, (aor.
magada , inf. n. magodN, S, L.) It (a pleasant, or an ample, and easy, life) nourished him: (AZ, IAar, S, L:) or it (a life, or manner of living) nourished him, and rendered him in a state of amplitude and ease. (K.) ― -b5- magada He (a man, L) and it (a plant, L, K, or other thing, K, or anything, L) became tall. (Aboo-Málik, L, K.) ― -b6- magada fiY Eayo$K naAEimK, (aor.
magada , inf. n. magodN, S, L,) a phrase mentioned by Fr, (S,) He (a man) lived, and enjoyed abundant comforts, or luxury, in a pleasant, or an ample and easy, state of life. (K.) ― -b7- magadahu It (youth) caused him still to flourish, or to be in the flower of age. (En-Nadr, L.) ― -b8- magada He became in the full prime of youth. (L.) -A2- magada, aor.
magada , inf. n. magoda, He plucked out hair: (L:) as also maEada. (L, art. mEd.) ― -b2- magada mawoDiEa Algur~api He plucked out the hair in the place of the blaze, or white mark on the forehead or face, of a horse, in order that it might become gray. (L, K.)

4 Amgdt *
She (a woman) suckled her child; (S, L, K;) and a she camel, &c., her young one. (S, L.) ― -b2- Amgd, (inf. n. A_imogaAdN, L,) He (a man, S, L,) drank much, or abundantly: (S, L, K:) or he drank long. (AHn, L.)

magodN * The flower, or flourishing period, of youth. (En-Nadr, L.) ― -b2- Soft; tender; delicate: pleasant; easy and ample: syn. naAEimN: (S, L, K:) applied to the period of youth: (S, L:) and to life, or a manner of living. (L.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or magodu Aljisomi, (L,) Soft and plump: applied to a camel: (L, K:) or (so in the L; in the K, and) big, or bulky; (L, K;) as also maEodN; (L;) and tall: (K:) applied to anything. (L.) -A2- magodN, applied to the gur~ap, or blaze, on the forehead or face of a horse; app. an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n.; Having the hair plucked out in order that it may become gray: (L:) the term magodN is used with relation to the blaze of a horse when it appears as though it were swollen; for the hair is plucked out in order that it may grow white: (S, L:) and with relation to the forelock, when it is as though burnt. (L.) -A3- magodN (L, K) and ↓ magadN (L) The fruit of the [tree called] tanoDub: or (so in the L; but in the K, and) the [plant called] luf~aAH [q. v.]: (L, K:) or the wild lf~AH: (L:) or, both words, (so in the L; but in the K, and) the [plant called] baA*inojaAn: (L, K:) or a plant resembling the nA*njAn, growing at the roots of the EiDah: (L:) and the former word, a fruit resembling the cucumber, (Aboo-Sa'eed, L, K,) which is eaten: (Aboo-Sa'eed, L:) or a kind of tree that twines about other trees, more slender than the vine, having long, thin, and soft, leaves, and producing a fruit like that of the banana, but thinner in the peel and more juicy, which is sweet, and is not peeled [to be eaten], with pips like those of the apple; people share this fruit among themselves, taking it by turns, alighting where it grows, and eating it; it appears first green; then becomes yellow; and then, at last, green [again, or probably red; for I think that yxDr~, in the L, from which this is taken, is a mistake for yHmr~]: the word is a coll. gen. n.: and] the n. un. is with p: (AHn, L:) ISd says, I have not heard magadapN; but ↓ magadN may be a quasi-pl. n. of magodapN; like as HalaqN is of HaloqapN, and falakN of falokapN. (L.) ― -b2- magodN i. q. SarabapN, meaning as explained above, at 1: (S, L,) also, the gum of the lote-tree, sidor: (Aboo-Sa'eed, L:) or, of the lok-tree of the desert. (S, L.)
magadN * : see magodN.

2 mg~rhu *
He dyed it (namely a garment or piece of cloth) with magorap. (A.)

magarN * and ↓ mugorapN (K, TA) A colour inclining to red: (TA:) or a colour not pure red, (K, TA,) nor inclining to yellow; its redness being like the colour of ↓ magorap: (TA:) or i. q. $uqorapN [i. e., in a man, ruddiness of complexion combined with fairness, and in a horse, a sorrel colour,] with duskiness, or dinginess. (K.) See also A^amogaru.
magorapN * [Red ochre, called in the present day mugorap;] red earth, (S, A, Msb, K,) with which one dyes [and paints]; (TA;) well known; (A;) as also ↓ magarapN. (S, K.)
mugorapN * : see magarN.
magarapN * : see magorapN.

A^amogaru *
i. q. A^a$oqaru, (A, Msb,) applied to a man [and signifying Of a ruddy complexion combined with fairness], (A,) and to a horse [and signifying of a sorrel colour]: (A, Msb:) or red in the hair and skin, (S, K,) of the colour of magorap: (S:) and having redness in the face, with clear whiteness: (K:) or white, or white in face: as also A^aHomaru: applied to a man: (TA:) and, applied to a horse, of a colour inclining to A^a$oqar [or sorrel]; i. e. having his $uqorapN [or sorrel colour] tinged over with duskiness, or dinginess: (S:) and applied to a camel, of the colour of magorap: (K:) and so applied to a horse: or a horse not of a pure red colour, nor of a colour inclining to yellow, but of a red colour, like the colour of magorap, and having the mane and forelock and ears like the [red] colour termed Suhobap, without any whiteness: (TA:) [see also magarN:] the fem. is magoraA='u: and the dim. A^amayogiru. (TA.)

mamogarapN *
Land whence magorap comes forth, or is procured. (TA.)
mumag~arN * A garment, or piece of cloth, (A,) dyed with magorap. (A, K.)

1 magVSa [magaSahu, inf. n. magoSN, He pierced him with a spear or the like: for] magoSN is syn. with TaEonN; as also magosN. (TA.) -A2- [Hence, perhaps,] mugiSa, (ISk, S, Msb, K,) [of which magoSN, which see below, is app. the inf. n.] and magiSa, (A, Msb, [in a copy of the former of which, instead of the former verb, I find maguSa, but this is probably a mistranscription,]) inf. n. magaSN; (Msb;) He (a man, S, Msb,) had what is termed magoSN as explained below; (ISk, S, A, Msb, K;) as also mugisa and magisa: (IKoot, Msb:) and maEiSa: (TA:) [it is most commonly with g and S; but Z says, that] the original word is with s, from magasahu signifying TaEanahu. (A.)

5 tmg~S baToniY * , and tamag~aSaniY, My belly pained me; as also tmg~s, with s. (TA.) [In the CK, we find tmg~S baTonahu, explained by A^awojaEahu, as though signifying It pained his belly: but baTonahu is doubtless a mistake for baTonuhu. In MS. copies of the K, I do not find this verb.] ― -b2- And [hence,] tamag~aSaniY Al$~aYo'u (assumed tropical:) The thing hurt me: and in like manner, tamag~aSotu minohu (assumed tropical:) [I was hurt by it]. (TA.)

magoSN * (ISk, S, A, Msb, K) and magaSN; (IDr, A, K;) but the former is the chaste word; (A;) or the latter, accord. to ISk, is vulgar, (S,) and Az pronounces him right in saying so, (Msb,) and Yaakoob disallows the latter word. wherefore the author of the K is wrong in imputing error, in this matter, [if error it be,] to J; (TA;) [Colic; or] pain in the belly, (A, K,) and griping (taqoTiyEN) in the bowels; (A;) or griping (tqTyE) in the bowels, and pain [therein]; (S;) or pain in the bowels, and contortion [therein]; (Msb;) as also magosN. (Yaakoob, TA.)
mamoguwSN * A man (S, Msb) having what is termed magoSN as explained above. (S, Msb, K.)
See Supplement

magonaTiysN * , (S, K,) or magoniyTisN, (as in some copies of the K and in the TA,) and magoniyTiysN (CK) and magonaATiysN (K) [The magnet;] a certain
stone that attracts iron: arabicized [from the Greek μαγνῆτις]. (S, K.) [Mentioned in S, L, K, in art. gTs; but, as observed in the TA, it should have a separate place.]
See Supplement

maAqiy^N * and muwqiy^N The posterior, or, as some say, anterior, part of the eye: (K:) or the inner angle of the eye, next the nose. (K, &c., art. mA^q.) Mentioned by most of the lexicographers in art. mA^q, q. v. (TA.)

1 maqatahu * , (aor.
maquta , Msb,) inf. n. maqotN (and, accord. to the K, maqaAtapN; but this is the inf. n. of maquta, q. v.; TA) He hated him: (S, K:) as also ↓ mq~th, (K,) inf. n. tamoqiytN; (TA;) [but this has, probably, an intensive signification;] or he hated him on account of a foul action that he had committed: (Lth:) or he hated him with the most violent hatred, (Zj, M, Er-Rághib, Msb,) on account of a foul action. (Msb.) ― -b2- maquta A_ilaY Aln~aAsi, aor.
maquta , inf. n. maqaAtapN, He was hateful, or an object of hatred, to men, on account of a foul action that he had committed: (Lth:) or he was hateful, or an object of hatred, in the utmost degree, (M, Msb,) on account of a foul action. (Msb.)
2 maq~ata see 1.

3 maAqatahu *
He hated him [or hated him in the utmost degree] reciprocally, on account of some foul, or evil, affair. (A.) ― -b2- maAqatuwA [They bore hatred, one to another.] (TA, art. bht.)

4 maA A^amoqatahu EinodiY *
How hated, or hateful, or odious, is he to me! (Sb, K.) ― -b2- maA A^amoqataniY lahu How I hate him! (Sb, K.)

5 tmq~t A_ilayohi *
He showed, or manifested, hatred [or the utmost hatred] to him: contr. of tHb~b Alyh. (A.)

6 tmAqtwA *
They hated one another, [or hated one another in the utmost degree,] on account of some foul, or evil, affair. (A.)

nikaAHu Almaqoti *
The marrying the wife of one's father after him; (K;) that is, after his having divorced her or died: (TA:) this was done in the time of paganism, (S,) and was then thus called; maqotN signifying the “ most violent hatred: ” it is forbidden in the Kur, iv. 26. (Zj.)
maqotiY~F * A man who has contracted the kind of marriage termed nkAH Almqt: (ISd, K:) or the son of such a man. (Zj, K.)

maqiytN * and ↓ mamoquwtN Hated: (S, K:) or the former signifies hateful, and the latter hated: (MF:) [or hateful, and hated, on account of his having committed a foul action: in this sense mqyt is mentioned by Lth: or hateful, and hated, in the utmost degree, on account of a foul action: in this sense mqyt is mentioned in the Msb.]
mamoquwtN * : see maqiytN.

maqadiY~N *
A certain kind of beverage, prepared from honey, (S, L, K,) which the Khaleefehs of the sons of Umeyyeh used to drink: (L:) so called in relation to a town in Syria, (S, L,) called maqadN; or in relation to a town in Syria in the province of El-Urdunn: (L:) or this is a mistake; for the name of the town is with teshdeed [maqad~N]: IB says, that the orthography of the word as best known to the lexicologists is maqadiY~N, without teshdeed; but that A 'Obeyd and others write it with teshdeed; and that IAmb cites in confirmation of its being thus a verse of 'Amr Ibn-Maadeekerib, at the end of which occurs the expression $agaluwhu Eano $arobi Almaqad~i; without Y; [app. for maqad~iY;] adding, that it is thus called in relation to maqad~N, a town of Damascus, in the mountain overlooking El-Ghór: (L:) A 'Obeyd says, I hold it to be correctly maqad~iY~N; and I heard Rejà Ibn-Selemeh explain this as signifying “ wine diminished to half its quantity by boiling; ” as though it were divided (qud~a) in halves: (Sh, L:) IB adds, that Aboo-t-Teyyib the lexicologist says, that the word in question is with d without teshdeed; from maqadN; and is only written with teshdeed by poetic licence: and in confirmation of this assertion, IB cites verses in which the name of the town and that of the beverage are written without teshdeed. (L.) ― -b2- vawobN maqadiY~N A certain well-known kind of cloth, or garment: (L, TA:) you say viyaAbN maqadiy~apN. (K. [In the CK, erroneously, maqad~iy~apN.])

1 maqira * , aor.
maqara , (S, Msb,) inf. n. maqarN, (S, A, Msb, K,) It was, or became, bitter; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Amqr, (ISk, IKtt, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_imoqaArN: (Msb:) or sour, or acid: (K:) and ↓ Amqr, said of milk, (AZ, A, K,) it became almost bitter, by reason of its quality of biting the tongue: (A:) or lost its [proper] flavour (AZ, K) by becoming intensely sour or acid. (AZ, TA.) -A2- maqara Eunuqaha, (ISk, S, A, K,) aor.
maqura , inf. n. maqorN, (ISk, S,) He bruised his neck: (S, A:) or beat it with a staff or stick, so as to break the bone in pieces, leaving the skin whole. (A, K.) ― -b2- And hence, (A,) maqara Als~amakapa AlmaAliHapa He macerated the salt fish in vinegar; (A, K;) as also ↓ Amqr. (K.) And in like manner you say of anything that you macerate. (TA.)
4 A^amoqara see 1, in three places. -A2- A^amoqarotu lifulaAnK $araAbFA I made beverage bitter to, or for, such a one. (IDrd.)
maqorN * : see maqirN, in three places.

maqirN *
Bitter; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ maqorN (TA) and ↓ mumoqirN (S, A, K) and ↓ yamoquwrN: (Sgh, K:) or sour; acid; as also ↓ mumoqirN: (K:) which last also signifies intensely sour or acid; (AZ, Aboo-Málik, S; *) applied to milk: (the same, and K:) or sour, or acid, milk. (Msb.) ― -b2- Aloes; syn. SabirN: (As, S, A, Msb, K:) as also ↓ maqorN: (S:) or a certain thing resembling it: (IKt, Msb, K:) or poison: as also ↓ maqorN; (K;) which is said by some to be a form used by poetic license: (TA:) or, accord. to AA, a certain bitter kind of tree: and accord. to AHn, a certain plant, which grows in leaves without branches. (TA.) [See SaqirN.]
mumoqirN * : see maqirN, in two places.

samakN mamoquwrN *
Fish macerated in vinegar and salt, so as to become a cold sauce or fluid seasoning: (Az, TA:) or sour, or acid, fish: (IAar, TA:) or fish bruised (yumoqaru) in water and salt: you should not say manoquwrN. (S.)
yamoquwrN * : see maqirN.

maAqiTN * The freedman of a freedman: (K:) or the slave of a slave of a freedman: whence the Arabs say, in reviling, fulaAnN saAqiTu bonu maAqiTi boni laAqiTK. (S.) See art. sqT. ― -b2- muq~aATN [which is its pl.] like suq~aATN and luq~aATN, signifies, accord. to IAar, The refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, or mankind, or of people. (TA in art. x$r.)

div2.head: mqE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement
mako'N * The hole of a fox, or of a hare, or rabbit: or, accord. to Th, the hole of the kind of lizard called Dab~. (L.)

makata * , [aor.
makuta ,] He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in a place: (K:) like makada: accord. to some, a word mispronounced: accord. to others for makava; the v being changed into t. (TA.)

10 A_isotamokatati Albavorapu *
The pustule became filled with pus, or matter. (IAar, T, K.)

1 makava * , aor.
makuva ; and makuva, aor.
makuva ; inf. n. makovN [with which mukovN and mikvN (see below) are syn.] and mik~iyvaY (S, K) [like xiS~iySaY, q. v.,] and mik~iyvaA='u [like xiS~iySaA='u] and makavN and mukuwvN and mukovaAnN (K) and makaAvN and makaAvapN [which last is the inf. n. of makuva]; (TA;) He tarried; tarried and waited, or expected; (S, K;) was patient, and tarried, and waited, or expected: or he tarried, stayed, or stopped, expecting: loitered; tarried; stayed; waited; paused in expectation; fiY makaAnK in a place. (TA.) [In like manner,] ↓ tmk~v He loitered; tarried; stayed; waited; paused in expectation. (S, K.)
5 tamak~ava see 1.
mukovN * and ↓ mikovN, substs., from makava or makuva, A tarrying; tarrying and waiting, or expecting; &c. (S, A.)
mikovN * : see mukovN.

makiyvN *
Grave: (S, K:) who does not hasten in his affair: pl. mukavaA='u and makiyvuwna. (TA.) ― -b2- makiyvu AlkalaAmi (tropical:) Slow of speech. (Ibn-Abi-l- Hadeed.) ― -b3- Also makiyvN A man remaining; staying; abiding; remaining fixed, or stationary. (TA.)

saAra Alr~ajulu mutamak~ivFA *
The man journeyed, or proceeded, loitering; syn. mutalaw~imFA. (S.)

1 makada * , (S, L, K,) aor.
makuda , (L,) inf. n. mukuwdN (S, L, K) and makodN, (K,) He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (S, L, K,) bimakaAnK in a place; (S, L;) as also makata. (TA.)

maAkidN * Water (L) lasting, or continuing, (L, K,) unceasingly. (K.) ― -b2- naAqapN maAkidapN A she-camel abounding with milk; as also ↓ makodaA='u: (K:) or constantly, or always, abounding with milk; (L;) as also ↓ makodaA='u (S, L;) and ↓ makuwdN: (S, L, K:) like nakodaA='u: (S, L:) pl. of makuwdN, mukodN, (K,) or mukudN, and makaAy^idu. (L.) ― -b3- biy^orN maAkidapN, and ↓ makuwdN A well having a constant, or unceasing, supply of water: (L:) and rakiy~apN maAkidapN a well whereof the water remains without diminution [to which is added EalaY qaroni wAHidK laA yatagay~aru waAlqaronu qaronu AlqaAmapi, app. meaning, of the measure of one qaron, not changing; by qrn being meant the structure of stone which supports the wood whereto the pulley is suspended, and which is described as being of the proportion of a man]. (S, L.) ― -b4- wud~N maAkidN (tropical:) Unceasing love or affection. (L.)
makuwdN * : see maAkidN.
makodaA='u * : see maAkidN.

1 makara * , aor.
makura , (Msb, TA,) inf. n. makorN; (S, A, Msb, K;) and ↓ Amkr; (Msb;) He practised deceit, guile, or circumvention; or he practised deceit, guile, or circumvention, desiring to do to another a foul, an abominable, or an evil, action, clandestinely, or without his knowing whence it proceeded; syn. xadaEa; (Msb;) and of the inf. n. xadiyEapN: (S, A, K:) he practised an evasion or elusion, a shift, an artifice, or artful contrivance or device, a machination, a trick, a plot, a stratagem, or an expedient; he plotted; or he exercised art, craft, cunning, or skill, in the management or ordering of affairs, with excel-lent consideration or deliberation, and ability to manage according to his own free will; syn. of the inf. n. A_iHotiyaAlN: (S, TA:) or to this explanation, conveyed by AHtyAl as the syn. of the inf. n., should be added secretly, or privately: (Lth, TA:) makorN is praised or dispraised according to the nature of its object. (El-Basáir.) [For further explanation, see what follows.] ― -b2- It is trans. by means of bi: and also, accord. to Z, by itself: (MF:) [but I know not any instance of its being trans. by itself: except as meaning he plotted a thing: see makora Als~ay~iy^ in the Kur, xxxv. 41, cited voce say~iy^N:] you say makara bihi, (S, A, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S, TA,) meaning, He deceived, beguiled, or circumvented, him; or he deceived, beguiled, or circumvented, him, and desired to do him a foul, an abominable, or an evil, action, clandestinely, or without his knowing whence it proceeded: &c.: (S, A, TA:) syn. kaAdahu: or it differs [somewhat] from kAdh, accord. to Aboo-Hilál El-'Askeree: (TA:) some say, that mkr bh signifies as above with the addition of feigning the contrary of his real intentions; which kAdh does not imply: or this latter signifies “ he did him harm, ” or “ mischief; ” and the former, he did him harm, or mischief, clandestinely. (MF, voce kAd.) See art. xdE. ― -b3- makara also signifies He managed with thought, or consideration, or acted with policy, and practised stratagem, in war. (TA.) ― -b4- makara A@ll~`hu and ↓ A^amokara are syn., (IKtt, Msb,) signifying, (tropical:) God recompensed, or requited, for makor [or the practising deceit, &c.]: (Lth, * Msb, TA: *) or makoru A@ll~`hi signifies God's granting a man respite or delay, and enabling him to accomplish his worldly aims [so as to bring upon himself the punishment due to his evil actions]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or, accord. to IAth, God's causing his trials to befall his enemies, exclusively of his friends: or his taking men by little and little, so that they do not reckon upon it, bestowing upon them renewed favours for acts of obedience which are imagined to be accepted whereas they are rejected. (TA.)

3 mAkrhu *
He practised with him mutual deceit, guile, or circumvention; &c.; (A, * TA;) syn. xaAdaEahu. (TA.)
4 A^amokara see 1, in two places.

6 tmAkrwA *
They practised mutual deceit, guile, or circumvention; &c. (A, * TA.)
makuwrN * : see maAkirN.
mak~aArN * : see maAkirN.

maAkirN * (S, A, Msb, K) and ↓ mak~aArN (S, A, K) and ↓ makuwrN (K) epithets from makara: (S, A, Msb, K:) [the first signifying Practising deceit, guile, or circumvention; &c.: and the second and third, practising the same much, or frequently; deceitful, guileful, artful, crafty, or cunning; a trickster, or crafty knave.]

1 makasa * , aor.
makisa , (TK,) inf. n. makosN, (Sh, A, K,) He diminished, or deducted from, a thing; (Sh, * A, * K, * TK;) syn. of the inf. n. taqoSN. (Sh, A, K.) Thus Sh explains makos in the saying of Jábir Ibn-Jinnee Et-Taghlibee:
A^afiY kul~i A^asowaAqi AlEiraAqi A_itaAwapN
wafiY kul~i maA baAEa A@moruw^N makosu dirohami
[Is there bribing in every one of the markets of El-'Irák, and in the case of everything that a man has sold the deducting of a dirhem?]. (TA.) [Hence,] you say, makasa fiY AlbayoEi, aor. and inf. n. as above; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and ↓ mAks, inf. n. mumaAkasapN and mikaAsN: (S, Mgh, Msb:) both signify He diminished, or deducted from, the price in the selling, or buying: (Msb:) or both signify he desired, or demanded, a diminution of, or deduction from, the price in selling or buying: (Mgh, TA, *) or the former signifies he collected property in selling or buying: (K: [but from what I find in the other lexicons, I think it probable that an early copyist has perverted the text of the K here by making a transposition; writing makasa fiY AlbayoEi yamokisu makosFA jabaY maAlFA wAalmakosu Aln~aqoSu waAlZ~ulomu for
makasa yamokisu makosFA jabaY maAlFA waAlmakosu fY AlbayoEi Aln~aqoSu waAlZ~ulomu: in the TK we find jnY mAlA, which is certainly a mistake:]) or makosN signifies the diminishing (A_inotiqaAS) of the price of a commodity: (M, TA:) and ↓ mikaAsN, the acting with mutual niggardliness in bargaining; or, accord. to EshShereeshee, the vying in acuteness between a seller and buyer, the former demanding a price and the latter offering less, time after time, until they agree to a reduced price. (Har, p. 586.) You say also, mukisa, meaning, He (a man) suffered a diminution, or deduction, in selling or buying and the like. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps, or the reverse may be the case,] He wronged a man; treated him, or used him, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically. (A, * K, * TK. [In the first and second, only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is mentioned.]) ― -b3- [Hence, also, app.,] He (the mak~aAs, Mgh, Msb) collected a tax; syn. jabaY; [particularly, the tax termed makos:] (S, * M, Mgh, * Msb [in the first and third of which, only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is mentioned:]) or he collected property. (A.) Hence the saying, (Mgh,) in a trad., (S,) laA yadojulu SaAHibu makosK Aljan~apa (S, Mgh) [The taker of the tax termed mks will not enter paradise]; meaning, the Ea$~aAr. (TA.)

3 mAks fiY AlbayoEi * : see 1. ― -b2- mAkshu, (K,) inf. n. mumaAkasapN [and mikaAsN], (TA,) He acted with him in a niggardly, a tenacious, or an avaricious, manner; syn. $aAH~ahu: (K: but in some copies, $aAkasahu. TA,) or mAkshu fY AlbayoEi signifies he contended with him [by bidding against him or otherwise] in the sale. (MA.) [See, in art. kys, voce kaAsa, an ex. from a trad., accord. to one reading thereof.]

6 tmAksA *
They acted in a niggardly, a tenacious, or an avaricious, manner, each with the other, in bargaining: (IDrd, K:) or tmAkswA fiY AlbayoEi they contended, one with another, [by outbidding or otherwise] in the sale. (MA.)

makosN * , an inf. n., (see 1,) used as a subst., (Mgh, Msb,) Money that used to be taken from the seller of commodities in the markets in the time of ignorance: (IDrd, M, K:) and a dirhem which the collector of the poor-rate used to take after he had finished the receipt of that tribute: (IAar, K:) or what is taken by the Ea$~aAr, (S, Mgh,) or maAkis, (S,) or mak~aAs: (Mgh, Msb:) so [accord. to some] in the verse above cited: (S:) the tax, or impost, which he used to take: (TA:) and generally, what the Sultán's guards take wrongfully on an occasion of buying and selling: so [accord. to some] in the verse cited above: (Msb:) pl. mukuwsN. (A, Mgh, Msb.)
mak~aAsN * (A, Mgh, Msb) and ↓ maAksN (S) One who takes, or receives, what is termed makos: (Mgh, Msb;) i. e., (Mgh,) i. q. Ea$~aArN. (S, Mgh.)
maAkisN * : see mak~aAsN.

div2.head: mkl &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 malaA^a * , aor.
malaAa , inf. n. malo'N (S, K) and maloA^apN and miloA^apN; (K;) and maliy^a; (TA;) and ↓ ml~A^, inf. n. tamoliy^apN; (K;) He filled (K;) a vessel &c. (S, TA.) You may also say malaA^otuhu malFA, for maloy^FA, (TA.) ― -b2- malaA^a AlEayona (tropical:) He satisfied [or glutted] the eye by his comeliness of aspect. (TA.) See an ex. in a verse cited voce EaqibN. ― -b3- malaA^otu minohu EayoniY (tropical:) [I satisfied, or glutted, my eye by the sight of his comeliness]. (TA.) ― -b4- maluw^a, aor.
maluAa , (K,) inf. n. malaA='apN and malaA='N; (S, K;) and malaA^a, aor.
malaAa ; (K;) the former is that which commonly obtains; (TA;) He became rich, wealthy, &c., syn. SaAra maliyy^FA. (K.) ― -b5- kalimapN tamolaA^u Alfama (assumed tropical:) [A word, or saying, that fills the mouth;] i. e., gross, and abominable; not allowable to be spoken; that fills the mouth so that it cannot articulate. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b6- A_imolaw^uwA A^afowaA'akumo mina AlquroA=ni (assumed tropical:) [Fill your mouths with the Kur-án]. (TA.) ― -b7- muliy^a ruEobFA, and maluw^a rEbA, (tropical:) He was filled with fright. (A.) ― -b8- malaA^a viyaAbiY (tropical:) He sprinkled my clothes with mud, &c. (A.) malaA^a raAkibahu [He (a camel) bespattered his rider with his ejected cud]. (S, K, art. zrd.) ― -b9- malaA^a EinaAnahu (assumed tropical:) He made, or urged, his beast to run vehemently. (TA in art. En.) ― -b10- muliy^a, like EuniYa, [i. e., pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] and maluw^a, (tropical:) He had the disease called mulaA='ap. (A, K.) ― -b11- See 3.

2 ml~A^ furuwja farasihi *
He made his horse to run at the utmost rate of the pace termed HuDor. (TA.) ― -b2- And see 1, and 4.

3 mAlA^hu EalaY AlA^amori * , (S, K,) inf. n. mumaAlaA^apN; (S;) and ↓ malaA^ahu; (K;) but this latter the lexicologists do not hold in good repute; (TA;) He aided, or assisted, him, and conformed with him, to do the thing. (IAar, * AZ, S, K.)

4 AmlA^ Aln~azoEa fiY qawosihi * , (S,) and AmlA^ fY qwsh, and fY qwsh ↓ ml~A^, (K,) (tropical:) He pulled his bow to the utmost. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- AmlA^hu All~`hu, (S, K,) inf. n. A_imolaA'N, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) God affected him with the disease called mulaA='ap. (S, K.)

5 tml~A^ mina AlT~aEaAmi waAl$~araAbi *
