He became full of food and drink. (S.) ― -b2- See 8. ― -b3- tml~A^ gayoZFA, and ↓ AmtlA^, (tropical:) He became filled with rage. (S.) ― -b4- tml~A^ $ibaEFA, and ↓ AmtlA^, He became filled to satiety. (TA.) ― -b5- tml~A^ He put on himself a mulaA='ap; i. e., a covering of the kind so called. (TA.)

6 tamaAlaw^uwA EalaY AlA^amori *
They agreed, or conspired together, to do the thing: (ISk, S, K, TA:) they aided, or assisted, [and conformed with,] one another to do the thing. (TA.)

8 AmtlA^ * and ↓ tml~A^; (S, K;) and maliy^a, aor.
malaAa ; (K;) It (a vessel, &c., TA) became full. (S, K.) ― -b2- See 5. ― -b3- AmtlA^ $abaAbFA (assumed tropical:) [He became full of sap, or vigour, or youth, or young manhood]. (The Lexicons, &c., passim.) And AmtlA^ Al$~abaAbu (assumed tropical:) [The sap, or vigour, of youth, or young manhood, became full, or mantled, in a person.] (S, K, in art. gTY.) [And AmtlA^, alone, He was, or became, plump.] ― -b4- AmtlA^ EinaAnuhu (assumed tropical:) The utmost of his power, or ability, was accomplished. (TA in art. En.)

10 AstmlA^ fiY Ald~ayoni * signifies jaEala dayonahu fiY mulaA^='a (CK, and a MS copy of the K) [app., He made wealthy persons, or honest wealthy persons, his debtors: but in one copy of the K, for mulaA^='a, we find mulaA='K, which affords no sense that seems admissible here: and in another, diyn seems to be put in the place of dayon, in both the above instances; and malaA='K in that of mulaA^='a; for Golius renders the phrase AstmlA^ fY Aldyn by opulentiæ studuit in religione sua: i. e., religionem suam in illa posuit: a meaning which IbrD rejects].

milo'N * [A thing sufficient in quantity, or dimensions, for the filling of a vessel, &c., or] the quantity that a vessel, &c., holds when it is filled. (S, K.) ― -b2- A^aEoTihi miloA^ahu wamiloA^ayohi wavalaAvapa A^amolaA=y^ihi Give it (i. e., the cup, TA) what will fill it; and what will twice fill it; and what will thrice fill it. (S, K.) ― -b3- HajarN milo'u Alkaf~i A stone that fills the hand. (TA.) ― -b4- laka AlHamodu milo'u Als~amawaAti waAlA^aroDi To Thee be praise that shall fill the heavens and the earth. (TA.) ― -b5- milo'u kisaAy^ihaA A fat woman; that fills her ksA' when she covers herself with it. (TA, from a trad.)

malaA^N *
An assembly, (IAar, S, K,) absolutely, (TA,) [whether of nobles or others]: pl. A^amolaA='N. (IAar.) ― -b2- Nobles; chiefs; princes; syn. A^a$oraAfN and EiloyapN; (K;) principal persons; persons whose opinion is respected. (TA.) (AlmalaA^u AlA^aEloYa [The most exalted princes; i. e.] the angels that are admitted near [to the presence of God]; or the archangels. TA.) See samEahu, for other explanations. ― -b3- A people of comely appearance, figure, attire, or adornment, united for some purpose or design; expl. by qawomN *w Al$~aArapi wAlt~ajam~uEi liloA_iraAdapi: (Abu-l-Hasan, K:) [but this is wrong, see Beyd,
ii. 247.] Thus it is of a different class from rahaTN, though, like this word, a quasi-pl. n. It is an epithet in which the quality of a substantive predominates. (Abu-l-Hasan.) ― -b4- (tropical:) Consultation. (K.) [You say,] maA kaAna h`*aA AlA^amoru Eano malaA_K min~aA (tropical:) This thing was not the result of a consultation and consent on our part: [and] A^akaAna h`*aA Eano malaA_K minokumo (tropical:) Was this the result of a consultation of your nobles, and of your assembly? said by 'Omar when he was stabbed: asserted to be tropical in this sense by Z and others. (TA.) taHad~avuwA malaA^F They conversed, consulting together. (S.) ― -b5- Opinion. (K.) [See a supposed example below.] ― -b6- Disposition; nature; manners; (S, K;) a nature rich in needful qualities: (T:) pl. A^amolaA='N. (S.) [You say,] maA A^aHosana malaA^a baniY fulaAnK How good are the dispositions, or manners, and conversation, of the sons of such a one! (S.) ElJuhanee says,
tanaAdawoA yaAla buhovapa A_i*o raA^awonaA
faqulonaA A^aHosiniY malaA^F juhayonaA
(S) [They called out, one to another, O Buhtheh! come to our aid! when they saw us: and we said,] Be of good disposition, or manners, O Juheyneh! or, accord. to some, Be of good opinion, O Juheyneh! (see above:) or, as some say, Aid well, O Juheyneh! taking mlA^ in the sense of mumaAlaA^apF: [see 3]. (TA.) ― -b7- A^aHosinuwA A^amolaA='a kumo Amend your manners; or have good manners. From a trad. (S, K.) ― -b8- Also malaA^N A coveting. (K.)

muloA^apN *
A tremulousness and flabbiness and swelling of the flesh, in a camel, in consequence of long confinement after a journey. (K.) ― -b2- See mulaA='apN.

miloA^apN * The manner in which a thing is filled. (K.) [You say,] A_in~ahu laHasanu AlmiloA^api (not Alt~amal~uw^i) Verily it is well filled. (K.) ― -b2- miloA^apN An oppression occasioned by repletion with food. (K, TA.) [See also mulaA='apN.]
malaA='N * and ↓ malaA='apN Richness, wealthiness, &c.: (K:) or trustiness, or honest. (S.) [See maliYo'N.]
mulaA='N * : see mulaA='apN.

maliYo'N * , (S, K,) also written and pronounced maliY~N, (Nh,) A rich, wealthy, opulent, man: (K:) or trusty, or honest: (S:) or trusty, or honest, and rich: (TA:) or a rich man, or one not literally rich, who is honest, and pays his debts well, without giving trouble to his creditor: (K, * TA:) or an able, rich, man: (Msb:) [a solvent man:] pl. milaA='N and A^amoliy^aA='u and mulaA^='u. (K.) ― -b2- Also mulaA^='u Chiefs: so called because rich in needful things. (TA.)

mulaA='apN * (K) and ↓ muloA^apN (S, K) and ↓ mulaA='N (K) (tropical:) A defluxion, or rheum, syn. zukaAmN, (S, K,) occasioned by repletion, or a heaviness in the head, like a defluxion, or rheum, (zkAm,) from repletion of the stomach. (A.) [See also miloA^apN.] -A2- mulaA='apN A piece of drapery which is wrapped about the body; i. q., A_izaArN (TA) and rayoTapN: (S, K:) or the mlA'p is a covering for the body formed of two pieces; (TA;) composed of two oblong pieces of cloth sewed together; (Msb, in art. lgq;) and the ryTp is of a single piece. (TA.) [It appears to have been generally yellow, (see warosN, and A^aworasa,) and was probably otherwise similar to the modern milaAyap, which is described and represented in my work on the Modern Egyptians, part i., ch. 1.] Pl. mulaA='N; (S, K;) [or rather this is a quasi-pl. n.; or a coll. gen. n., of which mlA'p is the n. un.;] or, accord. to some, mulaA^N; but the former is better established. (TA.) Dim. mulayoy^apN; for which mulay~apN was also used, accord. to a tradition. (TA.) ― -b2- mulaA='apu AlHusoni (tropical:) Fairness of complexion. (TA.) ― -b3- AlmaHoDu ↓ AlmulaA='u (tropical:) Simple dust. (TA.) ― -b4- Also mulaA='apN The skim that forms on the surface of milk. (El-Moajam.)

maloA=nN * (S, K) [and maloA=nu, as it forms in the] fem. maloA=napN (K) and maloA^aY; (S;) pl. milaA='N; (K;) Full: (S, K) said of a vessel, &c. (S, TA.) The masc. is also written and pronounced malaAn; and the fem., malaA: (TA:) and the vulgar say A_inaA'N malaA A full vessel. (S, TA.) ― -b2- maloA=nN mn Alkarami (tropical:) [Full of generosity]. (TA.) ― -b3- See mamoluwo'N.

maAliy^N * (tropical:) A majestic person: one whose aspect satisfies the eye. (TA.) ― -b2- maAliy^N AlEayoni, and maAliy^N liloEayoni, (tropical:) A person whose aspect satisfies the eye by his comeliness &c. (TA.)

fulaAnN A^amolaA^u liEayoniY mino fulaAnK * (tropical:) Such a one is more satisfactory to my eye by his comeliness than such a one. (TA.) ― -b2- h`*aA AlA^amoru A^amolaA^u bika This thing is better for thee, and more satisfactory: expl. by A^amolaku [which is said to have this signification]. (TA.)

mamoluwo'N * , pass. part. n. of malaA^a, Filled. (S.) ― -b2- Also, (assumed tropical:) Having the disease called mulaA='ap: as part. n. of maliy^a. (A.) ― -b3- Also, (and accord. to some copies of the K, ↓ maloA=n,) Affected by God with that disease: extr. [with respect to rule], (S, K,) as it is used in the sense of the pass. part. n. of A^amolaA^a: by rule it should be mumolaA^N. (TA.)
mumoliy^N * An ewe in whose belly are water and matter [such seems to be the meaning of A^agoraAsN in the explanation] so that one thinks her to be pregnant. (K.)
$aAb~N mumotaliy^N * [A youth in the full bloom of his age. See art. EaboEabN.]
malaAbN * : see art. lwb, in which, as well as here, it is mentioned in the K.

1 malata * , aor.
malita , (inf. n. malotN, TA.) He put [a thing] in motion, or into a state of commotion: (ISd, K:) like matala: also mentioned by IDrd, who expresses uncertainty as to its correctness. (TA.)

mil~iytN *
i. q. snofu Almaroxi; (K;) i. e., The leaves of the tree called marox. (TA.)
A^amoluwtN * an epithet applied to a mafaAzap [or water-less desert]. (Marg. note in a copy of the S.)

A^amaAliytu *
Swift camels. (K.) It is said to be a quasi-pl. n.: or a pl. that has no sing.: or its sing. is A^umoluwtN or A_imaliytN: some of the lexicologists reject it. (MF.)

1 malavahu * , aor.
maluva , inf. n. malovN, He soothed, or tranquilized his mind, with words; spoke to him sweetly, or pleasantly; soothed him with agreeable words; (S, K;) not meaning to fulfil his words: as also mala*ahu, aor.
maluva , inf. n. malo*N: (TA:) ex. saA^alotuhu HaAjapF famalavaniY I asked him to do a thing that I wanted, and he soothed my mind by a promise, not meaning to fulfil it. (A.) ― -b2- In like manner, He made him a promise, (as though he would repel him from him, S,) not meaning to fulfil it. (S, K.) Accord. to Ibn-Abi-l-Hadeed, He made him a concealed promise: but this is a strange explanation. (MF.) ― -b3- malava, inf. n. malovN, He lied; as also mala*a. (TA, art. ml*.) ― -b4- malava AlZ~alaAmu The darkness became mixed with the light: this happens at nightfall and at daybreak. (AZ.) ― -b5- malavahu biAl$~ar~i He aspersed him, or bespattered him with evil. (A.) ― -b6- malavahu, [aor.
maluva ,] inf. n. malovN, He beat him lightly; (K;) like magavahu, q. v. (TA.) ― -b7- malava He (a hare, TK,) was unable to run; too weak to run. (K.)
3 mAlvhu * , (inf. n. milaAvN, TA,) He treated him with dissimulation, and jested, or joked, with him. (K.)

malovN * and ↓ malavN and ↓ mulovapN The first, or commencement, of the blackness of night: (K:) or it is after the sadaf: (TA:) or the first, or commencement, of the blackness of the place of sunset: when it has become intense, and the last Ei$aA=' has come, it is called malas. (IAar.) ― -b2-
AlZ~alaAmi ↓ A^atayotuhu malava, (S, K,) and malova AlZlAm, (K,) and Einoda mlvihi, (TA,) I came to him at the period when the darkness became confused, (S, K,) and had not yet become very intense, [as it has] when thou sayest A^axuwka A^ami Al*~iy^obu [(Is this) thy brother, or the wolf?]; (S;) i. e. at the time of the prayer of sunset, and after it. (As, S.) ― -b3- SlAp Almlvi The prayer of sunset: in the dial. of Rabee'ah. (A.) ― -b4- maA kaAna Eahoduhu A_il~aA walovFA wawaEoduhu A_il~aA malovFA [His compact was not otherwise than weak, and his promise not otherwise than one not meant to be fulfilled]. (A.)
milovN * One who does not become satiated with coitus. (K.) You say rajulN milovN and A_imoraA^apN milovN. (TK.)
malavN * See malotN.
mulovapN * See malotN.

1 malaja A^um~ahu * , (S, K,) aor.
maluja ; and malijahaA, aor. ??; (K;) inf. n. malojN; (S, K;) He (a child) sucked [the breast of] his mother: (S:) or he took his mother's teat with the extremity of his mouth. (S, K.) And malaja Aln~aAqapa, said of a young camel, He sucked the she-camel; like salajahaA. (L, TA, in art. slj.)
4 A^amolajatohu A^um~uhu * , (Msb,) inf. n. A_imolaAjN, (S,) His mother suckled him. (Msb.) [The masc. form of the verb is mentioned in the K.]

8 Amtlj *
He sucked milk: (K:) or he (a young weaned camel,) sucked what was in the udder. (S.)

mulujN *
Sucking kids. (K.)

malojapN *
A single suck. (Msb.) [See also maloHapN.]
malojaAnu * A man who sucks the teats of his camels, (or of his sheep or goats, TA,) by reason of his avarice; (S, K;) not milking them lest he should be heard: (TA:) as also maS~aAnu. (S.)

maliyjN *
A foster-brother; syn. raDiyEN. (K.) ― -b2- An illustrious man. (K.)
maAlajN * (S, K) and maAlajapN, (S, in art. syE,) [A plasterer's trowel;] a thing with which one plasters: (S, K:) an arabicized word, from the Persian, (S,) [originally maAlaho].
A^umoluwjN * [Sugar-candy]: see A^uboluwjN.

A_imolaAjapN *
A single act of suckling. (TA.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad., lA tuHar~imu AlA_imolaAjapu walaA AlA_imolaAjataAni, (S,) i. e. One act of suckling, or the giving one such, does not bar [the two parties from marrying each other], nor do two acts of suckling, or the giving two sucks, like as complete suckling does. (TA.)

1 malaHato fulaAnapN lifulaAnK * , (aor.
malaHa and
maluHa , L,) (tropical:) Such a woman suckled, or gave suck, for such a one. (A, L.) ― -b2- malaHonaA lifulaAnK, inf. n. maloHN, (S,) We [meaning the wife of one of us] suckled, or gave suck, for such a one: (As, L:) or we suckled such a one. (S.) ― -b3- malaHa Alwalada [app. He caused the child to be suckled;] syn. with A^aroDaEahu. (K.) [See A^aroDaEa.] ― -b4- maluHa; (L;) and ↓ ml~H, inf. n. tamoliyHN; and ↓ tml~H; (L, K;) the last said to be formed by transposition from tHl~m; but ISd, sees no reason for this assertion; (L;) (tropical:) He (a camel. L,) became fat. (L, K.) ↓ ml~Ht she (a camel destined for slaughter) became fat: (El-Umawee, S:) or, became a little fat: (K:) She (a camel) became fat in a small degree. (L.) Also ↓ tml~Ht (tropical:) They (lizards such as are called DibaAb) became fat; as also tHl~mt. (L.) -A2- maluHa, aor.
maluHa , inf. n. muluwHapN (S, Msb, K) and malaAHapN; (K;) this form of the verb is of the dial. of the people of El-'Áliyeh; (Msb;) and malaHa, aor.
maluHa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. muluwHN; (S, Msb;) and malaHa, aor,
malaHa ; (IAar, K;) and ↓ AmlH, inf. n. A_imolaAHN, of the dial. of El-Hijáz; (Msb;) It (water) was salt: (S, Msb, K:) or ↓ AmlH signifies it became salt, having been sweet. (K.) ― -b2- maluHa, aor.
maluHa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. malaAHapN (S, Msb) and muluwHapN (S) and miloHN, the first of which is the most common, and the last the least common, (TA,) (tropical:) It (a thing, S, Msb) was, or became, goodly, beautiful, or pretty; (S, Msb, K;) and beautiful of colour; or beautiful and bright; (Msb;) pleasing to the eye or ear; facetious. (The lexicons passim.) ― -b3- malaHa Alqidora, aor.
malaHa and
maliHa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. maloHN, (S, Msb,) He put salt into the cooking-pot: (K:) or put a proper quantity of salt into it: (S, A, Msb:) and accord. to Sb, ↓ ml~H and ↓ AmlH signify the same as malaHa: (ISd:) or mal~aHahaA, inf. n. tamoliyHN, and A^amolaHahaA, signify he put much salt into it, (S, Msb, K,) so that it [meaning its contents] became spoiled. (S, A.) ― -b4- malaHa, (S, K,) inf. n. maloHN; (S;) and ↓ ml~H, inf. n. tamolyHN; (TA;) He fed camels or sheep or goats with salt earth, (S, K,) or with earth and salt, the salt being more in quantity. (TA.) This is done when the animals cannot procure plants of the kind called HamoD. (S.) ― -b5- malaHa, aor.
malaHa and
maliHa , (K,) inf. n. maloHN; and ↓ ml~H; He salted fish. (K.) ― -b6- malaHa; aor.
malaHa , inf. n. maloHN, He salted flesh-meat, and a skin, or hide. (L.) ― -b7- Also ↓ ml~Hhu, inf. n. tamoliyHN, He rubbed his (a camel's, or sheep's, or goat's,) palate with salt. (TA.) ― -b8- maliHa, aor.
malaHa , inf. n. malaHN, (tropical:) He, or it, (a man, &c.,) was blue, or gray, [see muloHapN,] in such a degree as to incline to whiteness; (Msb;) as also ↓ A_imolaH~a, inf. n. A_imoliHaAHN; and ↓ A^amolaHa. (TA.) ― -b9- Also, (tropical:) He was black, with whiteness overspreading his hair: or, of a dusty white colour: or, of a clear white colour: (Msb:) [and in like manner,] ↓ A_imolaH~a, inf. n. A_imoliHaAHN, he (a ram) was of a white colour intermixed with black. (S, K.) -A3- maliHa, aor.
malaHa , inf. n. malaHN, He (a horse) had the kind of swelling called malaHN. (TA.)

2 mal~aHa See 1, in six places. ― -b2- ml~H (tropical:) He (a poet) produced, or said, something goodly, beautiful, pretty, [or facetious]: (S, K:) and ↓ AmlH he produced, or said, a goodly, beautiful, or pretty, [or a facetious,] word, or saying, or speech. (Lth.)

3 maAlaHotu fulaAnFA * , (A,) inf. n. mumaAlaHapN, (S, A, K,) (tropical:) I ate with such a one. (S, A, K.) Abu-l-Kásim Er-Zejjájee disapproves of this, saying that a verb of this form is only derived from an inf. n., as in the cases of DaAraba and qaAtala; whereas this is derived from miloHN, a subst. [But his objection seems to me invalid: this may be an anomalous instance, and yet of classical authority, like many others.] ― -b2- maAlaHahu, inf. n. mumaAlaHapN and milaAHN, (tropical:) He was, or became, his foster-brother. (L, TA.) [AlmilaAHu is explained in the K by AlmuraADaEapu: Lth explaines it by Alr~aDaAEu, as is mentioned in the TA: AlmumaAlaHapu is explained in the A, Mgh, L, and other lexicons by AlmuraADaEapu: in the copies of the K in my hands, by Alr~aDaAEu; and so in one copy of the S: in another copy of the S written Alr~iDaAEu; and in another Alr~DaAE, without any vowel to the r: AlrDaAEu, syn. with AlmuraADaEapu, is evidently the right reading.] Abu-l-Kásim Er-Zejjájee disapproves of the verb used as signifying the act of two men's sucking each other; [but this is not what is meant by AlmrADEp;] and pronounces it a post-classical word. (TA.) You say bayonahumaA Huromapu AlmumaAlaHapi Between them two is the sacred or inviolable bond, or obligation, which is the consequence of their being fosterbrothers. (A.)

4 A^amolaHa See 1, in four places, and 2. ― -b2- AmlH Alqawomu (assumed tropical:) The people possessed milk; (tropical:) the people had fat camels or other beasts. (L.) ― -b3- AmlH (tropical:) He (a camel) carried fat; (L;) [meaning was fat]. AmlH Alqidora (tropical:) He put some
fat [which is termed miloH] into the cookingpot. (AA.) -A2- AmlH AlA_ibila He gave the camels salt water to drink. (K.) ― -b2- AmlHt AlA_ibilu The camels came to salt water to drink. (S.) ― -b3- maA A^amayoliHa zayodFA (tropical:) [How very goodly, or beautiful, or pretty, is Zeyd! a diminutive form, meant to denote the contrary of the sense of a dim., being what is termed taSogiyru taEoZiymK, from maA A^amolaHahu:] (T, S, K:) the verb is here put into the dim. form, being meant to be used as an epithet, as though they said mulayoHN: (T:) it is the only instance of a verb put into this form, except maA A^uHayosinahu, (S, K,) and, as some say, maA A^uHayolaAhu. (TA.) This is said accord. to the doctrine of the Basrees, who assert the AfEl of wonder to be a verb: but as to the Koofees, who say that it is a noun, [meaning an epithet,] they allow the formation of the dim. from it without restriction; and from its admitting the dim. form, they argue that it is a noun. (MF.) ― -b4- maA A^amolaHa wajohahu, and fiEolahu, (tropical:) How goodly, beautiful, or pretty, is his face! and how good is his action! (A.) ― -b5- A^amoliHoniY binafasika (tropical:) Grace me, or recommend me, (zay~in~iY,) [by thy speech]. (T, L.)
5 tamal~aHa See 1, in two places. ― -b2- fulaAnN yataZar~afu wayatamal~aHu (tropical:) [Such a one affects to be clever, or graceful, and to be goodly, beautiful, pretty, or facetious]. (A.)
9 A_imolaH~a See 1, in two places.
10 AstmlHhu * (assumed tropical:) He esteemed him, or it, goodly, beautiful, or pretty; (S, K;) [pleasing to the eye or ear: (the lexicons passim:)] or found him, or it, to be so (TA.)
maloHN * : see miloHN.

miloHN * (S, M, K) and ↓ maloHN (M) (tropical:) The act of sucking the mother or any nurse; syn. raDaAEN; (S, M, K;) a child's sucking its mother. (Abu-l- Kásim Ez-Zejjájee.) ― -b2- miloHN (tropical:) Milk. (IAar.) The following verse of Abu-t-Tamahán, who had some camels, of the milk whereof he gave to drink to a people that afterwards made an attack upon them, and took them, is cited by As, [app., accord. to the S, as an ex. of mlH in the sense of raDaAE; but as MF observes, it may be taken as an ex. of that word in the sense of milk;]
wiA_in~iY laA^arojuw miloHahaA fiY buTuwnikumo
wamaA basaTato mino jildi A^a$oEava A^agobaraA
(S, L.) The poet says, Verily I hope that ye may regard (A^ano taroEawoA [which is understood]) the milk which ye have drank, of these camels, [lit., their milk in your bellies,] and the skins which they have expanded, of a people with matted and dusty hair, and of a dusty hue; as though their skins had dried up, and they had fattened upon them. [Another explanation will be noticed below.] IB says, that the last word should be read A^agobari, for the sake of the rhyme; for each verse of the poem to which it belongs ends with kesreh. (L.) -A2- miloHN a thing well known, (S, K,) [Salt;] that with which food is made pleasant: (L:) of the fem. gender (Z) generally; (O;) sometimes masc.: (K:) pl. milaAHN. (Msb.) Dim. mulayoHapN. (Msb.) ― -b2- maA='N miloHN, (S, K, &c.,) originally ↓ maliHo, from the verb maluHa, like xa$inN from xa$una, contracted because of the frequency of its usage; (Msb;) and ↓ mA' maliyHN, (K,) and ↓ maAliHN; (IAar, ADk, Az;) [respecting which last, see what will be found after the explanation;] Salt water. (S, K, &c.) J says, that maA' mAlH is not allowable, except in a bad dial.: but Az says, that, though rarely found in the language of the Arabs, it is not to be rejected; and IB says, that it occurs in verses of chaste poets; and may be considered as used after the manner of a rel. n., [meaning *uw miloHK,] like rajulN taArisN, i. e. *uw turosK, and daAriEN, i. e. *uw diroEK: (TA:) it is a chaste word, of the dial. of El-Hijáz, but extr., being from A^amolaHa AlmaA='u, like as you say baAqilN from A^aboqala AlmawoDiEu; and when it is said that it is rare, it is meant that it is not agreeable with its verb, not that it is rare with respect to usage, seeing that it is of the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz, who selected the most chaste words of the various dialects: or it is regularly formed from malaHa AlmaA^'u, a form of the verb sometimes used. (Msb.) The pl. of miloHN is miloHapN and milaAHN and milaHN: (L, K:) and sometimes is said A^amowaAhN miloHN salt waters; and rakiy~apN miloHapN a salt well. (L.) ― -b3- milaAHN Salt waters. (T, K.) ↓ qaliybN malyiHN A well of salt water: (S, K:) pl. A^aqolibapN milaAHN, occurring in a verse of 'Antarah. (S.) ― -b4- miloHN (assumed tropical:) Knowledge; science; learning; syn. EilomN. (IKh, Kz, K.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Men of science; learned men; syn. EulamaA='u. (IKh, Kz, K.) ― -b6- (tropical:) Goodliness, or beauty. (K.) [Accord. to the TA, it is an inf. n.: see maluHa.] ― -b7- (tropical:) Fat, as a subst. (Sh, K.) ― -b8- (tropical:) Fatness: (K:) or a small degree of fatness. (TA.) ― -b9- miloHN and ↓ miloHapN (tropical:) A sacred or inviolable bond, or the like, or any compact, bond, or obligation, which one is under an obligation to respect, or honour, or the cancelling or breaking of which renders one obnoxious to blame; syn. HuromapN and *imaAmN; and a compact, or confederacy; syn. HilofN. (K.) In some copies of the K, for HilofN is put HalfN. (TA.) ― -b10- Accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, this is the signification of the former word in the verse of Abu-t-Tamahán cited above, and the poet means, I hope that God may punish you for your perfidious violation of the sacred obligation to their owner, which they imposed upon you. You say bayona fulaAnK wafulaAnK miloHN, and ↓ miloHapN, There is a sacred or inviolable bond, &c., between such a one and such a one. [This meaning is derived from miloHN as signifying “ salt; ” the eating of which with another imposes upon the two parties a sacred mutual obligation.] The Arabs, says Abu-l-'Abbás, pay a high respect to salt and fire and ashes. (L.) [You say,] miloHuhu EalaY rukobatihi, so in the copies of the K, but correctly ElY rukobatayohi, as in all the other lexicons, (TA,) (tropical:) [lit., His salt is upon his knees;] meaning he has no good faith, so as to fulfil his promises, or engagements: (K:) or he has little good faith, so as to fulfil his promises, &c., for the Arabs swear by salt, and by water, because of their respect for them: (IAar:) or he violates the obligation imposed by such, the smallest thing making him forget it, like as the least thing scatters salt if a person puts it upon his knees: (T:) or he is fat: (K:) As says, that in the following verse,
laA talumohaA A_in~ahaA mino nisowapK
miloHuhaA mawoDuwEapN fawoqa Alr~ukabo
[Blame her not; for she is of women whose fat is placed above the knees;] the woman meant was of the people called Ez-Zenj, whose fat is in their thighs, and mlHhA signifies their fat: (TA:) or he is sharp in his anger: (K:) or he is of evil disposition, rendered angry by the least thing; like as salt upon the knee is scattered by the least thing: (T:) or he is frequently engaged in altercation; as though his knees were much wounded by his long kneeling in altercation, and by his long striking his knees against those of another, and he therefore put salt upon them to cure them. (A.) [See also rukobapN.] -A3- nabotN miloHN, and ↓ maAliHN, A plant of the kind called HamoDN. (ISk, S.)

malaHN * : see muloHapN. ― -b2- A certain disease and fault in the kind leg of a beast of carriage; (TA;) a swelling in the hock, or hock-tendon, (Euroquwb,) of a horse; (S, K;) less than what is called jara*N; which is a name given to it when it has become violent. (S.)
maliHN * : see miloHN.

maloHapN * (tropical:) A single feed taken by a child from the breast. malojapN, with j, signifies a single suck. (TA.) -A2- maloHapN The main body of the sea; or the fathomless deep of the sea; or a great expanse
of sea of which the extremities cannot be seen. (K.)

muloHapN * (S, K) and ↓ malaHN (K) (tropical:) A white colour intermixed with black: (S, K:) whiteness overspreading blackness in the human hair, and in anything: or a dusty white colour: or a clear white colour: or whiteness inclining to any kind of redness; like the colour of the antelope. (L.) [See also A^amolaHu.] ― -b2- Also, muloHapN (tropical:) The utmost degree of blueness or grayness, [app. meaning the latter, from miloHN as signifying “ salt, ” as salt in the state in which it is commonly used in Arabia is of a pale gray colour,] A^a$ad~u Alz~arqi: (K:) or blueness, or grayness, (zuroqap,) of such a degree as to incline to whiteness. (S.) [See A^amolaHu.] ― -b3- muloHapN (tropical:) A goodly, beautiful, pretty, or facetious, story, or narrative, and word, or saying, or speech; a bon-mot; (L;) waAHidapu AlmulaHi mina AlA^aHaAdiyvi; (S, K;) [what is deemed beautiful, elegant, facetious, or the like, of stories, &c.: (Ibr D:) and so ↓ A^umoluwHapN, coupled with A^ufokuwhapN in art. fkh in the TA:] also said to signify a bad, an abominable, or a foul, word, saying, or speech; a meaning taken from a trad. of 'Áïsheh, who applied this term [perhaps ironically] to a bad answer which she had given in consequence of her having misunderstood a question put to her: (L:) pl. mulaHN. (S, K.) As said nilotu biAlmulaHi [I have attained to the station, or rank, to which I have attained by means of goodly, or facetious, sayings, &c.] (S.) Had~avotuhu biAlmulaHi (tropical:) [I related to him goodly, beautiful, pretty, or facetious, stories.] (A.) ― -b4- [A curiosity, an extraordinary thing.]
miloHapN * : see miloHN.
maloHaAnu * : see miloHaAnu. ― -b2- [A sucker: see maS~aAnN in art. mS.]

miloHaAnu * , (S, K,) sometimes written ↓ maloHaAnu, (TA, art. $yb, voce $iybaAnu,) [written in both these ways in a copy of the S in my hands,] (tropical:) A name given to one of the winter-months, because of the whiteness of its snow: (S:) the month called Jumáda-l-Ákhireh, jumaAdaY AlA=xirapN, (K,) [in the old Arabian calendar;] because of its whiteness; Jumáda-l-Oolà, jumaAdaY AlA^uwlaY, being called $iybaAnu: or this was a name of Kánoon el-Owwal, kaAnuwnu AlA^aw~alu; (TA;) and miloHaAnu was Kánoon eth-Thánee, kaAnuwnu Alv~aAniY: (K, TA:) [but see $iybaAnu:] or $iybaAnu and miloHaAnu were names applied to the days when the earth was white with hoar-frost, or rime. ('Amr Ibn-Abee-'Amr, Az.)
mulaAHN * : see maliyHN.

maliyHN * and ↓ mulaAHN and ↓ mul~aAHN, (S, K,) but the last signifies more than the first, (T, S,) (tropical:) Goodly; beautiful; pretty; (S, Msb, K;) and beautiful of colour; or beautiful and bright; (Msb;) pleasing to the eye or ear; facetious: (the lexicons passim:) fem. of the first with p: (Msb:) pl. of the same, milaAHN and A^amolaAHN; (AA, S, K;) and of mulaAHN, mulaAHuwna; and of mul~aAHN, mul~aAHuwna. (K.) ― -b2- See miloHN. ― -b3- [Facetious speech.] ― -b4- One in whose counsel, or advice, one seeks a remedy; acc. to AA: hence the phrase qry$ mlH AlnAs: acc. to some, one with whom one finds, or esteems, it pleasant to sit and converse. (IB, in TA, voce niqaAbN.) ― -b5- A^abuw AlmaliyHi [the bird Sifrid]: see SiforidN.
milaAHapN * and ↓ mal~aAHiy~apN: see mal~aAHN.

mulaAHiY~N * , sometimes written mul~aAHiY~N, (S, K,) occurring in poetry written in the latter manner, (S,) A kind of white, long-shaped, grape: (S, K:) so called from [the colour termed] AlmuloHap; (S;) or from the [plant called] mul~aAH, because of its taste. (AHn.) ― -b2- Also, A kind of fig, (K,) small, of the colour termed A^amolaH, very sweet, and which is dried. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, A species of the tree called A^araAk in which is whiteness and redness and the colour termed $uhobap. (AHn, K.)

mal~aAHN *
A seller of salt: or a possessor of salt: (IAar, K:) as also ↓ mutamal~iHN: (K:) which also signifies one who provides himself with salt for travelling-provision: or a trader in salt. (TA.) ― -b2- mal~aAHN A sailor; a shipman; a seaman, or mariner: (T, S, K:) so called because constantly upon the salt water. (T.) ― -b3- Also, One who constantly attends to a river (nahor; in some copies of the K, baHor; TA) to put its mouth into a right or proper state. (K.) ― -b4- His occupation is called ↓ milaAHapN and ↓ mal~aAHiy~apN. (K.)

mul~aAHN * : see maliyHN. ― -b2- [A coll. gen. n.] A certain plant, (S, K,) of the kind called HamoDN; (Lth, T, S;) a leguminous garden-plant; n. un. with p; it is a tender plant, with a salt flavour, growing in smooth, or soft, and depressed, tracts of land: (T:) a herb of the kind called HamoD, having twigs and leaves, growing in tracts such as are called qifaAf, of a salt flavour, wholesome to camels and sheep: (M:) a plant like the qul~aAm, in which is a red hue, eaten with milk, bearing grain which is collected like as is that of the fav~, and made into bread, and eaten: so says AHn, and he adds, I think that it is thus called because of its colour; not because of its taste: and in another place he says, that the mul~aAH is the raceme of the kabaAv of the A^araAk; thus called because of its taste, which is hot, as though containing salt. (M.) [Suœda baccata. Forsk., Flor., 69. (Freytag.)]
mal~aAHapN * (S, K) and ↓ mamolaHapN (K) A place where salt is generated. (S, K.)
mal~aAHiy~apN * : see mal~aAHN.
maAliHN * : see miloHN and mamoluwHN.

A^amolaHu * (tropical:) A ram, (S, K,) and a he-goat, (S,) of a white colour intermixed with black: (S, K:) any hair, and wool, and the like, in which are whiteness and blackness: (TA:) that in which are whiteness and blackness, the former colour predominating: (AZ, Ks and others:) or of a dusty white colour: or of a clear white colour: (Msb:) fem. maloHaA='u; applied to a ewe of a white colour intermixed with black: (K:) or black, with its hair pervaded by whiteness. (TA.) Aboo-Dhubyán Ibn-Er-Raabal employs AmlH as one of four epithets which he applies to those old men most hateful to him. (S.) ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) Blue, or gray, [see muloHapN,] in such a degree as to incline to whiteness; an epithet applied to a man, &c. (Msb) A^amolaHN AlEayoni Having the eye of that colour. (S.) ― -b3- Hence, katiybapN maloHaA='u [meaning (tropical:) An army, or a troop of horse, appearing of a white and black, or gray, hue, by reason of their glittering weapons; see also ktybp $ahobaA='u]: (S:) or one that is white and great: (TA:) or, great. (K.) ― -b4- A^amolaHu (assumed tropical:) Dew that falls in the night upon leguminous plants: so called because of its whiteness. (L.) Er-Rá'ee says, describing some camels,
A^aqaAmato bihi Had~a Alr~abiyEi wajaAruhaA
A^axuw salowapK mas~aY bihi All~ayolu A^amolaHu
meaning [by AmlH] dew: [They remained in it during the period of the season called AlrbyE, and their preserver from thirst was attended by comfort, being dew brought by the night]: he says, they remained in that place during the days of the season called AlrbyE, and while the dew lasted, so that he was (fahuwa [but this appears to be a mistake for fahiYa, “ so that they were, ”]) in a comfortable state of life: and he says ms~Y bh because the dew falls in the night: (S, L:) by jArhA he means the night-dew which preserved them from thirst. (L.) ― -b5- AlmaloHaA='u was also the name of a particular troop belonging to the family of ElMundhir, (S, K,) of the Kings of Syria, who had another called Al$~ahobaA='u. (TA.) ― -b6- namirapN maloHaA='u A burodap with black and white stripes. (L.) $ajarapN maloHaA='u (assumed tropical:) A tree of which the leaves have fallen, (L, K,) the branches, or twigs, remaining green. (L.) ― -b7- AlmaloHaA='u (in a camel, L) (assumed tropical:) Certain flesh in the back, (situate within, L,) extending from the withers (AlkaAhil) to the rump: (L, K:) or the middle of the back, between the withers (AlkAhl) and the rump: (T, S [in neither of which is reference made here to a camel]:) or the part between the hump of a camel and its rump: or
the vertebræ of a camel over which is the hump: (L:) or, in a camel, the part beneath the hump; containing six vertebræ (maHaAlaAt): pl. maloHaAwaAtN. (T.) faArsu AlmaloHaA='i The fat of the hump. (L.) ― -b8- A^amolaHu A horse having the kind of swelling called malaHN. (TA.)
A^umoluwHapN * : see muloHapN.
mamolaHapN * : see mal~aAHapN.

mimolaHapN *
A thing [or vessel or the like] in which salt is put. (S, A.)

mamoluwHN * and ↓ mumal~iHN (tropical:) A fat camel. (L.) ― -b2- ↓ mumal~iHN (tropical:) A camel destined for slaughter that is fat: (S:) or having some remains of fatness. (L.) -A2- samakN mamoluwHN, and ↓ maliyHN, (S, K,) and ↓ miloHN, (Msb,) Salted fish; (S, K;) i. q. ↓ mumal~aHN. (K.) You should not say maAliHN. As to the saying of 'Odháfir,
baSoriy~apN tazaw~ajato baSoriy~aA
wAlT~ariy~aA ↓ yuToEimuhaA AlmaAliHa
[A woman of El-Basrah who married a man of El-Basrah: he fed her with salted and fresh], it is not an evidence. (S.) ISd says, that some have disapproved of this word, as also of mlyH, not regarding the above verse as an evidence. You says, that mlyH and mmlwH are better than mAlH. (TA.)
mumal~aHN * and mumal~iHN: see mamoluwHN.
mutamal~iHN * : see mal~aAHN.

1 malaxa * , aor.
malaxa , inf. n. maloxN; (K;) and ↓ Amtlx; (L;) He pulled, or drew, a thing, grasping with the hand, or biting, (L, K,) and so pulling or drawing it out. (L.) ― -b2- ↓ Amtlx He pulled out a thing; (L, K;) drew it forth: or drew it forth quickly. (L.) He drew his sword. (S, K.) He pulled out his tooth: (S:) and his eye. (Lh.) It (an eagle) pulled out an eye; (S;) as also ↓ tml~x. (K, TA.) He pulled away his hand from the hand of a person grasping him. (L.) He pulled out a ripe date from its skin. (L.) He pulled off flesh from a bone. (L.) He pulled off the bridle and bit from the head of a beast of carriage. (L, K.) ― -b3- malaxa, aor.
malaxa , (L, K,) inf. n. maloxN, (S, L, K,) He went, or journeyed, at a vehement rats: (S, L, K:) or, at an easy rate: and, sometimes, vehemently: (ISd:) or, quickly: (TA:) or he (a beast) stretched forth his arms in the pace called HuDor, in any way, well or ill. (Ibn-Hánee.) ― -b4- malaxa fiY AlA^aroDi He went away journeying through the land, or earth. (TA.) ― -b5- fulaAnN yamolaxu fiY AlbaATili, (S,) inf. n. maloxN, (S, K,) Such a one goes to and fro, and occupies himself much, in vain affairs: (S, K:) or goes quickly and easily therein: (Sh:) or plays, or sports, and perseveres, therein. (L.) ― -b6- maloxN AlbaATili i. q. Alt~abaxoturu [Walking in an affected manner] (L, in art. Dndd.) ― -b7- malaxa Alqawomu maloxapF SaAliHapF The people, or party, went, or journeyed, far in the land. (S.) ― -b8- malaxa He (a man) fled (IAar; and Az, from several Arabs of the desert.) -A2- maluxa, aor.
maluxa , inf. n. malaAxapN, It (flesh-meat) was, or became, tasteless, or insipid; (S;) [i. q. masuxa]. See salaAxapN.
5 tamal~axa see 1.
8 A_imotalaxa see 1.

maliyxN * , applied to flesh-meat, (S,) or, accord. to some, specially to a new-born camel that is slaughtered when it falls from its mother's belly, (L,) That has no taste; tasteless; insipid; (S, L, K;) i. q. masiyxN. (S.) See saliyxN. ― -b2- Corrupt: (L, K:) or any corrupt food. (IAar, L.) ― -b3- maliyxN Milk that slips from the hand. (L.)

[
maluwxiy~apN *
Corchorus olitorius, or Jews' mallow: so used in the present day. See xub~aAzN.]

mal~aAxN *
Vehement in journeying, or in his pace. (S, * TA.) ― -b2- A slave who runs away often. (L, K.)

maAlixN *
Fleeing; as also maAxilN and xaAmilN. (Az.)

mumotalaxu AlEaqoli * (tropical:) A man deprived, or despoiled of his reason. (S, TA.) ― -b2- AlS~ulobi ↓ mutamal~ixi A man weakened, or enervated, in the back-bone, or back; (K;) as though it were pulled asunder. (TA.)
mutamal~ixN * : see mumotalaHN.

1 malida * , [aor.
malada ,] (TA,) inf. n. maladN (K, TA) and maladaAnN, (M,) It (a branch, M, TA) was, or became, soft, tender, or delicate; (M, K;) and quivered, shook, or played loosely. (M, K, TA.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. maladN, (tropical:) He (a youth) was, or became, soft, tender, or delicate. (T, S, L.) ― -b3- See also maladN, below. ― -b4- maladahu He drew or pulled it; strained it; or extended or stretched it; syn. mad~ahu. (K.)
2 ml~dhu * , inf. n. tamoliydN, It (the imbibing of moisture) rendered it (a branch) soft, tender, or delicate. (T, L.) ― -b2- He softened it, namely a tanned skin or hide. (S, L, K.)
malodN * : see A^umoluwdN. ― -b2- Also, The [creature called] guwl; (K;) i. e., i. q. siEolaApN; or an enchantress of the jinn. (TA.)

maladN * : see malida. ― -b2- maladN, (M, L, K,) and ↓ maladaAnN (K) (tropical:) Youth, or youthfulness; and its softness, tenderness, or delicateness. (M, L, K. * [In the CK, for naEomap, is erroneously put niEomapN.])
maladaAnu * : see maladN.
A^amoladu * , A^umoludN, &c.: see A^umoluwdN.

A^umoluwdN * (S, M, A, L, K) and ↓ A_imoliydN (M, L, K) and ↓ A^amoladN (S, M, L, K) and ↓ A^umoludN and ↓ A^umoludaAnN and ↓ A^umoludaAniY~N and ↓ malodN (M, L, K) Soft, tender, or delicate; (S, M, L, K;) and lithe or limber: (M, K:) the first (S, M, L, K) and second, (M, L, K,) or all, (K,) applied to a branch: (S, M, L, K:) and the first and third, (S, M, L, K,) or all, (M, L, K,) applied in the same sense to (tropical:) a man, or young man: (S, M, L, K:) or A^umolwdN, applied to a young man, (tropical:) beardless: (A:) or perfect in make, or full-grown, pubescent, and well-formed: (T, L:) and A^umoluwdN (S, M, L, K) and A^umoluwdapN (M, L, K) and A^umoludaAniy~apN (M, L) or A^umoluwdaAniy~apN (K) and malodaA='u (S, M, L, K) and malodaAniy~apN (M, L, K) [in the CK muloda Aniy~apN] applied to a woman, or a damsel, (tropical:) soft, tender, or delicate; (S, M, L, K;) and of just stature: (L:) pl. of A^umoluwdN (A, TA) and of A_imoliydN (TA) A^amaAliydu; (A, TA;) and of malodN, A^amolaAdN. (M, L.) The A^ in Amlwd and Amlyd is to render them quasi-coordinate to words of the classes of EusoluwjN and qiTomiyrN; as is shown by their having the augmentative letters w and Y. (IJ, M, L.)
A_imoliydN * : see A^umoluwdN. ― -b2- Also, applied to a desert (SaHoraA=') i. q. A_imoliysN (S, L, K) i. e., Bare, in which is nothing. (L.)

1 mala*a * , aor.
malu*a , inf. n. malo*N, He was quick in coming and going. (M, L.) This is the original signification. (L.) ― -b2- He (a horse) was quick in his running. (K, in which only the inf. n. is mentioned.) ― -b3- He (a-horse) stretched forth his arms, (ma*~a DaboEayohi, S, M, L, K,) in running, (S,) to a degree that he could not exceed, to overtake, (Hat~aY laA yajida maziydFA lil~iHaAqK, M, L, K,) and contracted, or drew in, (Habasa, [perhaps a mistake for xanasa, which may mean either contracted, or threw back,]) his hind legs to a degree that he could not exceed, to overtake, without any confusion [in his motions]. (M, L.) ― -b4- mala*ahu, aor.
malu*a , inf. n. malo*N and malaA*apN, He contented him with courteous and soothing speech, and made him to hear that which rejoiced him, without doing, or performing, anything. (T, L.) Accord. to Aboo-Is-hák, the * in this word is a substitute for v. (M, L.) See malavahu. ― -b5- mala*a, inf. n. malo*N, He lied; (K;) as also malava. (TA.) ― -b6- mala*ahu, (S, L,) inf. n. malo*N,
(S, L, K,) He smote him and pierced him with a spear. (S, L, K. *)
mala*aAnN * and mala*aAniY~N and malaA*aAniY~N: see mal~aA*N.
maluw*N * : see mal~aA*N.

mal~aA*N * A man who says but does not act, or perform; (S, L, K;) a liar; (S, L;) who behaves in an artificial manner, and is not true in his affection; (M, L, K;) as also ↓ maluw*N (M, L [in the K milowa*N, and said to be of the same measure as minobarN; but this seems to be a mistake]) and ↓ mala*aAnN and ↓ mala*aAniY~N (M, L, K) and ↓ malaA*aniY~N: (M, K:) [in some copies of the K, by a mistake in the last vowel-sign, each of the last three of these epithets is as though it were syn. with malo*N, the inf. n of mala*a, “ he lied ” &c.:] or a liar, who, if asked, will not tell truly whence he comes; as also all the above epithets: (M, L:) and ↓ mala*aAnN one who makes a show of sincerity, faithfulness, or honesty, concealing, or meditating, what is different therefrom. (S, L.) ― -b2- Also mal~aA*N Stealthy, (M, L,) and light, or active; applied to a wolf. (M, L, K.)
See art. mlS and Supplement.

1 malusa * , aor.
malusa ; (M, A, Msb, K;) and malisa, aor.
malasa ; (Msb;) or the second form is malasa, aor.
malusa ; (K;) [but the last of the inf. ns. here following seems to indicate that malisa is correct;] inf. n. malaAsapN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and muluwsapN, (M, K,) [accord. to rule, both of the first,] and malasN, (M, TA,) [accord. to rule, of the second;] It was, or became, smooth, sleek, or free from asperities; the inf. n. being the contr. of xu$uwnapN; (S, M, K;) it had in it nothing upon which to lay hold; it was, or became, smooth to the feel; (Msb;) and ↓ AmlAs~ signifies the same, (S, M,) inf. n. A_imoliysaAsN; (S;) and ↓ Amls~: (so in a copy of the A) and [in like manner] ↓ tml~s (S, A) and ↓ A_im~alasa, of the measure A_inofaEala, the n being incorporated into the m, both signify it was, or became, made, or rendered, smooth, &c. (S.) See also 4. -A2- malasa, aor.
malusa , inf. n. malosN, (tropical:) He (a man) went away quickly, or swiftly: (TA:) and malasati Aln~aAqapu, (M,) and AlA_ibilu, (A,) aor. and inf. n. as before, (M,) (tropical:) the she-camel, (M,) and the camels, (A,) went quickly, or swiftly: (M, A:) or malosN signifies the going easily, or gently: and also, contr., the going vehemently: (M:) or a gentle mode of going or journeying: (IAar:) and the being light, or active, and quick. (TA.) It is said in a trad., siro valaAvFA malosFA, i. e., valaAva layaAlK *awaAti malosK; or valaAvFA sayorFA malosFA; (tropical:) [Journey thou three nights of quick, or of easy, journeying; or with a quick, or an easy, journeying;] or mlsA signifies a certain mode of going or journeying; and is in the accus. case as an inf. n. (TA.) malasa, aor. and inf. n. as above, also signifies (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) went back, or retired, (A_inoxanasa,) quickly; (M;) and so ↓ A_im~alasa. (M, TA.) -A3- malasa AlZ~alaAmu, [aor.
malusa ,] (TK,) inf. n. malosN, (A, K,) or malasN, (S, M,) The darkness became confused; (S, M, A, K;) as also ↓ A^amolasa, (TK,) inf. n. A_imolaAsN: (K:) or became in the state after that which is termed malavN, (M,) or malovN. (TA.) See malosN below.

2 ml~shu * , inf. n. tamoliysN, He rendered it smooth, sleek, or free from asperities. (S.) You say, ml~s AlA^aroDa, (TA,) biAlomal~aAsapi, (A,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) [He smoothed the land with the ml~Asp;] he drew the mimolaqap [or ml~Asp] over the land, [and so made it smooth, or even,] after the ploughing and sowing thereof. (TA.) -A2- Also, (S, A,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He made him to escape; or to be, or become, or get, clear, quit, free, or at liberty; mina AlA^amori from the thing, or affair; (S, K;) and mno yadi gayorihi from the hand of another. (A.)
4 A^amolasa see 1. ― -b2- A^amolasato $aAtuka The wool of thy sheep, or ewe, fell off: (K:) from Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.)

5 tml~s * : see malusa. -A2- It (a smooth thing) slipped forth from the hand [&c.]. (Har, p. 119.) ― -b2- And hence, (Har, ubi supra,) (tropical:) He escaped; got away; or was, or became, or got, clear, quit, free, or at liberty; (S, * M, A, Msb, * K,) as also ↓ Anmls, (S, A, K,) and ↓ A_im~alasa, of the measure A_ifotaEala, [or rather A_inofaEala,] and ↓ AmlAs~; (K;) mina AlA^amori from the thing or affair; (S, A, TA;) and mino yadiY from my hand. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence,] tml~s mina Al$~araAbi (assumed tropical:) He recovered from the wine. (AHn, M.)
7 Anmls * and A_im~alasa : see malusa: -A2- and malasa: -A3- and 5.
8 A_imotalasa see 5. -A2- A^umotulisa baSaruhu (tropical:) His sight was suddenly taken away. (M, A, K.)
9 A_imolas~a see malusa.
11 A_imolaAos~a see malusa: -A2- and 5.

malosN * : see A^amolasu. -A2- Also, malosN, (A, K,) or ↓ malasN, (S, M,) The confusedness of the darkness: (S, M, A, K:) or it is after the malav, (M,) or malov: (TA:) the mlv is the first, or commencement, of the blackness of the west; and the mls is when the blackness has become intense, so that the time of the last Ei$aA=' comes; then the mls becomes confounded with the mlv, and the one is not distinguished from the other. (IAar.) You say, AlZ~alaAmi ↓ A^atayotuhu malasa, (S, M,) or malosa AlZlAm, (TA,) I came to him when the darkness had become confused; (S, TA;) when the night had become confused with the earth. (TA.) The word is used adverbially and otherwise. (M.) See malasa AlZ~alaAmu.
malasN * : see A_imoliysN, in two places: -A2- and malosN, throughout.

malasaY * : see A_imoliysN. -A2- (tropical:) A she-camel that escapes and goes away so quickly that nothing attaches, or clings, to her: (S:) or quick, or swift, in the utmost degree: (Z, K:) or quick, or swift; as also ↓ maluwsN: (M:) or the latter signifies a she-camel excellent, or good, in the pace termed Eanaq, [so I render miEonaAqN,] that outstrips, and is seen to be first among the camels in the place of pasturage and the watering-place and every journeying. (AZ, K. *) ― -b2- Also, (assumed tropical:) A man who will not remain firm to a compact, covenant, engagement, or promise; like as the smooth thing will not remain firm. (M.) It is said in a proverb, (El-Ahmar, M,) alluding to dislike, or hatred, of faults or the like, (El-Ahmar, TA,) AlmalasaY laA Eahoda lahu (assumed tropical:) [He who will not remain firm to a compact, &c., for him there is no compact, &c.]; (El-Ahmar, M;) meaning, that he has got out of the affair in safety, there being nothing due to him, nor anything to be demanded of him. (El-Ahmar, TA.) [But see what here follows.] ― -b3- It is said in a proverb, applied to him in whose fidelity one does not trust, (TA,) AlmalasaY laA Euhodapa lahu, meaning *uw AlmalasaY; (Az, L, Msb, TA;) i. e., (assumed tropical:) He who steals a commodity, and sells it for less than its price, and escapes immediately and hides himself, so that if he who has a just claim to it come, he finds his property in the hand of him who purchased it, he takes it, and the price which the thief gained goes for nought, and the purchaser cannot return to him to recover the price: (Az, TA:) or it means, (assumed tropical:) he who goes away privily, gets out of the affair in safety, there being nothing due to him, nor anything to be demanded of him: or AmlsY means, a (assumed tropical:) man's selling a commodity which he has stolen, and abating the price, and then absenting himself; so that when it is plucked from the hand of the purchaser, he cannot sue the seller as responsible for the loss thereof: (Msb:) or (tropical:) the sale to which attaches no claim upon the seller for having acted unjustly: (A, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) the selling a thing without making one's self responsible for any loss or the like that may be occasioned by it. (TA.) One says, also, in selling, malasaY laA Euhodapa, meaning, that he has escaped from the affair, or become quit of it; that there is nothing due to him, nor
anything to be demanded of him: [i. e., (assumed tropical:) I am quit of the affair: no claim shall be made for indemnification.] (S.) You say, also, A^abiyEuka AlmalasaY laA Euhodapa, meaning, (tropical:) [I sell to thee on the condition that] thou shalt get thee away, and not return to me, (S, Msb, K,) nor have any claim upon me for indemnification. (Msb.) [In some copies of the S, here and in art. Ehd, the verbs by which the meaning is explained are of the third person, as though referring to the things sold; but the right reading I hold to be that which I have followed. See also art. Ehd.]
maluwsN * : see malasaY.
maliysN * : see A^amolasu, in two places: -A2- and A_imoliysN.
mulayosaA='u * : dim. of malosaA='u, fem. of A^amolasu, which see, in two places.

mal~aAsapN *
An implement (S, A, K) of wood (A, TA) with which land is made smooth, or even; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ mimolasapN. (A, TA.)

A^amolasu *
Smooth; sleek; free from asperities; [contr. of xa$inN;] (S, M, K;) having in it nothing upon which to lay hold; smooth to the feel; (Msb;) and ↓ maliysN signifies the same; (TA;) and ↓ malosN [in like manner], anything smooth or soft: (TA:) fem. of the first, malosaA='u: (M, A, &c.:) and pl. mulosN. (A.) You say, vawobN A^amolasu [A smooth garment, or piece of cloth]. And SaxorapN malosaA='u [A smooth rock]. (A, TA.) And qawosN malosaA='u and ↓ maliysN A bow in which is no crack. (M.) And Darabahu EalaY malosaA='i matonihi and ↓ mulayosaAy^ihi He struck him upon the even and smooth part of his back. (M.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A camel (A) having a sound back, (S, K,) free from mange or scab. (A, TA.) So in the proverb, (S,) haAna EalaY AlA^amolasi maA laAqaY Ald~abiru (tropical:) [What he that had galls on his back experienced was a light matter to him that had a sound back]: (S, K:) applied to him who has an ill concern for his companion. (K.) ― -b3- A^aroDN malosaA='u: see A_imoliysN. ― -b4- sanapN malosaA='u (tropical:) A year without herbage: (A:) or a year of sterility: pl. A^amaAliysu, contr. to rule. (M.) ― -b5- AlmalosaA='u (tropical:) The lowest heaven. (TA, art. jrb.) ― -b6- qahowapN malosaA='u (A) or xamorN malosaA='u (K) (tropical:) Wine easy to swallow; (A;) wine that descends easily in the throat. (K.) ― -b7- malosaA='u [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates] (assumed tropical:) Sour milk with which pure [fresh] milk is mixed; as also ↓ mulayosaA='u. (IDrd, K.) ― -b8- jiloduhu A^amolasu (tropical:) He has no blame attaching to him. (A, TA.) ― -b9- ximosN A^amolasu (tropical:) A fatiguing, severe [journey such as is called] xms. (K.)

A_imoliysN * (S, K,) and with p, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) (tropical:) A desert in which is no herbage: pl. A^amaAliysu (S, K) and A^amaAlisu, [the latter] contr. to general rule, (K,) the Y being suppressed by poetic licence: (TA:) or A^amaAlisu signifies land in which are no trees, nor fresh nor dry herbage, nor wild animals; sing, A_imoliysN; app. from malaAsapN, [inf. n. of malusa,] i. e., smooth land, in which is nothing: (Sh, L, TA: *) or A^amaAliysu is pl. of A^amolaAsN, which is pl. [of pauc.] of ↓ malasN, meaning, an even place, (M, TA,) in which is no herbage; (TA;) and the pl. of mult. is muluwsN: and you say also, ↓ A^aroDN malasN and ↓ malasaY and ↓ malosaA='u and A_imoliysN, meaning, land that produces no herbage; (M, TA;) and the pl. is A^amaAlisu and A^amaAliysu, contr. to analogy [unless pls. of A_imoliysN, in which case the former only is so]. (TA.) ― -b2- You say also, rum~aAnN A_imoliysN (T, M, TA,) and ↓ A_imoliysiY~N, (T, S, M, K, TA,) as though the latter were a rel. n. from A_imoliysN, (T, S, K, TA,) not, as is implied in the [S, and] K, as meaning a desert, but as syn. with ↓ A_imoliysiY~N; (TA;) (assumed tropical:) A sweet pomegranate, having no stones: (T, M, TA:) and accord. to Lth, rum~aAnN maliysN signifies (assumed tropical:) the sweetest kind of pomegranate, which is that without stones. (TA.) [See $anobaA='u, voce A^a$onabu.]
A_imoliysapN * : see A_imoliysN.
A_moliysiY~N * : see A_imoliysN.
mmolasapN * : see mal~aAsapN.

1 maliSa * , (S, M, A, K,) aor.
malaSa , (S, K,) inf. n. malaSN, (S, M,) It (a thing, S, M, or a rope, Lh, M, A, and a bridle, Lh, M,) slipped; (S;) or fell, slipping; (K;) or got loose or free, or escaped, and slipped [away]; (A;) or slipped out by reason of its smoothness; (M;) from one's hand; (S, M, A;) as also ↓ A_im~alaSa, and ↓ tml~S: (M:) or ↓ AnmlS, (S, K,) also written A_im~alaSa, (S,) signifies it (a thing, Lth, S,) escaped, or got loose or free, (Lth, S,) from one's hand, after having been seized or grasped: (Lth:) and [in like manner] ↓ tml~S, it, and he, (a thing, S, or a rope, TA, and a man, S, A,) became safe or secure or free, or escaped, (S, A, K,) from one's hand. (TA.) You say, maliSati Als~amakapu mino yadiY and ↓ AnmlSt The fish escaped and slipped from my hand. (A, TA.) And maA kidotu mino fulaAnK ↓ A^atamal~aSu I hardly escaped, or became secure, from such a one. (S, A. *) ― -b2- He went back, or retreated, fleeing; as also maliza, inf. n. malazN. (TA.) -A2- malaSahu He set it loose, or free. (TA.) ― -b2- malaSa bisaloHihi Alvum dejecit: (K:) so says Ibn-'Abbád: but in the Tekmileh, malaSa bisahomihi he shot his arrow. (TA.)

4 AmlS * , (K,) inf. n. A_imolaASN, (TA,) It (a thing) made, or caused, to slip. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) AmlSt janiynahaA, (Mgh, TA,) or bijanyinihaA, (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA,) or biwaladihaA, (S,) or AmlSt [alone], (M, A, K,) She (a woman, S, M, A, Mgh, and a camel, M, TA) brought forth her fœtus, or offspring, prematurely, (S, M, A, Mgh,) or dead: (K:) i. q. A^azolaqato bihi and A^asohalato bihi and HaTaA^ato bihi. (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA.) ― -b3- AmlS also signifies He (a man) became poor, needy, or indigent. (TA.)
5 tamal~aSa see 1, in three places.
7 AnmlS * and Am~lS : see 1, in three places; and see 7 in art. dlS.

maloSN * (tropical:) Naked: [in the present day commonly preceded by EuroyaAn (vulgarly pronounced EaroyaAn), and with it signifying stark naked:] as though become divested of his clothes like a rope that is become divested of its villous coating. (TA.)

maliSN * A thing that slips out from one's hand by reason of its smoothness; as also ↓ maliySN and ↓ A^amolaSu: (M:) a rope from which the hand slips, (S, K,) not being able to keep hold of it; (S, TA;) as also ↓ maliySN. (TA.) You say, samakapN maliSapN (M, A) A fish that slips from the hand by reason of its smoothness: (M:) or that gets loose or free, or escapes, and slips [away]: (A:) or, accord. to AA, (TA,) AlmaliSapu signifies AlA^aTuwmu mina Als~amaki [app. meaning a kind of thick-skinned fish]. (K, TA.)
maliySN * : see maliSN, in two places: ― -b2- and see mumolaSN, in two places.
A^amolaSu * : see maliSN. You say also, rajulN A^amolaSu Alr~aA^osi, i. e. A^abolaTuhu [app. meaning A smooth-headed man.] (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- Also, Tender; or soft. (TA.)

mumolaSN *
Brought forth prematurely; as also ↓ maliySN: (M, TA:) an abortion. (TA.) You say, A^aloqato waladahaA mumolaSFA She cast her young one prematurely; (TA;) as also ↓ maliySFA and maliyTFA. (K, TA.)
mumoliSN * A woman, and a she-camel, (M,) that brings forth her offspring prematurely, (M,) or dead: (K:) pl. mamaAliySu, with Y. (M, TA.)

mimolaASN * A woman, and a she-camel, (M,) that usually brings forth her offspring prematurely, (M,) or dead.. (K.) [Several points of resemblance, and some of exact agreement, will be observed between this art. and art. mls.]

1 maliTa * , aor.
malaTa , (K,) inf. n. malaTN (S, K) and
muloTapN, (K,) He (a man) had little, scanty, or thin, hair upon the sides of his face, or of his cheeks: (S [which indicates that it is like mariTa:]) or had no hair upon his body, (K, TA,) but only upon his head and beard. (TA.) -A2- See also 4.

4 A^amolaTato * , (S,) or AmlTt janiynahaA, (K.) She (a camel) cast her fœtus (S, K) before it had hair growing upon it; (S;) without any hair upon it: (K:) [like A^amoraTatohu] and A^um~uhu ↓ malaTatohu, (K,) aor.
maluTa , (TA,) she brought it forth in an imperfect state. (K.) ― -b2- A^amolaTa [perhaps a mistake for A^abolaTa] He became poor, needy, or indigent; like A^amolaSa. [TA, art. mlS.]

5 tml~T *
It (an arrow) was, or became, without feathers upon it. (K.) ― -b2- It [a thing] was, or became, made, or rendered, smooth; syn. tml~S. (Sgh, K.)

8 AmtlThu *
He seized it, took it hastily, or snatched it unawares,; (Sgh, K;) like AmtrThu. (TA.)
milaATN * [gypsum]: see $iydN. ― -b2- The shoulderblade; syn. katifN: (TA, art. srH:) or the humerus, or upper bone, of the arm; syn. EaDudN. (T, ibid.) of a camel. (ISh, ibid.)

maliyTN * The fœtus of a camel having as yet no hair grown upon it: (S, K:) or that is cast prematurely; as also maliySN. (K, TA, in art. mlS.) ― -b2- Also, A lamb or kid: or one just born. (TA.) ― -b3- See also what next follows.

A^amolaTu * A man having little, or scanty, or thin, hair upon the sides of his face, or of his cheeks; like A^amoraTu: (S:) or having no hair upon his body, (Lth, K,) except the head and beard. (Lth.) ― -b2- An arrow of which the feathers have fallen off; like A^amoraTu: (S:) or an arrow having no feathers upon it; as also ↓ maliyTN. (K.)
mumoliTN * [like mumoriTN] A she-camel casting her fœtus without any hair upon it: pl. mamaAliyTu, (K, TA,) with Y. (TA.)
mimolaATN * [like mimoraATN] A she-camel that usually casts her fœtus without any hair upon it. (K.)

div2.head: mlE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 manaA^a * , aor.
manaAa , (S, K,) inf. n. mano'N, (S,) He soaked a hide in tanning-liquid, or ooze. (S, K.) -A2- manaA^ahu He conformed with him in what he did. (TA.)

maniyoy^apN *
A hide in the first stage of tanning: (AZ, S, K:) it is next called A^afiyqN; and then A^adiymN: (AZ, S:) or a hide as long as it remains in the tanning-liquid. (TA.) ― -b2- A place where hides are tanned. (As, Ks, S, K.) ― -b3- Also, accord. to some, Tan, or that with which one tans. (TA.) ― -b4- This word is not to be pronounced without ', because maniy~apN signifies “ death. ” (MF.)

mamonaA^apN *
A black land: (K:) also without '. (TA.)
See Supplement

[
manojaniyqN mnjnyq , as described in art. jnq (q. v.), seems to be the engine called by the Romans Onager: see Kitto's Pict. Bible, ii. 499: but was probably applied also to the balista.]

1 manaHahu * , aor.
manaHa and
maniHa , inf. n. manoHN, He lent him a she-camel, and a sheep or goat; (L;) that he might have the milk thereof, and return the animal after a certain period: this is the original signification: (L:) or he lent to him a she-camel, assigning to him her soft hair (wabar) and milk and offspring: (Lh, L, K:) and in like manner, he lent him a piece of land, that he might cultivate it and have the produce thereof: (L:) he lent him money or the like, to be repaid. (A, TA.) ― -b2- manaHahu, aor.
manaHa and
maniHa , (S, K,) inf. n. manoHN, (S,) He gave him a thing: (S, K:) he gave him a thing as a free gift. (A, TA.) ― -b3- tamonaHu AlmaroA^apu wajohahaA AlmiroA=pa The woman imparts somewhat of her beauty to the mirror: or directs her face towards the mirror. And in like manner, accord. to some, you say, when you direct anything (taqoSidu bihi) towards another thing, manaHotuhu A_iy~aAhu. (L.)

3 mAnHhu * , inf. n. mumaAnaHapN, He aided him, or assisted him, reciprocally, with a gift. (A.) ― -b2- mAnHt, inf. n. minaAHN and mumaAnaHapN, (tropical:) She (a camel) yielded plenty of milk in the winter, after the milk of the other camels had passed away. (L.) ― -b3- (tropical:) It (the eye) shed tears continuously. (K.)

4 AmnHt *
She (a camel) was near to bringing forth. (S, K.) Sh says, I know not AmnHt in this sense: but Az says that it is correct, and that the objection of Sh does not invalidate it. (TA.)
5 taman~aHotu AlmaAla * (tropical:) I fed others with the property. So in the trad. of Umm-Zara, waA=kulu faA^ataman~aHu (tropical:) And I eat, and then feed others. (K, TA.)

8 A_imotanaHa *
He took or received, a gift. (K.) ― -b2- A^umotuniHa maAlFA He was supplied with property, or wealth, by God. (K.)

10 AstmnHhu *
He asked, desired, or sought, a loan, or gift, (minoHap,) of him; i. e., asked, desired, or sought aid, or assistance, from him; syn. A_isotarofadahu; (S;) or asked, &c., a gift from him. (K.)

minoHapN *
A loan, or lending, of a she-camel or sheep or goat, that the person to whom the loan is granted may milk her for a certain period and then restore her to the lender: (A'Obeyd:) [and in like manner,] ↓ maniyHapN a gift (minoHap) of milk; as a she-camel or sheep or goat that is given to another that he may milk her and afterwards restore her to the lender: (S:) or minoHapN signifies a ewe or a she-goat or a she-camel, which her owner lends to a man that he may drink her milk and restore her when her milk ceases to flow: (Msb:) or both words signify a she-camel or sheep or goat whose milk is given to another: (A:) or a she-camel of which the soft hair (wabar) and milk and offspring are conceded by the owner to another: (K:) or ↓ maniyHapN signifies a she-camel or sheep or goat that is lent for the sake of her milk [&c.]; and minoHapN, the profit which the lender thereof bestows upon the borrower. (Lh, L.) The Arabs have four words which they use in the place of EaAriy~apN, viz. ↓ maniyHapN, Eariy~apN, A_ifoqaArN, and A_ixobaAlN. (A'Obeyd, S.) ― -b2- minoHapN mino layanK Milch sheep or goats; (L;) [app. meaning, that are lent to a person]. ― -b3- Also minoHapN A loan of land, and of money. (L.) ― -b4- Also, A gift, or thing given; (S, L, K;) as also ↓ maniyHapN: (TA:) a free gift: (A'Obeyd, L:) pl. minaHN; (A;) and pl. of maniyHapN, manaAy^iHu. (TA.)
manuwHN * : see mumaAniHN.

AlmaniyHu *
An arrow (of those used in the game called Almayosir, S) which has no lot, or portion, (S, K,) unless the person to whom it pertains be given something: (S:) it is the third of the arrows to which the term gufolN is applied, which have no notches, and to which is assigned no portion and no fine; these being only added to give additional weight to the collection of arrows from fear of occasioning suspicion [of foul play]: it is one of four arrows to each of which is assigned no portion and no fine; the first is called AlmuSad~aru; the next, AlmuDaE~afa; the next, AlmnyH; and the last, Als~afiyHu: (Lh:) accord. to some, (TA,) an arrow that is borrowed because it is regarded as fortunate: (K, TA:) or an arrow which has a portion assigned to it. (K.) ― -b2- kunotu maniyHa A^aSoHaAbiY yawoma badorK (assumed tropical:) I was, among my companions, like the arrow called AlmnyH, on the day of the battle of Bedr; i. e., by reason of my youth, I was like the arrow that neither gains nor loses. (L, from a trad.)
maniyHapN * : see minoHapN.
man~aAHN * One who gives many gifts. (TA.)
mumoniHN * A she-camel near to bringing forth. (S, K.)
mimonaHN * and mamaAniHu: see mumaAniHN.

mumaAniHN * (S, K) and ↓ manuwHN (S) (tropical:) A she-camel whose milk remains, (K,) or that yields plenty of milk in the winter, (S,) after the milk of the other camels has passed away; (S, K;) like mujaAliHN. (S.) You say also ↓ nuwqN mamaAniHu [app. pl. of mimonaHN, which is perhaps not used. (TA.) ― -b2- Also the former, (tropical:) Rain that does not cease: (K:) and (tropical:) wind of which the rain does not cease. (TA.)

munodu * is a simple word; (K;) or, accord. to some, a compound word, as will be explained hereáfter: (TA:) Sb says, that it is with respect to time like mino with respect to place: (S, L:) it is indecl., [generally] with damm for its termination; and mu*o is indecl. also, [generally] with its final letter quiescent, (S, L, K,) [unless followed by a quiescent letter, when it is movent in different manners which will be shown below,] and it is formed from muno*u by elision: (M, L, K:) mn* is also written and pronounced mino*u, (M, L, K,) in the dial. of the Benoo-Suleym; (M, L;) and m*, mi*o, (M, L, K,) in the dial. of the tribe of 'Okl. (M, L.) Each may be a prep., governing what follows it in the gen. case, and used in the same manner as fiY [signifying In, or during, or from the beginning of]: and in this case, each is prefixed only to that which denotes present time: thus you say, maA raA^ayotuhu mu*u All~ayolapi [I have not seen him in this night; or simply I have not seen him this night]: (S, L:) or each is followed by a noun in the gen. case, and in this instance is a prep., in the sense of mino [meaning Since, or lit., from,] when relating to a past time [such as a particular past day or the like]; and in the sense of fiY [meaning In, or from the beginning of,] when relating to the present time; and in the sense of mino and A_ilaY together [meaning From the beginning to the end of; or during the whole course of; or simply during, or for;] when relating to a computed period of time, or number of days or the like: ex. [relating to a past time,] maA raA^ayotuhu muno*u yawomi Alxamiysi [I have not seen him since Thursday, A_ilaY A@loA=na to the present time]; (Mughnee, K;) and [relating to the present time,] muno*u yawominaA or EaAminaA [in, or from the beginning of, (this) our day, or (this) our year;]; and, [relating to a computed period of time, or number of days or the like,] muno*u valaAvapi A^ay~aAmK [from the beginning to the end of, i. e., during, or for, three days]. (Mughnee.) Each may also be a noun, governing the noun which follows it in the nom. case, as signifying a particular day or the like, or as signifying a definite length of time: in the case of a noun signifying a particular day or the like, you say, maA raA^ayotuhu mu*o yawomu AljumoEapi [I have not seen him (since the commencement of a space of time); the commencement of the space of time thereof (i. e., A^aw~alu mud~api Eadami ruw^oyatiY A_iy~aAhu the commencement of the space of time of my not seeing him) was Friday; meaning, since Friday]: and, in the case of a noun signifying a definite length of time, you say, maA raA^ayotuhu mu*o sanapN, meaning, A^amadu *`lika sanapN, [I have not seen him (during, or for, a time); the time thereof (i. e., A^amadu Eadami ruw^oyatiY A_iy~aAhu the time of my not seeing him) is a year; meaning, during, or for, a year;] and the noun in this latter case can only be indeterminate; for you cannot say, mu*o sanapu ka*aA: (S:) when followed by a noun in the nom. case, as in the instance of muno*u yawomaAni [or, accord. to more approved usage, mu*o yawomaAni, as will be shown below, The time is two days, meaning during, or for, two days], each is an inchoative, and what follows it is an enunciative; and its meaning is the time with respect to what is present, and to a computed period, or a number of days or the like; and the commencement of the space of time with respect to a past time [such as a particular past day or the like]: or each is an adv. n. [of time], an enunciative, of which what follows is the inchoative, and meaning bayona wabayona, as in the instance of laqiytuhu muno*u yawomaAni, [or, rather, mu*o yawomaAni,] i. e., bayoniY wabayona liqaAy^ihi yawomaAni [Two days have been between the time in which I now am and (the time of) my meeting him]: (K:) but this opinion is rejected by Ibn-Hájib. (TA.) Accord. to some of the Arabs, for they differ on this point, m* governs in the gen. case a noun signifying a past time and one signifying a time not past: and accord. to some of them, mn* governs in the nom. case a noun signifying a past time and one signifying a time not past: (M, L:) but the general and most approved way is to make m* govern in the gen. case a noun signifying a time not past, and in the nom. case one signifying a time past; and to make mn* govern in the gen. case a noun signifying a time not past and one signifying a time past: (T, M, L:) most of the Arabs hold, that each must govern in the gen. case a noun signifying the present time; and that it is preferable to make mn* govern in the same case, and to make m* govern in the nom. case, a noun signifying a past time: (Mughnee:) [they therefore say, muno*u All~ayolapi and mu*u All~ayolapi, and muno*u yawomi Alxamiysi and muno*u yawomayni; but they say, mu*o yawomu Alxamiysi and mu*o yawomaAni.] Some [or, rather, most] say, lamo A^arahu mu*o yawomaAni, and lamo A^arahu muno*u yawomayni, [I have not seen him for, or during, two days;] making m* [in these instances] to govern the nom. case; and mn*, the gen. case. (L.) Such is said when the period of separation is a day and part of a day. (Msb, art. $hr.) The Benoo-Dabbeh and Er-Rabáb make m* to govern the gen. case in every instance. (M, L.) The phrases, maA raA^ayotuhu mu*o EaAmN A^aw~alu, and mu*o EaAmN A^aw~ala, (S, K, art. wA^l; and L,) and mu*o EaAmu AlA^aw~ali, and mu*o EaAmFA A^aw~ala, [I have not seen him since last year,] are also mentioned by different authors. (L.) The Arabs generally agree in pronouncing mn* with damm to the * when it is followed by a movent or a quiescent letter; (T, M, L;) as in lamo A^arahu muno*u yawomK, and muno*u Alyawomi: (T, L:) and to pronounce m* with the * quiescent when it is followed by a movent letter, (T, M, L,) and with damm and [sometimes] with kesr when it is followed by a conjunctive A; (M, L;) as in lamo A^arahu mu*o yawomaAni, and lamo A^arahu mu*u Alyawomi, [and mu*i Alyawomi]: (T, L:) and so say most of the grammarians. (T.) Lh says, The Benoo-'Obeyd, of the tribe of Ghanee, make the * of m* movent when it is followed by a movent or a quiescent letter, and make the noun following it to be in the nom. case, saying mu*u Alyawomu; and some of them pronounce it with kesr when followed by a quiescent letter, saying mu*i Alyawomu; but this is not the proper way. (M, L.) In the phrase maA raA^ayotuhu mu*u Alyawomi, the Arabs make the * movent because of the occurrence [otherwise] of two quiescent letters together; and they [generally] give it not kesr, but damm, because the latter is the final vowel of its original mn*. (M, L.) One says also, maA laqiytupu muno*a Alyawomi, and mu*a Alyawomi, which fet-h to the * in each. (K.) The Benoo-Suleym are related to have used the expression maA raA^ayotuhu mino*u sit~N [by st~ meaning six nights], with kesr to the m of mn*, and with the noun following it in the nom. case: and the tribe of 'Okl are related to have used the expression mi*u yawomaAni, with the n elided, and with kesr to the m, and damm to the *. (M, L.) ― -b2- Each of the two words mn* and m* is also followed by a verbal proposition, as in the instance
maA zaAla mu*o Eaqadato yadaAhu A_izaAzahu
[He has not ceased, since his two hands tied his wrapper of the lower part of the body]: or a nominal proposition, as in the instance
walaA zilotu A^abogiY AlmaAla mu*o A^anaA yaAfiEN
[And I ceased not to seek wealth from the time of my being a youth, or young man]: in such cases, each is an adv. n. prefixed to the proposition [and governing it virtually in the gen. case], or to a noun significant of time [understood as] prefixed thereto [in the same manner]: or, as some say, each is an inchoative. (K.) ― -b3- The original of m* is mn*, because they restore the dammeh
to the * in the case of the occurrence of two quiescent letters together; as in the instance of mu*u Alyawomi, for were not its original with damm, they would give it kesr: [but this some do, as has been shown above:] and because its dim. is munayo*N: (K:) for when m* is used as a proper name of a man, its dim. is thus formed, by restoring the n, that it may be of the measure fuEayolN: (IJ, M, L:) or when m* is a noun, it is originally mn*; and when it is a particle, it is itself original. (K.) ― -b4- Accord. to some, mn* (T, S, L, K) and m* (K) are originally mino and A_i*o, which are made one word, (T, S, L, K,) by eliding the hemzeh, and then giving damm to the * because of the occurrence of two quiescent letters together; (K;) muno*u kaAna [and mu*o kaAna] meaning mino A_i*o kaAna: (T, L:) but there is nothing to indicate the truth of this opinion: (S, L:) or, as some say, mn* and m* are originally the prep. mn and *w in the sense of Al~a*iY (L, K) in the dial. of Teiyi: so says Fr.; adding, that when either governs a gen. case, it is used in the manner of mano; and when it governs a nom. case, it is as though one said, [in using the expression muno*u A^awo mu*o yawomaAni,] mina A@l~a*iY huwa yawomaAni; and that the former government prevails in the case of mn* because the n is not suppressed: (L:) or, as some say, they are originally mino and the noun of indication *aA; so that in the phrase maA raA^ayotuhu muno*u yawomaAni, [accord. to more approved usage, mu*o yawomaAni,] we virtually say, mino *aA A@lowaqoti yawomaAni: but each of these assertions is a deviation from the plain way. (K.)

div2.head: mnE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 mahaja * , aor.
mahaja , (inf. n. mahojN, TA,) He sucked [the breast of his mother]. ― -b2- mahaja Inivit ancillam suam. (K.) -A2- mahaja He became goodly in countenance after disease. (AA, K.)
8 A^amotuhija * (tropical:) His soul was torn from him. (A, K.)

muhojapN *
Blood: or the blood of the heart: (S, K:) pl. muhajN. (A.) An Arab of the desert is related to have said, dafanotu muhojatahu, meaning damahu: so in the S: but in a marginal note in a copy of that work, it is said that this is a mistake; and that the correct expression, as mentioned by IKt and others, is dafaqotu muhojatahu I poured forth, or shed, his blood: and so it is in the copies of the A. (TA.) In like manner, dafaqa All~`hu muhojatahu (tropical:) May God destroy him! (A. [See also dafqa.]) ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) The soul, or spirit. (S, K.) Ex. xarajato muhojatuhu (tropical:) His soul went forth, or departed. (S.) A^unotuziEato muhojatuhu (tropical:) His soul was torn from him. (K.) ― -b3- Also, (tropical:) One's self: the best of one's self, and one's powers, efforts, endeavours, or energy. (L.) Ex. ba*alotu lahu muhojatiY (tropical:) I gave, or gave up, myself, and the best of my powers, efforts, endeavours, or energy, to him, or it. (T.) ― -b4- Also, (tropical:) The purest, choicest, or best, of anything. (L.) ― -b5- Also, (assumed tropical:) The heart. (MF.)
maAhijN * : see A^umohujN.

A^umohujN * (K) and ↓ A^amohujaAnN and ↓ maAhijN (S, K) Thin milk: (S, K:) or, the first and second, milk free from water: and, the second, milk of which the froth has become still, and which is clear, and not thick: and, the last, thin milk, of which the taste has not changed; as also ↓ A^umohuwjN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, the first, Thin fat; (S, K;) as also the second and third: (K:) or raw fat. (M.) ― -b3- The first is an epithet of a form not mentioned by Sb. (TA.) It may be a contraction of A^umohuwjN. (IJ.) [And the like may be said of A^umoludN.]
A^umohujaAnN * : see A^umohujN.
A^amohuwjN * : see A^umohujN.

mamohuwju AlbaToni *
Lax in the belly. (K.)

1 mahada * , (S, L, K,) aor.
mahada , (L, K,) inf. n. mahodN [q. v. infra]; (S, L;) and ↓ mh~d, (L, K,) inf. n. tamohiydN; (TA;) He made plain, even, or smooth, this is the original signification: he made a place plain, even, or smooth, [makaAnFA being understood,] linafosihi for himself: (L:) he spread a bed, (S, L, K,) and made it plain, even, or smooth. (S, L.) ― -b2- mahada lahu (assumed tropical:) He did well, or kindly, in his affair in his absence; like fahada and faA^ada. (L, art. fhd.) ― -b3- mahada, aor.
mahada , (inf. n. mahodN, L,) He gained, or earned, or sought to gain sustenance, and worked, (L, K,) linafosihi for himself. (L.) ― -b4- mahada linafosihi xayorFA, and ↓ Amthdhu, (tropical:) He prepared for himself good, good things, or the like. (L.) ― -b5- lahu manozilapF saniy~apF ↓ mh~d (tropical:) [He prepared, or established, for him a high station]. (A.) ― -b6- fulaAnN EinodiY yadFA ↓ maA A@motahada (tropical:) [Such a one has not prepared for himself, with me, a benefit, for me to owe it him]: you say this when one has not conferred upon you a favour or kindness. (AZ, L.) And fulaAnN EinodiY ↓ maA A@motahada mahoda *aAka (tropical:) [Such a one has not prepared for himself, with me, that thing, that I should owe it him]; is said on one's asking a kindness without having previously conferred a benefit; (AZ, JK, L;) and with reference to one who acts in an evil manner, when asking a kindness, or when a kindness is asked for him. (AZ, L.)

2 mh~d * , inf. n. tamohiydN, (tropical:) He adjusted, or arranged, an affair, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) and made it plain, (A, Msb,) and easy. (Msb.) See 1. ― -b2- mh~d nafosahu lifiEoli AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) He disposed and subjected his mind, or himself, to do the thing. (S, * K, * Msb, art. wTn.) ― -b3- mh~d, inf. n. tamohiydN, (tropical:) He accepted, or admitted, an excuse. (S, L, Msb, K.) You say, mah~adotu lahu AlEu*ora (tropical:) I accepted, or admitted, his excuse. (Msb.)

5 tmh~d * and ↓ Amthd It (a bed) became spread, and made plain, even, or smooth. (A.) ― -b2- tmh~d lahu AlA^amoru (tropical:) The affair became adjusted, or arranged, and made plain, and easy, for, or to, him. (Msb.) ― -b3- tmh~d firaA$FA [He spread for himself a bed, and made it plain, even, or smooth]. (A.) ― -b4- tamah~adato lahu EinodiY HaAlN laTiyfapN (tropical:) [A genteel situation was prepared for him with me, or at my abode]. (A.) ― -b5- tmh~d (assumed tropical:) He (a man, TA) became possessed of authority and power; syn. tamak~ana. (S, L, K.) ― -b6- tmh~dt nafosuhu (assumed tropical:) His mind, or he, became disposed and subjected [lifiEoli AlA^amori to do the thing; see 2]; syn. tawaT~anato. (K, art. wTn.)

8 Amthd *
It (a camel's hump) became spreading and high. (S, L, K.) See 1 in three places.
10 Astmhd firaA$FA * [He asked, or desired, that a bed should be spread for him, and made plain, even, or smooth]. (A.)

mahodN * [A child's cradle, or bed;] a place prepared for a child, and made plain, even, or smooth, (S, * L, K,) that he may sleep in it: (L:) a bed; a thing spread to lie, recline, or sit, upon; (A, Msb;) as also ↓ mihaAdN; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) so called because of its plainness, evenness, or smoothness: (L:) Az says, that the latter word is more comprehensive than the former: (L:) it is applied to the ground, or earth; [meaning a plain, an even, or a smooth expanse; see a verse of Lebeed cited voce xawaAliqu:] (Az, L, K:) and so is mahodN: (K:) some say, that mahodN and ↓ mihaAdN are [originally] two inf. ns., of the same meaning: or that the former is an inf. n., and the latter a simple subst.: or that the former is sing., and the latter pl.: (MF:) the pl. of the former [in common use] is muhuwdN, (L, Msb, K,) and mihaAdN; and of the latter, [pl. of pauc.,] A^amohidapN (L, K) and [of mult.,] muhudN. (L, Msb, K.) ― -b2- ↓ A^alamo najoEali A@loA^aroDa mihaAdFA [Kur, lxxviii. 6,] Have we not made the earth an expanse (bisaAT) adapted to be travelled over. (K, TA.) ― -b3- ↓ labiy^osa AlmihaAdu [Kur. ii. 202,] (tropical:) Evil is that which he hath prepared for himself in his final place.
(K.) Such is said to be the meaning. (TA.) ― -b4- sahodN mahodN Good; goodly: the latter word is an imitative sequent. (L.)

muhodN *
Elevated ground or land: (IAar, L, K:) or depressed and smooth and even ground or land; (K;) as also ↓ muhodapN: (En-Nadr, K:) pl. mihadapN and A^amohaAdN: (K:) but the former of these pls. is doubtful. (TA.)
