muhodapN * : see muhodN.
mihaAdN * : see mahodN.

mahiydN *
Pure butter: (L, K:) or the purest of butter when melted, and that which has the least milk. (L.)
mumah~adN * (tropical:) Lukewarm water; neither hot nor cold. (A, K.)

1 mahara AlmaroA^apa * , (AZ, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
mahara (S, Msb, K) and
mahura , (K,) inf. n. mahorN, (S, Msb, TA,) He gave the woman a mahor [or dowry]: (A, Mgh, Msb, K:) or he assigned to her (jaEala lahaA) a mahor: (K:) and ↓ A^amoharahaA signifies the same as maharahaA, (AZ, S, Msb, K,) which is of the dial. of Temeem, and the more usual: (Msb:) or maharahaA has the first of the above significations, (A, Mgh, Msb, K,) or signifies he set apart for her a mahor: (Msb:) and ↓ A^amoharahaA signifies he named for her a mahor and married her to himself for it; (A, Mgh;) or he married her to another man for a certain mahor; (Msb, K;) or he sent for her a mahor. (TA.) -A2- mahara Al$~aYo'a, (S, K,) and fiyhi, and bihi (K,) and fiyhi ↓ tmh~r, (K, * TA,) and mahara SinaAEatahu, (A,) and fiyhaA, (Mgh, Msb,) and bihaA, and fiyhaA ↓ tmh~r, (A,) and mahara fiY AlEilomi wagayorihi, (Msb,) aor.
mahara , (Msb, K,) inf. n. mahaArapN (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K) and mihaArapN (L) and muhuwrN (Msb, K) and mahaArN and mahorN, (K,) He was, or became, skilled, or expert, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) in the thing, (S, K,) and in his art, or craft, (A, Mgh, Msb,) and in science, &c., (Msb,) knowing its abstrusities and niceties, or having learned the whole of it; syn. Ha*aqa. (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K.)

2 mh~r * , inf. n. tamohiyrN, He desired a colt: (K, TA:) he procured for himself a colt. (JK, K, TA.) [In the CK, and in a MS. copy of the K, we find Almahor put by mistake for Almuhor.] Aboo-Zubeyd says, describing a lion,
A^aqobala yarodiY kamaA yarodiY AlHiSaAnu A_ilaY
musotaEosibK A^aribK minohu bitamohiyri
He came [beating the ground with his feet] like as a horse comes [so beating the ground] to a man borrowing him for covering, wanting by his means to procure for himself a colt. (TA.) [In the L, and TA, yarowiY is put for yrdY in both instances: but it is corrected by SM in the margin of the L.]

4 Amhr AlmaroA^apa * : see 1, in two places. -A2- Amhr Aln~aAqapa He called, or rendered, (jaEala) the she-camel a mahoriy~ap: (K:) [it has sometimes, if not always, the latter meaning; for] it is said of the breaker, or trainer; and is like A^aroHalahaA. (TA, in art. rHl.) -A3- Amhrt Alfarasu The mare had a colt following her. (TA.)
5 tamah~ara see 1, in two places.

mahorN *
A dowry; a nuptial gift; a gift that is given to, or for, a bride; syn. SadaAqN: (S, A, Msb, K:) pl. muhuwrN, (K,) or muhuwrapN, like as buEuwlapN is pl. of baEolN, and fuHuwlapN of faHolN. (Msb.) zawojN mahorK A husband from whom a dowry is got: (S, art. bhr:) or a husband who has not nobility of race, and who therefore doubles the dowry to make himself desired. (TA, same art.) See bahorN. ― -b2- The hire of a prostitute. Ex. nahaY Eano mahori AlbagiY~ He forbade [receiving] the hire of the prostitute. (Mgh, Msb.)

muhorN *
A colt; the male foal of a mare; (S, K;) and of a mare kept for breeding: (TA:) or the first male offspring of a mare or other animal; (K;) i. e., of a tame ass; &c.: (ISd, TA:) fem. with p; a filly: (S, Msb, K:) and dim. muhayorN: (JK:) pl. masc., (of pauc., TA,) A^amohaArN, and (of mult., TA) mihaArN and mihaArapN; (S, Msb, K;) and pl. fem. muharN and muharaAtN. (S, Msb.)

A_ibilN mahoriy~apN *
Camels of Mahreh; i. e. certain camels, so called in relation to Mahreh Ibn- Heydán, (T, S, Msb, K,) a tribe, (K,) or a great tribe, (TA,) or the father of a tribe of El-Yemen: (S:) or in relation to Mahreh, a district of 'Omán: (Msb:) they are excellent camels, that outstrip horses; and some add, that they are unequalled in quickness of running, understanding what is desired of them with the least training, and having names, by which being called, they answer quickly: (Msb:) [and hence, any such like camels; i. e. any excellent, fleet, camels: (see 4:) n. un. mahoriY~N:] pl. mahaAriY~u [which is irreg. like ZahaAriY~N] (S, Msb, K) and mahaArK (S, K) and mahaAraY, (K, TA,) written in the L mahaAriY, (TA,) [and so in the CK,] or mahaAraA, the Y being changed into A, (Msb,) [but it generally retains the form of Y, though pronounced A.] See also Huw$iY~N.
mahiyrapN * [A woman to whom a dowry has been given: and hence,] a free [married] woman: (S, K:) opposed to sur~iy~apN: (A:) pl. mahaAy^iru. (A, TA.) And, (TA,) One whose dowry is dear. (K, TA.)

maAhirN *
Skilled, or skilful, (A, Msb, K,) fY SinaAEatihi, in his art, (A, Msb,) and bkul~i EamalK, in every work, (A, K,) fiY Eilomi wagayorihi in science &c., (Msb,) knowing its abstrusities and niceties, or having learned the whole of it; syn. HaA*iqN: (A, Msb, K:) and, (K,) in most instances, (TA,) [but only when used absolutely,] a good swimmer; (JK, K;) as also ↓ mutamah~irN: (Z, TA;) pl. maharapN: (A, K:) also ↓ mutamah~irN a lion skilled in slaying his prey. (K.)
mumohirN * A mare having a colt or foal. (S, K.)

mamohuwrapN * A woman dowered; to whom a dowry has been given; or for whom a dowry has been set apart. (Msb.) It is said in a proverb, kaA@lomamohuwrapi A_iHodaY xadamatayohaA [Like her who has been dowered with one of her two anklets]: (S, K:) or A^aHomaqu mina A@lomamohuwrapi A_iHodaY xadamatayohaA [More stupid than she who has been dowered with one of her two anklets]: (Mgh:) applied to him who has reached the utmost degree of stupidity: from the following case: (TA:) a stupid woman demanded of her husband her dowry, (K, TA,) when he paid her his first visit, and she said, I will not obey thee unless thou give me my dowry: (TA:) so he pulled off one of her two anklets (K, TA) from her foot, (TA,) and gave it to her, and she was content with it. (K, TA.) In like manner, a certain man gave to another property, and he married with it the daughter of the giver, and then reproached her for the dowry he had given her: so they said, kaA@lomamohuwrapi mino maAli A^abiyhaA [Like her who has been dowered from the property of her father]: (K, TA:) [a proverb] applied in relation to him who reproaches for that which is not his own. (TA.)
mutamah~irN * : see maAhirN, in two places.

div2.head: mhz &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 maA='a * , aor. yamuwo'u, inf. n. mawo'N (K, TA: in the CK muwo'N) and muw^aA='N (but see below) or (as in some copies of the K) muwaA='N; (K;) and ↓ A^amowaA^a; (AA;) It (a cat) mewed: (K:) like maA^aY, (TA,) and A^amaA. (S in art. Amw.)
4 AmwA^ * : see 1. ― -b2- Also, He (a man) mewed like a cat. (K.)
muw^aA='N * , accord. to the K, an inf. n. of maA='a; but accord. to the L and other lexicons, The mew of a car; a word expressing the sound of mewing. (TA.)
maw^uwo'N * (in some copies of the K, mawuwo'N,) A mewing cat. (K.)
maAy^iy^apN * and maAy^iy~apN and maAy^iyapN [and epithet of] A cat. (K.)

1 maAta * , aor. yamuwtu, (inf. n. mawotN; Msb,) and maAta, (originally mawita, like xaAfa, originally xawifa, MF) [sec. per. mit~a,] aor. yamaAtu, (S, K,) which latter is of the dial. of Teiyi; (TA;) and maAta, (in which the medial radical letter is originally Y, like baAEa, MF) aor. yamiytu, (K,) a form which some have disapproved; (MF;) and maAta, (originally mawita, Kr,) sec. pers. mit~a, aor. yamuwtu, like daAma, (originally dawima, Kr,) aor. yaduwmu, (Kr, Msb, &c.,) and like the sound verbs naEima, aor. yanoEumu, and faDila, aor. yafoDulu, (TA,) of the class of words in which two dial. forms are intermixed; (Msb;) He died; contr. of HayiY. (K,) ― -b2- [maAta Eano baniyna wabanaAtK He died having passed away from, i. e. leaving behind him, sons and daughters. And maAta Eano vamaAniyna sanFp He died having passed beyond eighty years; i. e. being eighty years old.] ― -b3- All~abanu laA yamuwtu [The milk will not die], in a saying of 'Omar, in a trad., means, that if a child sucks the milk of a dead woman, it becomes unlawful for him afterwards to marry any of her relations who would be unlawful to him if he sucked her milk while she was living: or it means, that, if milk taken from the breast of a woman is given to a child to drink, and he drinks it, the consequence is the same; that the effect of the milk in producing this consequence is not annulled by its separation from the breast; for whatever is separated from a living being is termed myt, or dead, except the milk and hair and wool on account of the necessity of making use of these. (TA.) ― -b4- maAtati AlA^aroDu, inf. n. mawataAnN and mawaAtN, (tropical:) The land became destitute of cultivation and of inhabitants. (Msb.) ― -b5- maAta (tropical:) It (soil) became deprived of vegetable life. Hence an expression in the Kur, xxx. 18. (Az, Er-Rághib.) ― -b6- maAta (tropical:) He became deprived of sensation; [dead as to the senses]. So in the Kur, xix. 23: [but this appears to me doubtful]. (Az, Er-Rághib.) ― -b7- maAta (tropical:) He became deprived of the intellectual faculty; [intellectually dead;] or ignorant. Hence an expression in the Kur, vi. 122; and another in the Kur, xxvii. 82; and xxx. 51. (Az, Er-Rághib.) ― -b8- maAta (tropical:) [He became as though dead with grief, or sorrow, and fear;] he experienced grief, or sorrow, and fear, that disturbed his life. Hence what is said in the Kur, xiv. 20. (Az, Er-Rághib.) ― -b9- maAta (tropical:) He or it, was or became, still, quiet, or motionless. (K.) ― -b10- mAtati Alr~iyH (tropical:) The wind became still, or calm. (TA.) ― -b11- maAta (tropical:) He slept. (AA, K.) ― -b12- maAtati Aln~aAru, inf. n. mawotN, (tropical:) [The fire died away;] the ashes of the fire became cold, or cool, and none of its live coals remained. (TA.) ― -b13- maAta (tropical:) It (heat or cold) became assuaged. (TA.) ― -b14- maAta (tropical:) It (water) became dried up by the earth. (TA.) ― -b15- maAta (and ↓ AstmAt, TA.) (tropical:) It (a garment, TA,) wore out; became worn out. (A, K.) ― -b16- mAt (tropical:) It (a road) ceased to be passed along. (TA.) ― -b17- baladN tamuwtu fiyhi Alr~iyHu [A town, or country, &c., in which the wind becomes broken, or loses its force]. (TA.) ― -b18- maAta fuwqu Alr~ajuli (tropical:) The man slept heavily; became heavy in his sleep. (TA.) ― -b19- yamuwtu mina AlHasadi (tropical:) [He dies, or will die, of envy]. (TA.) ― -b20- maAta (tropical:) He became poor; was reduced to poverty: he became a beggar. (TA.) ― -b21- (tropical:) He became base, abject, vile, despicable, or ignominious. (TA.) ― -b22- (tropical:) He became extremely aged, old and weak, or decrepit. (TA.) ― -b23- (tropical:) He became disobedient, or rebellious. Iblees is said, in a trad., to be A^aw~alu mano maAta because he was the first who became disobedient, or rebellious. (TA.) ― -b24- maAta (assumed tropical:) He (a man) became lowly, humble, or submissive, to the truth. (TA.)

2 maw~atati Ald~awaAb~u *
The beasts of carriage died in great numbers; or deaths amongst them were frequent. (TA.) ― -b2- See 4.

3 maAowata [mAwthu,] inf. n. mumaAwatapN, He vied with him in patience, (K,) and in firmness, or steadiness, or the like. (TA.) [In the K, the inf. n. is expl. by muSaAbarap; and in the TA, by muvaAbatap also.]

4 AmAthu * and ↓ mw~thu (but the latter has an intensive signification, S,) He (God) caused him to die; put him to death; killed him. (S, K.) ― -b2- AmAt (tropical:) He (a man) lost a son, or sons, by death. (ISk, S.) ― -b3- AmAt fulaAnN baniyna Such a man lost sons by death. (A.) ― -b4- AmAtt She (a woman, AO, S, K, and a camel, S, K.) lost her offspring by death. (S, K.) ― -b5- AmAtwA Death [or a mortal disease] happened among their camels. (K.) ― -b6- maA A^amowatahu signifies maA A^amowata qalobahu [(tropical:) How dead is his heart !] for one does not wonder at any action that does not increase: (S, K:) therefore what is here meant is not literally death. (TA.) ― -b7- AmAthu (tropical:) He (God) rendered him poor; reduced him to poverty. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b8- AmAthu (tropical:) He [or it] caused him to sleep. Ex., in a prayer said on awaking, AlHamodu lil~`hi Al~a*iY A^aHoyaAnaA baEoda maA A^amaAtanaA Praise be to God who hath awaked us after having caused us to sleep ! (L.) ― -b9- yumiytu All~ayola (assumed tropical:) He sleeps during the night. (W, p. 9.) ― -b10- AmAt All~aHoma, (and ↓ mw~thu, TA,) He took extraordinary pains in thoroughly cooking, and in boiling, the meat. (K.) And in like manner, onions, and garlic, so as to deprive them of their strong taste and odour. (TA.) ― -b11- A^umiytati Alxamoru The wine was cooked, and ceased to boil. (TA.) ― -b12- [AmAthu is also employed in various other senses, agreeably with the senses of the primitive verb.]

6 Darabotuhu fatamaAwata * (tropical:) I beat him and he feigned himself dead, being alive. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He pretended to be weak and motionless by reason of acts of devotion and fasting: [see the act. part. n. below]. (TA.)

10 AstmAt * [He sought death: &c.: see musotamiytN]. ― -b2- A_isotamiytuwA Sayodakumo, and daAb~atakumo, Wait until ye ascertain that your game, and your beast of carriage, has died. (A.) ― -b3- AstmAt [properly, He sought, or courted, death;] i. q. Astqtl; (S, K; in art. qtl;) meaning he cared not for death, by reason of his courage. (JM, in art. qtl.) ― -b4- AstmAt (assumed tropical:) He (a man) was pleased with death; content to die. (TA.) ― -b5- AstmAt (assumed tropical:) He (a man, TA.) tried every way, or did his utmost, in seeking a thing. (IAar, K.) ― -b6- AstmAt, inf. n. A_istimaAtN, (occurring thus with the final p elided, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man, and a camel, IAar,) became fat after having been emaciated, (IAar, K.) ― -b7- AstmAt (tropical:) It (a thing) became relaxed, loose, or flabby. (A.) ― -b8- AstmAt liynFA (assumed tropical:) It attained the utmost degree of softness: said of a fine skin, that is likened to the thin pellicle that adheres to the white of an egg: and of other things, as also AstmAt fiY All~iyni: and in like manner, fiY AlS~alaAbapi, in hardness. (TA.) See musotamiytN ― -b9- And see 1.

mawotN * (and ↓ mawataAnN, TA,) Death; lifelessness; contr. of HayaApN: (S, TA:) as also ↓ muwaAtN, (S, K,) and ↓ mamaAtN. [Occurring in the Kur, vi. 163, xvii. 77, and xlv. 20,] (S, * TA, in art. HY, and Jel, in vi. 163.) [See also muwtaAnN, below: and see 1.] Or ↓ mawataAnN, signifies much death, like as HayawaAnN signifies much life. (Msb, in art. HY.) ― -b2- Almawotu AlA^aboyaDu, and AljaArifu, and All~aAfitu, and AlfaAtilu, Sudden death. (IAar, in T and TA, art. flt.) ― -b3- Almawotu AlA^aHomaru Death by slaughter with the sword. (IAar, in T, TA, art. flt.) ― -b4- Almawotu AlA^asowadu Death by drowning, and by suffocation. (IAar, in T and TA, art. flt.) ― -b5- banaAtu Almawoti (assumed tropical:) [The daughters of death;] meaning deadly arrows. (A, TA, voce jaEobapN, q. v.)

mayotN * : see may~itN. ― -b2- A^aroDN mayotapN: see mawaAtN: Unfruitful land; like as ArD Hay~apN means fruitful land, or land abounding with herbage. (TA, in art. HY.) ― -b3- mayotapN Carrion: whatsoever hath not been killed in the manner prescribed by the law. (K, Jel, ii. 168.) See may~itN.

muwtapN * (tropical:) A fainting, or swoon; (K;) and languor in the intellect: (TA:) or [an affection] like a fainting, or swoon: (Lh:) madness, or insanity, or diabolical possession; syn. junuwnN; (AO, K;) because it occasions a stillness like
death: (TA:) or a kind of madness or diabolical possession (junuwnN), and epilepsy, that befalls a man; on the recovery from which, his perfect reason returns to him, as to one who has been sleeping, and to one who has been drunk. (S.) [See humozN.]

miytapN *
A kind, mode, or manner, of death: (S, K:) pl. miyatN. (TA.) ― -b2- maAta fulaAnN miytapF HasanapF Such a one died a good kind of death. (S.) ― -b3- maAta miytapF jaAhiliy~apF He died a pagan kind of death, in error and disunion. (TA, from a trad.)

mawotaAnu Alfuw^aAdi * (tropical:) A man who is [dead, or] not lively, in heart: (A:) a man who is stupid, dull, unexcitable, or not to be rendered brisk, sprightly, or lively; (S,. K;) as though the heat of his intelligence had cooled and died: (TA:) fem. with p. (S, K.) ― -b2- See muwtaAnN and mawaAtN.

muwtaAnN * (Fr, S, K) and ↓ mawotaAnN (K) and ↓ muwaAtN (Fr) Death, [or a mortal disease, or a murrain,] that befalls camels or sheep or the like. (Fr, S, K.) The first is of the dial. of Temeem: the second, of the dial. of others. (Et-Tilimsánee.) ― -b2- waqaEa fiY AlmaAli muwtaAnN, and ↓ muwaAtN, Death [or a mortal disease] happened among the camels &c. (Fr.) ― -b3- Also, The like among men. Ex., from a trad., yakuwnu fiY Aln~aAsi muwtaAnN kaquEaASi Alganami There will be, among men, a mortality, or much death, [or mortal disease], like the quEaAS that befalls sheep or goats. (TA.)

mawataAnN * (assumed tropical:) Inanimate things, or goods; dead stock; such as lands and houses [&c.]; (S;) contr. of HayawaAnN [q. v.] (S, K.) It is made of this measure to agree in measure with its contr. HywAn: both these words deviate from the constant course of speech; being of a measure properly belonging to inf. ns. (TA.) [See also mawaAtN.] ― -b2- A_i$otari AlmawataAna walA ta$otari AlHayawaAna Buy lands and houses [or the like], and buy not slaves and beasts of carriage [&c.]. (S.) ― -b3- rajulN yabiyEu AlmawataAna A man who sells utensils or furniture or the like, and anything but what has life. (L.) ― -b4- See also mawotN.

mawaAtN * That wherein is no spirit or life; an inanimate thing. (S, K.) [See also mawataAnN.] ― -b2- mawaAtN (you say A^aroDN mawaAtN, TA,) (tropical:) Land that has no owner (S, K) of mankind, and of which no use is made, or from which no advantage is derived, (S,) and in which is no water: such as is also called ↓ A^aroDN mayotapN: (En-Nawawee:) land that has not been sown, nor cultivated, nor occupied by any man's camels &c.: ↓ mawataAnN signifies the same as muwaAtN (mawaAtN?), namely, land that is no man's property; and is also written mawotaAnN: (L:) or mawataAnN signifies land that has not yet been brought into a state of cultivation: (Fr, S, L, K:) in a trad. it is said, that such land is the property of God and his Apostle; and whosoever brings into a state of cultivation such land, to him it belongs. (S.)
muwaAtN * : see mawotN and muwtaAnN.

may~itN * and ↓ mayotN signify the same, [Dead, or dying]: (Zj, S, K:) the former is originally mayowitN, of the measure fayoEilN: (S:) the latter is contracted from the former; and is both masc. and fem.; (Zj, S;) as is also the former. (Zj.) 'Adee Ibn-Er-Raalà says,
↓ layosa mano maAta faA@sotaraAHa bimayotK
A_in~amaA Almayotu may~itu AlA^aHoyaA='i
[He who has died and become at rest is not dead: the dead is only the dead of the living]. (S, TA.) Or ↓ mayotN signifies One who has died (actually, TA,); and may~itN, as also ↓ maAy^itN, one who has not yet died, (K,) but who is near to dying: or, accord. to a verse cited by AA, to Kh, mayotN is applied to him who is borne to the grave; [i. e., who is dead, or lifeless]; and may~itN, to him who [is dying, but] has life in him. (TA.) Fr says, you say of him who has not died, A_in~ahu maAy^itN, Eano qaliylK ↓ and may~itN; but you do not say of him who has died ↓ h*A maAy^itN: (S:) but some say, that this is an error, and that may~itN is applicable to that which will soon die. Those who assert that my~t is applicable only to the living adduce the following words of the Kur, [xxxix. 31,] A_in~aka may~itN waA_in~ahumo may~ituwna: (TA:) i. e. Verily thou wilt die, and verily they will die. (Msb.) MF observes, that mayotN is asserted to be contracted from may~itN; and if so, that there can be no difference in their meanings: that the making a difference between them is contrary to analogy; agreeably with which, they should be like hayonN and hay~inN, and layonN and lay~inN: and also contrary to what has been heard from the Arabs; for they made no difference in their use of these two words. (TA.) [See also what is said of mayotapN, below.] The pls. are A^amowaAtN and mawotaY and may~ituwna and mayotuwna. (S, K.) The first of these is pl. of may~itN, and consequently of mayotN, because this latter is contracted from the former: as may~itN is of the measure fayoEilN, and this measure resembles faAEilN, it has received a form of pl. which is sometimes applicable to the measure fAEl: (Sb:) or AmwAt is [only] pl. of mayotN. (Msb.) [The second form (which is applied to rational beings, Msb,) is also pl. of my~t and myt.] The third and fourth are [only] applied to rational beings. (Msb.) The fem. epithet is may~itapN and mayotapN and may~itN (K, TA) and mayotN. (TA; and so in some copies of the K, in the place of may~itN.) may~itapN is an epithet applied to a female rational being; [and its pl. is may~itaAtN:] mayotapN, to a female brute, for the sake of distinction; and its pl. is mayotaAtN: the latter is contracted because it is more in use than the former epithet applied to a female rational being: (Msb:) the pl. of my~t and myt as fem. epithets is as above [A^amowaAtN and mawotaY]. (TA.) ― -b2- ↓ mayotapN signifies That which has not been slaughtered (AA, S, K) [in the manner prescribed by the law, i. e., carrion]: or that of which the life has departed without slaughter: so in the classical language and in the language of practical law: all such is unlawful to be eaten, except fish and locusts, which are lawful by universal consent of the Muslims: (En-Nawawee:) or, in the common acceptation of the language of law, what has died a natural death, or been killed in a state or manner different from that prescribed by the law, either the agent or the animal killed not being such as is so prescribed; as that which is sacrificed to an idol, or slaughtered [by a person] in the state of A_iHoraAm, or not by having the throat cut, and that which it is unlawful to eat, such as a dog: (Msb:) [and any separated part of an animal of which the flesh is not lawful food: see EaAjN.] ― -b3- baladN may~itN A tract of land without herbage, or pasture, (Msb, in art. bld.) ― -b4- may~itN (assumed tropical:) An unbeliever; like as HaY~N means a Muslim. (TA, in art. HY.)

[
may~itN * and mayotN are employed in various other senses, agreeably with the senses of the verb.]

maAy^itN * : see may~itN. ― -b2- fulaAnN maAy^itN fY Algam~i (tropical:) [Such a one is dying, or absorbed, in grief]. (TA.) ― -b3- mawotN maAy^itN A severe, painful, or violent, death: (TA:) like layolN laAy^ilN: the latter word being added to corroborate the former. (S.)
mamaAtN * : see mawotN.
mumiytN * and mumiytapN (tropical:) A woman, and a she-camel, that has lost her offspring by death: (S:) and a woman who has lost her husband by death: (TA:) pl. mamaAwiytu. (S.)

mutamaAwitN * (tropical:) [Feigning himself dead]. ― -b2- (tropical:) An epithet applied to A hypocritical devotee, (S, K,) who pretends to be like one dead in his devotion, who lowers his voice, and moves little: as though he were one who put on the outward appearance of devotees, and constrained himself to characterize himself by the characteristics of the dead, that he might be imagined to be weak by reason of much devotion. (TA.)

musotamiytN * A courageous man, who seeks, or courts death: (K:) a man who seeks to be slain; who cares not, in war, for death: (S:) abandon-
ing, or devoting, himself to death, (msotarosilN lilomawoti,) as also musotaqotilN. (A.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Abandoning, or devoting himself to a thing, or affair; syn. musotarosilN liA^amorK. (S, K.) ― -b3- hawa musotamiytN A_ilaY ka*aA, as also musotaholikN, (tropical:) He [is devoted to such a thing, so that he] imagines that he shall die if he do not attain it. (A.) ― -b4- Ru-beh says,
wazabadu AlbaHori lahu katiytu
waAll~ayolu fawoqa AlmaA'i musotamiytu
[And to the froth of the sea there was a sound like that of boiling, and night impended over the water]. (S.) [It is implied in the S that mstmyt here signifies musotarosil.] ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) One who feigns himself to be insane, or possessed by a devil; not being really so. (TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) One who feigns lowliness, or submissiveness, in voice, &c., to this man until he feeds him, and to this until he feeds him, and, when he is satiated, is ungrateful to his benefactors. (TA.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) One who makes a show of being good and quiet or tranquil, and is not so in reality. (Ibn-El-Mubárak.) -A2- musotamiytN The thin pellicle that adheres to the white of an egg. (K.) [See 10: and see also musotamiyvN, in art. myv.]

1 maAva * , aor. yamuwvu, inf. n. mawovN (and in the CK mawavN) and mawavaAnN; (S, K;) as also maAva, aor. yamiyvu; (TA;) and ↓ AmAv; (Hr;) but this is disapproved by IAth; He steeped a thing in water, and mashed it with his hand: (TA:) he mixed and moistened a thing in water. (S, K.) [See also art. myv.] ― -b2- See also 7. ― -b3- mAvati AlA^aroDu The land became soft and even. (Msb.)
4 A^amowava see 1.

7 AnmAv * , inf. n. AinomiyaAvN, It (a thing) was steeped in water, and mashed with the hand: (TA:) it was mixed and moistened in water. (S, K.) [See also art. myv.] ↓ maAva, aor. yamuwvu, is also [thus] used intransitively. (Msb.)
miyvaA'u * , with kesreh, of the measure mifoEaAlN Soft and even land. (Msb.) [See also mayovaA'u, in art. myv.]

1 maAja * , aor. yamuwju, inf. n. mawojN (S, K, &c.) and mawajaAnN and muw^uwjN; (TA;) It (the sea) was in a state of commotion; was tumultuous; (Msb;) was agitated with waves, conflicting, or dashing together; (S, K;) as also ↓ tmw~j: (TA;) or this latter signifies it (the sea) was, or became, very tumultuous. (Msb.) [You say,] maAja Almawoju The waves were in a state of commotion; were tumultuous; conflicted, or dashed together. (TA.) [And hence,] maAja A^amoruhumo (assumed tropical:) Their affair became in a confused and disturbed state. (TA.) ― -b2- maAja, inf. n. mawojN and mawajaAnN, (assumed tropical:) It (anything) was in a state of commotion, or agitation. (TA.) ― -b3- maAja (tropical:) He was in a state of commotion, or agitation, and confounded, perplexed, or amazed. (IAar.) ― -b4- Aln~aAsu yamuwjuwnN (tropical:) The people, or men, are in a state of commotion, or tumultuous. (S.) ― -b5- maAjati Aln~aAsu (tropical:) The people were in a discordant and disturbed state of affairs. (Msb.) ― -b6- maAja Eani AlHaq~i, inf. n. mawojN, (tropical:) He declined from the truth, or from the true, right, or just, course. (A, K.) ― -b7- maAjati Ald~aAgiSapu, inf. n. muw^uwjN, (tropical:) The patella, or knee-pan, moved backwards and forwards, or from side to side, between the skin and the bone, or, as in one copy of the K, flesh: (K, TA:) and in like manner Als~iloEapu [the ganglion]. (TA.)
5 tamaw~aja see 1.

mawojN * , [a coll. gen. n., Waves; billows; surges; or a collection of waves;] water rising above other water: (TA:) pl. A^amowaAjN: (S, K, Msb:) mawojapN has a more special signification; [namely, a wave, a single wave;] and the pl. of this, which is the n. un., is mawojaAtN. (Msb.) ― -b2- farasN gawojN mawojN: see art. gwj. mwj is here an imitative sequent. (TA.) ― -b3- mawojapu Al$~abaAbi (tropical:) The prime of youth. (K.)

nAqp mawojaY * (assumed tropical:) A swift (naAjiyap: in the CK naAjibap) she-camel, whose A^anosaAE [or woven thongs of the fore girth] have moved round (jaAlat) by reason of the backward and forward motion (AixotilaAf) of her fore and hind legs. (K.)
maw~aAjN * [A sea tumultuous with waves]. (K, art. rd.)
maAy^ijN * A sea in a state of commotion; tumultuous; agitated with waves, conflicting, or dashing together. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, and ↓ mutamaw~ijN, A man in a state of commotion, or agitation. (TA.)
mutamaw~ijN * : see maAy^ijN.
1 maA*a * , [aor. yamuw*u,] He lied. (L.)

maA*N *
Good in natural disposition, happy in spirits, cheerful in mind, merry, jocose, (L, K,) and pleasant in speech. (L.) See TaAbN.

maA*iY~N * (K) and maA*iy~apN (S, L, Msb, K) A soft coat of mail, easy to the wearer; (S, L, Msb, K;) and [so] the former, any weapon: (K:) or the latter, a white coat of mail. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, (Msb,) the latter, White honey: (S, L, Msb, K:) or [in the CK and] new honey: or pure honey: or excellent honey. (K.) ― -b3- Also, the latter, Wine. (S, L, K.)

1 maAra * , aor. yamuwru, inf. n. maworN, It moved from side to side, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) like the knee-pan on the knee; (A;) or to and fro, like as the tall palm-tree moves; (S;) as also ↓ tmw~r: (S:) it came and went; (T;) as also ↓ tmw~r. (K.) You say of a camel, tamuwru EaDudaAhu The upper bones of his two arms move from side to side. (S, TA.) And maAra Als~inaAnu fiY AlmaToEuwni [The spear-head moved from side to side in the person pierced]. (A.) And AlT~aEonapu tamuwru The thrust inclines to the right and left. (TA.) And Aln~ujuwmu tamuwru The stars come and go. (TA.) And maAra AlgubaAru, inf. n. maworN, The dust moved to and fro: or became raised by the wind. (M, K.) ― -b2- It moved round about, (T, TA,) and to and fro: (TA:) it was in a state of commotion; in a state of tumult: (S, * M, Msb, K:) said of the sea, (Msb,) &c.: (M:) it was in a state of quick motion or commotion. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., that when the soul, or spirit, was blown into Adam, maAra fiY raA^osihi faEaTasa It circulated, and moved to and fro, in his head, and he sneezed. (TA.) And in the Kur, [lii. 9,] yawoma tamuwru Als~amaA='u maworFA On the day when the heaven shall actually be in a state of commotion, or tumult: so accord. to Ed-Dahhák: or shall move from side to side: so accord. to AO and Akh: (S:) or shall come and go; or move to and fro; or reel. (T.) And in a trad. of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, bikataAy^iba tamuwru karijoli AljaraAdi With troops moving to and fro, in a state of commotion, like the leg of the locust, by reason of their multitude. (TA.) You say also, maArati Aln~aAqapu fiY sayorihaA The she-camel was in a state of commotion, and reeled, in her pace, or going: and in like manner you say of a mare. (TA.) ― -b3- maA A^adoriY A^agaAra A^amo maAra, a saying of the Arabs, related by IAar, (TA,) I know not whether he have come to low country, or turned and returned to high country (najod): (S, TA:) or have come to the low country, or come to the high country. (IAar, K, * TA.) ― -b4- maAra Ald~amu (S, &c.) The blood ran, or flowed, upon the surface of the ground; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) and in like manner you say of tears, meaning they flowed: (M:) or the blood poured upon the surface of the ground, and went hither and thither, (TA,) sideways. (A.) ― -b5- See also 4.

4 AmAr Als~inaAna fiY AlmaToEawni * [He made the spearhead to move from side to side in the person pierced]. (A.) AmArt Alr~iyHu AlgubaAra The wind
made the dust to go to and fro: or raised the dust. (M, K.) ― -b2- AmAr Ald~ama He made the blood to run or flow; (T, S, * IKtt, Msb;) as also ↓ maArahu, (IKtt, Msb,) inf. n. mayorN. (IKtt. [as in the TA; but this seems to be a mistake for maworN.])
5 tamaw~ara see 1, in two places.

maworN *
A road: (T, S:) or a trodden and even road: (M, K:) an inf. n. used as a subst.: because people come and go upon it. (TA.)

muwrN *
Dust moving to and fro (M, K) in the air: (TA:) or raised by the wind: (M, K:) or carried to and fro by the wind. (T, S.) ― -b2- See also maw~aArN.

maw~aArN * , (TA,) or maw~aAru AlmilaATi, (S, TA,) A camel that moves the upper bones of his two arms from side to side; (S, TA;) and maw~aAru AlD~aboEayoni [signifies the same]. (A.) ― -b2- maw~aArapN, (M, K,) or maw~aArapu Alyadi, (S, Msb,) A she-camel quick in her pace: (S, Msb:) or easy in her pace, and quick. (M, K.) ― -b3- riyHN maw~aArapN Wind that blows the dust to and fro: or that raises the dust: pl. riyaAHN muwrN, which is extr. [with respect to rule]. (M.)

maAy^iraAtN *
Bloods [flowing, and running hither and thither]. So in the following verse (of Rusheyd Ibn-Rumeyd El-'Anazee, TA; not of El-Aashà [as it is said to be in the S in art. EwD;] Sgh, in TA, art. EwD:)
Halafotu bimaAy^iraAtK Hawola EawoDK
waA^anoSaAbK turikona ladaY Als~aEiyri
[or Als~uEayori, i. e., I swore, or I swear, by bloods flowing and running hither and thither, around 'Owd, and stones set up to be worshipped, left by Es-Sa'eer or Es-So'eyr]. 'Owd and Es-Sa'eer [or Es-So'eyr] were two idols. (S, TA.) [See also another verse, cited in art. Ez.]

mawozN *
A certain kind of tree, (Mgh,) or fruit, (Msb, K,) well known; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) [the fruit of the banana-tree, or musa paradisiaca;] i. q. TaloHN [in one of the acceptations of this latter word]: (Msb:) it is lenitive, diuretic, provocative of venery, and augments the spermatic fluid and the phlegm and the yellow bile, and the eating much of it is very oppressive, (K,) for it is slow of digestion: (TA:) the tree grows in the manner of the barodiY~, [i. e., papyrus, or perhaps other rushes,] and has a long and broad leaf, which may be three cubits by two cubits, (AHn, Mgh, TA,) the mawoz [i. e., the fruit] is found, where it grows, throughout the whole year, (AHn, as cited by 'Abd-El-Lateef,) and there may be on one of its racemes from thirty to five hundred fruits; (AHn, Mgh, K, TA;) this is seen in the districts of Makdishoo [between Abyssinia and the country of the Zenj]; (TA;) and when this is the case, the raceme is propped up; (AHn, Mgh;) it rises to the height of the stature of a man, [and higher,] and its offsets continually grow around it, every one of them smaller than another; and when it has produced its fruit, the mother-tree is cut down at the foot, and its offset that has attained to its height fructifies, and becomes a mother, the rest remaining its offsets, and thus it continues: whence the saying of Ash'ab, to his son, as related by As, Wherefore dost thou not become like me? to which he answered, Such as I is like the mawozap, which does not attain to a good state until its mother dies. (AHn, TA.) mawozapN is the n. un. (S, Msb.)

maw~aAzN *
A seller of mawoz [or fruit of the bananatree]. (K.)

1 maAsa * , aor. yamuwsu, (Msb,) inf. n. mawosN, (Sgh, Msb, K,) He shaved (Sgh, Msb, K) the head, (Sgh, Msb,) or the hair: (K:) but Sgh says, that its correctness requires consideration, and it was doubted by IF. (TA.) See muwsaY, below.

AlmaAsu * , not A^alomaAsN, (K,) i. e., with the disjunctive hemzeh, (TA,) for this is an incorrect pronunciation, (K,) of the vulgar, as Sgh and others have plainly asserted; but IAth says, I think that the hemzeh and lám in it are radical letters, as they are in AlyAs, [i. e., A_iloyaAs or A^aloyaAs,] and it is not Arabic; and if so, its place is under the letter hemzeh, because they say A^alomaAsN; but if they be [prefixed] for the purpose of rendering the word determinate, the present is its [proper] place; (TA;) [The diamond;] a certain precious stone, (K, * TA,) reckoned among jewels, like the yaAquwt and the zumur~ur*, (TA,) the largest of which is like the walnut, (K, TA,) or the egg of the pigeon, (TA,) and this is rare, or very rare, (K, TA,) the only instance being said to be the one called Alkawokabu Ald~ur~iY~u, which is suspended at the tomb of the Prophet: (TA:) it breaks all stony bodies, and the holding it in the mouth breaks the teeth, and fire has no effect upon it, nor iron, but only lead breaks it and powders it, [a strange mistake, for it is well known that it is powdered by being pounded in a steel mortar,] after which it is taken [in the state of powder] upon drills, and pearls &c. are drilled with it. (K.)

muwsaY * [A razor;] a certain instrument of iron, (M, Msb, TA,) with which one shaves: (Lth, L, K, TA:) of the measure fuEolaY, (Ks, M, Msb, K,) from Almawosu, [inf. n. of maAsa,] so that the m is a radical letter, (K,) accord. to Lth, (TA,) [for] Lth says, (L, TA,) Almawosu is the root (taA^osiys [lit. foundation]) of AlmuwsaY, (L, K, TA,) the thing with which one shaves; (L, TA;) therefore, (Az, Msb, K,) it is imperfectly decl., because of the short fem. A [written Y], (Msb,) without tenween; (Az, K;) and Fr cites a verse [of obscene meaning] in which it is made fem.: (TA:) or it is from A^awosayotu raA^osahu, meaning “ I shaved his head, ” (ISk, M, * Msb, K,) of the measure mufoEalN, (ISk, Msb, TA,) so that the Y is a radical letter, as El-Umawee and Yz say, and Aboo-'Amr Ibn-el-Alà inclined to think it so, (TA,) and therefore it is perfectly decl., (Msb,) with tenween, (Msb, K,) when indeterminate; (Msb;) or it is of the measure mufoEalN because this measure is more common than fuEolaY, and because it is perfectly decl. when indeterminate, whereas fuEolaY is not so when indeterminate and when determinate: (Ibn-EsSarráj, TA:) but IAmb says, that it is masc. and fem., and perfectly decl. and imperfectly decl.: ISk says, that the approved way is to make it perfectly decl.: (Msb:) [but] he says that it is fem. [also, and if so it is imperfectly decl.]: (TA:) and it is related of A'Obeyd, in the Bári', that he said he had not heard it made masc. except by El-Umawee; (Msb;) who asserted it to be masc. only: (TA:) the pl., accord. to him who makes it imperfectly decl., is muwsayaAtN; and accord. to him who makes it perfectly decl., mawaAsK. (Msb.) The dim. of mwsY, in the sense above explained, [not as a proper name, in which case it is muwsaY only, without tenween, and has no relation to the same word signifying a razor,] is muwayosiyapN, [but by rule it should be muwayosaY, like HubayolaY,] accord. to him who says h`*ihi muwsaY; and muwayosK accord. to him who says h`*aA muwsFY. (ISk, TA.)

maA$N * [Indian peas;] a certain grain, well known, (S in art. my$, and K,) round, smaller than the Him~aS [or chick-pea], of a tawny colour inclining to greenness; it is in Syria and India; and is sown; (TA;) also called maj~N and xul~arN and zin~N: (TA, art. mj:) it is of moderate temperature; and the mixture made thereof is commended, being beneficial to him who is fevered, and him who is affected with rheum; it is lenitive; and when cooked with vinegar, it is beneficial for purulent pustulous mange or scab; and an external application thereof strengthens feeble limbs: (K:) the word is arabicized [from the Persian maA$o], or postclassical. (S.) -A2- Utensils and furniture, of the meaner sort, of a house or tent. (IAar, K.) Hence the saying, AlmaA$u xayorN mino laA$a, [in one copy of the K I find laA$K, but the former seems to be the right reading,] meaning, Mean house-
hold utensils and furniture are better than nothing; or] what is in the house, or tent, of worthless utensils and furniture, is better than its being empty: (K, TA:) lA$ is here contracted [from laA$aYo'a] for the sake of its resembling mA$. (TA.) And xaA$a maA$a and xaA$i maA$i signify the same as maA$N thus used: (K, TA in art. xw$:) or the refuse, or meanest sort, of people, or of mankind; as in the M. (TA.)

div2.head: mwS &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

mayobapN *
A certain remedy, or medicine: (K:) [an arabicized word] from the Persian maYo “ a beverage, ” and biho “ a quince: ” quince-beverage; diacydonium; a medicine prepared of the juice of quinces: some of it is raw; and some, not raw: some is perfumed; and some, not perfumed. (TA, from the book entitled Má lá yesa'u, &c.)
1 maAta * , aor. yamiytu: see art. mwt.

dArY bimiytaA'i daArihi * , [as also bimiydaA'i,] My house is opposite to his house. (L, not in the TA.) [See also art. AtY.] ― -b2- miytaA'u TariyqK The measure of the two sides, and the distance, of a road; as also miydaA'. (L, not in the TA.) [See also art A^tY.]

1 maAva * , aor. yamiyvu, (inf. n. mayovN, K,) i. q. maAva, aor. yamuwvu, inf. n. mawovN; (S, K;) [in the CK, for Almawovu is put Almawotu;] as also ↓ my~v, inf. n. tamoyiyvN; (K;) and ↓ AmAv, inf. n. A_imaAvapN; but this is disapproved by IAth; (TA;) and ↓ AmtAv, inf. n. A_imotiyaAvN; (K;) and ↓ A_im~aAva, [for A_inomaAva,] inf. n. A_im~iyaAvN; (TA;) [but the last form I have only found used intransitively;] He steeped a thing in water, and mashed it with his hand: (TA:) he mixed and moistened a thing in water: (S, K:) or mAv and ↓ my~v, he steeped anything, such as saffron, and dates, and raisins, and the preparation of churned milk called A^aqiT, in water, so that it dissolved, and mashed it with his hand. (Lth.) ― -b2- maAva He dissolved salt in water; (ISk, Lth;) and in like manner clay, or loam. (ISk.) ― -b3- All~`hum~a mivo quluwbahumo kamaA yumaAvu AlmiloHu fiY AlmaA'i [O God, dissolve their hearts, like as salt is dissolved in water!] (TA, from a trad.)

2 my~v * : see 1. ― -b2- (tropical:) He rendered a man gentle. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) He rendered a man submissive. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) It (fortune, or misfortune,) rendered a man expert and submissive. (TA.) ― -b5- [And so] ↓ tmy~v (tropical:) He (a man) became submissive, and languid, or flaccid. (TA.)
4 A^amoyava see 1.

5 tamay~ava
tmy~vt AlA^aroDu The ground became softened (and cooled, S,) by rain. (S, K.) [See also maAvati AlA^aroDu, in art. mwv.] See 2.
7 AnmAv * , [inf. n. A_inomiyaAvN;] (ISk;) and A_im~aAva, inf. n. A_im~iyaAvN; (Lth;) It (salt) became dissolved in water; (ISk, Lth;) and in like manner, clay, or loam. (ISk.) ― -b2- See 1.

8 AmtAv * , (inf. n. A_imotiyaAvN, TA,) He attained to an easy state of life; (K;) or a pleasant life. (TA.) ― -b2- AmtAv He steeped in water, and mashed with his hand, and drank, the preparation of churned milk called A^aqiT. (K.) ― -b3- See 1.

may~ivN *
Soft. (K.) ― -b2- rajulN may~ivu Alqalobi (tropical:) A man of soft, or gentle, heart. (TA.)

mayovaA'u *
Even, or plain, or soft, land: pl. miyvN: (S, K:) you say, A^aroDN mayovaA='u, and A^araADK miyvu: (A:) [see also miyvaA='u, in art. mwv:] an even, or a plain, or soft, tract of sand: and a hill of good soil: (L:) and a [water-course such as is called] taloEap, that becomes as large as half, or twothirds, of the valley. (L, Sh, in TA, voce tlEp.)
musotamiyvN * The thin pellicle that adheres to the white of an egg. (AA, K.) [See also musotamiytN, in art. mwt.]

1 maAHa * , aor. yamiyHu, (S, K,) inf. n. mayoHN; (A, K;) and ↓ AmtAH; (A, [and the same seems to be indicated in the S, where it is said that A_imotiyaAHN signifies the same as mayoHN;]) He descended into, (S, A,) or entered, (K,) the well, and filled the bucket: (S, A, K:) this is done when its water is little. (S.) ― -b2- maAHa AlmaA='a, aor. yamiyHu; and ↓ AmtAHhu; He drew water by descending into the well and filling the bucket. (A.) ― -b3- maAHa fiY mi$oyatihi, (S, A, K, *) inf. n. mayoHN and mayoHuwHapN; (K;) and ↓ my~H, and ↓ tmAyH; (A;) (tropical:) He walked in a certain elegant manner, (K,) with a self-conceited gait, and with an affected inclining of his body from side to side, (S, A,) like as a duck walks. (S, K.) ― -b4- ↓ mar~a yatamay~aHu (tropical:) He passed along so walking, and looking at his shadow. (A.) ― -b5- Also ↓ tmy~H (tropical:) He inclined his body from side to side in walking: (K:) and ↓ tmAyH he, or it, (a drunken man, and a branch, S,) inclined from side to side; (S, K;) as also ↓ my~H and ↓ tmy~H: (TA:) which last is also said of a branch, or twig. (M, L, art. rA^d.) ― -b6- ↓ Als~akoraAnu yatamay~aHu, and ↓ yatamaAyaHu, (tropical:) [The drunken man reels, or inclines from side to side in walking]. (A.) ― -b7- maAHati Alr~iyHu Al$~ajarapa (assumed tropical:) The wind made the tree to incline. (TA.) -A2- mAHhu Einod Als~uloTaAni, aor. yamiyHu, (S, K, *) inf. n. mayoHN, (K,) (tropical:) He interceded for him with the Sultán. (S, K.) -A3- maAHahu, aor. yamiyHu, (S, K,) inf. n. mayoHN and miyaAHapN; and ↓ AmtAHhu; (K;) (tropical:) He gave him [a thing]. (S, K.) ― -b2- maAHa (tropical:) He conferred a benefit, favour, or kindness. (L.) -A4- maAHa faAhu, biA@lomisowaAki aor. yamiyHu, (S, K,) inf. n. mayoHN, (K,) (tropical:) He rubbed and cleaned his teeth with a toothstick: (AA, S, K:) or [so accord. to the L; but in the K, and] he cleansed out the saliva from his mouth with the tooth-stick. (L, K.)
2 may~aHa see 1.

3 mAyHhu * , (A, K,) inf. n. mumaAyaHapN, (A,) (tropical:) He commingled, or conversed, or held intercourse, with him; (K;) namely, with a Sultán; and in like manner with women. (A.) ― -b2- bayoniY wabayonahu mamaAyaHapN wamumaAlaHapN (tropical:) [Between me and him are a commingling, or converse, or intercourse, and fellowship in eating.] (A.)
5 tamay~aHa and 6: see 1.

8 AmtAHhu * : see 1. ― -b2- (tropical:) It (heat, and work or labour,) made him to sweat. (A.) ― -b3- AmtAHt Al$~amosu *iforaY AlbaEiyri (tropical:) The sun drew forth the sweat from the protuberance of the camel's head, behind his ears. (K.) -A2- See 10.

10 AstmAHhu * , (S, A, K,) and ↓ AmtAHhu, (A,) (tropical:) He asked him for a gift. (S, A, K.) ↓ AmtAHhu (tropical:) He came to him seeking his bounty. (L.) ― -b2- AstmAHhu (tropical:) He asked him to intercede for him, (S, A, K,) Einoda Als~uloTaAni with the Sultan. (S, A.)
maAHN * The yolk of an egg: or its white. (AA, K.) [See also muH~N.]
mayoHN * (tropical:) Profit; advantage. (K.) See maAy^iHN.

miyHN *
A bad kind of dates; i. q. $iySN (K.)
maAHapN * The court of a house: (K:) a dial. form of baAHapN. (TA.)
may~aAHN * (tropical:) A man who walks with a self-conceited gait, and with an affected inclining of his body from side to side: (L:) fem. with p. (S, L.)

maAy^iHN * A man who descends into a well and fills the bucket, when its water is little: pl. maAHapN. (S.) The maAtiH is he who draws the water from the mouth of the well. (L.) ― -b2- maAy^iHN (tropical:) A tooth-stick; syn. siwaAkN: so called because it draws away the saliva, like as he who descends into a well ladles out the water: (L:) and so (accord. to some, TA) ↓ mayoHN. (K.)

1 maAda * , aor. yamiydu, inf. n. mayodN (S, L, Msb, K) and mayadaAnN, (L, Msb, K,) It (a thing) was, or
became in a state of motion, or commotion; was, or became agitated: (S, L, Msb, K:) or, in a state of violent motion or commotion; or violently agitated. (El-Basáïr, TA.) So in the expression in the Kur, [xvi. 15; and xxxi. 9;] A^ano tamiyda bikumo Lest it (the earth) should be convulsed with you, and go round with you, and move you about violently. (El-Basáïr, TA.) ― -b2- maAda It turned or twisted about, or became contorted and convulsed. (IKtt.) ― -b3- maAda fiY Alr~umoHi (tropical:) He (a man pierced) writhed upon the spear. (A.) ― -b4- maAda It (the mirage, saraAb,) was in a state of commotion; it quivered, or trembled. (L, K.) ― -b5- maAda (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, confounded, perplexed, or amazed. (TA.) ― -b6- maAda, (aor. yamiydu, TA, inf. n. mayodN or mayadN, L,) (tropical:) He (a man, L,) became affected with a heaving of the stomach, or a tendency to vomit, and a giddiness in the head, by reason of intoxication, or of voyaging upon the sea. (L, K.) ― -b7- You say also maAda bihi AlbaHoru, aor. yamiydu, inf. n. mayodN, (tropical:) The sea affected him with a heaving of the stomach, &c. (L.) And maAdato bihi AlA^aroDu (tropical:) The ground went round with him. (A.) ― -b8- maAdati AlHanoZalapu, (aor. yamiydu, L,) The colocynth became affected by day-dew, (L, K,) or by moisture, (L,) and in consequence, changed [in odour, or stinking]: (L, K:) and in like manner a date. (L.) ― -b9- maAda, (S, A, L,) inf. n. mayodN (L) and mayadaAnN; (A;) and ↓ tmAyd; (A;) It (a branch) inclined from side to side. (S, A, L.) ― -b10- (tropical:) He inclined from side to side in walking. (L.) ― -b11- maAda, inf. n. mayodN and mayadaAnN, It inclined to one side: as the earth is, in a trad., described to have done before the mountains were formed. (L.) ― -b12- maAda (tropical:) He (a man, S,) affected a bending of his person, body, or limbs; (L;) he walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side; (S, L, K;) and maAdato and ↓ tmy~dt signify the same, said of a woman. (A.) -A2- maAda He conferred, or bestowed, a benefit or benefits, or a favour or favours. You say, maAdaniY fulaAnN Such a one conferred a benefit or benefits upon me. (L.) ― -b2- maAdah, (L, Msb,) and ↓ AmAdhu, (L,) He gave him. (L, Msb.) ― -b3- maAda He furnished persons with, or gave them, provisions for travelling; syn. zaAda. (L.) [In the K, zaAra He visited.] ― -b4- He brought a people wheat, or food; i. q. maAra, (S, L, K,) of which it is a dial. form. (S.) ― -b5- He trafficked as a merchant. (L.) ― -b6- maAda, inf. n. mayodN and mayadaAnN, It increased, or grew; syn. raAEa and zakaA. (M, L, K.) [In the copies of the K in my hands, for rAE is put zAg.]
4 A^amoyada 5, and 6: see 1.

8 AmtAdhu *
He asked him, or desired him, to give him. (L.) ― -b2- AmtAdhu He asked or desired him to bring him wheat, or food. (A.)

mayoda * a dial. form of bayoda, (S,) in the sense of gayor: (S, L;) and in that of EalaY: (L:) or that of mino A^ajoli. (S, L.) It is said in a trad., A^anaA A^afoSaHu AlEarabi mayoda A^an~iY mino qurayo$K wana$aA^otu fiY baniY saEodi boni bakorK [rendered in art. byd]. (S, L.) See what next follows.
faEalotuhu mayodaA *`lika * , (M, K,) or mayoda *lk, (L,) I did it on account, or for the sake, of that. (M, L, K.) mino mayodaA *`lika has not been heard. (M, L.)
mayodapN * : see maAy^idapN.

miydaA='N * The amount, and measure, of a thing: (L, K:) and the two sides, and distance, or extent, of a thing, (L,) or of a road; (K;) and the surface of a road. (L.) One says, lamo A^adori maA miydaA='u *`lika I knew not what was the amount of that, and its measure: or, what was the measure of its two sides, and its extent: as also miytaAw^uhu. (L.) ― -b2- The extreme limit of the distance to which horses run; and so myiy^otA='N. (S, TA, art. A^tY.) -A2- miydaA='N A mode, manner, fashion, or from. Ex. banuwoA buyuwtahumo EalaY miydaA='K waAHidK They built their houses, or constructed their tents, after one mode, &c. (L.) [See also miy^otaA='N, in art. AtY.]

h`*aA miydaAw^uhu * , [thus in the copies of the K and in the TA, app. a mistake for miydaA='ahu, like tiloqaA='ahu,] and bimiydaAy^ihi, and bimiydaAhu, This is opposite to, or facing, it. (K.) And daAriY bimayodaA daArihi, with fet-h to the m; (as also bimiytaA='i dArh, L in art. myt; and bimiy^otaA='i dArh, S in art. AtY;) My house is opposite to his house. (Yaakoob, L.) ― -b2- miydaA='u AlTariyqi: see miy^otaA=' in art. A^ataY, and miytaA=' in art. myt.

mayodaAnN * (S, L, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ miydaAnN (K) A horse-course; race-ground; hippodrome: (Msb, TA:) pl. mayaAdiynu: (S, K, &c.:) of the measure faEolaAnN, (IKtt,) from mAd “ it was in a state of motion; ” because the sides of the horsecourse shake on the occasion of a race: (Msb:) or from mAd “ it turned or twisted about, or became contorted and convulsed; ” because the horses wheel about, and bend or convulse themselves, in the place so called: or of the measure faloEaAnN, from madFY “ a limit, or goal; ” because horses run to their goals in the place so called; originally madoyaAnN, the second and third radicals being transposed; as in biyzaAnN, originally buzoyaAnN: or of the measure fayoEaAlN, from madana “ he abode, or dwelt; ” because horses confine themselves especially to the place so called for wheeling about and the like. (IKtt.) -A2- Eayo$N mayodaAnN A delicate, a pleasant, or an ample and easy, life. (S, L.) ― -b2- mayodaAnu AlxulafaA='i (tropical:) a term applied by historians to The period of the reign of Khaleefehs; from twenty to twenty-four years. (MF, TA.)
miydaAnN * : see mayodaAnN.

mayuwdN *
That moves about, or is agitated, much; that vacillates much: (L:) an intensive epithet; applied in a trad. to worldly prosperity. (L., art. Hyd.)
may~aAdN * : see maAy^idN.

maAy^idN * (tropical:) A man affected with a heaving of the stomach, or a tendency to vomit, and a giddiness in the head, by reason of intoxication, or of voyaging upon the sea: pl. mayodaY. (L.) ― -b2- maAy^idN A branch inclining [from side to side: see 1]: (A, L:) as also ↓ may~aAdN: (L:) [or rather the latter signifies inclining much, or frequently, from side to side:] pl. [of the former] muy~adN. (TA.) ― -b3- fulaAnN yamo$iY EalaY AlA^aroDi fay~aAdFA may~aAdFA (tropical:) Such a one walks upon the ground with an elegant and a proud and a self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side. (A, Art. fyd.)

maAy^idapN * (and ↓ mayodapN, El-Jarmee, L, K) A table with food upon it: (S, L, K:) without food upon it, a table is not thus called, but is called xiwaAnN: (AAF, S, L:) or also applied to a table itself: (L:) MF says, that this latter application is allowable, considering that food has been, or is to be, placed upon the table: but El-Hareeree asserts it to be incorrect, and the former application only to be allowable: (TA:) mAy^dp is thus used in its proper sense of an act. part. n., and is from mAd “ it was in a state of motion; ” as though the table [which was generally a round piece of leather or the like spread upon the ground] moved about with what was upon it: (Zj, L, Msb: *) or from mAd “ he brought wheat or food; ” because food is brought upon it [or as though it brought food]: (L:) or from mAd “ he gave; ” as though it gave of what was upon it to those around it: (El-'Ináyeh:) or it is of the form of an act. part. n. and used in the sense of a pass. part. n., from mAd “ he gave, ” (AO, S, L, Msb,) like raADiyapN in the phrase Eiy$apN raADiyapN; (AO, S, L;) because what is thus called is given by its owner to the people [who are to eat]: (Msb:) also, food itself; (Akh, AHát, ISd, L, K;) even if without a table: (L:) [pl. mawaAy^idu]. See also faAvuwrN. ― -b2- maAy^idapN: (tropical:) A round piece of land or ground: (L, K:) likened to a table. (TA.)
mawaAy^idu * : see maAy^idapN. ― -b2- Also, Calamities: formed by transposition from maA=widu. (T, L.)

mumotaAdN *
Asking, or desiring, to give; asking or
desiring, a gift. (K.) And Asked, or desired, to give; one of whom a gift is asked, or desired. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- mumotaAdN A man [asking, or desiring, and ― -b3- ] asked, or desired, to bring wheat or food. (S, L.)

1 maAra A^aholahu * (T, * S, A, Msb, *) and EiyaAlahu, (M, K,) aor. yamiyru, (T, S, A, &c.,) inf. n. mayorN, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) He brought, or conveyed, or purveyed, TaEaAm, [here meaning wheat, or other corn, and food, victuals, or provision, of any kind, (see miyrapN,)] (T, S, M, A, K) to, or for, his family, (T, * S, A,) or his household: (M, K:) or he brought to them miyrap, i. e. TaEaAm: (As [accord. to whom, as I find in the TA, the aor. is yamuwru, but this I suppose to be a mistranscription,] T, Mgh, Msb:) or he gave them miyrap: (TA:) and ↓ A^amaArahumo signifies the same as maArahumo; (K;) and so lahumo ↓ AmtAr: (S, * M, K:) or you say, humo yamotaAruwna liA^anofusihimo they bring, or convey, or purvey, TEAm for themselves; (T;) and linafosihi ↓ AmtAr, (A,) or Almiyrapa linafosihi ↓ AmtAr, (Mgh, Msb,) he brought, (A, Mgh, Msb,) or conveyed, or purveyed, (A,) TEAm for himself. (A, Mgh, Msb.) See miyrapN.
4 A^amoyara see 1.
8 A_imotayara see 1.
mayorN * : see miyrapN.

miyrapN * : i. q. TaEaAmN [here meaning Wheat, or other corn, and food, victuals, or provision, of any kind,] (T, S, A, * Mgh, Msb, K, *) which a man brings, or conveys or purveys (yamotaAruhu) [to be laid up in store for himself or his family or household, or for sale]; (S, TA;) and ↓ mayorN signifies the same as miyrapN [in these senses, as will be seen from what follows], and is applied to victuals, or food, or aliment, syn. quwtN. (TA.) Ex. jaAlibu Almiyrapi, (K,) or ↓ Almayori, (M,) [The bringer, or conveyer, or purveyor, of wheat, &c.] And A^ataAhu bimiyrapK He brought him TaEaAm. (T.) And jaAw^uwA biA@lomiyrapi [They brought, or conveyed, or purveyed, the wheat, &c.] (A.) And maA Einodahu ↓ xayorN walaA mayorN [He has not wealth, nor wheat, &c.] (T, S, A.) ― -b2- Also, (T,) The bringing, or conveying, or purveyance, of TaEaAm [here meaning as explained above] from another place (T, M, A, K,) [for one's self or family or household, (see 1,) or] for sale: (T:) pl. miyarN. (M, arts. dfA^ and Syf; &c.) The first miyrap is the riboEiy~ap (M, arts. dfA^ and Syf,) which is the myrp in the beginning of [the season called] the $itaA=' [or winter, i. e., in the latter part of December or in January, during the season of rains called Alr~abiyE, about which time, the species of millet called *urap, which, as Niebuhr mentions, (Descr. de l'Arabie, p. 135, note,) is called in El-Yemen TaEaAm, is gathered in]: (S, K, art. rbE:) the second, the Sayofiy~ap, (M, arts, dfA^ and Syf,) also called the SaAy^ifap, (S, M, K, art. Syf,) which is the myrp in [the season called] the Sayof [or spring], (S, M, art. Syf,) in the first part of the Sayof [i. e., in the latter part of March, about which time, wheat, and a second crop of millet (*urap), and barley, are gathered in]: (M, art. Syf:) the third, the dafay^iy~ap, (M, arts. dfA^ and Syf,) which is [also] in the first part of [the season called] the Sayof [or spring, and consequently immediately after the Sayofiy~ap, commencing in the season of the dafay^iY~ rains, and app. continuing during part of April, when the same grains are gathered in; or by the Sayof in this instance may be meant summer, but the more proper meaning is spring, and the term dafay^iy~apN seems already to point to the season of the dafay^iY~ rains]: (M, art. dfA^:) and the fourth, the ramaDiy~ap, (M, arts. dfA^ and Syf,) which is the myrp coming when the earth becomes burnt [by the sun, about July, when the month of ramaDaAn began at the period when the calendar by the months was fixed by Kiláb Ibn-Murrah, about two centuries before the Hijreh, and at which season of the year a third crop of *urap is gathered in; for in some parts of Arabia they have three crops of this grain in the year; the second and third being sown immediately after, or produced by the grain which is let fall in cutting, the first and second]. (M, art. dfA^.)
may~aArN * : see maAy^irN.

maAy^irN * (S, M, K) and ↓ may~aArN (M, K) One who brings, or conveys, or purveys, miyrap, (S, * K,) or mayor: (M, L:) pl. of the former, muy~aArN (S, M, K) and may~aArapN, like raj~aAlapN. (S, K.) You say naHonu nanotaZiru muy~aAranaA, and may~aAratanaA, [We are expecting our bringers, or conveyers, or purveyors, of wheat, &c.] (S.) The pl. may~aArapN is applied to A company of men who go together from the desert to the towns or villages to bring miyrap. (TA.) It is said in a trad. AlHamuwlapu AlmaAy^irapu lahumo lAagiyapN, meaning, The camels that carry miyrap for them for sale and the like are exempt from the eleëmosynary taxation, because they are working beasts. (TA.)

1 maAzahu * , aor. yamiyzuhu, inf. n. mayozN; (S, A, Msb, K;) and ↓ my~zhu (S, K,) inf. n. tamoyiyzN; (S;) or the latter has an intensive signification; (Msb;) He put it, or set it, apart, away, or aside; removed it; or separated it; (S, A, Msb, K;) from another thing, or other things; (Msb;) as also ↓ AmAzhu: (K:) [or the second, rather, he did so much, or greatly, or widely; like zay~alahu.] You say, maAzahu minohu, and ↓ my~zhu. (A.) Ex. maAza AlA^a*aY mina AlT~ar~iyq He put aside, or removed, what was hurtful from the road. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur, [viii. 38,] liyamiyza A@ll~`hu Alxabiyva mina AlT~ay~ibi [That God may separate, or sever, the evil from the good]. (Msb.) [It seems also, from what is said in the A, that maAyazotu bayonahumaA signifies I separated them two: besides having another signification, which see below.] You say also maAza Al$~aYo'a, (aor. and inf. n. as above, TA,) meaning, He separated one part of the thing from another; faSala baEoDahu mino baEoDK, (M, TA,) or Eano baEoDK: (as in a copy of the A:) expl. in the K as signifying faD~ala baEoDahu EalaY baEoDK [he judged, or made, part of the thing to excel, or to have excelled, another]; but the explanation in the M is the right. (TA.) And AlA^a$oyaA='a ↓ my~z He separated the things after knowledge of them. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence, He distinguished it, or discriminated it, or discerned it. And maAza bayona AlA^a$oyaA='i, and bayonahaA ↓ may~aza, He distinguished, or discriminated, or discerned, between the things. This is what is meant by its being said,] Almayozu also signifies Alt~amoyiyzu bayona AlA^a$oyaA='i. (TA.) You say also, bayonahumaA ↓ maAyazotu [I distinguished, or discriminated, or discerned, between them two]. (A.) From my~z AlA$yA=', meaning as explained above, is [also], app., derived the phrase sin~u Alt~amoyiyzi, used by the doctors of practical law, as signifying, [The age of discrimination;] the age at which one knows what things are beneficial to him and what are hurtful to him: or, accord. to some, Alt~amoyiyz is a faculty in the brain whereby meanings are elicited. (Msb.) -A2- maAza [is also intrans., and signifies] He (a man) removed from one place to another. (IAar, K.) See also 8.
2 may~aza see maAzahu, throughout.
3 maAoyaza see maAzahu, in two places.
4 A^amoyaza see maAzahu, first signification.

5 tamay~aza see 8, throughout. ― -b2- You say also, fulaAnN yakaAdu yatamay~azu mina AlgayoZi Such a one almost bursts asunder with wrath, or rage. (S, K. *) The like is said in the Kur, lxvii. 8, tropically, of hell. (A, TA.)
6 tamaAoyaza see 8, throughout.
7 A_inomayaza see 8, throughout.

8 AmtAz * , and ↓ tmy~z, (S, A, Msb, K,) and ↓ AnmAz. (S, A, K,) and ↓ A_im~aAza, (Lh, TA,) [the
last being a variation of that immediately preceding,] and ↓ AstmAz, (S, A, K,) It was, or became, put, or set, apart, away, or aside; or removed; or separated; (S, A, * Msb, * K;) from another thing, or other things: (Msb:) and the last, ↓ AstmAz, he went, or withdrew, aside, or to a distance, (K, TA,) Eani Al$~aYo'i from the thing. (TA.) All these forms are syn.; but in the phrase mizotuhu falamo yam~azo [as though signifying I put it, or set it, apart, &c., but it did not remain so] Lh allows the verbs to be only in these two forms: (TA:) [though ↓ AnmAz is used in other cases; for] you say Eano ↓ AnmAz muSal~aAhu He shifted from his place of prayer; or quitted it for another. (TA.) [See also 1, last signification.] You say also, AmtAr Alqawomu, meaning, baEoDuhumo mino baEoDK ↓ tmy~z [The people were, or became, put, or set, apart, &c., one from another]: (S, TA:) and, as also ↓ tmy~zwA, they became on one side: or they became alone, or separate: and the former, they withdrew, in a company or troop, aside; as also ↓ AstmAzwA: (TA:) and [in like manner] ↓ tmAyzwA they became separated: (A:) and they formed themselves into separate companies, or troops, and went away, one from another. (TA. [Alt~amaAyuzu being there said to signify Alt~aHaz~ubu waAlt~anaAfuru.]) ― -b2- [AmtAz, and the other forms mentioned above, in the first sentence of the paragraph, as syn. with it, also signify It was, or became, distinguished, or discriminated, or discerned: in which sense, ↓ tmy~z is the most common. You say also, fulaAnN ↓ tmy~z biA@lokarami Such a one was, or became, distinguished by generosity. And AlA^a$oyaA='u ↓ tamaAyazati and ↓ tumay~azat The things were, or became, distinguished, or discriminated, one from another; or distinct.]
10 A_isotamoyaza see 8, throughout.
mayozN * inf. n. of 1, q. v. ― -b2- Also, High or elevated rank or condition or state [by which one is distinguished from others]. (TA.)
miyzapN * [The act of putting, or setting, apart, away, or aside; of removing, or separating]: a subst. from maAzahu. (TA.) ― -b2- [Discrimination, or discernment: and hence,] understanding. (TA.)
rajulN may~aAzN * , and ↓ mumay~izN, [A man of much discrimination or discernment.] (A.)
mumay~izN * [Distinguishing, or discriminating: and hence, a rational animal]. rajulN mumay~izN: see may~aAzN.

1 maAsa * , aor. yamiysu, inf. n. mayosN and mayasaAnN, He walked with an elegant and a proud and selfconceited gait; or so walked with an affected inclining of the body from side to side; (S, M, A, K;) excepting that in the A the fem. forms of the pret. and aor. are given;) as also ↓ tmy~s: (S, A, * K:) accord. to the Lth, mayosN signifies a kind of mayasaAn, [app. a mistranscription for mayalaAn, or inclining,] with, or in, the gait and motion above described, like that of the bride, and of the camel; for he sometimes does this in going along with his hawodaj [or litter which serves as a vehicle for women]. (TA.)
4 A^amaAsato jisomahaA * [She (a woman) made her body to incline from side to side in walking in the manner above described.] (M.)
5 tamay~asa see 1.

mayosN *
A kind of tree, (AHn, S, M, K,) of great size, (A, Hn, M, K,) resembling in its growth and its leaves the [kind of willow called] garab: when young, it is white within; but when it grows old, it becomes black, like A=bunuws [or ebony], and so thick that wide tables are made of it; (AHn, M;) and camels' saddles (riHaAl) are made of it. (AHn, S, M.) ― -b2- Hence, A camel's saddle (raHolN), as being made of the kind of tree above described. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, A species of grape-vine, that rises somewhat upon a trunk, (AHn, M, K, *) not all of it spreading out into branches: (AHn, M:) AHn adds, its native place is the district of El-Jezeereh called Sarooa (saruwE), and it is related, of a person of knowledge, that he saw it at Et-Táïf: and hence the name of the raisins called ↓ mayosiY~: (TA:) [but ISd says, in continuation of AHn's account of the former of the trees above mentioned, not of the latter,] an Arab of the desert informed me, that he had seen it at Et-Táïf, and hence, he said, the raisins called mayos [not mayosiY] are thus named: (M:) [and F says,] mayosN signifies a kind of raisins; as well as a species of grapevine &c. (K.) ― -b4- Also, [The pole of a plough;] the long piece of wood that is between the two bulls. (AHn. M.)
mayosiY~N * : see mayosN.
mayosaAnN * : see may~aAsN.
mayosuwnN * : see may~aAsN. ― -b2- Also, A boy beautiful in stature and face. (K.)
mayuwsN * : see may~aAsN.

may~aAsN * (S, A, K) and ↓ mayosaAnN (Ibn-'Abbád, A, K) and ↓ mayuwsN and ↓ maAy^isN (K) One who walks with an elegant and a proud and selfconceited gait; or who so walks with an affected inclining of the body from side to side: (S, A, K:) [or the first and second and third, one who does so much, or often, or habitually: and the last, being a simple act. part. n., one so walking:] fem. of the first and second, with p: (A, TA:) and ↓ mayosuwn signifies the same as may~aAsapN, in the sense explained above, applied to a woman, and is of one of the measures not mentioned by Sb, like zayotuwnN; or it is from masana, and therefore of the measure fayoEuwlN; but more probably from Almayosu. (M.) ― -b2- Also, Almay~aAsu The lion that so walks; (K, TA;) an epithet applied to him because of his little regard for him whom he meets: (TA:) or the lion: (Sgh, TA:) and, (accord. to IDrd, TA,) the wolf; (K;) because he so walks. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, guSonN may~aAsN An inclining, or a bending, branch. (M.)
maAy^isN * : see may~aAsN.
See Supplement

1 maATa * , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor. yamiyTu, inf. n. mayoTN (Msb, K) and mayaTaAnN, (K,) He removed; retired, or went, to a distance; or became remote; (As, IAar, * A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K;) Eanohu from him; (IAar, A'Obeyd, S, K;) as also ↓ AstmAT; (TA;) and ↓ AmAT; (IAar, A 'Obeyd, S, K;) but As disallows the last in this sense; (S, * Msb;) it occurs, however, in a trad.: (TA:) also, he went away; (S, TA;) and so ↓ AmAT: (TA:) and it (a thing) went away. (TA.) ― -b2- He, or it, inclined to one side; or declined; i. q., maAda, and HaAda. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, aor. as above, inf. n. mayoTN, He declined, or deviated, from the right course; or acted unjustly; (AZ, Ks, S, K;) fiY Hukomihi in his judgment. (AZ, Ks, S.) ― -b4- [See also mayoTN, below: and see 3.] -A2- Also, (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K,) inf. n. mayoTN; (TA;) and ↓ AmAT, (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_imaATapN; (S, Msb;) or the latter only, accord. to As; (S, * Msb, TA;) He removed, put away, or put at a distance, (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K,) him, or it; (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb;) and maATa bihi signifies the same as AmAThu; (Msb;) and some say bihi ↓ may~aTotu [if this be not a mistranscription for miTotu bh] in the sense of A^amaTotuhu. (TA.) You say, AlA^a*aY Eani AlT~ariyqi ↓ A^amaATa, (Mgh, TA,) inf. n. A_imaATapN, (S, Msb,) He removed, or put away, or put at a distance, what was hurtful from the road, or way; (S, Mgh, Msb, TA;) and [some say] maATahu, inf. n. mayoTN. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., Ean~aA yadaka ↓ A^amiTo Remove thou from us thy hand. (TA.) And maATa bihi and ↓ AmAThu signify He took away him, or it; syn. *ahaba bihi and A^a*ohabahu. (TA.) ― -b2- mayoTN also signifies The act of repelling, impelling, pushing, or thrusting; (S;) and so ↓ miyaATN: (S, K:) and both signify the act of chiding: (S, K:) the former
being an inf. n. of which the verb is maATa, aor. yamiyTu: (K:) [the latter, app., an inf. n. of which the verb, namely mAyT, is unused; the like being said of hiyaATN, which we find coupled with miyaATN.] You say, ↓ Alqawomu fiY hiyaATK wamiyaATK The people, or company of men, are engaged in making a clamour, and repelling, &c.: (S, in the present art. and in art. hyT:) or hyAT and myAT, respectively, signify the most vehement driving in coming to water, and the most vehement driving in returning from water; (Fr, K;) and maA zalonaA biAlhiyaATi waAlomiyaATi means we ceased not to be engaged in coming and going: (Fr, TA:) or advancing (Lh, TA) and retreating: (Lh, K:) or labouring, or striving, or conflicting, one with another, to overcome, (Lth, TA,) and inclining [one towards another]: (Lth, K:) or collecting together, in a neuter sense, and mutual retiring to a distance: or collecting themselves together for peace or reconciliation, and dissolving themselves from a state of peace or reconciliation: or raising a clamour, or confused noise; and retiring to a distance: or saying No, by God, and Yes, by God. (TA.) [See art. hyT.] You say also, maA zaAla fiY hayoTK wamayoTK, meaning He ceased not to be engaged in crying out, or vociferating, or calling for aid or succour, and in evil, or mischief, and raising a clamour, or confused noise. (K in art. hyT.)
2 may~aTotu bihi * : see 1. ― -b2- my~T bayonahumaA, inf. n. tamoyiyTN, He wavered between them two. (TA.)

3 miyaATN * : see 1, throughout the greater part of the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- bayonahumaA mumaAyaTapN and muhaAyaTapN and muEaAyaTapN and musaAyaTapN are said to signify Between them two is low, faint, or gentle, speaking. (TA in art. hyT.)
4 A^amoyaTa see 1, in five places.

6 tmAyTwA *
They removed, retired, went to a distance, or became remote, one from another; and their mutual state became bad, disordered, or disturbed; (S, K;) contr. of thAyTwA. (Fr, S, in art. hyT.)
10 A_isotamoyaTa see 1, first sentence.

mayoTN * : see 1. ― -b2- It also signifies Inclination: so in the trad., lawo kaAna Eumaru miyzaAnFA maA kaAna fiyhi mayoTu $aEorapK [If 'Omar were a balance, there would not be in it the inclination of a hair]. (TA.) -A2- Also, A state of mixture, or confusion: mentioned only by IF. (TA.)
maAy^iTN * and haAy^iTN are explained by IAar as signifying Coming and going. (TA.)
